Fourth was the May-December, love-from-the-wrong-side-of-the-tracks romance ``White Palace,'' with ticket sales of $3 million. It was followed by the martial-arts thriller ``Marked for Death'' on a gate of $2.58 million. ``Stephen King's Graveyard Shift'' plummeted from first place during the weekend before Halloween to sixth, with $2.55 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, tota gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Jacob's Ladder,'' Tri-Star, $7.5 million, 1,052 screens, $7,130 per screen, $7.5 million, one week. 2. ``Sibling Rivalry,'' Columbia, $3.25 million, 1,603 screens, $2,248 per screen, $8.4 million, two weeks. 3. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $3.22 million, 1,713 screens, $1,879 per screen, $180.6 million, 17 weeks. 4. ``White Palace,'' Universal, $3 million, 892 screens, $3,370 per screen, $9.1 million, four weeks. 5. ``Marked for Death,'' 20th Century Fox, $2.58 million, 1,553 screens, $1,664 per screen, $37.5 million, five weeks. 6. ``Stephen King's Graveyard Shift,'' Paramount, $2.55 million, 1,603 screens, $1,593 per screen, $9 million, two weeks. 7. ``Memphis Belle,'' Warner Bros., $2.48 million, 1,300 screens, $1,909 per screen, $19 million, four weeks. 8. ``Graffiti Bridge,'' Warner Bros., $2.45 million, 688 screens, $3,557 per screen, $2.45 million, one week. 9. ``Quigley Down Under,'' MGM-UA, $2.3 million, 1,035 screens, $2,262 per screen, $11 million, three weeks. 10. ``Avalon,'' Tri-Star, $1.7 million, 635 screens, $2,720 per screen, $8.8 million, five weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slips, Stocks Also Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar inched down further against the Japanese yen today, and share prices fell too amid pessimism over the U.S. economy and the Persian Gulf situation. The dollar closed at 127.20 yen, down 0.15 yen from Monday's close of 127.35 yen, but up 0.80 yen from its opening rate of 126.40 yen and New York's 126.55 yen late Monday. The dollar ranged between 126.35 yen and 127.30 yen. The dollar now has fallen 3.50 yen in the last three trading days. The benchmark Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 419.58 points, or 1.72 percent, to 23,965.75 in thin trading. The index gained 190.34 points Monday. The price of the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds was quoted at 84.77 points, down from late Monday's 85.05. Their yield was 7.755 percent, up from 7.690. Dubai oil for December delivery was valued at $27.45 to $27.55 a barrel, or or about 10 to 20 cents above levels late Monday in New York. The dollar, after opening lower in response to its decline on overseas markets, inched up on buy orders from institutional investors trying to cover short positions, dealers said. Also lending support was a British newspaper report that the United States and Britain had decided to launch an attack on Iraq by this weekend, said Koichiro Amaya, a dealer with Chemical Bank. Amaya said the Daily Star's report prompted some investors to buy the dollar. However, Amaya said that because of general pessimism about the U.S. economy, traders were expected to shun the dollar for the time being unless there were new developments. Spot transactions totaled $11.251 billion, down from Monday's $13.563 billion. On the stock market, the Nikkei index gained some 250 points in early trading, then turned down. ``The underlying worries about the Middle East situation, together with concerns about the congressional elections and a quarterly bond auction in the United States later this week, provided excuses to investors not to buy,'' said Toshiyuki Nishiguchi, an analyst with Daiwa Securities. Volume on the first section was estimated at 280 million shares, up from Monday's 214 million shares, but down from 313.3 million shares Friday. Declining issues outnumbered gainers 755 to 187, while 151 others remained unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Voters Decide on Tax, Environment, Abortion Measures
DOC.TEXT: The environment, taxes and whether politicians should be turned out of office before they get too comfortable in the job confronted voters today as they tackled 236 ballot questions in 43 states and the District of Columbia. Alaskans could make the private use of marijuana a crime, Arizona voters could declare Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a state holiday, and Oregon residents could give parents a $2,500 tax credit for sending a child to the public, parochial or private school of their choice. In California, Washington and Missouri, environmentalists looked to the voters to adopt measures protecting forests, coasts and other sensitive lands. The tax revolt faced an important Election Day as well. Citizen initiatives that would cut or limit taxes or hold down government spending were on the ballot in Massachusetts, Nebraska, Oregon and other states. Many of the anti-tax and environmental proposals appeared to be in trouble or in close races, according to recent polls. Politicians were at issue in proposals in California and Colorado to limit how long they may hold office. The measures were expected to win passage. ``The mood is real simple: Folks are really ticked or fed up with how legislative bodies are conducting themselves,'' said Los Angeles County Supervisor Pete Schabarum. Jim Monaghan, a Denver political consultant, said, ``One of the most disturbing things in politics is that it is one of a few professions where people aren't expected to tell the truth and get away with it.'' Voters in Oregon decided on two proposals to limit abortions, while the Nevada ballot had a measure to make it harder to change that state's liberal abortion law. The issue of what is a family was the focus in two local elections. The Seattle ballot contained an initiative to repeal health insurance and other benefits for unmarried partners of municipal employees. San Francisco voters decided whether to allow unmarried couples to register as formal partnerships, although no benefits would be required. Massachusetts voters were deciding the most drastic tax measure - the repeal of two income tax increases and a rollback in state fees to 1988 levels. Opponents estimated it would cut the state budget by $2.6 billion, or about 15 percent, and force widespread cuts in services. A proposal in Nebraska - dubbed the ``2 Percent Solution'' - would cap increases in state and local government spending at 2 percent a year. An initiative in Oregon would limit property tax increases to 1.5 percent a year by 1996, and a Utah measure would repeal the state sales tax on most food. Tax or spending measures also were on the ballots in California, Colorado, Florida and Montana. Much of the attention of environmentalists was focused on California's ``Big Green'' initiative that would phase out many pesticides, ban oil development in state waters, ban chemicals that harm the ozone and require a dramatic reduction in emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. The proposal was one of four on the California ballot related to the environment, including one to regulate the use of forests. The other two were less stringent proposals backed by business groups as alternatives to ``Big Green'' and the forestry measure. Washington voters decided whether to require the state to limit development in sensitive areas and to set up boards for mandatory land use planning at the local level. Missourians considered sweeping protections for mountain streams in the scenic Ozarks. Oregon voters could impose strict recycling requirements and force the shutdown of the state's only nuclear plant. South Dakotans could limit Black Hills mining and restrict dumping, and voters in Arizona and Minnesota could dedicate portions of lottery proceeds to preserving the environment. In other ballot questions: -Floridians considered making their state the first with a constitutional waiting period for buying handguns. -Montana residents voted on making their cigarette tax the highest in the nation to curb smoking. -Maine voters considered abolishing the state's tough blue laws, which force most big retailers to close on Sundays. -District of Columbia voters decided on restoring the right of the homeless to overnight shelter. Voters in the Staten Island borough of New York City and in predominantly black neighborhoods of Boston decided whether to begin studies on seceding from their cities. In Gwinnett County, Ga., voters considered a 1 percent sales tax to pay for expanding Atlanta's rapid transit system into the suburban area. Across the continent, in California, voters in Santa Clara County considered a utility tax to finance a new stadium to lure the San Francisco Giants, and residents of Sacramento voted on a city-county merger that would make it the nation's seventh-largest city.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., PLO Envoys Meet over Bid for Palestinian Protection
DOC.TEXT: In the United States' first reported contact with the PLO since it broke off a dialogue in May, U.S. Ambassador Thomas Pickering has met with a PLO envoy to discuss the plight of Palestinians. Pickering was acting as Security Council president at the meeting Monday night, which was called to discuss the PLO's call for U.N. observers to protect Palestinians in Israeli-occupied territories. Washington severed its dialogue with he Palestine Liberation Organization in May after an attack by a radical PLO faction on an Israeli beach. Both sides said Monday's meeting was businesslike, related only to Security Council business on the occupied territories. They said there was no hint of resuming the U.S.-PLO dialogue. Pickering said nonaligned nations had formally requested an urgent meeting of the 15-member Security Council to discuss the latest violence in the Gaza Strip. No meeting was set. The PLO said it hoped for a meeting today or Wednesday at the latest. Pickering, a former U.S. ambassador to Israel and Jordan, met the PLO's acting permanent observer, M. Nasser Al-Kidwa, for a half hour. U.S. diplomats emphasized that Pickering met Kidwa strictly in his role as president of the Security Council for November. The presidency rotates monthly among the 15 members. Pickering said only that the PLO discussed its position with him concerning a council meeting and its call for U.N. observers. He declined to elaborate. Earlier Monday, the PLO proposed a resolution asking the Security Council to send unarmed U.N. observers to protect Palestinians in the territories captured by Israel in the 1967 Middle East war. It also called for the parties to the 1949 Fourth Geneva Convention - on protection of civilians in time of war - to hold an unprecedented meeting to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories. The proposed PLO resolution says the council ``decides to establish immediately under its authority a U.N. Observer Force, and to dispatch it to the Palestinian territory occupied by Israel since 1967, including Jerusalem.'' Israel rejects the presence of observers as a violation of its sovereignty over the West Bank and Gaza Strip, which were captured in 1967 from Jordan and Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Possible EC Membership Causes Nordic Turmoil
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For decades, neutral Sweden and Finland never considered entering the Common Market. Now, the end of East-West rivalries and the prospect of economic difficulties ahead may combine to bring the countries on Europe's northern tier in from the cold. Last week, the image of Nordic self-sufficiency and disengagement suddenly came apart. Sweden announced its intention to join the European Community and angered Finland by calling for a joint Nordic application. In Norway, where voters said ``no'' to membership in a referendum 18 years ago, the governing coalition collapsed when its smallest partner opposed trade negotiations with the community. The new Laborite government favors the talks. Of the other two Nordic nations, Denmark already is a member, while Iceland is opposed to joining. Foreign Minister Sten Andersson says the end of the Cold War and the prospects for a new all-European security system clear the way for neutral countries like Sweden to join the European Community. Observers have called Sweden's intention to join the community the biggest turnaround in Swedish foreign policy since shortly after World War II. Wilhelm Agrell, a leading security policy expert, called it ``the most important political crossroads since 1948-49,'' when Sweden tried to organize a Scandinavian defense association. The government's change of position was announced in an emergency economic package presented last week, and observers agreed it was forced by economic concerns. The package itself made major changes in domestic policy, deeply cutting the welfare system the Social Democratic Party built. Economic observers said the ``declaration of intention'' to join the Common Market was an attempt to calm Swedish industry, which has made massive investments in community countries. The Swedish concerns do not want to be closed out of their main export market in 1993, when community nations are to unite in economic union. The investments had caused a large outflow of Swedish currency, intensifying a drop in the krona's strength and an increase in devaluation speculation before the package was announced. The Swedish announcement caused consternation at the European Community's Brussels headquarters and among fellow European Free Trade Association countries, which are currently negotiating an agreement that would link the two trade associations. Critics say the Swedish initiative renders the negotiations - which also involve Norway, Finland, Iceland, Austria and Switzerland - pointless. Finland, an avowedly neutral country with traditionally strong ties to the Soviet Union, has recently begun discussing future European Community membership. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said a year ago that Moscow would not object to Finland joining the community. But when Andersson was quoted as saying Nordic countries could start discussing a joint European Community application next year, Finland's President Mauno Koivisto said the statement was premature. Risto Penttila, a researcher at the Finnish Foreign Policy Institute, said that Finland could be in a problematic position in the future if there is friction between the Soviet Union and the European Community. Finland shares a long common border with the Soviet Union. For their part, Norwegians appear to be warming to the idea of European Community membership. A poll of 607 people conducted by the MMI survey institute in late October showed 38 percent favored membership, 33 percent opposed it and 29 percent were undecided. No margin for error was given.

DOC.HEAD: Volvo Agrees to Pull `Monster Truck' Ads
DOC.TEXT: A TV commercial in which a Volvo withstands attempts by a ``monster truck'' to crush it has been dropped by the automaker under pressure after it turned out the car had been reinforced with steel or wood. ``Volvo was touted as a car that you can believe in. Unfortunately, these ads, you could not believe in them,'' said Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox, who had challenged the commercial. The ad was broadcast nationally. William Hoover, senior vice president of Volvo Cars of North America, emphasized on Monday that independent studies have found that Volvos are ``among the safest, if not the absolute safest, cars on the road today.'' But he said, ``We agree that the consumers in the state of Texas, as well as consumers throughout the country, deserve better advertising.'' Volvo agreed to make no unproven claims, run corrective newspaper ads and pay the state $316,250 in investigative costs. The automaker admitted no wrongdoing. In the ad, filmed in Austin in June, a Volvo appears to be the only car left standing after being run over by a large-tire pickup. The ad is a dramatization of a 1988 Vermont event, according to the company. However, the ad is not billed as a dramatization. And Mattox said the other cars in the ad were weakened structurally, while the Volvo was reinforced. The modifications were made to ensure the crew's safety and allow the Volvo to withstand the number of runs required by the truck in filming, the company said. Some of the shots of the truck running over the Volvo also may have been fabricated, Mattox said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Rain in Midwest and Northeast
DOC.TEXT: A storm that dumped up to 10 inches of snow on Michigan's Lower Peninsula headed out of the state today, leaving cloudy skies and low temperatures. The tail of the storm produced flurries in the Detroit area and rain elsewhere in Michigan. More snow - up to five inches - was forecast today across the Midwest into Wyoming, Utah and Colorado. The Northeast looked for early rain, followed by mostly, sunny windy weather. Mostly sunny skies were forecast for the far West, Southwest, Texas and Southeast. Winds of 60 mph and stronger were forecast through tonight in California's Sierra Nevada. Stormy weather is forecast through Wednesday in the northwest gulf of Alaska, with winds of 115 mph expected through the Barren Islands. The high temperature for the nation Monday was 86 degrees at Fort Myers, Fla., Hollywood, Fla., and the Naval Air Station near Jacksonville, Fla. Other reports: -East: Albany, N.Y. 49 rain; Atlanta 43 fair; Boston 50 rain; Buffalo 46 showers; Charleston, S.C. 62 fair; Chattanooga 46 cloudy; Cincinnati 40 cloudy; Cleveland 39 cloudy; Detroit 36 windy; Hatteras 64 foggy; Jacksonville 65 fair; Key West 70 fair; Knoxville 46 cloudy; Macon 45 fair; Miami 68 fair; New York 63 foggy; Pittsburgh 40 drizzle; Portland, Maine 47 rain; Richmond 57 fair; Tampa 73 cloudy; Washington, D.C. 58 fair. -Central: Birmingham 45 cloudy; Bismarck 18 fair; Chicago 35 fair; Denver 32 snow; Des Moines 36 cloudy; Fort Worth 48 fair; Indianapolis 38 cloudy; Kansas City 39 partly cloudy; Little Rock 37 fair; Louisville 43 cloudy; Memphis 38 fair; Nashville 45 cloudy; New Orleans 47 fair; North Platte 32 snow; Oklahoma City 44 fair; Omaha 39 cloudy; Rapid City 27 snow; St. Louis 36 fair; Minneapolis-St. Paul 28 fair; Sault Ste. Marie 29 snow; San Antonio 42 fair. -West: Albuquerque 42 fair; Anchorage 25 snow; Boise 32 fair; Casper 20 snow; Fairbanks 22 cloudy; Great Falls 13 cloudy; Honolulu 77 fair; Las Vegas 56 fair; Los Angeles 58 foggy; Medford 36 fair; Pendleton 38 partly cloudy; Phoenix 58 fair; Portland, Ore. 40 cloudy; Reno 37 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 33 partly cloudy; San Diego 61 cloudy; San Francisco 56 fair; Seattle 44 partly cloudy; Spokane 30 fair. -International: Calgary 18 fair; Montreal 43 rain; Ottawa 39 rain; Regina 05 fair; Toronto 43 rain; Winnipeg 14 fair; Nassau 79; San Juan 76 partly cloudy.

DOC.HEAD: Navajos Say Weathering Corruption Scandal Will Make Tribe Stronger
DOC.TEXT: The corruption scandal that drove Navajo chairman Peter MacDonald from office and shook the tribe's political institutions will eventually result in a stronger, more honest government, some officials say. The scandal broke wide open two years ago when the Navajo council suspended MacDonald, its four-term chairman, amid allegations he took money and gifts in exchange for favors to those doing business with the biggest U.S. Indian tribe. MacDonald, convicted Sept. 17 of bribery, theft, extortion and conspiracy, was sentenced to six years in prison and disqualified from holding tribal office. His son, Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr., 36, was sentenced to 1{ years. ``The days of an imperial chairmanship are over,'' said Al Bennett, who provided security for several tribal council members during the corruption case's most bitter moments. Two men were shot to death during a clash between MacDonald supporters and Navajo police in 1989. ``The favoritism (of) the old days is slowly being phased out,'' Bennett added. ``What the turmoil has done has strengthened the court system of the Navajo Nation and strengthened the council's power. It has brought the executive branch in line with the distribution of power.'' The scandal gave birth to a three-branch form of government for the 180,000 Navajos living on the 21,000-square-mile reservation in Arizona, New Mexico and Utah. The new government, established in April, has already curbed abuses of power by splitting authority between the tribal chairman, the leader of the tribal council and the tribal courts, said Navajo Councilman Daniel Tso. He said the judicial branch in particular demonstrated its independence during MacDonald's trial. ``(Its judges) didn't yield to MacDonald or to the violence that occurred,'' he said. At the time of his conviction, MacDonald was seeking election to the new position of tribal president. His name was struck from the ballot, and the election was postponed from today to Dec. 18. Interim President Leonard Haskie will take MacDonald's place on the ballot against former Tribal Chairman Peterson Zah. Navajo legal advocate Carol Retasket, who defended MacDonald, complained that his punishment was too severe, but she agreed that the scandal should strengthen Navajo political institutions in the long run. Before MacDonald, she said, Navajos viewed theft by political leaders not as a crime but as a quirk to be punished by ridicule. Duane Beyal, spokesman for the tribe's legislative branch, likened the Navajos' problems to the growing pains of a new government. ``The U.S. government went through the same thing,'' he said. ``Like any adolescent, you're clumsy and awkward.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Joins Council of Europe
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: Hungary joined the Council of Europe today, becoming the first former East bloc country to enter the oldest postwar body promoting European cooperation. ``When the time came, Hungary was bold enough to open a hole in the Iron Curtain,'' said Catherine Lalumiere, secretary-general of the council. ``The leaders and indeed the people have contributed so much to bringing the division of Europe to an end.'' She and Foreign Minister Geza Jeszensky of Hungary sat at a table in a gilt-trimmed room of the 17th-century Barberini Palace to sign documents admitting Hungary as the 24th member of the council. ``I feel deeply moved standing in front of you,'' Jeszensky told the audience of European ministers. ``This is a momentous day in history, both for Hungary, and, I believe, the Council of Europe.'' Czechoslovakia and Poland, who like Hungary have made a dramatic, peaceful switch from Communist dictatorship to democracy, are expected to also join the council in the coming months. The Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria have observer status and Romania and Albania may become observers soon. The Council of Europe, which includes nearly all Western European countries, has produced 130 international treaties. It is best known for the European Human Rights Convention and European Court of Human Rights, whose rulings are binding on council members. Jeszensky signed the human rights treaty at today's ceremony. A country must sign the accord and have a parliamentary democracy to join the 41-year-old council. After the signing, Hungary's flag was raised along those of the other 23 nations at the Council of Europe offices in Strasbourg, France, as the national anthem was played. ``Hungary's admission is the first step in the restoration of the unity of our continent,'' Jeszensky said. He added that joining the council was ``one of the most important foreign policy successes of the Hungarian government.'' Hungary applied for membership in the council a year ago, when reform Communists were still in power. A government dominated by the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum was formed last summer after the country's first free multiparty elections in four decades. Today's ceremony opened a daylong meeting of the foreign ministers of Council nations. The Council is trying to decide what role it will have in the post-Cold War order. It is seeking to increase its influence in human rights issues and possibly develop a parliament bringing together the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union. The Council's other members are: Austria, Belgium, Britain, Cyprus, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, San Marino, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Four Blacks Die In Renewed Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Police said today that four blacks were killed, including one shot by the army, in a township near Johannesburg where more than 20 people have died in several days of black factional fighting. The killings occurred in Bekkersdal, where black students demanding a boycott of final exams to protest school conditions have clashed with pupils who want to take the tests. Police said they found the bodies of three people who were killed Monday by a crowd. The police statement did not indicate anything about the affiliation of the attackers or their victims. A man also died when he was shot by soldiers after he resisted arrest and attacked the troops with a knife, police said. At least 23 people have died in the township 40 miles west of Johannesburg since Thursday, according to police, who believe most of the killings are linked to the student violence. Schools have been empty this week, many workers have stayed home, businesses have been closed and some families have fled in search of safety. Police said several people were hurt, seven were arrested, and houses were set on fire in clashes on Monday. Authorities said they confiscated two AK-47 assault rifles from the house of a man who belongs to the Pan Africanist Congress, a militant black opposition group. Militant students are opposed to the year-end exams, which determine whether students advance to the next grade or gain admission to universities. They say they have not been able to prepare properly because of poor conditions at the schools. Last year, 42 percent of black high school seniors nationwide passed the final exam, compared to a pass rate of more than 95 percent for white students. The white-led government spends about five times as much to educate a white pupil as a black pupil, and anti-apartheid activists have complained for years about problems in the black schools. More than 800 blacks have died since August in factional fighting in the black townships around Johannesburg. Most of the battles have been between supporters of the African National Congress and the conservative Inkatha Freedom Party, the two largest black opposition groups.

DOC.HEAD: Guilty Plea In Business Week Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: A stockbroker pleaded guilty to trading stocks on the basis of tips from a printing plant employee about which companies were going to be mentioned in upcoming issues of Business Week magazine. John Petit, 34, faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines at sentencing March 25. He pleaded guilty Monday to securities fraud. Petit, now of Boca Raton, Fla., earned more than $66,000 from 1986 to 1988 by buying stocks he knew would be mentioned in Business Week's ``Inside Wall Street'' column before readers could bid up the price, prosecutors said. Prosecutors said Petit was tipped off by Shayne Walters, a worker at the plant where the magazine was printed. At the time, Petit worked in a Newport Beach office of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. Walters pleaded guilty earlier in federal court in New York to conspiracy to commit fraud and perjury, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Alice Hill. In August, as part of an SEC civil action, stockbroker Brian J. Callahan and print shop worker William N. Jackson were ordered to pay a total of more than $66,000 in ill-gotten profits and fines involving similar advance access to the Business Week column.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soviet Union Has Not Ruled Out Gulf Military Option
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's special envoy to the Middle East has told Western diplomats that his country is not ruling out the use of force against Iraq, the British Broadcasting Corp. has reported. The BBC reported Monday that Yevgeny Primakov told ambassadors in Moscow that a translator in Paris had erred last week in interpreting Gorbachev as saying a military option was ``unacceptable.'' Primakov has traveled twice to Baghdad for meetings with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in an effort to find a peaceful solution to the crisis precipitated by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The BBC said Primakov told the ambassadors that the Soviet Union continues to insist on full implementation of the U.N. resolutions ordering an embargo on trade with Iraq and demanding an immediate and unconditional withdrawal from Kuwait. Primakov also said there was no sign of the Soviet Union breaking with the international consensus, the BBC reported. The Soviet envoy was evasive on what the Soviet Union would do in the event of war in the Persian Gulf, it said. Soviet participation in military action would have to be approved by the country's Parliament, the BBC quoted Primakov as saying. Primakov said he found no evidence of popular dissatisfaction when he visited Iraq, and advised the ambassadors that domestic difficulties would not undermine Saddam's position, the BBC said. The BBC reported that Primakov told the briefing that the embargo appeared to be working, but only very slowly. Saddam is doubly determined not to be forced out of Kuwait empty-handed after his experience with the eight-year Iran-Iraq war, the BBC quoted Primakov as telling the ambassadors.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Baptist Meetings Could Deepen Conservative-Moderate Split
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf ```The most ...' to CORRECT to Good News Baptist Church, sted Good New. ^By KAREN HAYWOOD
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Southern Baptists nationwide are considering state budgets that could deepen the decade-old split between conservatives and moderates in the nation's largest Protestant denomination. Moderates in Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina are pushing for spending plans that would withhold contributions from some of the church's national programs in which the conservatives, or fundamentalists, hold way. Such contributions support missionary, educational and benevolent work. If the spending plans are approved, they could wreck the national budget adopted in June for the 14.9 million Southern Baptists. ``We are going to have churches torn apart, families torn apart, ministers torn apart,'' said Neil Jones, a moderate pastor of Columbia Baptist Church in Falls Church. ``Some of my good friends are preachers on the other side.'' ``The most damaging thing it will result in is a weakening of missions and fewer souls being saved, and more souls going to hell for eternity,'' said T.C. Pinckney, a conservative member of Alexandria Good News Baptist Church. Conservatives believe in the literal truth of the Bible. Moderates say the Bible is open to individual interpretation. The conservatives dominate the Southern Baptists. In the past 12 years they have gained control over many seminaries and national boards and forced out leaders who disagree with them. Representatives from churches in 21 states will hold separate meetings Nov. 12-14 to approve their spending plans. The denomination is based in Nashville, Tenn. The moderates' plans would restrict or cut off money for such programs as the church's executive committee, the Southeastern Baptist Seminary in Wake Forest, N.C., and the Christian Life Commission. The commission determines the Southern Baptists' position on social and ethical issues. Less money also would be sent to the Southern Baptist Convention's Cooperative Program, the denomination's major funding program. In Virginia, where moderates continue to wield influence, their plan urges more money for the new Associated Baptist Press. The group was chartered after editors of the Baptist Press were fired by conservatives. Pinckney said the spending dispute, while keeping the denomination together, ``diverts our attention and resources away from winning souls.'' ``If that's the alternative to a split,'' he said, ``then it's probably better in the long run for everybody on both sides that a split occur.''

DOC.HEAD: Monster Lobster Headed for Platters
DOC.TEXT: Mimi, the 17{-pound lobster described as the Elizabeth Taylor of crustaceans, died of natural causes days after being shipped to her new home - at a restaurant. She was 20 to 100 years old, officials said. Mimi, captured last week off the Maine coast and flown to Detroit, died Sunday in the tank at Carl's Chop House, which paid $320 for the huge lobster. ``She had quit moving. I picked her up. She still didn't move,'' said Barry Hornecker, executive chef at Carl's. So he chilled and poached Mimi and began making plans for a feast. ``Mimi was like Elizabeth Taylor. ... She was always beautiful,'' said Jim Richards, owner of the Long Wharf Lobster Co., which flew the lobster to Detroit. Although Mimi was a lot bigger than the 1{-pound average lobster, she wasn't the biggest. Earlier this year, Florida's Sea World adopted a 19-pound lobster, whose age was estimated at 100 years, from a grocery store in Oklahoma. The largest known lobster lives in a museum in Maine. It weighs 58 pounds and is estimated to be 300 years old.

DOC.HEAD: European Leaders Urge Worldwide Action to Fight Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said today there is a ``clear case'' for immediate worldwide action against global warming and said foot-dragging could spell disaster. More research is needed on a potential climate upheaval next century, but that ``should not be an excuse'' for delay, Mrs. Thatcher said in a keynote speech to ministers meeting on the issue. ``We will not succeed if we are too inflexible,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``And succeed we must for the sake of this and future generations.'' French Prime Minister Michel Rocard told the officials from about 120 countries they face a ``race against time ... to save our planet.'' In an appeal believed aimed largely at the United States and the Soviet Union, Mrs. Thatcher demanded all countries begin work on binding commitments to limit emissions of so-called greenhouse gases. The commitments would be part of a global treaty on climate change, to be completed in 1992. Washington and Moscow are resisting the setting of targets now. They argue more study is needed to justify huge expenditures on emission controls. The United States and the Soviet Union are the biggest sources of man-made carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas, much of which comes from burning fossil fuels. Mrs. Thatcher and Rocard spoke as top officials were wrapping up a U.N. conference on climate change. The gathering was aimed at giving momentum to negotiations on global warming, due to start in February. Scientists from 100 countries who met last week issued a united appeal for immediate steps to counter pollution from gases trapping heat in the atmosphere. Officials drafting a political declaration to cap the meeting Wednesday are facing a clash between European Community efforts to urge quick action and the less enthusiastic U.S. stand. Mrs. Thatcher conceded ``much more research is needed.'' But she added: ``There is already a clear case for precautionary action.'' Many steps would be ``sensible in any event'' - improving energy efficiency, developing alternative sources of supply, reforestation, rethinking industrial processes and tackling the waste problem, she said. Less air pollution, reduced acid rain and lower energy costs are desirable in any case, she said. Both Mrs. Thatcher and Rocard offered their government's support to help developing countries cope with the research and vast technical resources required to help in the fight against warming. ``The cost of inaction would be much too great to risk,'' said Rocard. He said Wednesday's ministerial declaration should have ``real content,'' setting objectives and deadlines. He cited as a model an EC agreement last week to stabilize carbon dioxide emissions at current levels by the start of next century. Six other countries, grouped in the European Free Trade Association, joined that effort Monday. However, a draft of the concluding ministerial declaration sets no targets, reflecting the U.S. approach. The United States, which has sent a lower-level delegation, did not immediately take the floor at the U.N.-sponsored gathering. Among the feared results of global warming are higher sea levels that would displace coastal dwellers, a disruption of agriculture, and vast changes affecting wildlife.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Says U.N. Does Not Restrict Forceful Recovery Of Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 13-16 bgng, Baker later... to UPDATE with meeting with Chinese foreign minister over, quotes; minor editing thruout to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's foreign minister today warned Iraq the United Nations has not restricted the use of military force to liberate Kuwait. Prince Saud's assertion at a news conference in Jiddah, Saudia Arabia, as he saw Secretary of State James A. Baker III off to Egypt marked a hardening of the anti-Iraq coalition. ``We would like a peaceful settlement, but that option is in the hands of the Iraqis,'' the foreign minister said. He confirmed, meanwhile, that King Fahd and Baker had devised a joint command in the event of war. U.S. troops defending Saudi Arabia would be under the joint command, but if the Americans go into combat elsewhere in the Persian Gulf they would take orders only from U.S. commanders. Saud said Baker had not discussed military options with the Saudis during his talks Monday in Jiddah. However, Saud said the U.N. resolutions demanding that Iraq give up Kuwait do not foreclose force. ``The United Nations has not put any restrictions on what actions the United Nations would take to implement this,'' Saud said. In Cairo, Baker was seeking reaffirmation of Egypt's role in the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq. He met with President Hosni Mubarak, who has sent about 14,000 troops to defend Saudi Arabia and may double that number. There was no immediate appraisal of the meeting with Mubarak. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Mubarak canceled his appearance at a planned joint news conference, saying he had another appointment. Baker decided not to appear without the president, Tutwiler said. Baker later met at Cairo International Airport with China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. As they posed for pictures, the Chinese official dodged a question about whether his government would support military action against Iraq. ``All the armed forces have two roles to play,'' he said. ``One is to fight a war, and the other is to seek peace.'' Asked if by authorizing the use of force the United Nations would increase pressure on Iraq to release its hold on Kuwait, the foreign minister again avoided a direct reply. ``We'll still have to wait and see,'' he said. The 10 resolutions approved by the U.N. Security Council, Qian said, ``are intended to increase the pressure on Iraq to reach a peaceful settlement.'' The Bush administration needs the support of China, a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, for further economic and political moves against Iraq - or military action, if that is taken - to reverse the ocupation of Kuwait. Baker reached agreement Monday with King Fahd that U.S. troops will be under American command if they are sent into combat. The decision on command and control was announced after Baker held a two-hour meeting with the king. A U.S. official, who insisted on anonymity, said the Saudis would play a decisive role in two ways - they would share command of American troops used to defend Saudi Arabia and would have to give a green light before the 100,000-plus U.S. troops in the oil-rich kingdom were sent into action. Once the Americans go into battle outside Saudi Arabia, American commanders will direct them, the official said. Baker and the king resolved the issue as tensions appeared to heighten over Iraq's annexation of Kuwait three months ago. A senior Saudi official said ``we are satisfied'' and from the kingdom's standpoint there had never been a problem. The Saudi official, who talked to reporters under condition of anonymity, said ``we are still genuinely hoping to see a peaceful outcome.'' Baker, leaving the Saudi mountain resort of Taif earlier Monday after talks with the exiled emir of Kuwait, said the situation was changing. ``This crisis is entering a new phase,'' he said, ``and while we are still seeking a peaceful political and diplomatic solution, we have to put ourselves in a position where we would be able to exercise any options that might be available.'' Baker did not elaborate, but the U.S. official said he meant the United States and its allies were bringing ``increasing pressure'' to bear on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The secretary implied a heightening of tensions in the region and a redoubled U.S. resolve to evict Iraq from Kuwait. ``I don't think that we can or should we rule out resort to force if that should be necessary,'' he said. Baker is on a seven-country trip designed to test support among Arabs, Europeans and the Soviets for military action against Saddam. Of critical importance are the opinions Baker hears from leaders of Saudi Arabia, the linchpin in the Arab alliance, and from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Frees 106 More Foreigners
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS first graf show not all of those to be freed were held at strategic sites. Minor editing throughout.
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein today ordered 106 more foreigners freed, including some detained at strategic sites as part of his ``human shield'' against attack. The official Iraqi News Agency said those being allowed to leave are 77 Japanese, 20 Italians, five Swedes, two Germans and two Portuguese. The announcement indicated Saddam is continuing his practice of selectively freeing foreigners held since his troops seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. The Iraqi president has used the hostages - including hundreds of Americans - to try to splinter the alliance against him. The dispatch said some of the foreigners to be freed are ``guests,'' the term the Iraqi media use for those held as part of Saddam's ``human shield'' against attacks by the U.S.-led forces assembled in the Persian Gulf. An estimated 600 foreigners are held at strategic sites, mainly Americans, Britons, Germans and Japanese. INA said Saddam's order was in response to appeals made by various delegations that visited Iraq in recent days. It mentioned specifically former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, a delegation of Swedish Moslems and a parliamentary delegation from Italy. It said those to be allowed to leave include 15 construction workers - 10 Italians, two Germans, two Portuguese and a Swede. They are being freed, INA said in the dispatch monitored in Nicosia, in response to appeals by the Arab Union of Laborers. The agency did not provide the names of those to be freed, nor say when they could leave.

DOC.HEAD: American Reported Missing, Possibly Kidnapped By Communists
DOC.TEXT: An American has been missing since last month in northern Luzon and may have been kidnapped by Communist rebels, U.S. and Philippine officials said today. A U.S. Embassy official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Harvey Drown, believed to be from California or Washington, was reportedly taken at gunpoint from a vehicle Oct. 24 in Cagayan province 270 miles north of Manila. Police Col. Miguel Fontanilla said in a report that the American was on board a jeep near the town of Aparri when it was stopped by a rebel checkpoint. Fontanilla's report identified the American as a Protestant missionary but gave no details about his denomination nor how long he had lived in the country. U.S. officials said Drown had not registered with the embassy in Manila and they were unaware of him until receiving fragmentary reports of his possible abduction. American and Philippine authorities said no demands had been made by the American's kidnappers. U.S. officials said they doubted the incident was linked to this week's scheduled resumption of talks on the future of U.S. military bases, whose lease expires next year. Communist rebels oppose the bases. In May, Communist guerrillas in the central Philippine province of Negros Occidental kidnapped U.S. Peace Corps volunteer Timothy Swanson. He was released on August 2. U.S. authorities suspended Peace Corps operations in the Philippines and ordered all volunteers home before Swanson's release.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Say They Discussed Media Coverage During Trial in Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who convicted four men of crimes in the death of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena said they discussed media coverage of the trial and facts not admitted as evidence during their deliberations. The jury convicted Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, Ruben Zuno Arce and Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez of conspiracy, kidnapping and violent crime in aid of racketeering in Camarena's slaying. Javier Vasquez Velasco was convicted of violent crimes in aid of racketeering for the deaths of two Americans mistaken for U.S. drug agents in Guadalajara, Mexico. Eight jurors testified in a hearing Monday before U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie on defense claims that the jurors were unfairly influenced by media reports about the case and their clients should get a new trial. The 12-member jury discussed press accounts of the trial on July 28, the day after they convicted defendant Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, the jurors said. ``We went back over the verdict,'' juror Linda Overholt said. ``We reconsidered everything because of what we heard. We wanted to make sure of our feelings.'' Other jurors testified that they reviewed their verdict only briefly before moving on to the other defendants. Juror William R. Parris said the panel talked about a previous drug conviction of Matta that was not introduced as evidence at the Camarena trial. But other jurors said they didn't remember discussing the prior conviction. Rafeedie gave defense lawyers 10 days to submit written arguments supporting their claims. Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent, was abducted, tortured and killed in Guadalajara in 1985. Prosecutors said members of a cocaine cartel ordered the killing because Camarena's work had led to seizures of cocaine and marijuana.

DOC.HEAD: Third-Quarter Productivity Up 1.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The productivity of American workers rose at the fastest rate in two years in the July-September quarter, climbing at an annual rate of 1.6 percent, the government said today. However, the rebound is still well below the level needed to significantly boost Americans' living standard, according to most economists. Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more during each hour of work, is vital to increasing the nation's standard of living without inflation. The 1.6 percent third quarter gain in non-farm productivity reported by the Labor Department was a marked improvement over the 0.3 percent advance in the second quarter, revised from an earlier estimate, which showed a 1.5 percent gain. It was also the biggest advance since productivity shot up at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the third quarter of 1988. However, because productivity plunged at a 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, it is averaging only a scant 0.2 percent advance for the first nine months of 1990. Still, that is better than the 0.7 percent decline for all of 1989. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged around 1.4 percent a year - better than the 1.2 percent average in the 1970s, but far worse than the 3.3 percent annual gain posted in the two decades following World War II. During the July-September period, the number of hours worked edged down 0.1 percent, the first decline in more than four years. Economists say this is a sign that employers are preparing for a recession by not hiring new workers or allowing existing employees to work more hours. Hourly labor costs, a major indication of inflation for businesses, shot up 4.5 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 5 percent rise in the second quarter. Hourly labor costs advanced at a 4.5 percent average for the year so far, compared with 3.2 percent for all of 1989. Meanwhile, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 2.8 percent in the third quarter compared with 4.7 percent in the second quarter. For the year so far, unit labor costs averaged a 4.3 percent gain compared with 3.9 percent in the 1989. Total business productivity, including farming, rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter, bringing the average for the year so far to up 0.5 percent compared with a decline of 0.5 percent in all of 1989. Manufacturing productivity climbed at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter, bringing the average for the year so far to 4.5 percent, compared with 2.6 percent last year.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Wound Monk in Shootout at Monastery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th pvs, `Brother Zepherin...' with 2 grafs to ADD that abbot says the thieves fled empty handed. Pickup last graf, `They were...'
DOC.TEXT: SAINT-LAURENT-LES-BAINS, France (AP) - Heavily armed bandits seeking cash at a wealthy, isolated monastery wounded a monk in a gun battle with brothers who had taken up arms after a wave of robberies. The Rev. Pierre-Marie, abbot of the 19th-century Trappist monastery Notre-Dame des Neiges, said that a burglar alarm sounded at the monastery about 3 a.m. Monday, an hour before morning prayers. The bell signaled to the 36 monks, who produce 4 million bottles of wine a year on their immense estate in the Languedoc region of southern France, that they were being robbed for the third time this year. The monks have been organizing themselves as a self-defense force the past few weeks. In previous robberies, ``the telephone lines were cut and we couldn't call for help,'' the abbot said today. Arming themselves with shotguns, the brothers raced outside to a nearby administrative building where the alarm had sounded. ``The alarm stopped after three rings, so the thieves were able to believe they hadn't been discovered,'' the abbot said. But one brother blasted a round into the air, flushing two masked men. They fled down the winding road to the monastery, the abbot said. The bandits found their way barricaded by a parked car and shotgun-toting Brother Zepherin, organizer of the monastery's hunting expeditions, who demanded they stop. The robbers pulled out a sawed-off shotgun and a semiautomatic pistol and opened fire on Brother Zepherin and other monks approaching in cars. The monks returned fire. Brother Zepherin fell with 200 pellets in his leg. The robbers got into a waiting car with one or two accomplices inside and sped off empty handed, the abbot said. They were still at large today.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Votes After Signing Tax-Raising Budget Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Recasts lead and SUBS 7th graf, The president... to make clear that $492 billion package signed by Bush includes both tax increases and budget reductions
DOC.TEXT: President Bush cast his vote in his home state today after signing a tax hike as part of a $492 billion deficit reduction plan that was a campaign albatross for many fellow Republicans. Bush and his wife, Barbara, waited in line behind other voters for about 10 minutes this morning at a polling place in a nursing home near the hotel they use as a legal residence. He waved aside reporters' questions, saying only ``good to be home'' as he left the polling place to return to Washington, where he will spend the evening in the White House. The president signed the budget package Monday night at his Houston home. The late hour guaranteed that the news would not make prime-time news broadcasts and also would miss the deadlines for many newspapers that voters would be reading on Election Day today. In a statement, Bush called the hard-fought budget compromise ``the centerpiece of the largest deficit reduction package in history and an important measure for ensuring America's long-term economic growth.'' He said that in the agreement, ``No one got everything he or she wanted, but the end product is a compromise that merits enactment.'' The bill Bush signed was a $245 billion, 5-year deficit-reduction package. It was the major component of a five-year plan reducing the budget gap by $492 billion. The remaining savings came from defense cuts in other legislation, and lower than planned interest payments on the national debt. Bush spent the home stretch of the campaign trekking to eight states and urging voters to go to the polls and prove wrong the pundits who say the electorate is depressed and disgusted. On Monday, Bush made a day-long swing around Texas with GOP gubernatorial candidate Clayton Williams. The deficit-reduction plan approved by Congress last week includes $140 billion in new taxes that Bush agreed to, but that election-conscious Republicans found hard to swallow. The plan also included a number of government spending cuts. The president continued on Monday to emphasize upbeat themes at the urging of some advisers that he try to look more ``presidential.'' But his election-eve speech to a ballroom full of Republican loyalists was interrupted by about four anti-war protesters who chanted, ``No war for oil.'' The audience shouted them down and they were quickly ushered from the room. The outburst gave Bush an opportunity to repeat his rationale for sending more than 200,000 U.S. troops to the Persian Gulf region. ``They got it wrong,'' he said, referring to the protesters. ``What we're doing is not anything about war for oil. What we're doing is standing up against naked aggression.'' Bush's appearances have increasingly attracted anti-war protesters around the country. In the closing days of the campaign, the president's senior advisers have been divided on how Bush should conduct himself, with some recommending that he take off the gloves and bash congressional Democrats, as he did in Oklahoma City 10 days ago. But sources who spoke on condition of anonymity said that approach, favored by White House chief of staff John Sununu and some high Republican Party officials, appeared to backfire. They concluded that Democrat-bashing was not helping Bush's popularity, which has foundered with his wavering positions on tax and budget issues coupled with the slumping economy. The sources said Bush's former pollster, Robert Teeter, and his 1988 media consultant, Roger Ailes, persuaded the president to be more positive. That approach was evident Monday, when Bush traveled with Williams to Tyler and Waco. While still accusing Democrats of wanting to raise taxes on ``every working man and woman,'' Bush said he was tired of ``the cynics, these Washington pundits ... telling us everything that's wrong with the United States.'' He said people should vote and ``show us what's right about it.'' Bush tried to shore up Williams' support, which has flagged with recent gaffes. Williams admitted knowing nothing about the one proposed constitutional amendment on the Texas statewide ballot, a measure dealing with gubernatorial appointment powers. Williams also has had to fend off criticism that he paid no taxes in 1986, a year when he said business was bad and he had no income. But Bush said of Williams: ``I know of his sincerity. I know of his integrity. And he will be a great governor of the state of Texas. And I'm going to vote for him early tomorrow morning.''

DOC.HEAD: Nawaz Sharif Sworn in as Pakistani Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Nawaz Sharif, a conservative industrialist and Benazir Bhutto's chief rival, was sworn in today as prime minister of Pakistan's fifth freely-elected government in 43 years. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan administered the oath of office to the 41-year-old Sharif in a 10-minute ceremony attended by 600 guests, including politicians, military leaders and bureaucrats. Earlier today, the National Assembly elected Sharif prime minister after a brief walkout by supporters of ousted Prime Minister Bhutto, who demanded a secret ballot. Sharif, whose Islamic Democratic Alliance soundly defeated Ms. Bhutto in the Oct. 24 election, sounded a conciliatory note today. ``The government and opposition should join hands to help the country's poor,'' he said. ``For the prosperity of the country we have to join hands.'' He referred to the majority of Pakistan's 110 million people, most of whom are illiterate and landless laborers earning less than $400 a year. Earlier, in an address to the assembly, Ms. Bhutto sharply criticized the army-back caretaker government that succeeded her after she was dismissed from office Aug. 6. ``I hope the new administration will depart from the policy of repression, persecution and discrimination launched by the caretaker government,'' she said. ``Democracy to us is not just a way to govern but a value.'' Ms. Bhutto's candidate for prime minister, Mohammad Afzal Khan, was a political unknown who was seen as her Pakistan People's Party's sacrificial candidate. Sharif's election was virtually assured when his alliance of 18 parties named him their candidate for prime minister. He controls 105 seats in the 217-seat National Assembly, but claims to have the support of several smaller parties and independents. He was elected prime minister with 159 votes. Ms. Bhutto's party was routed in the national elections, leaving her with 45 seats. Her candidate received 39 votes today. In provincial elections Oct. 27, Ms. Bhutto's party was decimated in Punjab province, and weakened in her home province of Sindh. She has repeatedly charged she was cheated out of victory. Sharif began his political career in the 1980s, during military rule in Pakistan. His mentor, President Gen. Mohammad Zia-ul Haq, died in a plane crash in 1988, paving the way for the first free elections after more than a decade of military rule. Shortly before those elections, Sharif formed his democratic alliance of parties espousing a wide range of political ideologies but united in their contempt for Ms. Bhutto. Her party won the largest bloc of votes in 1988, but required the support of smaller parties and independents to stay in power. After 20 months and little legislation, President Ghulam Ishaq Khan dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government, charging her with corruption and ineptitude. She discounted the charges. Ms. Bhutto faces seven charges of misconduct. A guilty verdict on any one charge could disqualify her from politics for up to seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis, At a Glance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Tuesday ordered the release of 106 foreigners, including some who were held as ``human shields'' at key installations, Iraq's official news agency said. The report said those to be freed are 77 Japanese, 20 Italians, five Swedes, two Portuguese. News of the planned releases came one day after European countries denounced individual attempts to gain the freedom of hostages. --- Secretary of Stwo Germans and tate James A. On Monday, Baker and Saudi King Fahd agreed that the United States will not attack Iraq without Saudi approval, but that American troops would be under U.S. command once they go to battle. --- Baker also met in Cairo with China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. China is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, and its support would be needed for a U.N.-sanctioned military strike against Saddam. Qian was asked whether his government would support such military action. ``All the armed forces have two roles to play,'' the Chinese official said. ``One is to fight a warver, the rebound is still well below the level needed to significantly boost Americans' living standard, according to most economists. Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more during each hour of work, is vital to increasing the nation's standard of living without inflation. The 1.6 percent third quarter gain in non-farm productivity reported by the Labor Department was a marked improvement over the 0.3 percent advance in the second quarter, revised from an earlier estimate, which showed a 1.5 percent gain. It was also the biggest advance since productivity shot up at a 2.8 percent annual rate in the third quarter of 1988. However, because productivity plunged at a 1.3 percent rate in the first quarter, it is averaging only a scant 0.2 percent advance for the first nine months of 1990. Still, that is better than the 0.7 percent decline for all of 1989. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged around 1.4 percent a year - better than the 1.2 percent average in the 1970s, but far worse than the 3.3 percent annual gain posted in the two decades following World War II. During the July-September period, the number of hours worked edged down 0.1 percent, the first decline in more than four years. Economists say this is a sign that employers are preparing for a recession by not hiring new workers or allowing existing employees to work more hours. Hourly labor costs, a major indication of inflation for businesses, shot up 4.5 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 5 percent rise in the second quarter. Hourly labor costs advanced at a 4.5 percent average for the year so far, compared with 3.2 percent for all of 1989. Meanwhile, unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 2.8 percent in the third quarter compared with 4.7 percent in the second quarter. For the year so far, unit labor costs averaged a 4.3 percent gain compared with 3.9 percent in the 1989. DOC.HEAD: Court Ruling Leaves Army Ban o Homosexuals Intact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS throughout to remove references to Supreme Court `ruling' since the court only let stand an existing lower court ruling.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE3 of Nov. 5
DOC.TEXT: A gay former soldier celebrated a U.S. Supreme Court decision to let stand a ruling that will allow him to re-enlist, but said it was not a significant victory because it leaves intact the military's ban on homosexuals. The high court, without comment, on Monday let stand an appeals court ruling last year in the case of former Staff Sgt. Perry Watkins, 42, of Tacoma. That ruling did not address the validity of the ban but instead noted the Army repeatedly had re-enlisted Watkins while knowing he is homosexual. There was no immediate reaction from the Pentagon. The Bush administration had sought to overturn the appeals court ruling. Watkins celebrated with sparkling apple juice. A 16-year veteran with an excellent service record, he said he wants to serve five more years so he could retire with an Army pension. The court's action requires no change in military regulations. ``It's not a significant victory,'' Watkins said. ``However, because I am an admitted homosexual, it is a good ruling and could certainly have an effect on other cases.'' Gay rights advocates agreed, athough the appeals court ruling implied the Army could try to discharge Watkins for any future homosexual acts. ``These days, we'll take a victory any way we can get one,'' said Paul DiDonato of the National Gay Rights Advocates in San Francisco. The court's decision to let the earlier ruling stand ``sends a broader signal out to the military and the country at large that gays and lesbians cannot be treated unfairly forever by the military or any other employer,'' DiDonato said. Watkins was inducted in 1968 even though he marked ``yes'' on a questionnaire that asked whether he had homosexual tendencies. He was allowed to re-enlist three times after Army investigators looked into his homosexuality but was forced to accept an honorable discharge in 1984. He sued for reinstatement. Asked if he anticipated problems after his reinstatement, Watkins said, ``That goes without saying. The problems that are going to be there are the problems the system itself will create.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Allow Some Japanese Hostages to Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with INA announcement, background on Japanese position, other hostages to be freed. This incorporates material from a0514, PM-Gulf-Foreigners, and stands as the main foreigners sidebar. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq said today that it would release 77 Japanese nationals in response to the intervention of former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. Japan welcomed the move and said it had made no changes in its gulf policy in order to win its citizens' freedom. The official Iraqi News Agency also said 20 Italians, five Swedes, two Germans and two Portuguese would be allowed to leave. Japanese diplomats in Baghdad said at least 20 of the Japanese nationals to be released were among those who were held at strategic installations to serve as ``human shields'' against a possible attack. The others are businessmen who were in Iraq during the invasion, according to Japan's Kyodo News Service. In Tokyo, the Foreign Ministry said Iraq was freeing 69 Japanese hostages. Japanese diplomats in Baghdad said later that was the number Nakasone was originally promised would be freed. But they said Nakasone held a second meeting today with Saddam and won the release of additional Japanese nationals. Japan, which has contributed $4 billion to the anti-Iraq effort, has said in the past it would not make a separate deal for its hostages. Nakasone's mission was technically private but had the support of the Japanese government, and the 72-year-old former leader retains considerable influence in Japanese political affairs. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe welcomed today's Iraqi move, but said other foreigners should be freed too. ``We are delighted to see the release of some Japanese people in Baghdad. But we cannot permit the Iraqi government to force other foreign visitors to remain there, and we have continued our demands that Iraq release these hostages as soon as possible,'' Watanabe said. He said the Japanese hostages' freedom had been achieved without compromising the government's stand against Iraq. Nakasone's visit comes as Japanese lawmakers are considering a measure to deploy Japanese troops to the Persian Gulf in a non-combat role. The official Iraqi News Agency had reported over the weekend that Nakasone had assured Saddam the measure was unlikely to pass. The troop-deployment plan has prompted strong protests in Japan and by today officials of the governing Liberal Democratic Party had all but given up hopes for its passage. Critics contend the proposal violates Japan's constitutional ban on sending troops overseas. The Iraqi News Agency said Nakasone met with Saddam today to ``thank him for Iraq's decision to allow a large number of Japanese nationals - elderly, sick and students - to travel out.'' Nakasone had carried a list of 90 elderly or ailing Japanese, which he presented to Saddam during their first meeting on Sunday. Japanese diplomats in Baghdad said the Iraqi government did not say why it refused to free all 90. They said by late this morning, 40 of those Japanese cleared to travel had arrived at the Mansour-Melia Hotel in preparation for departure. The Japanese, like most foreigners, had been banned from leaving as Iraq responded to buildup of the multinational force in Saudi Arabia that followed Saddam's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait. After his weekend meeting with Saddam, Nakasone said he had urged an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and the freeing of all hostages. The Iraqi leader ``demonstrated serious encouragement to end the crisis peacefully,'' Nakasone told reporters afterward.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Couple $7.5 Million from Toyota
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 4Runner is correct.
DOC.TEXT: A jury has ordered Toyota Motor Corp. to pay $7.5 million for an allegedly faulty seat belt that allowed a man to go through the windshield of a light truck that hit a tree. Toyota spokeswoman Mindy Geller said the company was shocked and planned to appeal. The jury awarded $6 million to Cliff Sadlier, who was partially crippled, and $1.5 million to his wife, Joanne. The Sadliers' lawsuit claimed the seat belt failed when the Toyota 4Runner struck a tree on Feb. 9, 1988. Sadlier, who was alone in the vehicle, said he was going 25 mph; a Toyota expert testified he was going 40 mph. Sadlier, of suburban Bloomfield Hills, said his head went through the windshield and his body hit the dashboard. He said he now must rely on a wheelchair, although he can walk short distances with crutches and braces. Sadlier's attorneys charged the Toyota seat belt lacked a device to take up slack. Toyota's lawyers said the seat belt met federal specifications. ``We felt the seat belt was defective by design,'' said jury foreman Robert Gura. ``It doesn't provide the protection the federal law says it should.'' Geller said the belt saved Sadlier's life. ``It is ironic that under these circumstances, such a verdict was awarded to Mr. Sadlier,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Laws, Discrimination Fears Blamed for Lax Enforcement of Alien Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Immigration and Naturalization Service isn't cracking down on California employers who hire illegal aliens because of political pressure and weak laws, a study concludes. Still, the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 has compelled the INS to develop a framework to implement stricter laws if Congress passes them, concludes the study by the Rand Corp. and the Urban Institute. ``In Los Angeles, the law is being implemented appropriately. It's not being implemented in a very strong, draconian fashion, but Congress probably didn't intend it to be,'' said Rand Corp. researcher Elizabeth Rolph, coauthor of the study with Abby Robyn. Employers are required to make sure job applicants have legal documents, such as a valid drivers license or Social Security card. But an INS official in Washington said that is circumvented by the widespread availability of counterfeit documents, such as drivers licenses and Social Security cards. Fraudulent Social Security cards can be purchased on either side of the border for about $25, said INS spokesman Duke Austin. The study said the INS has moved slowly to enforce laws against hiring of illegal immigrants because many communities depend heavily on cheap immigrant labor. INS officials ``do not want their enforcement posture to alarm employers, generating a political backlash that might cause Congress to amend their new authority.'' Nor does the INS want strict enforcement to trigger employer discrimination against Hispanics and other immigrant groups, a trend that could spur Congress to invoke provisions that would repeal the act, the report says. As a result, the 1986 act has done little to reduce the flow of illegal immigrants into the country, the authors said. The INS reports that more than one million illegals were caught nationwide during the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30, compared to 850,000 in fiscal 1989. The study, which focused on implementation of the act in the Los Angeles area, was based on interviews with INS officials, employers, illegal aliens and advocacy groups in the seven Southern California counties that make up the INS Los Angeles District between November 1986 and December 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Killing Children Surrenders
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered a man accused of fatally stabbing four children and wounding three other family members held without bond after the man surrendered to authorities. Henry Curtis Jackson Jr., 26, surrended Monday to police in his hometown of West Point, about 90 miles east of Greenwood. He was returned to Greenwood later Monday. Leflore County Justice Court Judge Curtis Underwood ordered Jackson jailed without bond pending grand jury action in March. Jackson was charged with four counts of capital murder, three counts of aggravated assault and one count of attempted armed robbery. Capital murder carries a mandatory sentence of death or life in prison. In a statement to police, Jackson admitted the killings, said LeFlore County Sheriff Ricky Banks. Authorities had searched since Thursday for Jackson, who they believe attacked his sister and six nieces and nephews in his mother's home. Leflore County deputies said they believe Jackson tried to steal a safe belonging to his half-brother, Eddie Self, that was kept in the house. Forensic pathologist Steve Hayne said the four children, ages 2 to 5, died of stab wounds to the throat. Jackson's 23-year-old sister and an 11-year-old niece were in stable condition Monday with stab wounds at Greenwood-Leflore Hospital, a spokeswoman said. A spokesman at University of Mississippi Medical Center in Jackson said Jackson's 1-year-old niece was paralyzed by the attack and was in critical but stable condition.

DOC.HEAD: Slayings of Palestinians Linked to Kahane Assassination
With PM-Kahane Slain, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf, ``Kahane was slain...'' to UPDATE with police giving new spelling of alleged assailant's name, revised age.
DOC.TEXT: Two elderly Palestinians were shot and killed in the occupied West Bank today, hours after a gunman believed to be of Arab descent assassinated militant Rabbi Meir Kahane in New York. Israeli news reports suggested the killings were linked. An Israel radio police reporter said that before news of the West Bank slayings was aired, an anonymous caller speaking Hebrew told him ``to check in one of the villages near Nablus, two Arabs were killed there.'' The reporter, Moshe Nussbaum, quoted Kahane supporters in Jerusalem as saying they believed the killings were carried out to avenge the assassination and that more attacks could take place. Arab reports said the killings in the West Bank village of Lubban Sharqiya near Nablus were carried out by a man in civilian clothing who fired an Uzi submachine gun and drove a car with Israeli license plates. The army said the deaths were under investigation. Several Israeli political leaders tied Kahane's assassination to his call for expelling Palestinians from the West Bank and occupied Gaza Strip and throwing Israeli Arab citizens out of the Jewish state. Kahane was slain in a hotel Monday night after addressing a Zionist group. The gunman, identified by police as El Sayed A. Noseir, 37, was shot in the chin by a police officer and hospitalized. Israel Army radio said today the assailant once lived in the occupied territories, but the report could not be confirmed. Palestinians said the name as given by police was not typical, and might be Said Nasser or Nasser el-Said. Kahane, a 58-year-old former legislator, was widely hated by mainstream Israelis, but he and his anti-Arab party, Kach, had a small core of fervent and vocal supporters. The Israeli government appealed for calm as police and army reinforcements spread out in Israel and the occupied territories to head off revenge attcks. ``We are deeply shocked by this murder,'' said Avi Pazner, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. ``Even those, and they are a great majority in Israel, who do not agree with the political views of the late Rabbi Kahane deplore and condemn this further act of Arab terrorism.'' Israel has been torn by Arab attacks on Jews and revenge assaults by Israelis since the Oct. 8 riot on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, when 20 Palestinians were killed by police. At least five people have been killed and a dozen wounded in the series of attacks. Faisal Hussein, a Palestine Liberation Organization supporter in Jerusalem, said today's killings ``raised concerns about the security of our people.'' Kahane supporters warned of violence to avenge the assassination. Officials of his Kach faction dictated a statement to journalists saying: ``The Lord will avenge his blood.'' Kach leader David Ben Dor said Kahane's ideas will live on. ``Whoever thinks that today Rabbi Kahane and the Kach movement have been destroyed has made a great mistake,'' he said. Ben Dor spoke beside Kach flags, their yellow fields centered by a black Jewish star and a clenched fist. About 50 supporters milled about, some shouting ``Death to the Arabs.'' Earlier, several Kach supporters threw chairs at reporters to keep them away from their Jerusalem headquarters. An Israeli television crewman was beaten by Kach supporters, and one sprayed tear gas in his face. He was hospitalized, the radio said. One woman, who refused to give her name, told reporters: ``You haven't seen anything yet. One Jew is worth millions of Arabs, especially when we are talking about Rabbi Kahane.'' Some Israeli and Arab leaders linked Kahane's killing to his beliefs. Labor Party lawmaker Avraham Burg condemned the assassination, but said: ``We must not forget that Kahane is the victim of his own ideology. He sowed hatred and destruction and, in the end, reaped death.'' Saeed Kanan, a Palestinian from the West Bank town of Nablus, quoted the biblical phrase ``He who lives by the sword, dies by the sword,'' adding: ``Kahane was an advocate of racial discrimination and apartheid ... He became a victim of his own slogans and mottos.'' Residents of the Palestinian village where today's killings occurred said a man, believed to be from a nearby Jewish settlement, approached at about 5:45 a.m. in a white car. They said he opened fire with his Uzi on Mohammed al-Khatib, 65, who was riding his donkey to harvest olives in his grove. The attacker continued down the road and fired again, this time killing Miriam Khassan, 60, villagers said. The deaths raised to 773 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the nearly 35-month Palestinian uprising. An additional 294 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Police Feed Media Fake Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to raise reference to undercover sting, ADD reason police conducted sting rather make immediate arrest, details on operation. No pick up.
DOC.TEXT: Police running an undercover sting fed radio stations and a newspaper a false story, saying a lawyer had been castrated on Halloween during an attack at his home. After the story made the front page of the Daily American Republic and was broadcast across southeast Missouri and northeast Arkansas, police revealed the assault was a hoax. The sting was intended to convince a man who allegedly paid a police informant $4,000 for the job that the Arkansas lawyer really had been castrated and his arms and legs broken, police said. On Halloween night, officers acted out the assault at the lawyer's home, and rushed a phony injured man to the hospital. When reporters heard on police scanners what they thought was a story, they contacted the sheriff's office in Clay County, Ark. Sheriff Darvin Stow then told reporters that city attorney C.W. Knauts, of Piggott, Ark., was stabbed and rushed to a hospital. Stow said the attorney had two broken arms and was bleeding from the groin. The target of the sting, Harold Speer of Greenway, Ark., was charged Thursday in Stoddard County, Mo., with conspiracy, burglary and assault. He was arrested in Arkansas. Knauts represented Speer's former wife in a 1985 divorce. Investigators said they wanted to keep the plan a secret for a few days rather than arresting Speer on the spot when he hired the informant because Speer allegedly told the bogus hit man of other jobs he wanted done. Authorities also said they hoped Speer might provide information on the slaying of his ex-wife in Phoenix a month after their divorce.
