Stow said he was sorry if anyone was offended, but it was necessary. ``It's pretty disturbing to me,'' Stan Berry, news editor of the Daily American Republic, said Monday. ``We're not in the business of printing fake stories for anybody.'' The false information was given only by the Clay County Arkansas Sheriff's Department. No news conference was held and no press releases were issued by either the Missouri Highway Patrol or Arkansas State Police, although both were involved in the staged assault.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Council Disqualifies 10 of 26 Presidential Candidates
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - The independent Electoral Council has barred 10 of the 26 declared candidates from running for president, including two men who were key members of the Duvalier regime. The council released a statement late Monday saying the 10 failed to comply with filing procedures. In anticipation of the council action and possible retaliation by Duvalier supporters, Haitians jammed stores Monday night to stock up on supplies. No incidents were reported immediately. The 29-year Duvalier dictatorship ended in 1986 when Jean-Claude Duvalier went into exile, but Haiti has been wracked by turmoil since then. The current provisional government of Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since 1986. The Electoral Council based its decision on technicalities, not on Article 291 of the 1987 Constitution, which bars criminal supporters of past dictators from running for office until 1997. The candidates - including Duvalierists Claude Raymond and Dr. Roger Lafontant - were disqualified for failing to conform to electoral laws, the council said. Raymond, former army chief of staff, was removed from the list because his political party had not been legally registered until after the Oct. 21 deadline for filing his candidacy, the council said. Lafontant failed to obtain clearance from the government auditing office on his handling of public funds while serving as minister of the interior and defense. He also failed to provide a birth certificate, the council said. Council member Jean-Francis Merisier said the decision was based on election rules. He said application of Article 291 would have been ambiguous because no candidate has been tried in a court of law for murder, torture, or misappropriation of public funds. Raymond has been accused publicly of having participated in the massacre that aborted the 1987 presidential elections. He has never been charged. Human rights organizations have accused Lafontant of multiple human rights violations. An arrest warrant charging him with conspiring against national security was never served. When 12 Duvalierists were barred from running for president in 1987, dozens of people were killed. On election day, armed men in collusion with the army killed at least 34 voters. Also disqualified Monday was conservative candidate Gregoire Eugene, who as a dissident was exiled by Duvalier. The council said he failed to pay the required deposit and failed to furnish a bank account statement. The only female candidate, Colette Jacques, was disqualified for failing to pay the required deposit and for not belonging to a legally recognized political party. The election campaign officially opens Wednesday and will close Dec. 14, two days before the voting. The new president is to take office in 1991. Among candidates who qualified for the race is the Rev. Bertrand Aristide, a Duvalier opponent who is believed to have a mass following among the country's poor, a majority in this Caribbean nation of 6 million people. Other major candidates qualified by the council included Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official; Silvio Claude, a former preacher; Louis Dejoie Jr., a businessman; Hubert De Ronceray, a sociologist; former President Leslie Manigat; and Communist Party leader Rene Theodore. Two Duvalierist candidates, Clemard Joseph Charles and Remy Joseph also qualified for the race.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Held as Human Shields Will Be Allowed to Send Messages Home
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi officials have agreed to allow Americans held as human shields at strategic sites to send messages home to their families, the Red Cross announced today. The agreement between the Red Cross and its sister organization, the Iraqi Red Crescent, eventually will permit family members to send parcels containing medicine, food, clothing and paperback books to their loved ones in Iraq. The agreement ``extends humanitarian assistance to Americans in Iraq,'' said Stephen Richards, executive vice president of the American Red Cross. Richards recently returned from Bagdhad where he helped complete the agreement. He did not see any of the American hostages held at the sites outside Baghdad. The messsage exchange program is expected to get under way in about 10 days. About 106 Americans at the strategic sites will be handed short forms to write messages. Those will be shipped to the United States by the Red Cross. The family members will be given the messages and allowed to write responses, which in turn will be delivered to the hostages. The Iraqi Red Crescent officials will serve as the couriers inside Iraq. Richards said the Red Cross eventually hopes officials will be allowed to examine the hostages to make sure they are in good health. Iraqis have told the Americans the hostages are physically all right, but they miss their families and their psychological state could be better.

DOC.HEAD: Foreigners Still In Crisis Zone
DOC.TEXT: Here is a breakdown of some of the foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait as of Tuesday. Most estimates are based on embassy registrations. Some 600 Americans, Britons, Germans and others are being held in Iraq and Kuwait as ``human shields'' at some 30 strategic targets. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has said he will free some of them. An estimated 2,000 Westerners are hiding in Kuwait. According to U.S. State Department figures, more than 900,000 of the estimated 3 million foreigners who were in Kuwait and Iraq Aug. 2 have left. Most of the remaining 2 million are expected to try to leave. Some foreigners, mostly women married to Iraqis or Kuwaitis, have elected to stay. Some governments or independent figures have negotiated the release of their nationals. Saddam has offered to free foreigners in exchange for U.S. guarantees he will not be attacked. But some governments have said they will not negotiate any releases because they believe Saddam is trying to divide the anti-Iraq coalition. ---= AUSTRALIA - Before the invasion of Kuwait, there were 127 Australians in Iraq and Kuwait. There are now 44 Australians in Iraq and 50 in Kuwait, including diplomats. ---= AUSTRIA - Before the invasion there were 70 Austrians in Kuwait and the same number in Iraq. One remains in Kuwait and three to four are still in Iraq, all of Arab background. ---= BANGLADESH - About 110,000 Bangladeshis were in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2. About 15,000 remain, including 2,000 reported to be working as forced laborers at Iraqi military camps in Kuwait. ---= BELGIUM - Before Aug. 2, there were 38 Belgians in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait. Now 37 remain in Iraq and five in Kuwait. ---= BULGARIA - There are 690 Bulgarians in Iraq and Kuwait and the Iraqi parliament voted Nov. 3 to allow all of them to leave. The pre-invasion figure is not known. ---= BRAZIL - There were 450 Brazilians in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2. About 40 remain in Iraq and Kuwait because they are married to citizens of those countries. ---= BRITAIN - Before the invasion there were about 3,000 Britons in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq. There are now about 650 British citizens in Kuwait, mostly in hiding, and about 850 in Iraq. Some 340 are held as human shields in Iraq and 70 in Kuwait. ---= CANADA - Of the approximately 600 Canadians in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq before the invasion, about 50 remain in Kuwait and 50 in Iraq. ---= CHINA - There were about 10,000 Chinese in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. About 4,800 Chinese remain. About 150 citizens of Hong Kong and Taiwan have been evacuated from Kuwait and Iraq. ---= CYPRUS - There were 35 Cypriots in Iraq and Kuwait before Aug. 2. Twenty remain voluntarily. ---= CZECHOSLOVAKIA - Of 470 Czechoslovaks in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2, only six women married to Kuwaitis remain in Kuwait. Around 60 are in Iraq. ---= DENMARK - Twenty-four Danes remain voluntarily in Kuwait, with 36 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of 100. ---= EGYPT - Some 363,000 Egyptians have left Iraq and Kuwait, out of more than 1.3 million in Iraq and 300,000 in Kuwait before the invasion. ---= FINLAND - There were 23 Finns in Iraq and 23 in Kuwait before Aug. 2. Thirteen, including diplomats, are in Iraq and two have stayed in Kuwait voluntarily. ---= FRANCE - Before the invasion, there were 270 French citizens in Kuwait and 290 in Iraq. Some 60 remain. On Oct. 29, Saddam allowed 257 to leave Iraq, including 67 who had been held as human shields. ---= GERMANY - Of the pre-invasion total of 1,000 in Iraq and Kuwait, some 385 remain in Iraq, including about 75 held at strategic locations, with 13 still in Kuwait. Saddam said Tuesday two Germans are among those to be freed. ---= GREECE - There were about 127 Greeks in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Fourteen remain in Iraq and are expected to be freed soon. ---= HUNGARY - There were 178 Hungarians in Kuwait and Iraq before Aug. 2. Now, 32 remain in Iraq, with none in Kuwait. ---= INDIA - There were about 170,000 Indians in Kuwait and 20,000 in Iraq before the invasion. An estimated 16,000-18,000 remain in Kuwait with 6,000 in Iraq. ---= IRELAND - Of the 380 Irish citizens in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. There are now about 220 in Iraq, mostly nurses, and 34 in Kuwait. Some are expected to be allowed to leave soon. ---= ITALY - Before the invasion there were 160 Italians in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. Some 316 remain in Iraq. Six people with dual nationality remain voluntarily in Kuwait. On Tuesday, Saddam listed 20 Italians among those to be released. ---= JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion and 305 are still in Iraq, 139 as human shields, and eight in Kuwait. Saddam said Tuesday he will free 77 of them. ---= LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in Kuwait on Aug. 2, about 5,000 have left. There have been no reports that any of the approximately 10,000 Lebanese in Iraq have left. ---= NETHERLANDS - There were 200 Dutch nationals in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, and 169 remain. ---= NEW ZEALAND - Seven New Zealanders remain in Iraq and 11 in Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36. ---= NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and 26 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of about 46. ---= PAKISTAN - About 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and some 90,000 remain. ---= PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq before the invasion. Some 2,300 remain in Iraq, with an estimated 2,000-3,000 in Kuwait. ---= POLAND - There were 3,123 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now there are 1,213 in Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling project contracts. ---= PORTUGAL - About 40 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, mostly masons who had been working on Saddam's new palace in Baghdad, leaving eight to 10 in Iraq. Saddam said Tuesday two Portuguese will be among those to be freed. ---= ROMANIA - There were 3,055 Romanians in Iraq before the invasion. Some 640 remain. ---= SOUTH KOREA - About 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq, with 140 remaining in Iraq and nine in Kuwait. ---= SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. There are now around 3,000 in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and 206 military advisers. There are none in Kuwait. ---= SPAIN - There were 183 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Six diplomats remain in Baghdad. ---= SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2. Some 65,000 remain in Kuwait. There are 125 Sri Lankans in Iraq. ---= SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total of about 200, 79 remain in Iraq and a few are still in Kuwait. Saddam said Tuesday five Swedes will be among those to be freed. ---= SWITZERLAND - Befre the invasion, there were 97 Swiss nationals in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait and about 80 in Iraq. ---= THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and some 1,150 in Iraq before Aug. 2, with 874 remaining in Iraq and 20 in Kuwait. ---= TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait at the beginning of the Persian Gulf crisis. Almost all have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis. ---= UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of about 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, around 600 remain in hiding or are held in Kuwait and about 330 are in Iraq, including 104 men held as human shields. ---= VENEZUELA - There were 38 Venezuelans in Kuwait and Iraq Aug. 2. Twenty-eight remain. ---= VIETNAM - There were an estimated 17,000 Vietnamese in Iraq before the invasion. Around 1,000 have left and the others are trying to get out. There are no figures available for Kuwait. ---= YUGOSLAVIA - There were some 9,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and about 1,000 in Kuwait on Aug. 2. Some 300 remain in Kuwait and about 1,000 in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: CBS, NBC Election Coverage With Commercials
DOC.TEXT: Tonight's prime-time election specials on CBS and NBC won't be sponsored, although ABC's coverage will have commercials. The one-hour NBC special and CBS' two hours of election night coverage in prime time will be carried as ``sustaining,'' or unsponsored, representatives of both networks said. This means the CBS and NBC broadcasts won't be counted in the current November ratings ``sweeps,'' one of four key ratings periods each year that help network affilliates set their local advertising rates. Both NBC and CBS will use the time to promote shows they're broadcasting as the sweeps period continues this month. NBC acted after CBS decided against seeking sponsorship for its election night program, said an NBC executive who asked not to be identified. It took that step because of the tight prime-time ratings race of all three networks this season, the executive said. If NBC's coverage was sponsored and included in Nielsen ratings, low viewing levels the networks expect on election night might pull down NBC's overall ratings average for this week. NBC again is first in prime time ratings this season, but its margin over second-place CBS is small. According to ratings averages for the season through last Sunday, NBC has a 13.3 ratings average, CBS a 13.0 and ABC a 12.5. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Killed In Dutch Highway Pileup
DOC.TEXT: Up to 100 cars smashed into each other in dense fog on a Dutch highway Tuesday, killing at least 10 people and injuring 27 others, police said. Rescue workers were still pulling people out of the wreckage more than eight hours after the accident on the Rotterdam-to-Antwerp highway, and the casualty toll could still rise, Breda police spokesman Roel Holvast said. The accident just west of this southwestern city occurred shortly after 9:30 a.m., when a driver heading south on collided with two motorcyclists, Holvast said. The crash turned into a pileup because drivers coming fromthe A16 highway behind were surprised by a dense fog patch on an otherwise clear day, he said. A second pileup occurred on the northbound lane when drivers there slowed down to see what happpened, Holvast said. The road, which links two of Europe's most important ports, was expected to be closed well into Tuesday evening, Holvast said.

DOC.HEAD: Dennis The Menace's Hometown Revealed: Wichita
DOC.TEXT: He may have terrorized Mr. Wilson for four decades, but officials of Wichita are glad to have Dennis Mitchell, a.k.a. the Menace, as a neighbor. ``I had no idea he lived here, but he by investigators in 1988. The check was handed over by John E. Robson, an assistant secretary of state. Charasse said the money would be used to strengthen France's ability to uncover money laundering schemes. Investigators involved in ``Operation Cocaine Chase'' seized $32 million in October 1988 that allegedly had been laundered by the Paris-based Banque de Credit et de Commerce International. Authorities arrested bank officials in Paris, London and Tampa, Fla. The seizure followed a two-year investigation by U.S., French and British agents into a Colombian drug ring.

DOC.HEAD: Candidates Watching Voter Turnout for Signs of Winners and Losers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Helms, Martinez, Chiles voting; winter weather in Nebraska; Democratic congresswoman alleging White House is discriminating against her. EDITS throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Nervous politicians put aside opinion polls and campaign strategies and watched voter turnout across the nation today for signs of winners and losers in the first midterm election of the 1990s. In North Carolina, where voters were deciding a bitterly contested Senate contest, officials reported long lines at polling places. President Bush and his wife, Barbara, stood in line for 10 minutes at a polling place at a Houston nursing home. They waved off reporters' questions and, after voting, went to the airport for a flight back to Washington. Republicans, admitting a low turnout would be bad news for their candidates in most states, had spent the closing days of the campaign exhorting their partisans to go to the polls. Democrats counted on uneasiness over the economy to induce their followers to vote. The Senate contest between conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms and his black challenger, Harvey Gantt, appeared to generate a heavy turnout in North Carolina. ``Most precincts say they have more people voting than they do in presidential elections,'' said Mecklenburg County election supervisor Bill Culp. ``When you see long lines like this - more than 300 voters were here before 8:30 - you know you're going to have a nice day,'' Gantt said. ``It's a good sign for us.'' Helms voted in Raleigh and described himself as ``always a little bit anxious'' about the outcome of a campaign. ``I've done the best I can and if it's not the best for the people of North Carolina, then we'll see, but I think it is,'' Helms said. In northern Michigan, highway crews had to dig out the snowed-in clerk of Wellington Township so he could open the polls. Snow also was reported in Iowa, but election officials said early turnout was ``heavier than a normal off-year election.'' In parts of Nebraska, officials said snow and ice was keeping turnout down. ``We've had trouble even getting poll workers to the polls to open them up,'' said Nebraska Secretary of State Allen Beerman. Embattled Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., said the White House was discriminating against her by withholding word on whether the president would sign or veto legislation for a study of a proposed historic reserve in her district. Aides to Unsoeld alleged the White House didn't want to allow her to take credit for enactment of the bill. Voters were choosing 36 governors, 34 senators and the entire 435-member U.S. House, as well as more than 6,000 state legislators. Normally obscure legislative races have gotten national attention from party officials battling for control of the once-in-a-decade redrawing of political boundary lines to conform to new census figures. The stakes are highest in races for governor in the nation's fastest-growing states - California, Florida and Texas. When House seats are redistributed to follow population shifts to the Sun Belt, those three states will pick up a total of 14. In Florida, where Democrats were hopeful that former Sen. Lawton Chiles would unseat Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, election officials forecast a high turnout. Chiles and Martinez were among the early Florida voters. ``You can see the shifting,'' said the underdog Republican governor. ``You can hear the sound of victory.'' In California, Republicans were confident Sen. Pete Wilson would outpoll Democrat Dianne Feinstein in the race to succeed Republican Gov. George Deukmejian. After weeks of barnstorming for GOP candidates from Maine to Hawaii, Bush concentrated on helping the faltering campaign of Clayton Williams for governor of Texas. Once far ahead in the polls, oilman Williams was struggling to outlast Democratic state Treasurer Ann Richards. ``I urge all Texans ... to get out there and vote and do not take democracy for granted,'' Bush said Monday, campaigning with Williams at his side. But one pre-election poll found 80 percent of Texans thought the governor's race was too negative. ``My biggest complaint was we had no good choice in the governor's race,'' said Louis Lauritzen, one of about 50 people waiting to vote at a Grand Prairie, Texas, precinct. ``It was more a case of voting against someone.'' A Republican ``ballot security'' program in North Carolina prompted Democrats to go to a federal judge in New Jersey who had ruled against such activities in prior elections. U.S. District Judge Dickinson Debevoise held Monday that the Republican National Committee was not involved in the North Carolina mailings. But later in the day, the Justice Department sent lawyers to North Carolina to try to ensure that black voters aren't disqualified at the polls based on information gathered by the state Republican Party. Senior Republican Sens. Mark Hatfield of Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota had reason for uneasiness entering Election Day, even though closing polls indicated a trend in their direction. Hatfield was challenged by businessman Harry Lonsdale and Boschwitz was under siege from college professor Paul Wellstone. Rep. Pat Saiki was the best GOP hope for ousting a Democratic senator. She was challenging appointed Sen. Daniel Akaka of Hawaii. Pollsters agreed that voters were in a sour mood, unhappy with the president and Congress alike on their handling of the economy. An ABC News poll said 61 percent of the people disapprove of how Bush is handling the economy and the same percentage also is unhappy with how Congress has handled the same issue. The biggest turnover was expected to come in governors' offices. No one was predicting much change in the 55-45 Democratic majority in the Senate or that party's 258-175 margin of control in the House, which has two vacancies. Among the nation's governors, 29 are Democrats and 21 Republicans. All indications were that the Democrats would add one or two to their total. But there also was a strong chance that two independents - former Republicans - would join the ranks of the governors. In Alaska, former Gov. Wally Hickel was leading the major party candidates in the polls, and former Sen. Lowell Weicker was doing the same in Connecticut. Democrats felt good about their chances in Maine, where former Gov. Joseph Brennan was challenging his Republican successor, John McKernan. Democrats also were optimistic about Nebraska, where businessman Ben Nelson was running against Republican Gov. Kay Orr. The hottest prospect for a Republican pickup was in Ohio, where Republican George Voinovich was leading Democrat Anthony Celebrezze in independent polls.

DOC.HEAD: Former State Official Got Check from Lincoln S&L
DOC.TEXT: A former state savings and loan commissioner received a $50,000 consulting fee from the now-defunct Lincoln Savings and Loan within a week after he left office, a newspaper reported today. ``There are indications the lucrative deal was being arranged while he was with the state,'' the San Francisco Chronicle said of former commissioner Larry Taggart. The check was accompanied by a proposed contract that set up three more quarterly $50,000 payments ending Oct. 1, 1985. The contract was typed with the year 1984 above the signature blanks, although Taggart did not leave his state job until 1985. Taggart told the Chronicle that two Lincoln representatives ``asked if I could be of any service to them in consulting with them'' after he left state office. ``I told them I really didn't want to discuss anything until I was out of office,'' he said. Of the agreement with the year 1984 on it, Taggart said: ``People type stuff up. I'm not sure what it is.'' The check was written 27 days after Taggart approved a request by the now defunct savings and loan involving $900 million in taxpayer-insured deposits. In one of his last major acts as S&L commissioner, Taggart approved a $900 million transfer to a Lincoln subsidiary - where Lincoln hoped they would be grandfathered against a forthcoming rule prohibiting S&Ls from making risky direct investments. Taggart gave his approval three days before the deadline for meeting the grandfathering provision. Taggart joined the consulting company TCS Enterprises after he left office on Jan. 1, 1985. TCS Consulting, a subsidiary, was set up specifically for Taggart to head. On Jan. 18, 1985, Lincoln invested $2.89 million in TCS Enterprises. The investment bought Lincoln 24.9 percent of TCS, which Taggart has testified had a net worth of between $200,000 and $300,000 at the time. Thomas Stickel, the founder of the TCS parent company, speculated that the 1984 date on the contract may have been a typographical error. The agreement was enclosed in a Jan. 4, 1985, letter to Taggart written by Lincoln corporate counsel Mark Sauter who wrote that a $50,000 check was also enclosed ``representing Lincoln's first quarter payment.'' Lincoln was taken over by federal regulators a day after its parent company, American Continental Corp., sought bankruptcy court protection from its creditors. It will cost taxpayers an estimated $2 billion to bail out the thrift. Charles Keating Jr., head of American Continental, is accused in civil suits of looting Lincoln. Keating also faces criminal charges in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Target Key Republican Senators, Four GOP Governors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First polls close at 6 p.m. EST. First add should stand as background.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats bid Tuesday to fortify their majorities in Congress and challenged Republican control of four key governorships, highlights of a midterm election punctuated by the autumn stirrings of voter discontent. With 34 Senate races on the ballot, Democrats took aim at Republican incumbents Jesse Helms in North Carolina, Mark Hatfield in Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz in Minnesota in hopes of padding their current 55-45 majority. The House of Representatives was securely in Democratic control, as it has been since the Eisenhower era. All 435 seats were on the ballot, although most attention clustered around 29 races without an incumbent, 18 of them currently in Republican hands. Among 36 statehouse races, Republican governorships in California, Texas, Florida and Illinois were at risk, probably the biggest prizes of the year. The GOP hoped for victories that would protect their influence in drawing boundaries for House seats that will shift to the Sun Belt in 1992. Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo sought a third term in New York in a possible prelude to a 1992 presidential campaign. Three other potential challengers to President Bush also seemed headed for landslide re-election: Democratic Sens. Bill Bradley of New Jersey; Al Gore of Tennessee and Sam Nunn of Georgia. More than 6,100 legislative races crowded the ballots, and voters in 43 states and the District of Columbia decided issues ranging from a proposed tax rollback in Massachusetts to an environmentalist-sponsored measure known as Big Green in California. Jesse Jackson was on the ballot for the first time as a non-presidential candidate, seeking to become an unpaid, non-voting ``shadow senator'' to lobby Congress for statehood for the District of Columbia. The city also chose a new mayor to replace Marion Barry, who bid for a city council seat in the face of a six-month jail sentence for a drug offense. All in all, the first election of the 1990s came at a time of extraordinary volatility - with the nation on the verge of recession and on the edge of war in the Persian Gulf. Other issues emerged in scattered races - abortion, crime, the savings and loan crisis and ethics scandals among them. The pundits agreed in advance that the electorate was pessimistic about the future and angry about the way the government is run. Whether that would imperil incumbents or benefit one party over another was a different question. ``The conventional wisdom is that people are more satisfied with their own congressman,'' said Frank Newport of the Gallup polling organization. President Bush voted in his home state of Texas after an energetic yet awkward campaign for GOP candidates. Bush sparked a season of Republican discontent when he broke his memorable 1988 campaign pledge and embraced an October deficit-reduction plan that raised tax rates. Democrats held a 259-176 majority in the old House. A pickup of only a few seats in either the House or Senate could vastly complicate the president's success with the 102nd Congress and make it more difficult to cast his vetoes without fear of being overridden. Black political leaders expressed hope they could add to the 24-member Congressional Black Caucus. Republicans hoped to elect their first blacks to the House since 1935: Gary Franks in Connecticut and former Cincinnati Mayor Kenneth Blackwell in Ohio. Among the most closely watched races was the California governor's contest pitting GOP Sen. Pete Wilson against former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein. Democrats control the legislature and the GOP needed the governorship to influence redistricting that follows the 1990 Census when California is expected to gain seven House seats. The Senate race that drew the most attention was in North Carolina, where three-term conservative Jesse Helms battled Harvey Gantt, a black former mayor of Charlotte. Boschwitz was challenged by Paul Wellstone, a liberal political science professor who waged an ingenious ad campaign and took advantage of the disarray that revolved around a hapless Republican nominee for governor. In Oregon, Hatfield battled businessman Harry Lonsdale in his bid for a fifth term. Republicans hoped to capture a seat in Hawaii where Rep. Patricia Saiki ran against Sen. Daniel Akaka, appointed after the death of Spark Matsunaga. The GOP counted on three members of the House to move into the three Senate seats being vacated by retiring Republicans. Robert Smith was favored in New Hampshire; Hank Brown in Colorado and Larry Craig in Idaho. In all, 16 Democrats and 15 Republicans sought Senate re-election. Democrats Sam Nunn of Georgia and David Pryor of Arkansas were unopposed. Republicans Thad Cochran of Mississippi and John Warner of Virginia were also assured of victory. Thirty-six states elected governors, and in 13 of them the incumbent was not on the ballot. Twenty-nine of the nation's governors are currently Democratic and the party was hoping to add a few to the list before the night was over. Clayton Williams angled to keep the Texas governorship in Republican hands in a hotly contested race with Democratic state Treasurer Ann Richards. In Florida, former Sen. Lawton Chiles challenged first-term GOP Gov. Bob Martinez' bid for re-election. Other Republicans facing difficult re-election opponents included Guy Hunt of Alabama and John McKernan Jr. of Maine. The experts and the polls predicted Edward DiPrete of Rhode Island would be turned out of office. Democrat Rudy Perpich faced a tough fight in a Minnesota race marked by Republican turmoil. Arne Carlson was on the ballot, but only because Jon Grunseth dropped out in late October over allegations of sexual improprieties. Eras were ending in Massachusetts, Illinois and Ohio where governors were electing successors to Michael Dukakis, Jim Thompson and Richard Celeste. Dukakis had been so discredited that both candidates - Republican William Weld and Democrat John Silber - were running as outsiders ready to shake things up. In the House, party leaders faced little opposition. Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., was heavily favored, while GOP Leader Bob Michel of Illinois did not have a Democratic opponent. For all the campaign hoopla, voter participation was forecast to be dismal - as usual. Curtis Gans, director of the Committee for the Study of the American Electorate, predicted turnout similar to the last midterm election, in 1986, when 36.4 percent of eligible voters cast ballots.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
Eds: This take provides campaign background; should stand for AMs.
DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: cast ballots.
DOC.TEXT: The historic trend in midterm elections is for gains of 28 House seats and four Senate seats for the party not holding the White House. That seemed unlikely this time, in part because Democrats began with such large majorities, and in part because incumbents of both parties had well-stocked campaign warchests. The battle for control of congressional redistricting was extraordinary as both parties mounted multimillion-dollar efforts to gain control of state legislative chambers in anticipation of the reapportionment wars to come. ``We are under siege like I have never seen,'' said Pennsylvania Senate President Robert Jubelirer, a Republican. The Democrats needed to capture three Republican Senate seats to gain control over the chamber. An estimated 19 House seats are expected to move from northeastern and industrial midwestern states to California, Texas, Florida and other Sun Belt states. A party that controls both houses and the governor's office would have a far easier time redrawing the district lines to its liking, and maximize its strength in the House for the next decade. Eight women were candidates for governor and eight for Senate. At least some candidates had nothing to worry about. For 33 Democratic members of the House and 30 Republicans, Election Day brought no opponent. Pre-election surveys indicated that voters were angry about their government and concerned about the future, yet unlikely to toss out incumbents in any number. Much of the discontent erupted in the fall, well after primary elections had safely returned incumbents to the ballot. A Gallup poll released on election morning said nearly two of every three people surveyed were dissatisfied with the way things are going in the nation, many of them because of economic concerns. A survey by the New York Times and CBS said 77 percent of those surveyed believed the government was run by big interests looking out for themselves. The same polls showed that many Americans didn't know whether their representatives were Democrats or Republicans. But they liked them, and in most cases the incumbents had far more money than their challengers - a seeming prescription for re-election. Republicans had high hopes earlier in the year that they could make serious inroads into the Democratic majority of the Senate and House, and pave the way for possible majority rule later in the decade. Bush made over 100 appearances leading up to Election Day and raised more than $80 million for Republican candidates, by White House reckoning. But his decision to embrace a tax increase after a prolonged series of flip-flops sparked a rebellion among many Republican candidates and seemed to bring to the surface the concern voters had about the economy in general. It also sent his extremely high approval ratings plummeting. Democrats seized on the tax negotiations with Bush to portray themselves as the protectors of the middle class and the Republicans as defenders of the rich, and Republican analysts watched glumly in mid-October as the polls charted a decline in GOP support. Some Republicans criticized the president's decision to his face; still others stayed away from rallies he held for them; others decided they didn't want his help. ``A major mistake,'' said one Republican senator of the tax agreement. He was Dan Coats, appointed to his seat to succeed Vice President Dan Quayle. Bush did his best to minimize the damage. ``Don't listen to that tired, liberal, divide class warfare rhetoric about soaking the rich,'' he said in Texas the day before the election. Hold onto your wallets - they're after you, every single one of you,'' he said of the Democrats. Toward the end, Bush changed the focus of his speeches to the Persian Gulf, and analysts said it arrested the Republican decline in the polls, and in the president's approval ratings, as well. ``I want to see a peaceful resolution to this crisis,'' Bush said the day before the election. ``But let me be very, very clear. We will stop short of making one single concession, because aggression that goes rewarded today will be much worse tomorrow.'' Whatever the outcome, there was already talk about the impact of this year on 1992. Many Republicans said Bush had damaged himself, and some held out the possibility that he would face a largely symbolic, conservative challenge for the GOP presidential nomination in two years. Democrats hoped that the emergence of the ``tax fairness'' issue would give them a wedge for the 1992 campaign. Even taking the economy into account, this was an election without an overriding theme. Abortion played a role in a scattering of races, and a few lawmakers were challenged for their ties to the savings and loan industry. Bush's veto of a year-end civil rights bill came up in the California governor's race - Wilson voted to sustain it - and in a few Senate contests as well. But some of the issues that provoked the loudest debate in Congress had long since faded by the time the fall arrived, including controversies over flag burning, the ``peace dividend'' and many environmental concerns. With Democrats joining the president's Persian Gulf policy, the deployment of more than 200,000 troops half a world away never became an issue, either.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq to Free More Hostages; Baker Makes Plans with Saudis
LaserPhoto NY6, DHA2, CAI1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 26 grafs to UPDATE with Arafat commment, Red Cross announcement on messages to be allowed. Pick up 22nd graf pvs, `In Bonn...'
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein today ordered the release of 106 foreigners, including some who were held as ``human shields'' at key installations, Iraq's official news agency said. The report said those to be freed are 77 Japanese, 20 Italians, five Swedes, two Germans and two Portuguese. The Iraqi News Agency said the move to free more hostages was in response to appeals made by various visiting delegations. It had already said the Japanese nationals were being freed in response to an appeal by former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt was also in the region in an effort to win the freedom of captive foreigners. Today's news of the planned releases came one day after European countries denounced individual attempts to gain the freedom of hostages. Also in Baghdad today was PLO chief Yasser Arafat. He told reporters that prospects for a peace settlement are better than what they were a month ago, and urged the United States to show flexibility. Arafat met with both Brandt and Nakasone. In addition to announcing the new hostage releases, Iraqi officials have reportedly agreed to allow Americans held as human shields at strategic sites to send messages home to their families. The Red Cross said under an agreement with its sister organization, the Iraqi Red Crescent, family members will also be allowed to send parcels containing medicine, food, clothing and paperback books to the captives. The agreement was announced in Washington by Stephen Richards, executive vice president of the American Red Cross, who recently returned from Baghdad. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III traveled to Egypt for the next leg of his weeklong trip to test the idea of military action against Iraq. A key Soviet envoy, meanwhile, reportedly told Western diplomats that his country does not rule out the use of force against Iraq. On Monday, Baker and Saudi King Fahd agreed that the United States will not attack Iraq without Saudi approval, but that American troops would be under U.S. command once they go to battle. Under the accord, the Saudis will share command of U.S. troops as long as the Americans are defending Saudi Arabia, a Bush administration official said on condition of anonymity. Saudi Arabia's foreign minister pointedly reminded Iraq today that the United Nations has not ruled out the use of military force to liberate Kuwait. ``We would like a peaceful settlement, but that option is in the hands of the Iraqis,'' said the minister, Prince Saud. Baker also met in Cairo with China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. China is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, and its supprt would be needed for a U.N.-sanctioned military strike against Saddam. Qian was asked whether his government would support such military action. ``All the armed forces have two roles to play,'' the Chinese official said. ``One is to fight a war, and the other is to seek peace.'' A poll released Monday, meanwhile, said 56 percent of Americans would support an attack on Iraq if U.S. hostages are mistreated. Fifty-one percent said they would back an attack if Iraq refuses to quit Kuwait. Nearly seven in 10 of those responding to the ABC News survey said they expected the United States to go to war. In Tokyo, the Foreign Ministry said 19 of the Japanese captives being freed were among those transferred from Kuwait to Iraq to serve as ``human shields'' against a feared attack by U.S.-led multinational forces in the Persian Gulf region. Another 50 are businessmen who were in Iraq at the time of the invasion, according to Japan's Kyodo News Service. The Foreign Ministry put the number of Japanese to be freed at 69, while the Iraqi report said 77 would be released. Japanese diplomats said Nakasone had won the freedom of the extra hostages in a second meeting with Saddam today. Japan, which has contributed $4 billion to the anti-Iraq effort, has said it would not make a separate deal for its hostages. Japanese lawmakers are considering a measure to send troops to the gulf, but in non-combat roles. On Monday, the European Community pledged to remain united against Saddam by refusing to negotiate individually for the release of hostages. Italy, president of the 12-member community, convened an emergency foreign ministers' meeting at the request of Belgium and the Netherlands to discuss potential cracks in the EC's Iraq policy stemming from the separate hostage missions. In other private visits, a delegation of Irish legislators left Baghdad Monday after a similar mission, and former New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange was reported en route to the gulf to arrange a meeting with Saddam. In Bonn, German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher today suggested Arab states friendly with Iraq be asked to mediate the release of hostages. Brandt's mission has the backing of the German government despite the European Community's stand. Meanwhile, the British Broadcasting Corp. on Monday quoted Yevgeny Primakov, an envoy to Mikhail Gorbachev, as saying a translator erred last week in interpreting Gorbachev as saying a military option was ``unacceptable.'' Primakov has traveled twice to Baghdad for meetings with Saddam in an effort to find a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis. The BBC said Primakov told ambassadors in Moscow that the Soviet Union continues to insist on the full implementation of the two U.N. Security Council resolutions, which call for a trade embargo on Iraq and the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: New Homeowners Find Honey of a Problem
DOC.TEXT: Allen and Annette Clausen never thought about another interpretation of the phrase ``home sweet home'' until they found a 300-pound beehive in a wall of their new house oozing with honey. ``It's a nightmare, this honey,'' Clausen said Monday, surveying the two-story home that had been vacant for two years before he bought it from the U.S. Department of Veteran Affairs. Honey was dripping down the walls and spilling onto floors. Hundreds of bees killed by fumigators last month were under the kitchen stove and behind fireplace tile. Some live ones have returned. ``This has been the worst thing of its kind that we have run up against,'' said Bruce Manning, vice president of Land Ho, the company that managed the property for the Veterans Department. The Clausens bought the three-bedroom house last month for $78,500. They had planned to put in new carpets, tile and baseboards before moving in. Now, since no one realized the extent of the problem, those plans are on hold. Thousands of bees built the 6-foot, 300-pound hive between the back of the fireplace and an outside wall. Another colony built a hive in a kitchen wall and has spread between the kitchen ceiling and a bedroom floor. Fifty pounds of honeycomb were found above a ceiling panel. A pest control company killed the bees before the Clausens completed the purchase, Manning said. But no one realized the extent of the hives or that other bees might move in. Mrs. Clausen complained that Veterans Affairs, Land Ho and the pest control company seem to be avoiding responsibility for the problem. Manning disputed that, saying they had done everything possible to help the couple. ``They're going to be happy when it gets done,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede Washington
Justice Department Monitoring North Carolina Voting for Violations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with comments from North Carolina party officials about today's voting, election officials. No pick up
DOC.TEXT: Justice Department lawyers monitored voting today in North Carolina because of postcards the Republican Party sent regarding eligiblity to vote, but officials reported no problems at polls. ``We do not have anyone who has gone to the polling place with the card and been denied the right to vote,'' said Everette Ward, executive director of the North Carolina Democratic Party. Ward said party lawyers were on duty to explain that voters who had moved from their old precinct still could vote. The Justice Department is threatening legal action if North Carolina election officials try to disqualify voters with information that state Republicans compiled from a postcard mailing. An investigation in the closing days of the heated Senate race between Republican incumbent Jesse Helms and Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt found that more than 100,000 postcards bearing misleading and inaccurate information were sent to voters in 29 counties. The investigation began Friday after Democrats charged that the North Carolina Republican Party targeted heavily black precincts with mailings of 150,000 postcards intended to intimidate voters from going to the polls. A heavy turnout of black voters is important to Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, in his effort to unseat three-term Helms. The race has been close down to the wire. The postcards told voters that they could not cast ballots if they had moved in the last 30 days. They also warned voters it was a federal crime to give false residency information to election officials. ``The card says if you have moved you can't vote,'' Ward said. ``That's not true. As late as this morning we have people who have received the cards who are calling in and want to discuss that with us. ``What we're doing is trying to eliminate the confusion and encourage people that they can vote.'' Alex Brock, state director of elections, said no problems from the GOP postcards had been reported to his office. Brock said the turnout at the state's 2,416 precincts was brisk and he predicted a 55 percent turnout. ``We've had no problems caused by those postcards,'' Brock said. ``In our judgment the statement on the card was misleading, if not totally inaccurate,'' John R. Dunne, assistant attorney general for civil rights, said Monday night. Dunne said the Justice Department had secured a written pledge from the state GOP that it wouldn't compile lists of voters to challenge at the polls from postcards that had been returned because the addressee had moved. While there was no evidence of criminal wrongdoing, the department will review the evidence to determine if a civil suit should be brought, he said. Jack Hawke, the North Carolina GOP chairman, defended the postcards, saying ``the only people who received a mailing from us are those that are improperly registered.'' The lawyers were assigned to travel to the 29 counties ``to send out the message that these challenges should not be honored'' and, if necessary, seek court injunctions, Dunne said.

DOC.HEAD: Richard Clark Lindsay, Commanded NATO Air Forces in Southern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Richard Clark Lindsay, a retired Air Force lieutenant general who commanded NATO air forces in southern Europe, has died. He was 85. Lindsay died of heart failure Saturday at a Glendale hospital, said his son, Richard B. Lindsay, of Fremont. Born in Minneapolis, Lindsay graduated from the University of Minnesota and enlisted as a flying cadet with the Army Air Corps in 1928. He became assistant director of training at Brooks Field in Texas in 1941. Later that year, he joined the War Department general staff. Lindsay became chief of the combined Joint Staff Division of the Army Air Forces Headquarters in 1944. In 1945, he served as assistant chief of staff of plans for the U.S. Army Strategic Air Forces at Guam. Lindsay served in Tokyo for 10 years, then was appointed commander of NATO air forces in southern Europe in 1957. He held the position until he retired from the service in 1960. He worked as a consultant to defense contractors until 1969. In addition to his son, survivors include a daughter, Raylyn Terrell of Alexandria, Va.; nine grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Services will be held Sunday at the Presidio in San Francisco and at Arlington National Cemetery on Nov. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Words Of A Right-Wing Jewish Extremist
With AM-Kahane Shot Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Meir Kahane, who was assassinated in New York on Monday night, was known for statements that opponents viewed as outrageous and supporters saw as revelations. Here are some words of his and of his ultra right-wing party, Kach:
``I want to remove the Arabs - including Israeli Arabs - from the entire land of Iew, 1985.

``Revenge is a very Jewish concept ... Normal people would have done this a long time ago. The Jewish people have been very restrained.'' News conference, 1989, during anti-Arab violence following an attack on Jews.

srael.'' Intervi ``Western democracy, as we know it, is incompatible with Zionism ... Zionism declares that there is going to be a Jewish state with a Jewish majority come what may. Democracy says, `No, if the Arabs are the majority, then they have a right to decide their own fate.' ... I stand with Zionism. I want a Jewish state, not a Hebrew-speaking Portugal.'' Newspaper interview, 1985.

``(It's) the Jewish establishment that destroys the Jew, spiritually and physically. It ignores with contempt any suggestion that Jew hatred in the United States or the West is a serious thing. Having a vested interest - due to wealth and position - in not wishing to believe that Jew hatred could erupt and destroy the Jews, thewould grow by one to three members. ``Twenty-five years after the Voting Rights Act was passed, black Americans have become a major force in the political life of this nation,'' said Eddie N. Williams, president of the center. Three veteran black Democratic congressmen, Augustus Hawkins of California, George Crockett of Michigan and Walter Fauntroy, the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate, all were retiring and were likely to be replaced by black Democratic women. They are: California Assemblywoman Maxine Waters; Detroit City Councilwoman Barbara-Rose Collins and lawyer Eleanor Holmes Norton in Washington. New Orleans was certain to elect a black Democrat to succeed retiring Rep. Lindy Boggs. Tuesday's runoff under Louisiana's unusual election system pits two black Democrats against one another: attorney Marc Morial against state Sen. William Jefferson. The joint center counts 51 blacks in races for House seats or statewide offices, including Democrat Theo Mitchell, a state senator trying to oust incumbent Republican Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. Six black Republicans were on the ballot in House races in Kentucky, Connecticut, Ohio, Illinois and Mississippi. Two open seat races in Ohio and Connecticut appeared to offer the best chance of producing the first black Republican member of the House since 1935: former Cincinnati Mayor J. Kenneth Blackwell and alderman Gary Franks in Waterbury, Conn. Republican Gov. Kay Orr in Nebraska was in a stiff re-election fight. The nation's two other incumbent women governors, Madeline Kunin in Vermont and Rose Mofford in Arizona, chose not to run for re-election. Like Pat Saiki, Republican congresswomen Lynn Martin of Illinois and Claudine Schneider of Rhode Island relinquished their congressional seats to run for the Senate. But Martin was trailing Democratic Sen. Paul Simon in pre-election polls and Schneider was a longshot against Sen. Claiborne Pell. Women were vying for 66 House seats and eight Senate seats. In two House races, both candidates were women. There are currently 28 women in the House and two senators. There are no blacks in the Senate, but the House has 24 blacks, 13 Hispanics and one American Indian. Overall, there are 85 women seeking federal or statewide office, according to the Center for the American Woman and Politics.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Voters Weigh $2.6 Billion Tax Cutting Measure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 8 p.m. EST; matter below the dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts voters grappled Tuesday with a $2.6 billion tax-cutting initiative that opponents feared would devastate the state's frail finances. Question 3, backed by Citizens For Limited Taxation, would shrink state taxes and fees to 1988 levels. It would slash $1.3 billion from the state's $13.4 billion budget in the second half of the current fiscal year, and cut $2.6 billion in fiscal 1992, which begins next July. Recent increases in the state income, sales and gas tax would all be rescinded. --- Opponents argued the cuts would hamper state services, including day care, elderly programs, and police and firefighter training. College campuses could be shut down, and weaker school districts dependent on state funding could face bankruptcy, officials warned. Proponents, angry over four major tax increases in a little more than a year to try to pay state bills, said budget cuts were in order. ``This is a chance to stop the tax increase that is coming if Question 3 does not pass,'' said Barbara Anderson, head of CLT. The financially ailing state already has the lowest bond rating in the country. Bond rating agencies warned passage of Question 3 could drop the state's rating from its current level of Baa to junk bond status. Acknowledging the voter discontent that spawned the initiative, opponents had campaigned on the theme: ``I'm mad but I'm not crazy.''

DOC.HEAD: Six-Mile Oil Spill in Chariton River
DOC.TEXT: Workers today mopped up thousands of gallons of crude oil that spilled from an Amoco pipeline into the Chariton River, authorities said. Estimates from Amoco indicate 21,000 gallons spilled from a break in the line, said Scott Holste, a spokesman for the Missouri Department of Natural Resources. The spill covers six or seven miles, he said. ``It may not be known for several more days how much was spilled. There are indications that that estimate is low,'' Holste said. The oil was contained and Amoco was using absorbing equipment to clean up the oil, he said. It was not immediately known when the spill occurred. The DNR was notified about the spill by Amoco after early this morning, Holste said. Damage to fish and other wildlife was unknown, officials said. The Chariton River runs from the Missouri-Iowa border and empties into the Missouri River.

DOC.HEAD: Race for Governor, Environmental Initiative Top Ballot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Material below dash will stand; polls close at 11 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: A high-stakes race for governor between Republican Pete Wilson and Democrat Dianne Feinstein topped a cumbersome California ballot Tuesday, along with a sweeping environmental initiative known as ``Big Green.'' With Republican Gov. George Deukmejian retiring after two terms, the GOP sought desperately to hold onto the office. Otherwise, Democrats who control the Legislature would have a free hand drawing new congressional boundaries to their party's liking. The long list of 28 ballot issues included two conflicting term limit initiatives and two competing liquor tax increases. Democrat Kathleen Brown, the sister of former Gov. Jerry Brown and daughter of former Gov. Pat Brown, tried to launch her own statewide political career by challenging the incumbent Republican state treasurer, Tom Hayes. Incumbents were heavily favored in most of California's 45 congressional races, but there were several tight races: -Actor Ralph Waite, television's ``Papa John Walton,'' waged an unexpectedly strong campaign as a Democrat in a heavily Republican desert district surrounding Palm Springs against GOP incumbent Al McCandless. -GOP incumbent Charles ``Chip'' Pashayan, crippled politically by links to indicted former Lincoln Savings chief Charles Keating, was in a close fight against Democratic challenger Calvin Dooley in a San Joaquin Valley race. -San Diego Democrat Jim Bates, formally rebuked by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harrassment of women employees on his congressional staff, was challenged by former Navy flyer, Republican Randy ``Duke'' Cunningham. -Rep. George Brown, a perpetual target of Republicans, faced another strong challenge from Republican Bob Hammock, a San Bernardino County Supervisor.

The current makeup of the congressional delegation is 27 Democrats and 18 Republicans. A final round of independent pre-election polls in the governor's race showed Wilson, the state's junior U.S. senator, leading by anywhere from 1 to 8 percentage points over Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco. --- Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, and Wilson, the state's junior U.S. senator, waged a see-saw campaign in which they spent a combined total of nearly $40 million. Much of the campaign focused on comparisons of Wilson's 11-year tenure as mayor of San Diego before his 1982 election to the Senate and Feinstein's nine years as mayor of San Francisco. Both are political moderates, both pro-choice and both pro-death penalty. Below the surface was the issue of reapportionment in 1992, when California's congressional delegation expands from the current 45 to 52 or more seats. Since Democrats have had firm control of both houses of the Legislature for the past 20 years, Republicans believed their only hope to prevent a Democratic gerrymander of those districts is the threat of a veto from a GOP governor. Leaders of both parties said the difference between a Democratic and Republican governor could be 10 to 12 congresssional seats. Proposition 128, the ``Big Green'' initiative, was a sweeping plan to phase out cancer-causing pesticides, ban chemicals that harm the ozone, and reduce emissions of gases that contribute to global warming. It would also preserve old-growth redwood stands, restrict offshore oil drilling and create a new elective office of environmental czar. It was supported by every major environmental group in the state and vigorously opposed by water, timber, agricultural and manufacturing groups. Proposition 140 would limit the governor and most other elected state officials to eight years in office, limit state senators to eight years and Assembly members to six years. Its rival, Proposition 131, would limit legislators to 12 years in office. The two liquor tax proposals were put on the ballot by competing interests. Proposition 134, a nickel-a-drink plan, was a $750-million-a-year tax hike supported by emergency room physicians, and many law enforcement and alcohol counseling groups, among others. Proposition 126 was a penny-a-drink alternative sponsored by the liquor industry.

DOC.HEAD: Herbert Berghof, Actor, Director and Teacher, Dies at 81
DOC.TEXT: Herbert Berghof, an acting teacher whose students included Geraldine Page, Fritz Weaver, Liza Minnelli, Al Pacino and Robert DeNiro, has died at age 81. Berghof, who also was a director and actor, died Monday at his Manhattan home of a heart ailment, a family spokesman said. For more than 50 years, Berghof helped to hone the stage and screen skills of performers. Among his students were Miss Page, Weaver, Miss Minnelli, Pacino, DeNiro, Anne Bancroft, Donna McKechnie and Matthew Broderick. He showcased many works by new playwrights at his Greenwich Village school, the Herbert Berghof Studio. Berghof, who fled his native Austria after the country merged with Nazi Germany in 1938, opened an acting school in the Chelsea section of Manhattan in 1945. In 1947, he became a charter member of the Actors Studio, but came to disagree with his colleagues there who preferred the Method Technique when he shifted his own focus to an emphasis on actions rather than thoughts and reactions. Among the plays he directed was the American premiere of Samuel Beckett's ``Waiting for Godot,'' in 1956. He also directed New York productions of the first black version of ``Godot'' in 1957, Jean Cocteau's ``Infernal Machine'' (1958), F. Scott Fitzgerald's ``This Side of Paradise'' (1962), Pavel Kohout's ``Poor Murderer'' (1976), and Peter Hacks' ``Charlotte,'' starring his wife, Uta Hagen, in 1980. Some of Berghof's Broadway roles were in ``King Lear'' (1940), ``Little Women'' (1944), ``Ghosts'' and Hedda Gabler'' (1948). In addition to Hagen, his wife of nearly 40 years, Berghof is survived by a step-daughter, Letitia Ferrer of Manhattan, and a granddaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Capital Choosing Successor To Barry
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Sharon Pratt Dixon battled Maurice Turner on Tuesday as the District of Columbia picked a new mayor to replace scandal-scarred Marion Barry. Jesse Jackson sought election as a ``shadow senator'' to lobby Congress for statehood. Barry, who faces a six-month jail term for cocaine possession, sought election to an at-large city council seat. He has served three terms as mayor. Democrat Eleanor Holmes Norton was favored in her race against Harry Singleton for the non-voting House seat despite revelations that she failed to file city income tax returns for a seven-year period beginning in 1983. Voters also decided whether to restore a sweeping overnight shelter provision gutted by the city council earlier this year because of cost concerns. A record number of city residents was registered to vote. Board of Elections spokeswoman Leona Agouridis forecast a high voter turnout from the 308,000 residents eligible to go to the polls. Whatever the outcome, the election was certain to produce new leadership for a city that spent much of last year buffeted by the details of Barry's arrest on drug charges, his sensational trial and the imposition of a six-month jail sentence. Dixon, a 46-year-old former utility company executive, scored a surprise primary win in September after pledging to eliminate waste and fraud in the district government. Turner, the city's former police chief, zeroed in on Dixon's lack of political experience and criticized her plan to drop 2,000 workers from the city payroll. The Democratic nominee hit Turner for his conversion to the GOP last year, frequently calling him ``a born-again Republican.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Money Ex-Senator Seeks Comeback Against GOP Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Matter below dash will stand; polls close at 8 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles, who said he was ``burned out'' two years ago when he retired from the Senate, tried Tuesday for a political comeback against Republican Gov. Bob Martinez. Chiles, 60, said he came out of retirement to lead a revolt against big-money politics. State Democrats hoped he would help them rally against a GOP tide. Martinez, 55, was trying to cap his own comeback after a shaky first term. Only the second Republican governor in Florida since Reconstruction, Martinez headed a GOP ticket aiming to boost its 11-8 congressional delegation lead and take control of the state Senate. It would be the first time Republicans have been the majority party in a Deep South legislative chamber in modern history. Floridians also voted on whether to retain their first black chief Supreme Court justice, Leander Shaw, who was targeted by anti-abortionists, and on whether the crime-beset state should make mandatory a three-day waiting period for handgun purchases. --- With reapportionment looming in 1992, Florida drew heavy attention from both national parties. The state is expected to gain at least three congressional seats, and Republicans said they could reverse traditional Democratic gerrymandering if they could control the governorship and at least one legislative chamber. President Bush campaigned for Martinez three times and his son, Jeb, was Martinez's campaign chairman. Martinez started in April against Chiles as much as 30 points behind in some polls but headed to the finish in what polls indicated was a dead heat. Spending $10.6 million, the grandson of Spanish immigrants kept up a torrid campaign schedule and bombarded Floridians with feel-good ads that portrayed him as a beach-strolling family man who did best at protecting the environment and executing criminals. One tough-on-crime ad featured a picture of serial killer Ted Bundy, who was executed on Martinez' order last year. He tried to portray himself as the populist outsider fighting ``that Tallahassee gang'' and called Chiles a liberal Washington insider. Chiles voluntarily limited individual contributions to $100 each and spent $5.2 million. He said his refusal to rely on heavy contributors would let him govern without obligations to special interests. His low-key, low-budget pace worried supporters such as Steve Pajcic, the 1986 Democratic nominee who said Chiles' money strategy was ``dumb, naive and idealistic.'' And Chiles said because he personally was anti-abortion although pro-choice politically, his conscience wouldn't allow him to hit Martinez hard on the governor's unpopular efforts to further restrict abortion in the state. Chiles stunned Democrats in December 1987 by announcing he wouldn't seek a fourth term. He had become the Senate Budget Committee chairman, but said he was ``burned out'' by Washington's failure to fight the budget deficit. When he abruptly entered the gubernatorial race, it was disclosed Chiles was on the anti-depressant drug Prozac. Chiles, who underwent quadruple-bypass heart surgery in 1985, halted taking the drug but resumed its use midway through his campaign.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Watergate burglar and former FBI agent G. Gordon Liddy says his transformation from convict to novelist is not surprising because prison gave him what he needed to write. ``The thing you need to write is time - I had lots of it,'' Liddy, 60, said Monday during a visit to Alaska to plug his newest book, ``The Monkey Handlers.'' The novel, published by St. Martin's Press, focuses on the efforts of a former Navy Seal to stop medical experiments on animals at a chemical plant on the Hudson River. It is Liddy's third book and second novel. Liddy served time in nine prisons after being convicted of participating in the 1972 burglary of the Democratic Party's Watergate headquarters. --- BILLINGS, Mont. (AP) - A 14-year-old boy aiming his shotgun at a pheasant accidentally shot Sen. Conrad Burns. The Montana Republican's injuries were minor and he stopped for breakfast on his way to the hospital. Eleven pellets struck Burns during Sunday's hunting accident. He was struck in the forehead, left hand and shoulder. Burns, who was elected to his first term in 1988, was treated in the emergency room at a Billings hospital, said Yellowstone County Deputy Sheriff Bill Michaelis. Michaelis said the teen-ager was in a creek bottom and the senator was on a hillside about 20 yards away. The boy fired when a pheasant flew by. ``I don't know if he got it, but he got Senator Burns,'' Michaelis said. The shots knocked the senator down, Michaelis said. At a news conference Monday, Burns showed few scars from his accident. He said the young hunter was a friend of his son. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version moving on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Former senator and presidential candidate George McGovern and his partners in a Stratford hotel have filed a Chapter 11 bankruptcy petition to avoid eviction. McGovern and his partners in the Stratford Inn filed the petition Friday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport. ``It was done to buy enough time to reorganize,'' said Richard D. Zeisler, an attorney for the partnership. Stratford Inn Associates Limited Partnership, whose president is McGovern, was delinquent in paying the hotel's landlord, Goldman D. Lorenzo. Lorenzo had threatened to terminate the lease McGovern signed when he purchased the hotel in October 1988 for $1 million, Zeisler said. Court records show the partnership listed $986,000 in liabilities, including $43,000 in taxes owed to the town of Stratford. The petition also lists $986,000 in assets. Earlier this year, the state filed three liens against the Stratford Inn totaling more than $60,000 for non-payment of sales tax and room occupancy tax. McGovern, a former senator from South Dakota, was defeated by President Nixon in the 1972 presidential race. --- PHILADELPHIA (AP) - American bass James Morris has been described as a bigger than life cowboy because of his love for wide open spaces and his imposing presence on and off the stage. He has also been described as demanding and aloof. But after a Monday night season opener for the Opera Company of Philadelphia, Morris was in good spirits - partly because his wife performed in the same opera. Morris sang Count Almavivia ,the philanderer in Mozart's ``The Marriage of Figaro.'' His wife, mezzo soprano Susan Quittmeyer, sang the role of Cherubino, a page and an unwitting foil for Figaro. Quittmeyer said the casting didn't happen by chance. ``These are never coincidences,'' she said. Morris agreed, saying scheduling was a problem in their personal lives. ``It's great when we get a chance to be in the same part of the country and even greater to be together in a production,'' he said. ``I especially like it when we can both go to Santa Fe because I love the West, too.'' The couple lives in New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Seek to Regain Governor's Seat for First Time Since 1976
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Matter below the dash will stand; polls close at 8 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Neil Hartigan and Republican Jim Edgar battled Tuesday in Illinois' first wide-open governor's race in more than a decade - a race that reversed the usual political wisdom on taxes. Democratic Sen. Paul Simon was challenged in a bid for re-election by Republican Rep. Lynn Martin, whose anti-tax message and late call for limiting the terms of Washington lawmakers had not stopped her slide in the polls. Hartigan, the attorney general, tried to appeal to voters weary of taxes by saying he would not ask lawmakers to extend a special income tax for education. Edgar, the secretary of state, said pinching pocketbooks was better than shortchanging schools. A late October survey done for the Chicago Tribune had Edgar in front, 45 percent to 34 percent, with 20 percent undecided, but a Chicago Sun-Times poll in the same period found the race a dead heat. There also was a wild card: a slate of black candidates in Cook County who ran under the banner of the Harold Washington Party - named after Chicago's late black mayor - and urged blacks to oppose Hartigan. The latest Senate survey showed Simon ahead, 62 percent to 28 percent, with 10 percent undecided. Most members of the state's congressional delegation appeared headed for re-election, but there were two competitive races in the Chicago area. In the 11th District, Republican Walter Dudycz tried to oust Democratic U.S. Rep. Frank Annunzio by portraying him as a friend of the savings-and-loan industry. The National Republican Congressional Committee put Annunzio on its list of endangered Democrats. He is the No. 2 Democrat on the House Banking Committee and chairman of a subcommittee that has some S&L oversight. Annunzio's relatives have ties to the industry, and S&Ls executives have helped finance his re-election bid. In the 4th District, freshman U.S. Rep. George Sangmeister, who knocked off an incumbent by only 1,000 votes in 1988, faced Republican Manny Hoffman. Before the election, Illinois Democrats had a 14-8 edge in the U.S. House.

After 14 years in office, Republican Gov. James R. Thompson did not seek re-election, leaving the field open. Hartigan, 52, staked his campaign primarily on one issue: opposition to extending an income tax that is earmarked for schools and local governments and expires in June 1991. Edgar, 44, said school districts would be a financial mess if the tax revenue stopped flowing. In the Senate race, Martin told voters that Simon was too liberal for the state. The five-term congresswoman from suburban Rockford struck a time-for-change theme and declared that she would not vote for higher taxes, although she had supported several increases during her House career. Simon had been considered vulnerable going into the race. But he outspent Martin roughly 2-to-1 by late in the campaign, and Martin conceded she knew her race was a long shot.

DOC.HEAD: Regardless of Who Wins, Gubernatorial Candidates Promise Shakeup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 8 p.m. EST; matter below dash will stand
DOC.TEXT: Voters chose between two political newcomers for governor Tuesday, both promising to rebuild Massachusetts from the ashes of what only two years ago Gov. Michael S. Dukakis ballyhooed as a miracle economy. In the race between moderate Republican William Weld, a former federal prosecutor, and fiery John Silber, on leave as president of Boston University, the name of Dukakis was mentioned often and unfavorably. Weld and Republicans, who have not won the governor's race since 1970, also got behind Question Three on the ballot, a tax rollback initiative that would return $1.2 billion to taxpayers this fiscal year. Silber opposed the rollback as an economic disaster for a state that can hardly pay its bills now. Sen. John F. Kerry, a Democrat and former lieutenant governor under Dukakis, was bidding for a second term. He faced James Rappaport, a mutimillionaire businessman in a surprisingly tight race. Such challenges were otherwise restricted to the state and local level. Of the state's 11 congressmen, four were not opposed in the general election, and the other seven, including lone Republican incumbent Silvio Conte, were favored to win re-election. Although Democratic Rep. Barney Frank was reprimanded by the House earlier this year for his activities with a male prostitute, Republican candidate John Soto attracted little money in his bid to oust him. --- Silber, who emerged as the underdog winner of the Sept. 18 Democratic primary, was no die-hard Democrat. He acknowleded he voted for President Bush over Dukakis in 1988, and he didn't hesitate to blame Dukakis for the state's fiscal mess, including annual deficits and the lowest bond rating of any state in the nation. ``The incompetence of the Dukakis administration is appalling to me,'' Silber said in the final televised debate of the campaign. Still, Silber stressed traditional Democratic positions, such as economic pump-priming to help ease the state's economic recession. He opposed Question 3 and pointed to Weld's opposition to an assault weapons ban as a sign of the GOP nominee's basic conservatism. Silber's general election campaign was calmer in tone than his primary election, in which a series of statements on women, immigrants, welfare mothers were dubbed ``Silber shockers'' by the media. But the statements never seemed to have a serious impact on Silber, who frequently complained he was quoted out of context. Silber, 64, has his roots in Texas, but campaigned on his 20-year record at BU and as a political outsider who would end what he says are the tax and spend policies of Dukakis. Weld, 45, a former U.S. attorney for Massachusetts and former head of the Justice Department's criminal division, argued that underneath the rhetoric, Silber was a traditional Democrat tied to other members of the power structure. The Kerry-Rappaport race was negative from the start. Rappaport attempted to tie Kerry to Dukakis and also criticized the incumbent for his interest in foreign relations issues. Kerry struck back, claiming Rappaport's family had made millions through federal housing money and agricultural subsidies that Rappaport opposed in his Senate campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Twelve Illinois Students Charged in Hazing Death
DOC.TEXT: Twelve members of a university lacrosse team were charged with misdemeanors in the death of a teammate who overdosed on alcohol during an alleged initiation, school officials said. The 12 were arrested Monday and charged by the McDonough County state's attorney's office with hazing and unlawful delivery of alcohol to a minor. Nicholas Haben, 18, of Oswego, was found dead Oct. 19 in a Western Illinois University dormitory room. Officials said he was forced to drink a large quantity of alcohol. Authorities refused to say how much alcohol was involved. Haben died after he and other first-year players were led to a wooded area, swatted, and encouraged to consume ``rookie juice,'' a concoction that included beer, schnapps, coffee, tuna, eggs and hot dogs, authorities said. Brian Donchez, who is among those charged, said the students did nothing wrong. ``We didn't haze and that's all there is to it,'' said Donchez, 21, of Chicago. The 12 students were released after each posted $100 on $1,000 bonds.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Families Of Killed Seamen Not Eligible For Monetary Damages
DOC.TEXT: A unanimous Supreme Court ruled Tuesday that families of American seamen killed on the job may not be awarded monetary damages for lost future earnings or ``loss of society.'' The 8-0 decision, yielding the first signed opinion of the court's 1990-91 term, said general maritime law allows wrongful-death lawsuits in such cases. But it added that any damages recovered cannot include those for loss of society or for lost future earnings. Loss of society is defined as a broad range of mutual benefits family members receive from each other, including love, affection, care, attention, companionship, comfort and protection. The ruling was a defeat for the mother of a young seaman murdered while his ship was docked in Vancouver, Wash., six years ago. ``We sail in occupied waters. Maritime tort law is now dominated by federal statute, and we are not free to expand remedies at will simply because it might work to the benefit of seamen and those dependent upon them,'' Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote. Justice David H. Souter, who joined the court after the case was argued last month, did not participate in the decision. The ruling leaves families of seamen free to sue allegedly negligent shipowners and shipping companies under a 1920 federal law, the Jones Act, but that law places specific limits on such suits. Ludwick Torregano, a 24-year-old galley assistant, was killed aboard the Archon on July 18, 1984.
