Clifford Melrose, the ship's chief chef, stabbed Torregano at least 62 times, and later was convicted of second-degree murder. Torregano's mother, Mercedel Miles, later sued the ship's owners and operators in federal court in New Orleans, contending that their negligence in hiring an unfit crewman caused her son's death. Ms. Miles was awarded $140,000 for the pain and suffering Torregano experienced prior to his death and $7,800 for the loss of her son's support. Those awards were made under the Jones Act. But the jury refused to award additional damages, under general maritime law, for the loss of Torregano's future income or for the loss of society by both Ms. Miles and the seaman's father, Joseph Torregano. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the damages award last year, and Tuesday's decision in turn upheld the appeals court ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Voters Deciding Wild Governor's Race; Surprising Senate Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Matter below the dash will stand; polls close at 9 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: In Minnesota's wildest governor's race ever, Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich struggled to win a fourth term Tuesday against Arne Carlson, a Republican who was put on the ballot just last week. Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz also was locked in a tight contest, partly because of the GOP's gubernatorial turmoil. He faced Democratic college professor Paul Wellstone, who waged a campaign with puckish humor. Election officials predicted that results could be delayed several hours because a switch in GOP gubernatorial candidates forced the printing of supplemental ballots, which were to be counted by hand. Carlson finished second in the GOP primary. But he became his party's gubernatorial candidate a week ago to replace Jon Grunseth, who withdrew amid allegations he swam nude with teen-age girls and cheated on his wives. An independent poll taken Oct. 19-21, while Grunseth was still in the race and Carlson was being urged to mount a write-in campaign, showed Carlson leading Perpich 51 percent to 41 percent in a hypothetical race. Five Minnesota Democratic congressmen and two Republican House members were seeking re-election. Republicans also hoped to retain the 3rd District seat, which Bill Frenzel is vacating after 20 years. Republican Rep. Arlan Stangeland, under fire for billing personal telephone calls to his congressional expenses, faced frequent challenger Collin Peterson in Minnesota's 7th District in the northwestern and central parts of the state. Also on the ballot was a proposal that would send 40 percent of net state lottery proceeds to a trust fund designated to protect natural resources and wildlife. --- Republican turmoil in the gubernatorial race far overshadowed the problems that plagued Perpich at the beginning of the year, when he was dubbed ``Governor Goofy'' for his actions in a series of disputes with the news media. Perpich, 62, was seeking to become the first Minnesota governor to serve four terms. Carlson, 56, has been state auditor for 12 years. He had launched a general election write-in campaign a week before Grunseth withdrew. Three weeks before the election, Grunseth was accused of encouraging four girls aged 13 to 16 to join him for a nude swim at a 1981 pool party and of trying to touch one girl's breast. Grunseth denied those allegations. Then late last month a newspaper described a woman's story of having an affair with Grunseth during both of his marriages. Grunseth said the affair ended before he married for the second time, but he dropped out of the race later that day. ``Certainly there have been other election seasons in Minnesota fraught with conflict, acrimony and dispute,'' said Hyman Berman, a history professor at the University of Minnesota. ``But we've never had a candidate who was found to have his zipper unzipped and we've never had a major party candidate drop out voluntarily within a week of the election.'' Wellstone, 47, a Carleton College political science professor, campaigned with a series of humorous television ads - one of which showed him ``looking for Rudy'' in a takeoff of the documentary film ``Roger and Me.'' But Wellstone was on the defensive in the last week of the campaign after Boschwitz, 59, told voters that Wellstone's national health care plan would result in the shutdown of the Mayo Clinic and that Wellstone's spending proposals would require a doubling of taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Order First Use of Reserves for Gulf Combat Roles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 2nd graf with Pentagon raising total of U.S. forces in gulf
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps said today it was ordering to active duty about 630 reservists from units in eight states for combat roles in the Persian Gulf. It is the first such use of American combat reserves in the crisis. Also today the Pentagon announced that more than 230,000 U.S. forces are deployed in the gulf area, and that deployments are continuing. The total is 20,000 more than the Pentagon's previous official estimate, issued last month. The Marine Corps decision, while not significantly increasing U.S. combat capability in the gulf, marks an important departure for the Pentagon. It opens the way to possible use of major Army reserve combat units in Operation Desert Shield and signals a growing U.S. military and political commitment to evicting Iraq from Kuwait. The more than 34,000 reserves called to active duty by all the military services over the past 10 weeks have been used only in non-combat roles. Pete Williams, a Pentagon spokesman, said today that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering giving the Army the authority to call up major combat reserve units, but that no decision has been made. The approximately 630 Marine combat troops being put on active duty are among 824 Marine reserves called up for a variety of combat and support duties. The callup order issued by Gen. Al Gray, commandant of the Marine Corps, brings to 998 the total number of Marine reserves put on active duty for Desert Shield. Among all the military services, 35,173 reserves have been called to active duty for the gulf crisis, including the Marines' latest call-up, Williams said. The 630 Marine combat reserves are being assigned initially to the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade at Camp Pendleton, Calif., to form a specially tailored group known as an air-ground task force. It is expected that the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade will be sent to the gulf as replacements for one of several Marine task forces already there as part of Desert Shield, although Pentagon spokesman Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner said no decision had been made on an eventual deployment of the 5th MEB to the gulf. The combat reserves are being called from the following units: -4th Light Anti-air Defense Battalion at Pasadena, Calif., totaling 55 men. -4th Light Armored Vehicle Battalion at Camp Pendleton, 34 men. -4th Tank Battalion, Company A and a detachment from Headquarters and Service Company, at Miramar Naval Air Station, Calif., totaling 120 men. -An anti-tank platoon from the 23rd Marines at Brousard, La., totaling 75 men. -4th Combat Engineer Battalion, an engineer support company and a detachment from headquarters and service company, at Baltimore, Md., totaling 24 men. -4th Amphibious Assault Battalion at Gulfport, Miss., and 4th Assault Amphibian Battalion at Norfolk, Va., totaling 189 men. -4th Force Reconnaissance Company at Reno, Nev., 34 men. -2nd Battalion, 25th Marines at Bronx, N.Y., 53 men. -4th Combat Engineer Battalion, Charleston, W.Va., 49 men. Use of reserves for combat roles is politically sensitive because it can be viewed as putting the country on a wartime footing. No shots have been fired in the confrontation with Iraq, but President Bush has not ruled out the use of force to oust Iraq from occupied Kuwait. The Pentagon has been under pressure from some congressional leaders to use combat reserves. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had resisted using them, saying the 180-day maximum period of activation for reserves was too short to make good use of them. That concern was erased earlier this month when Congress, shortly before adjourning, doubled the limit on active duty service for combat reserves to 360 days.

DOC.HEAD: Helms, Gantt Face Off in Struggle of Old, New South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Matter below the dash will stand; polls close at 8:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Three-term Republican Sen. Jesse Helms and Democratic challenger Harvey Gantt squared off Tuesday in an epic clash between the conservative Old South and the progressive New South. Gantt, 47, an architect who served two terms as the first black mayor of Charlotte, campaigned as an unabashed liberal. He advocated the idea that ``government has a role'' in solving the nation's education, environmental and health care problems. Helms, 69, a leading spokesman for the American right, argued that government is too large and intrusive and needs to be cut back. He sounded his familiar themes, attacking affirmative action programs as unfair to whites and decrying pornography and homosexuality as signs of declining moral values. Voter turnout was running heavy in both urban and rural areas of the state. Long lines were reported in both predominantly white and black precincts as the polls opened. Opinion polls released last week showed a close race. One poll gave Helms a lead of 4 percentage points; another gave Gantt the same lead. Both had margins of error of 3.5 percentage points.

Helms, limited to eight days of full-time campaigning by the late adjournment of Congress, injected the issue of race into the campaign in the final week. Helms accused Gantt of running a ``secret campaign'' aimed at getting black voters to the polls. He played a radio ad for Gantt in which a black couple discusses the need to vote. Helms' television ads also accused Gantt of using his minority status in 1985 to acquire a television station license that later was sold to a white-owned company. The Federal Communications Commission approved that sale, which Gantt called ``a private business deal that did not involve one dime of government money.'' Helms also criticized the 1990 Civil Rights Act, calling it the ``quota bill.'' The measure failed when the Senate fell one vote short of overriding a veto by President Bush. Bush said he vetoed the bill because it would force businesses to develop quotas for minority hiring. ``If you want quotas to dominate and dictate whether you get a job or get a promotion, you vote for Mr. Gantt,'' Helms said. Gantt said Helms' claims of a secret campaign to get blacks to the polls were ``stupid.'' ``Don't let Jesse Helms divert you into thinking that Harvey Gantt is doing something sinister or secret over the airwaves,'' Gantt said. ``How can you run a secret campaign in the black community over radio stations? That is stupid.'' Gantt also ridiculed the senator's claim to represent North Carolina values. ``With his lies?'' Gantt asked campaign crowds. ``With his distortions? With his lack of courage? Of course not.'' Gantt campaigned on Helms' votes against education and environmental bills. He said Helms was more interested in foreign affairs than state concerns. Helms argued that his votes against those measures were based on his concerns that federal spending was excessive.

DOC.HEAD: Hatfield Fights to Keep Job
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Matter below dash will stand; polls close at 11 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Mark Hatfield bid for a fifth term Tuesday against a surprisingly strong challenge from Democrat Harry Lonsdale, a free-spending businessman who campaigned as a political outsider. Lonsdale, who also criticized Hatfield for not doing enough to reduce cutting of old growth forests, had led in some late October polls. But the incumbent appeared to aave regained momentum in the final week. In the race for governor, Democrat Barbara Roberts held a slight edge in polls over Republican Dave Frohnmayer. Independent anti-abortion candidate Al Mobley appeared to be stealing support from Frohnmayer and was favored by about 14 percent of voters in a late survey. Incumbent Gov. Neil Goldschmidt, a Democrat, did not seek re-election. Republican Denny Smith was in trouble in his bid for a sixth term in the U.S. House from the state's 5th District. He faced Democrat Mike Kopetski, who came within 707 votes of upsetting Smith two years ago. Democrats were likely to retain control of the state Senate, where they hold a 19-11 advantage. Control of the state House, now 32-28 in favor of Democrats, could go either way. Voters also faced 11 statewide ballot issues. Polls showed voters closely divided on a measure that would shut down the state's only nuclear power plant, the Trojan plant in northwestern Oregon. Another measure would reduce property taxes by an average of nearly 50 percent over five years, threatening the funding of schools and local governments. Late polls showed the measure had a slight edge Still another proposition would give $2,500 income-tax credits to parents for sending children to private schools. Polls indicated that measure was falling out of voters' favor. A proposition to ban abortions except in reported cases of rape or incest or to save the mother's life appeared headed for defeat. But a measure requiring doctors to notify a parent before performing an abortion on a minor had voters split. --- The Senate race was one of the most bitter in Oregon in years. Both Hatfield and Lonsdale used television advertisements to make increasingly negative allegations. Lonsdale, 58, financed his campaign primarily out of his own pocket and charged that Hatfield was protecting timber companies at the expense of the environment. Hatfield was slow to respond. He initially ignored Lonsdale and invested little in television advertising, relying instead on traditional handshaking and personal appearances. After polls showed Lonsdale closing to within striking distance, Hatfield counterattacked with a blitz of television commercials. Hatfield, 67, is completing his fourth term in the Senate and is the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee. Roberts, 53, in the middle of a second term as secretary of state, portrayed herself as a leader who takes decisive stands on tough issues. She charged that Frohnmayer was indecisive. Frohnmayer, 50, halfway through a third term as state attorney general, claimed spending programs advocated by Roberts would require tax increases.

DOC.HEAD: Vials of AIDS-Contaminated Blood Stolen From Researcher's Car
DOC.TEXT: A thief took a cooler containing nine vials of unlabeled AIDS-contaminated blood from a researcher's car and may not realize the danger, police say. Whoever took the blood ``should be alarmed because what they have is potentially fatal,'' especially if a vial breaks in somebody's hand, said Police Sgt. Joe Sweeney. Several items were taken from the car, including the cooler containing the unmarked vials. The researcher was identified as a 40-year-old woman who works for the California Heterosexual Partner Study, which is part of the University of California, San Francisco, AIDS project. The woman had the blood in her car because she does some of her research at home, Sweeney said. The car was burglarized Sunday night while the woman was visiting friend in east Oakland, he said. Besides the cooler, the car stereo, jewelry and personal papers were taken.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Train to Keep Their Edge Three Months Into Desert Shield
LaserPhoto DHA3
DOC.TEXT: Despite rumblings of impatience in some quarters, soldiers of the U.S. Army's 82nd Airborne Division said Tuesday they remain sharp three months after the first ground force arrived in Saudi Arabia. ``The only way you lose your edge is if you sit on your butt and don't train,'' said Sgt. Maj. J. R. Kendall of Bravo Co., 1st Battalion, 505th Paratroop Regiment. ``We keep from getting bored by training hard,'' said Kendall, carrying a shotgun during a trench warfare exercise. ``If the decision is made to go offensive, these paratroopers are ready.'' Elements of the 82nd Airborne were the first American ground forces to arrive in Saudi Arabia after President Bush drew ``a line in the sand'' Aug. 7, five days after Iraq's lightning conquest of Kuwait. About 220,000 U.S. troops are now in the region and more may be sent. On Tuesday, paratroopers swarmed a practice range, firing rifles, machine guns, grenades and anti-tank missiles during a number of drills. ``The soldiers here have the same edge they had before. As they train hard, these soldiers will stay hardened,'' said battalion commander Lt. Col. John Schmader of Clarion, Pa. But others say the months of waiting have taken a toll. Troops are hunkered down in the desert, with the relentless sun and flies, waiting for U.N. sanctions to work while military strategists plot war scenarios in their air conditioned corridors of power. In the bunkers, aboard the ships, even in the hospitals, there are signs of restlessness. ``We feel a lot of tension, like a tight spring,'' said 1st Sgt. George Spear, 40, of Coleman, Ala., and the 1st Marine Expeditionary Force. ``By our nature, it's difficult for a Marine to sit still.'' Marine Cpl. Carlin Walters, 21, of Vidor, Texas, sat on his bunk swatting flies earlier this week. ``We're not fighting Iraqis. We might as well throw away our M-16s and grab our flyswatters,'' Walters said. ``The boredom gets pretty strenuous. It's getting worse and worse. It'd be better just to go ahead and get it over with. It's going to happen anyway.'' Other soldiers are eager to get on with their mission. ``Let's do it ... and go home. All it's been is a waiting game,'' said Marine Pvt. Stephen Mayfiled of Seattle. Commanders have worked to keep their forces ready by training hard and varying their routines. ``Skills atrophy if you don't work at them,'' said Brig. Gen. Mike Myatt, commanding general of the 30,000 Marines on the ground in Saudi Arabia. The biggest fear is that troops may be getting sloppy by sitting around. So far, 43 military peopl have died in accidental deaths during the deployment. ``People are getting impatient,'' said Staff Sgt. Warren T. Williams, 29, of New York City. ``They came over here to do something and now they have to wait. Everybody's dropping their defenses.'' In an accident last week, Navy petty officer Ronald Fox took a .50-caliber round through his left shoulder while on a supply run when a Marine sentry improperly cleared his weapon. ``We got to get it done over here so we can all go home,'' Fox said from the intensive care unit of the hospital ship USNS Comfort. His age and address were not divulged. Even surgeons are wary of the lull. ``I tell my crew we're like a finely tuned race car, a Maserati, that's been put in the garage and allowed to collect dust,'' said Capt. Roger Pentzien, 44, of Vienna, Va., the Comfort's chief medical officer. ``They aren't going to lose their medical skills, but that's the fear.'' ``We just want to go in and clean house and go home,'' said Airman Mike Beam, 22, of Houston, serving with the Air Force 401st Supply Squadron. ``Just make Iraq a big parking lot.''

DOC.HEAD: Three Bodies To Be Exhumed
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of three elderly patients will be exhumed as part of a homicide investigation into deaths at Pinellas County nursing homes, authorities said. Two others already have been exhumed for autopsies, including one in Rhode Island. Medical Examiner Joan Wood is to perform an autopsy this week in Williamsport, Pa., on a sixth body - an 81-year-old woman who died in a Pinellas Park nursing home three years ago. Hazel DeRemer died at Sunshine Village Nursing Home during or shortly after the shift of licensed practical nurse Brian Kevin Rosenfeld on July 17, 1987, said Sheriff's Sgt. Greg Tita. Rosenfeld worked at Sunshine Village from February through September 1987. Wood will oversee the three exhumations in Florida when she returns. Authorities said the four died at county nursing homes while under the care of Rosenfeld. During the past five years, Rosenfeld has worked in at least 10 nursing homes in the county. Rosenfeld, 32, was charged with murder in August after two nurse's aides at Rosedale Manor nursing home said he injected a suspicious fluid into the feeding tube of comatose 80-year-old Muriel Watts. An autopsy revealed she died from a massive dose of a tranquilizer. Rosenfeld is being held without bail at the Pinellas County Jail. The medical examiner's office decided to seek the exhumation of DeRemer after officials noticed parallels to the Watts case, Tita said. Wood and investigators from the sheriff's and state attorney's offices also went to Pawtucket, R.I., on Sept. 6 and exhumed the body of Alphonse Silva. Toxicology tests showed no signs of foul play, sheriff's officials said. An affidavit seeking that autopsy said investigators were looking into numerous suspicious deaths at Rosedale Manor. Rosenfeld was employed there from April until late July. Sixteen residents, including Silva, 76, died during that time. Six of the deaths occurred during or shortly after Rosenfeld's shift, authorities said. The bodies of four of the six were cremated, leaving Watts and Silva. Investigators have subpoenaed Rosenfeld's work records, names of patients under his care and their medical records from 10 Pinellas County nursing homes where Rosenfeld worked since January 1985. Rosenfeld was released from or left the 10 jobs following allegations of misconduct or violation of nursing home policies, police have said.

DOC.HEAD: On Eve of Holiday, Yeltsin, Gorbachev Arrange Peacemaking Session
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: In a move toward peace on the eve of the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution, Boris N. Yeltsin said Tuesday he and Mikhail S. Gorbachev have agreed to discuss their differences. Yeltsin, the Russian president, declined to say who proposed the meeting scheduled for Sunday, but it was the Soviet president who approached Yeltsin to shake his hand after a holiday ceremony in the Kremlin's Palace of Congresses. ``We just agreed with Gorbachev to meet on the 11th one-on-one,'' Yeltsin said. ``There will be very many issues and it will be an important meeting,'' he said, declining to elaborate. The meeting will be the first between the rival politicians since their attempt at reconciliation over economic reform broke down in late summer. The rift put Yeltsin's Russian Federation, the Soviet Union's largest republic, on a collision course with the central government. Russia adopted its own plan for converting to a free market economy, conflicting with a more cautious plan endorsed by Gorbachev and adopted by the national legislature. Gorbachev appeared to have been motivated to suggest the peacemaking session by a speech at the Revolution Day gala in the congress hall. Leonid Y. Bliznov, a Soviet legislator, noted Gorbachev and Yeltsin had tried to work together but ``now, very little is left of this alliance.'' ``It's incomprehensible who or what stands in the way of the two leaders, who know the people's needs and whom the people recognize. Both of them must realize that future opposition makes them both less popular,'' Bliznov told the audience of more than 3,000 Communist Party officials and politicians. As applause erupted in the huge, wood-paneled hall, Gorbachev turned to look at Yeltsin, seated six people to his left on a long podium in front of a huge portrait of Soviet founder Vladimir Lenin. Yeltsin did not turn to make eye contact. Yeltsin told reporters later that he would make a speech in a few weeks explaining his differences with Gorbachev. The Kremlin ceremony amounted to a pep rally for Communists, who are expected to face criticism from dozens of groups on Wednesday. A traditional military parade, followed by a speech by Gorbachev, is scheduled for Red Square to celebrate the revolution that brought Bolsheviks to power in 1917. Yeltsin was invited to stand atop the Lenin Mausoleum along with Gorbachev and other officials. At least two anti-Communist groups plan marches in Moscow. Some demonstrators urge a ``day of mourning'' be held for victims of seven decades of totalitarian rule. Some have vowed to march through Red Square demanding the resignation of Gorbachev and the Soviet parliament. Yeltsin, who has quit the Communist Party, said Soviets should use the holiday as a time for reflection: ``People must again look back and pay tribute to what the revolution did and analyze what the mistakes were during that period.'' ``The biggest mistake was turning things over to a totalitarian regime,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Describes Watching Her Father Rape, Kill Her Childhood Playmate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with today's testimony. Picks up 4th graf, ```Her hands ...'
DOC.TEXT: A defense attorney today challenged the memory of a woman who says her father killed her childhood playmate more than 20 years ago. During the second day of cross-examination, defense attorney Douglas Horngrad questioned Eileen Franklin-Lipsker about the chronology of her actions as she allegedly resurrected the long-repressed memory. George Franklin Sr., 51, is on trial for the murder of 8-year-old Susan Nason after his daughter told police last November that she'd remembered the 1969 attack. Franklin has pleaded innocent to the charges. Franklin-Lipsker testified Monday that she first recalled the murder in January 1989 and told a therapist about it in June. But Horngrad asked her why she took so long to discuss the memory with a professional. ``Is five months recent?'' Horngrad asked Franklin-Lipsker. ``I would say that if I had a 5-month-old memory of a 20-year-old murder, that's very recent,'' she replied. Franklin-Lipsker at times seemed impatient under Horngrad's questioning. On Monday, she appeared near tears as she testified about the slaying. She said she watched as her father raped the girl in the back of his van, then killed her. The 29-year-old woman testified the girl was crouched down, crying, when her father approached with a rock. ``Her hands flew up to her head. ... The next thing I heard was two blows. It sounded terrible. It sounded like a crack and a splat,'' she said. Moments later, she said, she walked over to her friend's body. ``I saw blood,'' she said. ``I saw hair that was no longer attached.'' Franklin was charged with murder after his daughter went to police last year. She said she had repressed her memories of the slaying for two decades until they came flooding back when she looked at her own daughter. Franklin, a former San Mateo firefighter, could be sentenced to life in prison if convicted. The defense maintains that there is no evidence linking him to the murder and that his daughter could have based her allegations on old news reports of the slaying. Franklin-Lipsker appeared tense and sometimes distraught as she also told of suffering years of sexual abuse and beatings at the hands of her father. She denied defense claims that she told her story to collect thousands of dollars from book and movie deals. She said she signed a $50,000 book contract and a $10,000 movie deal only to stop the offers from pouring in. She used $5,000 to pay legal fees and donated $55,000 to children's charities, ``Children of the Night'' and the ``Children's Home Society,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Urges Action to Fight Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: All nations must face up to the threat of a climate disaster and take steps against global warming, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain said Tuesday. Thatcher, in a keynote speech to a United Nations meeting of ministers on the issue, said much more research is needed but a ``clear case for precautionary action'' exists now. ``It is a race against time ... to save our planet,'' French Prime Minister Michel Rocard told the officials from some 120 countries, including more than 80 ministers. In an appeal aimed in good part at the United States and the Soviet Union, Mrs. Thatcher demanded all countries begin work on binding commitments to rein in rising pollution by ``greenhouse gases.'' The limits would be for a planned global treaty on climate change to be ready in 1992. But there were increasing signs Tuesday that ministers, contrary to European Community hopes, will fail to agree on targets or deadlines so as not to endanger Wednesday's conference-ending declaration. ``Not to come to a result would be a very bad signal,'' German environment minister Klaus Toepfer told reporters. ``We have to do our best to come to a minimum compromise.'' Environmental groups said the draft declaration looks ``more like a non-declaration as all the crucial points on carbon dioxide reduction targets, dates and the urgent call for immediate action have been removed.'' Carbon dioxide pollution, much of it from burning fossil fuels, is seen as the leading cause of global warming. Methane and chlorofluorocarbons are other heat-trapping ``greenhouse gases.'' Americans and Soviets are the biggest contributors of man-made carbon dioxide emissions. Washington opposes immediate targets against carbon dioxide pollution, saying more scientific data is needed to justify the enormous costs involved in changing ways of life. The Soviet Union, Saudi Arabia and some other countries also have reservations. China sounded a Third World note of reluctance. ``Measures to protect the global climate should not hinder the economic development of developing countries,'' delegate Song Jian told the two-day meeting. Mrs. Thatcher, who holds a chemistry degree, warned climate change could occur more quickly than current computer models suggest. ``Should this happen it would be doubly disastrous were we to shirk the challenge now.'' Many steps would be ``sensible in any event'' - improving energy efficiency, developing alternative sources of supply, reforestation, rethinking industrial processes and tackling the waste problem, she said. Mrs. Thatcher and Rocard followed the lead of scientists from some 100 countries, who met last week in the conference's first part. The experts made plain that global warming undoubtedly exists and appealed to politicians for immediate measures. Scientists say global temperatures could rise at their fastest rate in 10,000 years next century if nothing is done. Among the feared upheavals are rising sea levels that would displace coastal dwellers, desertification and vast changes affecting wildlife. Bikenibeu Paeniu, prime minister of Tuvalu, told delegates they may hold the key to the ``continued existence'' of his South Pacific coral atoll group and other islands. ``We in the Pacific, the Carribbean and elsewhere have done the least to create these hazards but now stand the most to lose,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sacramento River's Chinook Salmon To Be Protected
DOC.TEXT: The National Marine Fisheries Service said Tuesday that the winter run of chinook salmon in the Sacramento River is a threatened species. The ruling blocks any take of the fish by sport or commercial fishermen. The service's final determination means the winter run of chinook salmon will be added to a list of threatened species under the Endangered Species Act. The American Fisheries Society asked the government to protect the salmon in 1985, pointing to evidence that run sizes for winter chinook in the northern California river had fallen to about 2,000 per year, down fromabout 84,000 in the late 1960s. The fisheries service decided in 1987 not to list the species as threatened, but to depend on restoration and conservation efforts planned by state and federal authorities. But in 1989, the run size for the year was estimated at 533 fish, and an emergency rule declared the species threatened on Aug. 4, 1989, the agency said in a statement. Early data for 1990 show even fewer winter chinook returning, so the ruling is being made final, ``based on the sizes of the returning runs of chinook in 1989 and 1990, the lack of information indicating success made by restoration efforts, and the unique and fragile nature of this stock.'' The fisheries service said its scientists would be monitoring water levels in the Sacramento River to make sure that distribution of water for development or irrigation would not increase the threat to the chinook.

DOC.HEAD: China's Foreign Minister Signals Support for New UN Resolution
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen signaled on Tuesday his government's willingness to go along with a U.N. resolution to authorize the use of force to liberate Kuwait from Iraqi invaders, U.S. officials said. Even though Qian did not explicitly approve sending troops into action - ``we`ll still have to wait and see,'' he said - the stance the Chinese minister took on the U.N. resolution in a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III enhances President Bush's campaign against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. U.S. officials, commenting on condition of anonymity, said Qian's comments were an indication that at the very least the Beijing government would not veto such a resolution. China, as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, has the power to use its veto to block approval of the resolution Bush wants authorizing the use of troops against Iraq. ``All armed forces have two roles to play,'' Qian told reporters at the outset of his two-hour meeting with Baker at Cairo airport. ``One is to fight a war. The other is to seek peace.'' Qian thereby underscored that China was not necessarily approving going to war to rescue Kuwait from Iraqi occupation. Baker, in his only public comment of a long day, which included a meeting with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, said he agreed with Qian that armies can be used for peaceful or military purposes. China has supported all 10 resolutions approved by the Security Council, but was considered hesitant to take an additional step authorizing use of what Bush and Baker call ``the military option.'' Qian stressed his government still preferred a peaceful solution of the Persian Gulf crisis, which Baker on Monday said had entered a new phase. ``I think all the resolutions adopted by the United Nations are intended to increase the pressure on Iraq so as to achieve a peaceful settlement,'' the foreign minister said. Baker on Thursday in Moscow will solicit the views of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has declared in the past that it is unacceptable to have a military solution to the gulf crisis. The outcome of Baker's meeting with Mubarak, meanwhile, was not all that clear. The Egyptian president abruptly canceled a news conference in Cairo and Baker did not give the 20 reporters traveling with him an account of the meeting as they flew to Ankara for talks Wednesday with Turkish officials. Instead, a memo was read to the reporters by a U.S. official in which these points were made: - Mubarak agreed with Baker that ``a partial solution'' to Iraq's occupation of Kuwait was unacceptable and that the U.N. resolutions should be implemented fully. - Mubarak told Baker that Egypt ``is very, very solid'' in supporting U.S. policy in the Persian Gulf. - They discussed ways of giving U.S. logistical support to the approximately 14,000 Egyptian troops deployed in Saudi Arabia alongside more than 100,000 U.S. troops. U.S. officials aboard Baker's U.S. Air Force jet refused to say whether U.S. B-52 bombers would be based in Egypt. They insisted, meanwhile, that Baker had not discussed a timetable with Mubarak for an attack. Still, as Baker completed the fourth day of an eight-day trip the possibility of war still hung in the air. Baker will dispatch John Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for the Near East, to Damascus on Wednesday to brief Syrian leaders. Kelly will then go on to Brussels to talk to officials of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Firebrand Assassinated; Gunman Believed to Be of Arab Descent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with city official saying suspect lived in Brooklyn, sted New Jersey, CORRECTS age to 34, sted 37. Picks up 6th graf, `Authorities said ...' INSERTS two grafs after 16th, ```Revenge is ...' with background.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY51,53,58,59,60
DOC.TEXT: A gunman believed to be of Arab descent assassinated Jewish extremist Meir Kahane at a Manhattan hotel, ending a fiery career that took the radical rabbi from Brooklyn street corners to the front line of the Arab-Jewish conflict in the Middle East. Kahane, 58, was shot to death Monday night in midtown Manhattan after addressing a Zionist group. The gunman, El Sayed A. Noseir, 34, was shot in the chin by a postal police officer as he fled and was hospitalized, police said. Noseir has repaired air conditioners for the city's Department of General Services since 1988, said Albert Scardino, a spokesman for Mayor David Dinkins. Other background on Noseir was not immediately available. Israel Army radio reported early today that Noseir once lived in the occupied territories. Police said only that the gunman was believed to be of Middle Eastern origin but that his exact nationality was not known. He carried several pieces of ID with different addresses. A city official said he lived in Brooklyn. Authorities said they were investigating a motive. ``Everything indicates he was acting alone,'' said Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli. Reverberations of the assassination were felt in Israel, where Kahane supporters threatened vengeance. Two elderly Palestinians were shot and killed in the occupied West Bank today. Israeli news reports suggested the killings were linked. An Israel radio police reporter, Moshe Nussbaum, quoted Kahane supporters in Jerusalem as saying they believed the killings were carried out to avenge the assassination and that more attacks could take place. Borrelli said Noseir stood up and opened fire twice with a .357-caliber handgun as Kahane was taking questions in a second-floor conference room. The rabbi, who stood about four feet from the gunman, was shot in the neck. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city Medical Examiner's Office, said a post mortem indicated ``a single bullet entered the left side of the neck and exited through the right cheek.'' The bullet was fired at close range, she said. Borakove said the family did not want an autopsy performed because of religious reasons. Noseir and an officer and a bystander also wounded in the attack were reported in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital, where Kahane was pronounced dead. Police stood guard early today over Noseir, who was under sedation and could not immediately be interrogated, officials said. Hospital spokesman Rob Frazier said it was unlikely he would be able to talk for at least two days. Kahane, as founder of the Jewish Defense League, urged Jews in the United States to arm themselves against anti-Semitism. Later, as a far right-wing member of Israel's Parliament, he was one of the Jewish state's fiercest anti-Arab politicians. ``Revenge is a very Jewish concept,'' he said of his call for the expulsion of the 1.7 million Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip as well as the 800,000 Arab citizens from Israel. The bearded, black-haired rabbi made his name with brutal, hot-tempered rhetoric. American blacks were guilty of Jew hatred, he said. Arabs were dogs. Jews who ignored this were lemmings. Another Holocaust was imminent, he declared, and made his symbol a clenched fist under the slogan ``Never again.'' In Israel, the rabbi could gather thousands of fanatical young Jews to march through the streets of Jerusalem shouting, ``Death to the Arabs!'' Many denounced him as a bigot and a demagogue. Others considered him a freedom fighter. ``He was our King David,'' said Charles Cohen, who stood sobbing with his wife in front of the hospital in a crowd of Orthodox Jews hoisting Israeli flags and reciting Hebrew prayers. Martin Cohen, a New York lawyer and Kahane follower who was at the hospital, called the slain rabbi a martyr. ``He stood for every Jew who no longer wants to be kicked around, for every Jew who remembers the Holocaust,'' he said. Kahane had no police protection. State Assemblyman Dov Hikind, who represents the rabbi's old Brooklyn neighborhood, said Kahane had refused it. ``He said that when his turn would come, when God called him, no one could prevent it,'' said Hikind. The shooting occurred shortly after 9 p.m. at the New York Marriott East Side. As the gunman fled he ran into 73-year-old Irving Franklin, who was selling booklets for a Zionist group, and shot him in the leg, police said. The gunman commandeered a taxi and rode a block before getting out and opening fire on Officer Carlos Acosta, 55, who was standing in front of a post office, police said. The bullet bounced off the officer's bulletproof vest and struck him in the arm as he returned fire, hitting Noseir, authorities said. Kahane founded the JDL in 1968 in New York. The JDL organized classes in karate and weapons training and patrolled high-crime neighborhoods. The group was linked to acts of violence, including a 1972 firebombing in which one person was killed and 13 were injured. After moving to Israel in 1971, Kahane founded the country's Kach Party, which advocates the ouster of all Arabs from Israeli-held territory and a ban on Jewish-Arab marriages. Its symbol is a clenched fist inside a Star of David. Kahane, who renounced his U.S. citizenship to run for Parliament, served four years but was barred from running for re-election in 1988 after a law was passed banning parties that have a racist platform. Seymour Reich, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American-Jewish Organizations, said Kahane ``had strong supporters and opponents.'' ``Whatever one thought about his political program, his shocking assassination will be deplored by friends and foes alike,'' he said. The president of the American-Arab Relations Committee, Dr. M. T. Mehdi, said he ``disagreed with the rabbi's every assumption during our many radio and TV debates concerning Zionist claims to Palestine.'' ``But we maintained cordial relations and I found Kahane more honest and straightforward than the rest of the Zionists with whom I have debated,'' he said. ``While we totally disapproved of his politics and rhetoric on the Middle East, we strongly condemn this deliberate act of terrorism,'' said a statement issued Monday night by the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, nonprofit insitution for the study of the Holocaust. ``The (center) is shocked at word of the cold-blooded murder of Rabbi Meir Kahane,'' it said. Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, said he disagreed strongly with Kahane's politics but added, ``I nevertheless deeply regret his violent end.'' ``He did not deserve to die by an assassin's bullet,'' Schindler said. Kahane is survived by his wife, two sons and two daughters. His funeral was scheduled for today at the Young Israel of Ocean Parkway Synagogue in Brooklyn. His body was to be flown to Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Singh, Facing No-Confidence Vote, Fights To Keep Rivals From Power
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister V.P. Singh, his government heading for collapse in Parliament, sought Tuesday to keep party defectors from taking power. Singh's government faces a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Wednesday, following Hindu-Moslems riots which killed at least 360 people in two weeks. The issue - Moslem possession of a site Hindus claim as the birthplace of an important Hindu god - prompted the desertion of the right-wing Hindu party from Singh's coalition and was the immediate spark of the political crisis. Even before the riots, Singh was beset by other problems. At least 148 people died in protests after he announced in August he would reserve nearly half of all government for low caste Hindus. He said the policy would raise the lower classes from economic and social impoverishment. But critics said Singh manufactured the caste problem to gain votes from the poor masses, while he failed to follow through with economic liberalization and ignored the increasingly deadly sepoaratist insurrections by Moslems in Kashmir and by Sikhs in Punjab. Singh's parliamentary maneuvering on the eve of Wednesday's vote created confusion and seemed to move the nation closer to elections just 11 months after the last national vote. In a last-ditch effort to save his government, the prime minister said he was ready to join a sweeping coalition, presumably encompassing the opposition Congress Party. But that option seemed unlikely to win much support. ``The need of the hour is a national government or a national coalition to look into the serious crisis the country is facing,'' he said. Singh's Janata Dal party split on Monday. The leader of the rebel faction, Chandra Shekhar, said he would join an alternative government with the help of Congress, the largest party in the legislature. Congress leader and former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi swung behind Chandra Shekhar, pledging to support him for prime minister and not to seek the post for himself. Chandra Shekhar said Monday he had the support of 58 of the Janata Dal's 140 members in the Lok Sabha, the all-important lower house of Parliament. But Singh moved quickly to block recognition of the group as a new party, expelling Chandra Shekhar and 24 of his supporters from the Janata Dal. Under a law designed to prevent individuals from crossing the floor, any breakaway faction must carry one-third of the party's members. Those whom Singh expelledstay in Parliament as independents, but the 33 other rebels technically remain trapped in the Janata Dal and are obliged to vote according to party lines. If they defect, taking less than one-third of the remaining 115 Janata Dal members, they forfeit their Parliament seats. Chandra Shekhar, in a letter to the house which barely concealed his anger, said it was ``public knowledge'' that he commanded the support of more than the required one-third. He accused Singh of acting ``with an evil design.'' Singh responded that the splinter group had no mandate from the voters to form a government. ``Apart from technicalties, there is a poltical context,'' he told reporters. ``By some manipulation, some group is formed which has no validity or sanction of the people as they have voted.'' The chaos gives Ramaswamy Venkataraman, the 80-year-old president of India, considerable leeway in deciding the nation's course. If Singh loses the confidence vote and resigns, Venkataraman can ask another member to form a government, or he can dissolve Parliament and call an election. Venkataraman has been holding daily meetings with political leaders and constitutional lawyers since the political crisis broke two weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Native Group Plans Turkey Drop to Top Voting Village
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS garble in Sturgulewski's name in 4th graf bgng ``Topping the''
DOC.TEXT: No matter how they voted in Tuesday's election, some residents of the Bristol Bay region were sure to end up with a turkey. The Bristol Bay Native Association said it would give away a planeload of the birds to the village in the area that had the highest voter turnout. ``I think that it's really critical that everybody in Alaska, particularly in rural Alaska, gets out and votes,'' said Terry Hoefferle, the native association's executive director. Topping the statewide ballot was a five-way race for governor. The leading candidates were state Sen. Arliss Sturgulewski, a Republican, Democratic former Anchorage mayor Tony Knowles and former Gov. Wally Hickel, who jumped party ranks to run as an independent. Green Party candidate Jim Sykes and Political Party candidate Jim O'Callaghan rounded out the race. The native association planned to airlift $500 worth of turkeys - probably about 80 birds - to the winning village in time for Thanksgiving, Hoefferle said. Only villages with 30 or more registered voters would be eligible.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Told Bomb Threat Was Thought To Be Hoax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Peirce in 21st graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A Pan Am security manager said Tuesday that before the Flight 103 bombing, the airline investigated a warning that one of its U.S.-bound flights would be a target but determined it was a hoax. Jim Berwick, Pan Am security manager at London's Heathrow Airport at the time of the Dec. 21, 1988, bombing, told a public inquiry that although the airline evaluated the warning made to the U.S. Embassy in Helsinki as a hoax, it stepped up security. The inquiry into the disaster, which killed all 259 people on board and 11 on the ground in Lockerbie, 12 miles northeast of Dumfries, is focusing only on the deaths and ways to prevent future bombings, not on criminal responsibility. The inquiry began Oct. 1 and is expected to last three months. Scottish authorities are still investigating the crime, inquiring into several radical Palestinian groups. And the U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency is looking into a news report that one of its agents might have unwittingly carried the bomb on board during one of its undercover operations. At Tuesday's session, Berwick said that while he was in Brussels Dec. 8, 1988, he heard from a colleague a warning that a Finnish woman would be duped into carrying the bomb on board a Frankfurt to New York flight. Berwick, who is now Pan American World Airways' managing ground security coordinator at Heathrow, said he returned to London, advised the U.S. Embassy regional security officer, asked the Federal Aviation Authority in Brussels for more information and flew to Helsinki the next day for a meeting at the airport. Officials later decided the threat was a hoax, Berwick said. But, he said, he made arrangements for all unaccompanied female passengers to be treated as ``selectees'' - earmarked for further security checks, and arranged for extra vigilance at Frankfurt. In a telex sent from Helsinki to Pan Am's New York headquarters, Berwick said emphasis should be placed on the handling of ``interline'' baggage from Frankfurt - baggage being switched from one airline to another. Flight 103 originated in Frankfurt and switched planes in London before heading for New York.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Union Treaty Allows Secession, Demands Single Economy
With AM-Soviet-Revolution Day, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Kremlin official on Tuesday outlined a new union treaty that would guarantee civil liberties and republics' right to secede, but he conceded the plan would fail without the agreement of the Russian republic. ``If Russia does not sign it, we'll have to be realistic: We would not be able to talk about any union,'' said Grigory Revenko, a member of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Presidential Council, a high-level advisory body. The proposal represented the government's latest attempt to appease secession movements by the republics and smaller regions while creating a uniform, market-oriented economic system in one country. The treaty would replace a 1922 document that formed the basis for the current union. But many details of the broad plan were unclear, and it faced an uphill battle for acceptance by the national legislature and the republics. The treaty would have a section defining human rights and voluntary republic membership in the redefined Soviet Union. Another would set out the Kremlin's military and economic authority. A third would establish legislative, judicial and executive branches of the central government, Revenko said. It would define the country as a ``union of sovereign republic-states,'' and would amount to a ``second chapter'' to the current constitution, he said. ``We do not need a union with somebody chained to it, because that would lead to a constant attempt to break those chains,'' Revenko said. ``Republics ... will not have to expect any actions that would stop sovereignty or independence. There will be no such actions.'' The plan grew out of a proposal by Gorbachev last summer that was widely criticized by the republics for failing to grant real independence. Revenko said Gorbachev's ``ideas'' and a number of variations later were reviewed by the Council of Federation, another high-level advisory body representing presidents of the 15 republics and one autonomous region. The council agreed last week to have a preliminary proposal published in the Soviet press in the next nine days. That would bring ``the entire population into the discussion of the future of the union,'' he said. Only after its publication, sometime before Nov. 15, could it be considered by the national parliament, Revenko said. He gave no date for legislative debate, saying only that he hoped the treaty could be approved in the next few months in conjunction with Gorbachev's economic reform plan. ``The union treaty and the program of transition to the market economy cannot go without each other,'' Revenko said. ``Political issues would inevitably slow down the transition to the market. The market would not tolerate any political or national isolation.'' Gorbachev last month won approval of the compromise plan that dropped provisions to allow private ownership and give more authority to republics. Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin immediately rejected the compromise. His parliament voted last week to proceed with the more radical plan on its own territory, which occupies nearly two-thirds of Soviet territory and possesses much of its raw materials. The republic already has declared the primacy of its laws over national laws and has moved to seize control of many of Russia's assets. But it has not taken an official stance toward the union treaty. The treaty would not require republics to belong to the union and lets each decide whether its legislature or population would vote on membership. While accepting that Russia might opt out of the treaty, Revenko sounded a hopeful note. ``I believe Russia's responsibility for its own state is too great, and that the politicians as well as the people of Russia will come to understand that,'' he said. All but one of the 15 republics also have declared some form of sovereignty from the Kremlin. Several have announced secession drives and said they would join any new federation with Moscow on a voluntary basis only.

DOC.HEAD: Industrialist Sworn In As Pakistan's Prime Minister
DOC.TEXT: Nawaz Sharif, an industrialist whose political mentor was the late President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, on Tuesday became prime minister of Pakistan. Sharif took the oath of office as head of Pakistan's fifth freely elected government in 43 years in a ceremony attended by military leaders, politicians and bureaucrats. He succeeds a caretaker government set up after the dismissal last August of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. Also Tuesday, a special anti-terrorist court denied bail to Ms. Bhutto's husband, Asif Ali Zardari. He has been jailed since Oct. 10 on charges of kidnapping and extortion. Zardari, 38, who was transferred to Islamabad on Sunday to take his oath of office in the National Assembly, denies any wrongdoing. He is under house arrest. The National Assembly chose Sharif to head the government after a brief walkout Tuesday by Ms. Bhutto's supporters, who demanded a secret ballot. They returned for the vote less than 10 minutes later. Sharif won 153 votes to 39 for Mohammad Afzal Khan, a token candidate put forth by Ms. Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. In his acceptance speech, Sharif sounded a conciliatory note. ``The government and opposition should join hands to help the country's poor. For the prosperity of the country, we have to join hands,'' he said. He referred to the majority of Pakistan's 110 million people, most of whom are illiterate and landless laborers earning less than $400 a year. In her address to the assembly, Ms. Bhutto recounted the promises made by Sharif and his alliance during the bitter campaign leading to the October elections. She urged lawmakers to strengthen civilian institutions weakened by a quarter-century of military rule. ``Increasing the authority of civilian institutions should not be deterred by the fact that those who have tried before have been stopped,'' she said. Sharif's election was assured last week when the Islamic Democratic Alliance, a conservative coalition of 18 parties, named him as its candidate for prime minister. The alliance controls 105 of the 217 seats in the National Assembly, the policy-making lower house of Parliament, and claims the support of several smaller parties and independents. Ms. Bhutto's party was routed in the national election, leaving her with only 45 seats. Sharif began his political career in the early 1980s when the country was under military rule. His mentor, Gen. Zia, ousted Ms. Bhutto's father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, in 1977. Bhutto was later executed. Zia died in a plane crash in August 1988, paving the way for the first free elections after more than a decade of military rule. Shortly before the 1988 elections, Sharif formed the Islamic alliance, a coalition espousing a wide range of political ideologies and united only in contempt for Ms. Bhutto. The People's Party won the largest bloc of votes in the 1988 election but required the support of smaller parties and independents to gain power and install Ms. Bhutto as the first woman leader of a modern Moslem nation. After 20 months in power, Ms. Bhutto was dismissed by the president, who charged her with political corruption and incompetence. She faces seven charges of misconduct and abuse of power. A guilty verdict on any one charge could banish her from politics for up to seven years. Ms. Bhutto denies any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Major Airlines Improve On-Time Record
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest airlines improved their on-time performance in September, achieving their best record in the past two years. They also set a record for the fewest reports of lost or mishandled baggage. The Department of Transportation, releasing its monthly Air Travel Consumer Report, said Tuesday the nation's 12 largest airlines reported that 84.3 percent of their flights arrived on time in September. That's an improvement from the August record when only 78.5 percent of flights arrived on time. The department, which began tabulating arrival records in September 1987, said September's performance was topped only in September 1988, when 85.6 percent of flights arrived at the airport gate on time. Delays caused by mechanical problems are not counted in the Transportation Department's monthly report. A flight is reported ``on time'' if it arrived less than 15 minutes after the scheduled arrival time. Pan American posted the best on-time performance for the month with 89.5 percent of its arrivals reported to have arrived on schedule. Other prompt arrivals were posted by Eastern, 88.2 percent; America West, 86.5 percent; and American, 85.7 percent. Reports of mishandled baggage filed by passengers against the 12 airlines averaged 5.63 per 1,000 passengers in September. The best previous record was 5.71 percent set in September 1988. In August, reports of mishandled baggage averaged 6.71 for every 1,000 passengers.

DOC.HEAD: First Reserves Called For Combat Duty in Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps on Tuesday called to active duty hundreds of combat forces from reserve units across the country, marking the first use of American citizen-soldiers in combat roles in the Persian Gulf crisis. At the same time the Pentagon announced that more than 230,000 U.S. forces are now in the gulf area as part of Operation Desert Shield. That is 20,000 more than the previous Pentagon count given Oct. 23. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Desert Shield deployments are continuing, but he declined to comment on what the additional forces would be. ``Stay tuned'' for announcements of new deployments, he told reporters. Williams also disclosed that the aircraft carrier battle group Independence had left the gulf area after being replaced by the carrier USS Midway. The spokesman said he could not comment on where the Independence was headed. Navy officials have said it is due back in the United States before Christmas. The Marine reserve call-up appeared to indicate that Gen. Al Gray, the Marine commandant, is preparing the first stage of a troop rotation to relieve the expeditionary force that has been stationed in the gulf since shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. About 45,000 Marines are in the gulf area. Lt. Col. Stuart Wagner, a Pentagon spokesman, said the Marine reserves would be assigned to the 5th Marine Expeditionary Brigade at Camp Pendleton, Calif. He said he could not comment on whether they eventually would deploy to the gulf. Gen. John R. Dailey, the deputy commandant, said in an interview Monday that the Marines have prepared about 55,000 regular Marines for possible deployment to the gulf area. He said no decision had been made on whether any or all of those would be used to increase the force in the gulf or to rotate there as replacements. The call-up of Marine reserves, while not significantly increasing U.S. combat capability in the gulf, marks an important departure for the Pentagon. It opens the way to possible use of major Army reserve combat units in Desert Shield. Williams denied published reports that the Pentagon has decided to activate major Army combat reserve units. He said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney had not yet granted the Army the necessary authority to order combat reserves to active duty. ``That is an option we'll certainly consider, but no decision has been made,'' Williams said. The spokesman suggested for the first time that Cheney was uncertain whether major combat units from the Army reserves are properly prepared for battle in the Persian Gulf. ``It's something of an untested question,'' Williams said. He indicated that any Army combat reserves called to active duty would be given extra training in desert warfare at the Army's National Training Center at Fort Irwin, Calif., and their readiness then evaluated before deciding to send them to the gulf. ``You don't want to send anyone there until you have full faith and confidence - in a tested environment - in their ability to defend themselves,'' Williams said. All of the more than 34,000 Army, Air Force, Navy, Coast Guard and Marine Corps reserves called to active duty for Desert Shield prior to Tuesday's Marine announcement are performing non-combat roles such as medical services and water purification. The Marine reserve call-up includes 824 personnel, of which 633 are from units with combat functions, although all 824 will be part of a Marine air-ground task force that itself is a combat unit. Those not counted by the Marines as combat forces include translators, interrogators, truck drivers and military police. All reserves called to active duty so far are on 90-day tours. Williams said Cheney has asked President Bush to grant him the authority to extend those tours by an additional 90 days.

DOC.HEAD: Two Palestinians Killed After Kahane's Assassination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Kahane was ...' to CORRECT age of alleged assailant to 34.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL1
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of the slain Rabbi Meir Kahane shouted ``Death to the Arabs!'' on Tuesday, and Israeli reports said police suspected a Jewish extremist already had retaliated by killing two elderly Palestinians. The day brought a second tragedy for Kahane's wife, Libby, when her father died after a long illness. Rabbi Yacov Blum had been unconscious and did not know of his son-in-law's death. Police and army reinforcements were deployed around Israel and in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to prevent violence. But the increased security came too late to save two Palestinians killed at about 6 a.m. Tuesday, about two hours after Kahane was slain in New York City. Israeli police said they suspected an Israeli radical killed the Palestinians and that the slayings may have been prompted by Kahane's murder, the national Itim news agency reported. Israel television said police received warnings of death threats against Israeli Arab members of Parliament and Palestinian leaders in the occupied territories. Kahane was slain in New York Monday night by a gunman believed to be of Arab descent. Israel army radio said the man, identifiedby police as El Sayed A. Noseir, 34, formerly lived in the occupied terrritories. Palestinians in Israel said the name as given by police was not typical and might be Said Nasser or Nasser el-Said. The 58-year-old Kahane, a former member of Parliament and founder of the right-wing Kach movement, advocated the expulsion of all Arabs from Israeli-held territory. The Israeli Foreign Ministry said Kahane's assassination was ``an unprecedented assault on an Israeli political figure on American soil'' and urged the United States to increase security against terrorism. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher called the killing ``a despicable and cowardly act.'' Asked about a possible vendetta by Kahane supporters, he said: ``We don't see this as a time for revenge. Now is the time for restraint.'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar also decried Kahane's killing and violence in the occupied territories. ``He deplores these and all acts of violence,'' said a spokeswoman, Nadia Younes. Several Israeli leaders linked Kahane's murder to his controversial views. Faisal Hussein, a Palestine Liberation Organization supporter in Jerusalem, appealed for calm, saying: ``Violence and calling for violence will lead nowhere.'' He said Tuesday's killings in the West Bank ``raised concerns about the security of our people.'' At least two Israeli Arab members of Parliament, Abdel Wahab Daroushe and Mohammed Miari, left Jerusalem for their homes in northern Israel for fear of reprisals. Daroushe said police told him of the threats. Tuesday's Parliament session began with a minute of silence for Kahane, but only about 30 of the 120 lawmakers were present. Kahane supporters warned of possible revenge attacks. Noam Federman, a Kahane spokesman, declined to say if the Kach movement was behind killings of the two Palestinians on Tuesday. But he told Israel television that ``I don't rule out that after the murder of Rabbi Kahane, Jews will rise up and will honor his memory ... and will attack Arabs.'' David Ben Dor, a Kach leader, told a news conference at Kach's Jerusalem headquarters that Kahane's ideas will survive. ``Whoever thinks that today Rabbi Kahane and the Kach movement have been destroyed has made a great mistake,'' Ben Dor said. He spoke beside Kach flags, their yellow fields centered by a black Jewish star and a clenched fist. About 50 supporters milled about, some shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' The crowd was hostile to journalists, at one point throwing chairs at reporters. An Israeli television crewman was beaten by Kach supporters, and one sprayed tear gas in his face. He was hospitalized. Villagers said the killings in the West Bank village of Lubban Sharqiya near Nablus occurred at about 6 a.m. They said a man wearing civilian clothes drove into the village in a white car bearing Israeli license plates. The man stopped and opened fire with a Uzi submachine gun, the villagers said, killing Mohammed al-Khatib, 65, who was riding his donkey to harvest olives from his grove. The gunman then drove on, stopping a second time to kill Miriam Khassan, 60, outside her house, the villagers said. Israel radio police reporter Moshe Nussbaum said that before news of the West Bank killings was broadcast, an anonymous caller speaking Hebrew told him ``to check in one of the villages near Nablus, two Arabs were killed there.'' The deaths raised to 773 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the nearly 35-month Palestinian uprising. An additional 294 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs. Fifty-one Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Combat Reserves
Marines Call Up Reserves From 20 Units in 14 States
DOC.TEXT: Here are the Marine Corps Reserve units from which 824 people were ordered to active duty Tuesday in support of Operation Desert Shield: COMBAT FORCES

-Battery A, 4th Light Anti-Air Defense Battalion at Pasadena, Calif., totaling 55 men. -A platoon from Company A, 4th Light Armored Vehicle Battalion at Camp Pendleton, 34 men. -Company A and a detachment from Headquarters and Service Company, 4th Tank Battalion at Miramar Naval Air Station, Calif., totaling 120 men. -An anti-tank platoon from the 23rd Marines at Brousard, La., totaling 75 men. -4th Combat Engineer Battalion, an engineer support company, and a detachment from headquarters and service company, at Baltimore, Md., totaling 24 men. -4th Platoon, Company A, 4th Amphibious Assault Battalion at Gulfport, Miss., and a platoon from Company A, 4th Assault Amphibian Battalion at Norfolk, Va., totaling 189 men. -A platoon from the 4th Force Reconnaissance Company at Reno, Nev., 34 men. -A platoon from Fox Company, 2nd Battalion, 25th Marines at Bronx, N.Y., 53 men. -A platoon from Company A, 4th Combat Engineer Battalion, Charleston, W.Va., 49 men. NON-COMBAT FORCES

-A detachment of 15 people from the Sensor Control and Management Platoon at Mobile, Ala. -An interrogator and a translator from the 31st Interrogator, Translator Team at Los Angeles. -Three members of the 14th Counter-Intelligence Team at San Diego. -A detachment from Headquarters and Service Company, 4th Anti-Aircraft Battalion, Tampa, Fla., totaling 20 people. -1st Military Police Company, Headquarters and Service Battalion, 4th Force Service Support Group, at Lexington, Ky., 33 people. -Detachment C, Marine Air Support Squadron-6, South Weymouth, Mass., 21 people. -Bridge Platoon, Bridge Company, 6th Engineer Support Battalion, Battle Creek, Mich., 43 people. -A platoon, Truck Company, 6th Motor Transport Battalion, Lubbock, Texas, 54 people.

DOC.HEAD: Preached Armed Militance To Counter Jewish Image
With AM-Kahane Shot, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Meir Kahane preached that for Jews to survive they had to change the world's perception of the Jew as patsy - a passive victim. To this end, he launched the Jewish Defense League in New York 1968 and led it in sometimes violent, high-visibility confrontations against anti-Semitism. Most Jewish organizations condemned his philosophy and tactics. The JDL picketed and created disturbances at performances of Soviet singers and dancers during the days Moscow blocked Jewish emigration. The young militants staged sit-ins at the offices of Columbia Artists Management, which booked the tours of Soviet companies. Then came a darker escalation. JDL members were convicted of bombings of the offices of Amtorg, the Soviet trading company, in 1971 and Sol Hurok, another booker of Russian talent, in 1972. A secretary died in the Hurok bombing. JDL members also admitted planting dynamite at the Soviet diplomatic residence at Glen Cove, on Long Island, in 1971. While he was arrested many times on charges relating to disorderly protests, Kahane never was convicted of personally participating in a bombing. In July 1971, two months before he moved to Israel, Kahane was given a five-year suspended sentence and fined $5,000 on a federal conviction of conspiring to manufacture explosives. Judge Jack B. Weinstein, sentencing Kahane and two teen-age members of the JDL, admonished that ``it is not permissible to substitute the bomb for the book as the symbol of Jewish manhood.'' He ordered Kahane to have nothing more to do with guns or bombs. But Kahane, jubilant at having avoided prison, told reporters outside the courtroom that he planned to buy rifles for all his followers for self defense and proclaimed the motto, ``Every Jew a .22.'' News organizations during those days frequently received anonymous calls claiming responsibility for violent acts against perceived anti-Semitism. The callers would sign off with the JDL slogan, ``Never again,'' a reference to Jews dying in the Holocaust. Official spokesmen for the JDL, however, had a formula comment in which they denied the deed but said the JDL sympathized with the motive. A decade later, during one of his frequent visits from Israel, Kahane told a Washington reporter: ``We bombed the Russian mission in New York, the Russian cultural mission here, the Soviet trade offices.'' He said the bombs put Soviet Jews on Page 1. ``Our violence was a very well-thought-out political movement,'' he said. Going against the grain was part of Kahane's nature. Kahane, son and grandson of rabbis from what is now Israel, was born Aug. 1, 1932, and raised in Flatbush. In the home of the Brooklyn Dodgers, the young Kahane rooted for the New York Yankees. He said growing up as a Yeshiva student in a mixed neighborhood meant ``I had fights regularly over my yarmulke (skull cap), and then afterwards I'd drink beer with them. ... Once you did it, it was over. Once you fight and you get bloodied, if you bloody back, then you're OK.'' The slaughter of Europe's Jews during World War II was always in the forefront of his thoughts, but he accused mainstream Jews of forgetting the lesson. ``To turn the other cheek is not a Jewish concept,'' he insisted when organizing the JDL. ``Do not listen to the soothing anesthesia of the Establishment. They walk in the paths of those whose timidity helped to bury our brothers and sisters less than 30 years ago.'' He said in an interview in 1971: ``I'd rather be respected, feared and safe than loved, with eulogies.'' To counter the view of Jews as patsies, he ran an ad in The New York Times with a photo of armed young members and a caption: ``Is this any way for nice Jewish boys to behave?'' The text of the ad said it was. Kahane claimed membership of 14,000. Unsympathetic observers conceded that Kahane's message had appeal to high school and college youths, but maintained actual membership was only in the hundreds.

DOC.HEAD: Faulkner Photographer Dead at Age 63
DOC.TEXT: Jack Cofield, who along with his father served as William Faulkner's personal photographer, has died after an extended illness. He was 63. Cofield's book, ``William Faulkner: The Cofield Collection,'' included the internationally known set of photographs that chronicled the life of the reclusive, Nobel Prize-winning author. Cofield's father, ``Col.'' J.R. Cofield, took some of the photographs. Much of the collection was reprinted from scrapbooks and contained personalized captions by J.R. Cofield. Parts of the collection, some of it autographed by Faulkner, burned in a studio fire in 1986, but most of the negatives were saved and are now in the possession of the family. Cofield, who died Monday, took the last formal portraits of Faulkner before the author's death in 1962. The photographs were used for the commemorative Faulkner postage stamp and have appeared in hundreds of books and publications around the world. Cofield also was a university photographer at the University of Mississippi, his alma mater, from 1960-85. ``The photographic legacy of Jack and his father is a historic treasure, which is enjoyed by Faulkner scholars from around the world who visit Oxford and Ole Miss,'' said university Chancellor R. Gerald Turner. ``His contributions to Ole Miss and the Ole Miss family are everlasting.'' He is survived by his wife, Martha Glenn, and four children.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Kahane's Father-In-Law Dies in Jerusalem
With AM-Kahane Shot, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rabbi Jacob Blum, father-in-law of the slain Rabbi Meir Kahane, died Tuesday after a long illness, Israel radio reported. Blum, father of Kahane's wife Libby, was not aware of Kahane's assassination Monday night in New York City, because he had been unconscious for days, the radio said. Family members denied rumors that Blum died of a heart attack after hearing about Kahane's shooting. They gave no further details about Blum or his illness. The office of Kahane's Kach Party also had no details on Blum and officials at Jerusalem's Hadassah Hospital, where Blum died, refused to disclose any information about him. Israeli journalists said Blum was in his 70s and apparently had suffered from a heart condition. He was an investigator for the New York State Department of Welfare before immigrating to Israel and settling in Jerusalem. New York-born Kahane, 58, founder of Israel's extremist anti-Arab Kach party, was shot to death after a speech in Manhattan. His assailant, who was wounded in an exchange of gunfire with a postal police officer, is believed to be of Arab descent.

DOC.HEAD: Mosley's `Hopeful Monsters' Wins Whitbread Award for Best Novel
DOC.TEXT: Nicholas Mosley's novel, ``Hopeful Monsters,'' won Britain's Whitbread award for best novel on Tuesday. ``Hopeful Monster,'' a love story spanning much of this century, chronicles the marriage of Max Ackerman, son of a Cambridge University botanist, and Eleanor Anders, a brilliant German Jew, and their experiences in Hitler's Germany and the Spanish Civil War and with the rise of Stalinism. A record 400 books were entered in this year's Whitbread contest, which is divided into five categories, each carrying a prize of $3,400. All the winners will compete for the $40,000 Whitbread Book of the Year prize, to be announced in January. Peter Dickinson's ``AK,'' about an African war orphan's relationship with his rifle, won the best children's novel category. Hanif Kureishi's ``The Buddha of Suburbia'' won the best first novel category; ``Daddy, Daddy'' by Paul Durcan was judged the best poetry entrant; and the best biography award went to Ann Thwaite for her biography of British author A.A. Milne, titled ``A.A. Milne: His Life.'' Mosley has written another well-received novel, ``Accident,'' and a two-volume biography of his father, Sir Oswald Mosley, the British fascist leader who died in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Clerk Retires
DOC.TEXT: Joseph E. Spaniol, a longtime federal court official and clerk of the Supreme Court since 1985, announced his retirement Tuesday. Spaniol, who turned 65 on Sunday, said he would retire at the end of 1990. He was appointed to his current job in 1985 after a 34-year career with the Administrative Office of the U.S. Courts. He was that agency's deputy director when appointed the court's clerk. Spaniol, a native of Cleveland, Ohio, earned a law degree from Case-Western Reserve University in that city and a Masters of Law from Georgetown University here. His replacement will be chosen by the full court.

DOC.HEAD: Fox Adds `Comic Strip' for `Against the Law,' Puts `DEA' In Hiatus
DOC.TEXT: The standup comedy show ``Comic Strip Live'' will replace ``Against the Law'' on Fox Broadcasting Co. on Sunday nights, and the police drama ``DEA'' is temporarily leaving the air, the network said Tuesday. ``Against the Law,'' the low-rated but critically praised courtroom drama, will replace ``DEA'' in its 9 p.m. EST Friday time slot on Nov. 16, and ``DEA'' will return later this season, Fox said. ``We think this move will help our schedule on Fox's most important night,'' said Peter Chernin, president of the Fox Entertainment Group. ``The viewers have told us that they want and expect comedy from us on Sunday nights.'' ``Comic Strip Live'' outperformed ``Against the Law'' in two Sunday night tryouts earlier this season, Fox executives noted. The standup comedy show will continue to air on late night Saturday, retitled as ``Comic Strip: Late Night,'' Fox said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Returns to White House to Await Election Results
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bush not expected to comment on election results; should stand
