DOC.TEXT: President Bush awaited midterm election results in the privacy of the White House on Tuesday, choosing to remain on the sidelines after campaigning extensively for scores of Republican candidates. Ending a six-day political trip, Bush and his wife Barbara returned in early afternoon after voting in Houston, their dopted home city. The first couple voted at a polling place in a nursing home on the west side of Houston - a few blocks from the Houstonian Hotel, where a suite of rooms serves as the Bushes' legal voting residence. Asked by reporters as he was waiting on line to vote if he cared to make a prediction, Bush said, ``Good way to go to jail.'' ``They're trying to get you arrested,'' Mrs. Bush joked to her husband. Politicking is prohibited in polling places. However, Bush's chief of staff John Sununu, whose abrasive tactics in dealing with Congress are blamed by some White House staffers for contributing to Bush's decline in popularity, had no hesitancy in discussing politics. Sununu said he was sticking with his prediction, made on a television talk show on Sunday, that Republicans would lose no more than one Senate seat and between four and 12 House seats. While some Republicans distanced themselves from Bush for his wavering stand on budget and tax issues, Sununu defended the campaign support provided by the White House. ``The motivation factor, the energizing the campaign - those are all pluses,'' Sununu said. ``You can't make a winning campaign out of a campaign that couldn't win anyway. And you can't cause a campaign that's on a landslide to lose. But what you can do is help in those marginal races. And that's what, if you're doing it right, you focus on,'' he added. Over the past year and a half, Bush attended 115 campaign events in 35 states and raised nearly $90 million for Republicans. For the last two weeks, he has been campaigning virtually nonstop. However, he saw his popularity - and his appeal as a campaigner to other Republicans - drop sharply in October because of the budget debacle. Sununu suggested Bush had decided against making any public statements on politics on Election Day. After voting, Bush again ignored reporters' questions and quickly stepped into his limousine. ``I don't want them to get me for loitering, so I'll go on,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Funerals Draw Thousands in Separatist Region of Moldavia
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people turned out Tuesday in the eastern Moldavian city of Dubossary for the funerals of three separatists killed last week in ethnic clashes, news reports said. The mourners, representing cities and villages throughout the Dniester region of Moldavia where about 200,000 Russians and Ukrainians live, filled Victory Square, the Tass news agency reported. The independent Interfax news agency said tens of thousands of people attended. Three people were killed Friday in ethnic fighting after Russian and Ukrainian separatists who proclaimed their own ``Dniester republic'' in the area seized government buildings in Dubossary and blocked roads leading to the city. A fourth person identified as a Moldavian policeman reportedly died Monday of injuries suffered in the clash. In the southern part of the republic, a special commission of the Moldavian parliament held talks with representatives of another separatist group, the Turkish-Christian Gagauz minority, Tass reported. The Moldavian parliamentary commission was headed by the republic's Communist Party leader, Peter Luchinsky. The Gagauz, who number about 150,000, declared sovereignty Aug. 18 and announced elections for an autonomous government. Moldavian nationalists, numbering tens of thousands, rushed to confront the Gagauz but pulled back after negotiations started. Because of the ethnic unrest, city authorities in Moldavia's capital of Kishinev canceled the traditional military parade, civil march and other rallies scheduled for Wednesday's celebration of the anniversary of the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, Tass reported. The Gagauz and Dniester separatists say they are the targets of discrimination by the Moldavians, who themselves are seeking independence from the Soviet Union. Two-thirds of the 4.3 million people in the republic bordering Romania speak Moldavian, a language identical to Romanian except for Cyrillic characters. A group of women in Dubossary began a hunger strike last week seeking the resignation of Moldavian Prime Minister Mircha Druk and the punishment of those to blame for the deaths of the separatists, Tass reported. But Lyudmilla Skalnaya, head of Moldavia's Women's Council, appealed for an end to the hunger strike, the news agency said. ``We women have lost three sons, and six children were left without fathers in nonsensical clashes in the area of Dubossary,'' Tass quoted her as saying.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's ``Cheers'' Tops Ratings For Fifth Time
With AM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: NBC's ``Cheers'' was the most-watched show on television for the fifth time this season, but CBS is moving close to NBC in ratings for the season to date, according to Nielsen ratings released Tuesday. NBC's saloon comedy, which celebrates its 200th episode on Thursday, averaged a 22.4 rating, helping the Peacock Network win the week with an average prime-time rating of 13.5. CBS, whose ``60 Minutes'' and ``Murder She Wrote'' each had their highest ratings since the season began, was second last week with a 12.6. ABC was third with an 11.9. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. However, CBS' season-to-date margin is much closer to NBC and is making the ratings race tighter than had been ancipated, said NBC research vice president Preston Beckman. Although NBC still leads with a 13.3 average, CBS, trying to rebound from three consecutive seasons as third in prime time ratings, now has a 13.0 average for the season so far. ABC is third with a 12.5. `It's a much tighter race - CBS is making it even tighter that we thought'' it would be, Beckman said. He credited part of CBS' surge with the Nielsen performances of CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' ``Designing Women'' and ``60 Minutes.'' In last week's battle of The Cos vs. Bart, NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' easily bested Fox Broadcasting's half-hour ``The Simpsons.'' The former averaged an 18.6 to the 15.8 for the Fox show when the two directly competed with each other, and NBC's show averaged a 20.2 rating for the full hour. A special Monday showing of Burt Reynolds' ``Evening Shade'' CBS comedy also fared well. It was 24th in the rankings with a 15.1 average, far better than the 9.5 rating and No. 57 ranking of its regular Friday broadcast. In the news wars, ABC's ``World News Tonight'' won the Nielsen battle for the 43rd consecutive week. It averaged an 11.4, well ahead of the 10.0 for the ``CBS Evening News'' and the 9.5 of the ``NBC Nightly News.'' The week's top 10 list was dominated by old reliables, save for NBC's showing of the movie hit, ``Three Men and a Baby,'' and ABC's new ``America's Funniest People.'' They were, respectively, fourth and 10th in the rankings, with NBC's movie getting a 19.9 rating, and ABC's show an 18.0. After ``Cheers,'' the other top-rated shows and their ratings were ``60 Minutes,'' 21.4; Bill Cosby's show, 20.2; CBS' ``Designing Women'' and ABC's ``Roseanne,'' each 19.1; ``Murder She Wrote'' and ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' each 18.8, and CBS' ``Murphy Brown,'' 18.7. Fox's ``American Chronicles'' occupied the Nielsen cellar, averaging a 2.6 rating.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Ship Diverts German-Flagged Ship Carrying Undocumented Chemicals
DOC.TEXT: A Navy warship intercepted and diverted from the northern Red Sea a German-flagged cargo ship carrying chemicals not listed on the ship's manifest, the Pentagon said Tuesday. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said he did not know what kind of chemicals were aboard the Red Sea Europa when it was diverted last Friday by the crew of the cruiser USS Biddle. The Pentagon said it could not say where the cargo ship had come from or where it was headed. The presence of a shipment of chemicals in the vicinity of Iraq is especially sensitive because of international concerns about Iraq's chemical warfare capabilities. Rabbi Abraham Cooper, associate dean at the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles, said his group was alarmed at the disclosure of a German-flagged ship carrying undocumented chemicals in the Red Sea. He said U.S. authorities should be investigating the incident in view of evidence that German companies in the past have supplied Iraq with chemicals used to manufacture chemical weapons. The Biddle is part of a multinational naval force in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf area that is enforcing the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. Commercial ships carrying goods to Iraq in violation of the embargo, or whose cargo includes items not listed on the ship's manifest, are routinely forced to divert. Williams said the diversion of the Red Sea Europa was the 16th since the embargo was put in place last August following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Election Day in Persian Gulf: War Games, Sorties, Testing Goggles
With AM-Election Rdp
DOC.TEXT: As Americans voted at home on Tuesday, the U.S. Army was practicing war games, the Marines were testing night vision goggles, the Navy was enforcing trade sanctions on Iraq and the Air Force was flying sorties along the Kuwaiti border. In other words, it was just another day in Saudi Arabia. True, Army Spec. Everett Thornton, 22, of Alexandria, La., discussed the senatorial race in North Carolina over breakfast. And Army Maj. Steve Fernell, 38, of Kansas City, Mo., remembered seeing a picture of Dianne Feinstein, the Democratic candidate for governor of California. But for most servicemen in Operation Desert Shield, squared off against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's forces, it was just Tuesday, not Election Day, and that meant more training to prepare in case of war. Elements of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division, the first American unit to arrive in Saudi Arabia following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, took to the firing range for drills with machine guns, rifles, shotguns, grenades, anti-tank rockets and trench warfare. At one air base, U.S. F-15 fighters took off in pairs, heading north toward the Kuwaiti border and at a Saudi port, small U.S. Coast Guard patrol boats were enforcing security. ``I did not realize it was election day,'' said Capt. Michael Wills, 27, of Wapakoneta, Ohio, with the Army's 12th Aviation Brigade, who was on the tarmac at an airbase. ``There are a lot of other things to talk about here.'' The main topic, he said, is ``probably the man across the border.'' The consensus? ``He's crazy.'' Army Lt. Kevin Klutz said he had no idea that it was Election Day, ``We're more concerned about the mission here.'' The military distributed about 100,000 applications for absentee ballots among the 220,000 U.S. troops in the gulf and a handful of GIs voted by fax. Servicemen could also send away for their own ballots. The Judge Advocate's Office in the Army Forces Central Command, which ran a three-week ``Get Out The Vote'' blitz, had no figures on how many servicemen actually got absentee ballots and voted. Even on Election Day, Army Staff Sgt. Patrick Jewell, of Santa Barbara, Calif., was hoping to vote. ``They say we're going to get the opportunity to vote. We haven't got the ballots yet, but I'm sure we will,'' he said. Some thought the elections would affect the policy toward the gulf, others thought international pressure would be more important. But enlisted men have never been avid voters. Said Army Pvt. 1 Scott Lynch of Downing Town, Pa. with the 82nd Airborne. ``It's only senators and congressman and all of that so it's really not that big a deal to us. We have more important things to do, definitely more important things to do.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Immigrants Remember `Ellis Island of the West' With Fear
DOC.TEXT: The Angel Island Immigration Station was dubbed the Ellis Island of the West, but Chinese immigrants detained there remember it more as a prison than a gateway to freedom. The island was a land of fear, not hope, for the Chinese who often gave false names and lied about their histories to escape the immigration center that closed 50 years ago Monday. The island marked another anniversary Tuesday - the 140th anniversary of its establishment as a military base. Today, Angel Island is part of the Golden Gate National Recreation Area under the National Park Service. The island, three miles north of San Francisco, is the largest island in San Francisco Bay. Him Mark Lai's father was among the first group of Chinese processed at the station. ``Like of a lot of people, my father had to lie about who he was and where he came from,'' Lai said Monday. ``He never talked about Angel Island. I found out about it after his death when I was going through his papers.'' The lies were necessary because strict immigration laws, such as the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, allowed entry from China only to merchants, scholars, tourists and children of U.S. citizens. Chinese laborers and peasants with dreams of opportunity in America were barred. The Chinese Exclusion Act wasn't repealed until 1943. Lai's father, Bing Lai, said he was born of a Chinese-American - a story that couldn't be discredited since birth records were destroyed in the 1906 earthquake and fire in San Francisco. Bing Lai, who died in 1976, also dropped his real surname, Mark. ``I guess he always had a fear that he would be caught and discovered by immigration and then sent back to China,'' said Him Mark Lai, co-author of a book about Angel Island. Some 175,000 Chinese who came to the United States between 1910 and 1940 spent time on Angel Island. The station was closed in 1940, after a fire that destroyed part of the two-story wooden buildings that housed as many as 300 Chinese immigrants at a time. The buildings, which are being restored, also carry evidence of the frustration some immigrants felt on the island. Riots sometimes broke out to protest the food quality and confined quarters. ``This place is called an island of immortals,'' one anonymous poet wrote. ``But as a matter of fact, the mountain wilderness is a prison. The bird plunges in even though it sees the open net. Because of poverty one can do naught else.'' John Yeehall Chin, who was 16 years old when he arrived at Angel Island, said his first month in America was disheartening, but he was glad to escape the poverty of his life in China. ``They told me America was wealthy, beautiful, a wonderful country, but when I came here I was alone on the island and I was scared all the time until I knew they would let me go,'' said Chin, 82, of San Francisco. Chin's immigration application was accepted after authorities questioned him for three hours - a routine interrogation that could result in deportation if immigrants gave the wrong answers. ``I remember I got out one week before the Fourth of July,'' Chin said. ``I jumped up and down and went to a Chinese-American picnic. I was very happy. ... It was worth the pain.''

DOC.HEAD: Ada Wins Second Term as Guam Governor
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Joseph Ada posted an easy victory Tuesday, making the Republican the first governor to win back-to-back terms in the U.S. territory's history. With all 76 precincts reporting, Ada received 20,677 votes to Democrat Madeleine Bordallo's 15,688 votes, the Guam Election Commission reported. Final official tallies are expected Wednesday, the commission said. The abortion issue was not a factor in the vote, as both candidates oppose abortion and support a court challenge to a decision striking down the territory's restrictive abortion law. Bordallo, the first woman and non-native Guamanian to run for governor, is the widow of former Gov. Ricardo Bordallo. Her husband committed suicide Jan. 30, one day before he was to begin an 18-month federal prison term in California. He was not in office at the time of his death. In the territory's congressional election, Republican Ben Blaz won a fourth term as a non-voting delegate, defeating Democrat Ben Pagelinan by 21,390 to 16,437.

DOC.HEAD: Duvalier Loyalists Disqualified from Presidential Campaign
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Leading Haitians on Tuesday welcomed the announcement that people linked to a brutal dictatorship were barred from the presidential race. The move made a leftist priest the front-runner. The Electoral Council on Monday night disqualified 10 of the 26 declared presidential candidates from running in the Dec. 16 general election. The ruling had been expected. The council said the 10 failed to comply with filing procedures and were barred based on technicalities under the election law. They included Claude Raymond and Dr. Roger Lafontant, two officials of the oppressive Duvalier family regime that ruled Haiti for 29 years. The council said Lafontant wasn't cleared by the government auditing office on his handling of public funds while serving as minister of the interior and defense. It also said he didn't provide a birth certificate. Raymond, a former army chief of staff, was disqualified because he didn't register until after the Oct. 21 filing deadline. There was no immediate reaction from any of the disqualified candidates. ``I foresee a relatively normal unfolding of the electoral process now,'' said Jean-Claude Bajeux, a human rights activist and leader of the Congress of Democratic Movements, a socialist party. Many Haitians feared possible retaliation by Duvalier supporters and they jammed stores Monday night to stock on supplies. There were no incidents as of Tuesday afternoon. When 12 Duvalierists were barred from running for president in 1987, dozens of people were killed. On election day, armed men in collusion with the army killed at least 34 voters. Raymond has been publicly accused of participating in that massacre. He has never been charged. Lafontant ran the Duvalier's private paramilitary militia, the Tonton Macoutes, who terrorized this poor Caribbean nation of 6 million people. There's an outstanding arrest warrant charging Lafontant with conspiring against national security, but it has never been served. The Duvalier dictatorship ended in February 1986 when Jean-Claude Duvalier, son of the late Francois ``Papa Doc'' Duvalier, fled to exile in France. But political turmoil and violence have continued despite Duvalier's fall. The interim government of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot, appointed in March, is the fifth since Duvalier was ousted. Although other major candidates qualified, none appears to have the pull of the Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide, an oustpoken critic of Haiti's dictatorships. He has stirred the impoverished masses from the pulpit with impassioned sermons. In 1988, the Roman Catholic Salesian Order dismissed him from the order, alleging his sermons provoked violence. His surprise candidacy appeared aimed at stopping Duvalierists and was announced under the slogan: ``Operation Torrent to Block the Path of Macoutes.'' Dr. Louis Roy, head of the Council of State that rules alongside the provisional government, said Aristide's campaign may lose momentum with Lafontant's disqualification. ``But he remains the leading contender because he enjoys the backing of the impoverished masses,'' Roy added. ``His candidacy upset everyone's calculations, and he cannot be gotten around.'' Other major candidates who qualified were Marc Bazin, a former World Bank official; Silvio Claude, a former preacher; and Louis Dejoie Jr., a businessman. It was expected the Electoral Council would disqualify Duvalierists from running based on the 1987 constitution, which bars criminal supporters of past dictators from running for office until 1997. The election campaign officially opens Wednesday and closes Dec. 14. About 800 observers from the United Nations and the Organization of American States will monitor the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Names New Irish Primate
DOC.TEXT: Bishop Cahal B. Daly, a fierce critic of the IRA and other guerrilla groups, was appointed Roman Catholic primate of Ireland on Tuesday and said he will continue his outspoken campaign for peace in his native Northern Ireland. Pope John Paul II named Daly as spiritual leader of 3.7 million Catholics in Ireland and Northern Ireland. Daly succeeds Tomas O Fiaich, who died in May, as the archbishop of Armagh and primate of All-Ireland. ``My continuing concern will obviously be to work for an end to the violence which has afflicted both our communities for two disastrous decades,'' Daly told a news conference shortly after the announcement. ``Refusing to give in to discouragement or to despair, we must continue to believe in peace, to pray for peace, to speak peace, to make peace, by being ourselves men and women of peace.'' As the voice of the Catholic church in Belfast, as bishop of Down and Connor, Daly has been a vigorous advocate for the Catholic minority in the North but a foe of the Irish Republican Army. The IRA, Daly said two years ago, ``is a question of sheer evil and we have got to face that evil and have no truck with it.'' Supporters of the IRA, which is rooted in the Catholic community, regard Daly as an apologist for British rule. The IRA is waging a guerrilla war to drive the British from Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and merge the province with the Irish Republic. Ireland's Anglican primate, Robin Eames, said he had the highest respect for Daly's ``intellectual gifts, his courage and integrity.'' Peter Brooke, the highest-ranking British official in Northern Ireland, said Daly was respected for ``his resolute condemnation of violence, his concern for individual well-being and his longstanding efforts to bring about reconciliation.'' At 73, Daly is the oldest prelate appointed to the Armagh post in 170 years. He must submit his resignation when he turns 75, the normal retirement age for bishop, although the pope need not accept it immediately. He is the 114th successor to St. Patrick. Daly's last six predecessors were made cardinals. Daly enthusiastically joined in ecumenical ventures with Anglican and Presbyterian leaders in Northern Ireland, but he also vigorously defended Catholic schools against those who criticized them as perpetuating old divisions. He was a defender of faith in a land where religions often are badges of lethal political differences. In his ``Letter to a Northern Protestant,'' published in 1979, Daly wrote: ``Irish Catholics and Irish Protestants can and must help one another to stay faithful to Christ in a world where more and more people walk away from Him. In that world, it is imbecilic to suppose that Protestantism would gain through Catholicism's loss, or vice versa ... only post-Christian secularism and materialism will flourish if either of our faith-communities declines.'' Born in 1917 in Loughguile, north of Belfast, Daly was ordained in 1941. He earned a doctorate in divinity and did postgraduate work in philosophy at the Sorbonne and the College de France. From 1946-67 he lectured on scholastic philosophy at Queen's University in Belfast, then was appointed bishop of Ardagh and Clonmacnois in central Ireland. Daly suffered a heart attack in 1982, but recovered and was appointed that year as bishop of Down and Connor. Books he has written include ``Violence in Ireland and Christian Conscience'' and ``Justice, the Work of Peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Snow in Rockies and Plains, Rain and Wind in Northeast
DOC.TEXT: The latest in a series of storms produced heavy snow Tuesday in the central Rockies and another weather system spread high wind and heavy rain across the Northeast. Parts of Wyoming got heavy snow from late Monday into Tuesday. Totals ranged up to 17 inches at Sinks Canyon, 7 miles southwest of Lander; 13 inches at Lander; 12 inches at Togwotee Pass, 40 miles northeast of Jackson; and up to a foot at Casper. Casper Mountain got nearly 3 feet of snow in a 30-hour period, the National Weather Service said. Snow also fell across parts of eastern Colorado and parts of Nebraska. By daybreak, 3 inches of snow had fallen at Denver's Stapleton Airport. Totals in north-central Nebraska ranged up to 12 inches at Greeley, with 7 inches reported at Erickson, O'Neillo and Loretto. A winter storm watch was in effect into Wednesday for New Mexico's central highlands and western mountains. Low pressure in southern Quebec spread rain and snow over northern New England. In Maine, heavy rainfall for the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST included 1.75 inches at Portland, 1.56 inches at Brunswick and 1.03 inches at Augusta. Snowfall totals in northern Maine ranged up to 4 inches at Saint Agatha by late morning. Strong west to northwest wind associated with the low pressure system over southern Quebec buffeted much of the Northeast. In western New York state, wind gusted to 55 mph at Rochester overnight. Wind gusted to 61 mph at Buffalo, and to 69 mph at Dunkirk. The wind in western New York state downed utility poles, power lines and large trees, causing scattered blackouts. In southern New England, winds gusted to 47 mph at Hartford, Conn., early in the morning. Wind over eastern New York state gusted to 48 mph at Rome during the afternoon. The storm crossing southern Canada also produced heavy snow in Upper Michigan late Monday and into Tuesday. Totals in northern Lower Michigan ranged up to 12 inches at Atlanta. Up to 6 inches of snow was reported in eastern Upper Michigan. Low pressure developing over southern Nevada generated strong and gusty wind in parts of California and Nevada. Strong, gusty wind blew over the San Francisco area, with gusts to 31 mph at the airport early Tuesday morning. Afternoon temperatures were mostly in the 20s from the northern and central high Plains to northern Minnesota, with readings in the teens in Montana, wyoming and Colorado, and in the 20s and 30s over much of the Rocky Mountain region. Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 7 below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: European Community Agrees on Farm Subsidy Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, Agriculture Secretary ... to CORRECT to Mermaz quote, not Gummer; SUBS 16th graf, ``We have ... to RESTORE Mermaz attribution.
DOC.TEXT: The 12-nation European Community on Tuesday approved a plan for moderate reductions in farm subsidies, resolving an impasse that had threatened to scuttle next month's world trade talks. The proposal calls for trimming government payments on major farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years, starting in 1986. Some cuts have already been made. The community had failed to agree in six previous attempts. The plan now will be presented to negotiators in the Uruguay Round talks, an ambitious four-year effort by about 100 nations to overhaul the world trading system. Those talks are being held under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum that advocates freer world trade. After two days of bargaining, the European trading bloc's agriculture and trade ministers endorsed a carefully worded proposal that sought to ease fears of some governments that the reductions would badly hurt their farmers. French Agriculture Minister Louis Mermaz, who had been holding up the agreement, described the outcome as ``excellent.'' Mermaz said the proposal ``will enable the European Comunity to start the negotiations with a united front, with an excessively dynamic position.'' The community is the last major player to put its offer on the bargaining table, having missed an Oct. 15 deadline for submitting positions for the final round of negotiations, which will begin in less than a month. It was unlikely, though, that the offer would be warmly received by the United States and other nations, which have demanded much greater reductions in the community's costly farm support programs. The Bush administration wants its trading partners to slash farm income supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent over a 10-year period, starting in 1991. But Italian Trade Minister Renato Ruggiero cautioned Tuesday, ``It would be a grave error on the part of our trading partners to judge that this position is not (one) of great openness and ambition.'' France and Germany had held up the agreement by insisting on guarantees that the cuts would not be too severe. In the end, the ministers adopted a list of assurances that promised not only to compensate farmers for income losses, but to make sure that cheaper, imported goods would not push home-grown products off the market. It also pledges to limit the impact of the reductions on poor regions in the community and to soften proposed cuts in supports for olive oil and other products grown in Mediterranean countries. ``After long negotiations, we got very good improvements,'' said German Agriculture Minister Ignaz Kiechle. Mermaz said, ``We have to look the Americans straight in the face. We are not going to buy from them what we make ourselves.'' Frans Andriessen, the community's top trade official, conceded that some of the guarantees adopted by the ministers ``will not make it easier to negotiate, but at least we are in a position to start.'' Agriculture is one of 15 areas under discussion in the world trade negotiations, which began in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este. The final week of bargaining, which is to end the round, opens Dec. 3 in Brussels. The United States is among nations insisting, however, that agriculture holds the key to liberalizing trade in other areas, including textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as telecommunications and banking. Argentina threatened to walk out of the round if deep cuts are not made in farm subsidies.

DOC.HEAD: Up to Foot of Snow in Colorado, Roads Icy in Nebraska, New England Wet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to update with snow amounts in Wyoming and Nebraska, picking up 9th graf pvs, ``It's snowing ...'
DOC.TEXT: An Election Day storm dumped heavy snow on the Rockies and left highways slippery on the western Plains, and snow over the Great Lakes closed some Michigan schools. ``In some counties we've had trouble even getting poll workers to the polls to open them up,'' said Nebraska Secretary of State Allen Beermann. High wind knocked out power to thousands of customers in upstate New York, and heavy rain soaked parts of New England. Heavy snow fell across parts of Wyoming from late Monday into Tuesday. Snowfall totals ranged up to 17 inches at Sinks Canyon, 7 miles southwest of Lander; 13 inches at Lander; 12 inches at Togwotee Pass, 40 miles northeast of Jackson; and up to a foot at Casper. Casper Mountain got nearly 3 feet of snow in a 30-hour period, the National Weather Service said. In Colorado, the National Weather Service said snow increased in coverage and intensity in Denver and other Front Range areas during the morning rush hour. The snow was driven by wind blowing at 15 to 25 mph, cutting visibility. Colorado ski resorts benefited from the storm, with Winter Park getting up to 10 inches on Monday and Steamboat Springs 8 inches. Meteorologists said accumulations of 6 to 12 inches were possible in Colorado's northern and central mountains. Freezing drizzle iced roads near the Colorado-Kansas line. Western and north-central Nebraska was hit by snow, rain, wind and cold and many voters needed chains on their car tires just to get to the polls. Most of western Nebraska was covered with 2 to 3 inches of snow, with reports of up to 5 inches on the ground in Kimball and 7 inches at O'Neill, said Larry Wirth of the weather service office in Scottsbluff. Twelve inches fell at Greeley in the north-central part of the state, the weather service said. ``It's snowing some and the wind is blowing and it's cold and icy,'' said Lincoln County Clerk Nadine Heath at midmorning. ``I understand in the rural areas it's really hard to see.'' Another storm dumped up to 8 inches of snow on Michigan's northern Lower Peninsula and caused scattered power outages from Monday into early Tuesday. State police said snow forced the closing of at least four northern Lower Peninsula school districts. A state police dispatcher at Alpena reported several minor traffic accidents. ``It's still snowing and blowing and it's probably 7 or 8 inches deep close to town and as you go out from the town it gets a little deeper,'' dispatcher George Beebe said early Tuesday. ``A pretty good percentage of the city is without power.'' Just four days earlier, Michigan had a spell of Indian summer, making the storm hard to take, said hairdresser Michelle Collins in Houghton Lake. ``I wasn't expecting it. We had such a nice week,'' she said. ``From what the customers are saying coming in, it's pretty bad, a lot of sleet, a lot of cars in ditches.'' Wind gusting to more than 60 mph whipped through upstate New York on Tuesday, downing trees and power lines. A peak gust of 63 mph was recorded at Buffalo, the weather service said. In Monroe County, N.Y., where wind was recorded at 59 mph, officials reported numerous power outages and trees falling on cars and houses. No injuries were reported. About a third of a church under construction in Pittsford collapsed but no one was there at the time. At least 20,000 homes lost power from southern New York state to Niagara Falls. All but a few hundred had been restored by noon, said E. Alfred Osborne, a spokesman for Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. Wind-whipped waves reached 8 feet on Lake Erie and 10 feet or higher on Lake Ontario. Minor flooding was reported along the Lake Erie shoreline south of Buffalo. High wind also buffeted parts of Maine, along with heavy rain. Cape Elizabeth and the Portland area were lashed with wind averaging 30 mph and gusts as high as 45 mph. ``A big storm developed very suddenly along the coast,'' said Art Lester, a weather service meteorologist. ``The rain was very heavy.'' Southern New Hampshire also had pounding rain that cut into morning voter turnout.

DOC.HEAD: French Investigators Probe Case of Tainted Truffles
DOC.TEXT: Truffles, the ugly fungi prized as a delicacy by gourmands, have been tainted by a fraud scandal. Authorities on Tuesday said four companies that handle the bulk of truffle sales in France have been implicated in a scheme to defraud wholesale buyers. The culprits allegedly used walnut juice to stain light-colored summer truffles so they appeared to be the more coveted and more expensive dark winter truffles. The case has been turned over to prosecutors in the southern town of Carpentras after an investigation by a government consumer fraud agency. Summer truffles sell for about $36 per pound, compared to $164 per pound for winter truffles. The fraud allegedly involved several tons of truffles. Truffles grow just under the surface of the soil. They can be found by a person using a stick, but more commonly pigs or trained hounds are used to sniff them out.

DOC.HEAD: Layoffs Continue at UPI
DOC.TEXT: United Press International laid off more emloyees Tuesday, a day after company officials said the news service faced liquidation unless remaining workers accepted a 90-day pay cut of 35 percent. ``There have been some further dismissals in various departments of UPI,'' said spokesman Milt Capps. ``They were in various places throughout the system. These dismissals have been effected over the past couple of weeks, some of those as late as today.'' He declined to give numbers. UPI officials on Monday said the 83-year-old news service will have to be liquidated Nov. 16 unless employees represented by the Wire Service Guild accept 90-day salary cuts. Managers and other non-guild workers already have been told they must accept similar cuts. Company officials said pay concessions by the union-covered employees would provide the news service more time to seek a buyer, although Pieter Vanbennekom, UPI executive vice president, cautioned that approval of the pay cut would not ``guarantee UPI will be successfully sold.'' Capps said the company normally does not reveal plans for layoffs in advance but also said, ``We do not anticipate many, if any, such moves during the balance of this interim plan that we have.'' UPI has changed ownership three times in the past eight years.

DOC.HEAD: Students Continue Protests for Better Education
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of high school students around France poured into the streets Tuesday, a day after 130,000 youths joined nationwide marches to demand better education and improved security on campus. The largest protests Tuesday involved 8,000 students in Besancon, 6,000 in Toulouse, and 4,000 each in Reims and Vannes, police reported. There were smaller marches in Marseille, Nancy, Metz, Belfort, Dijon, Nevers and Mulhouse. No violence or arrests were reported, although a police officer directing traffic away from the march in Marseille suffered minor injuries when accidentally struck by a car. Two police unions representing 35 percent of the uniformed officers denounced orders issued to riot police Monday in Paris to avoid confrontations with protesters. Scores of youths went on a rampage along the march route, wrecking businesses and hurling projectiles that injured 13 people, including five policemen. Police made several arrests, but generally avoided using force. One union statement said policemen were ``scandalized by the passive attitude of public officials,'' and warned that troublemakers would be encouraged to take advantage of police restraint. ``It's unacceptable that those in charge of the security of citizens, including the demonstrators, should transform the police into mere bystanders,'' said another union statement. Protests have spread nationwide since starting three weeks ago in the low-income suburbs north of Paris, where a student was raped in a school lavatory and several teachers and students were assaulted. The students are demanding more teachers, repairs to crumbling high schools and more security guards on crime-ridden campuses in ghetto neighborhoods. Students around the country marched Monday as the National Assembly debated the Socialist government's proposal to increase education spending by 9 percent, to the equivalent of $49 billion. Student leaders have criticized this as inadequate, although it outpaces the overall budget increase of 4.8 percent. Education Minister Lionel Jospin managed to have Assembly debate delayed until next week while he pursues dialogue with the student movement, which is split into moderate and hard-line leftist factions. Conservative opposition parties proposed Tuesday that the Socialist government sell off state-owned industries to finance school renovations.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait Says Jordan Breaking Sanctions, Asks Halt
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait accused Jordan on Tuesday of breaking U.N. sanctions by trucking food across its border into Iraq and asked it to stop. Mohammad Abu Al-Hassan, Kuwait's ambassador to the United Nations, warned Jordan it could face the same sanctions as Iraq if it failed to halt shipments of forbidden goods. He told a news conference that sanctions are not working mainly because the Iraqi government does not care ``for the suffering of its own people'' and is diverting all food and equipment to the army. ``Whatever Iraq has now is sufficient to run the army for quite a long time,'' he said. The U.N. Security Council is considering new resolutions, including one that would impose economic sanctions on countries breaking sanctions on Iraq, Hassan said. Kuwaiti refugees have reported seeing Jordanian trucks loaded with food all over the captured emirate. The ambassador said humanitarian food shipments are not barred, but a mechanism exists for determining what food is being sent on a humanitarian basis. ``This mechanism has not been followed by Jordan in their supplying of food to Iraq. Therefore, whatever food is supplied to Iraq, it is in violation of Security Council Resolution 661,'' which authorized sanctions, Hassan said. Asked if other countries were violating the sanctions, he said there were ``some violations'' by Yemen shortly after the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2 and there has been some smuggling from Iran that is not condoned by the Iranian government. He said the number of Kuwaitis fleeing their homeland was 300 to 350 on Monday and is increasing because of Iraqi ``atrocities'' and because the Iraqis are giving food and gasoline only to Iraqi citizens. No Kuwaiti wants to become an Iraqi, he said. The ambassador said Kuwaiti students are undergoing military training in the United States, Britain, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf states because they want to participate ``in the honor of liberating their country.'' He said he had no exact figures on how many were being trained.

DOC.HEAD: American Hostages To Be Allowed To Receive Packages, Red Cross Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS misspelling of Richards' name in 6th graf
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Americans held at strategic targets in Iraq will be able to send messages and receive care packages under an agreement announced Tuesday by the Red Cross. The first phase of the program involves message exchanges between the 106 hostages and their families, said Stephen Richards, the Red Cross' executive vice president. After a cycle of messages has been completed, the Red Cross, working with its sister organization, the Iraqi Red Crescent, will arrange for the shipment of packages including such items as drugs, food, clothing, paperback books and toiletries. Some hostages and their families have been able to communicate through letters shipped in and out of Iraq by the State Department, which is serving as a clearing house. In addition, Iraq has allowed a few hostages to telephone home. The Red Cross agreement only covers the men at strategic sites, not all the Americans held against their will in Iraq and Kuwait, he said. Richards, who just returned from Baghdad, said the Red Cross is also seeking permission to have a medical team visit the hostages to check on their physical and mental condition. The Red Cross, a neutral agency, has not been involved in efforts to gain the release of the hostages, which Richards called a governmental responsibility. The United States has demanded the hostages' unconditional release. Representatives of the Iraqi Red Crescent say the hostages are faring adequately, Richards said. ``They felt their general health and nutrition were satisfactory,'' he said. But ``their psychological well-being would be substantially improved were they able to send regular messages to and from their families.'' The State Department welcomed the Red Cross' agreement, saying it would make the hostages' lives easier. On Monday, department spokesman Richard Boucher said reports from Iraq are that many detainees are losing weight, eating poorly and are frequently cold as the winter approaches. Doris Whatley of Shreveport, La., said her husband, Donald, is ``doing alright. ... He is getting food even though what he gets is the same old thing.'' Mrs. Whatley has received several letters from her husband who is kept at a strategic site near Baghdad. The State Department has passed 408 letters to hostages and has received 269 back for their friends and family. ``He is optimistic that he is going to come home,'' Mrs. Whatley said of her husband. The Red Cross message exchange program is expected to get under way in about 10 days. Each cycle will take about two weeks. The hostages will be handed short forms to write messages. Those will be shipped to the United States, through Jordan, by the Red Cross. Then, the family members will be allowed to write responses, which in turn will be delivered to the hostages. The Iraqi Red Crescent officials will serve as the couriers inside Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbi Stood for Jewish Power with a Clenched Fist
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 19-20 to DELETE incorrect reference to Times in exposing Kahane's affair with model. Picks up 21st graf, `Kahane soon...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: From his native Brooklyn to the rock-strewn hills of the Israeli-occupied West Bank, Rabbi Meir Kahane preached a violent doctrine of Jewish power. In New York he railed at blacks, and in Israel he advocated the mass expulsion of the Palestinians. On Monday in New York, at age 58, he was slain by an assassin police said was believed to be of Arab descent. Kahane, who founded the Jewish Defense League in New York, was both revered and reviled in Israel. The establishment, both liberal and conservative, shunned him as a racist. But his small band of followers worshiped him. ``A prophet has died,'' Kahane aide Herbert Sunshine said at the Jerusalem headquarters of the rabbi's anti-Arab Kach movement. ``Kahane was an advocate of racial discrimination and apartheid,'' said Palestinian Saeed Kanan. ``He became a victim of his own slogans and mottos.'' The bearded, black-haired rabbi made his name with brutal, hot-tempered rhetoric. American blacks were guilty of Jew hatred, he said. Arabs were dogs. Jews who ignored this were lemmings. Another Holocaust was imminent, he declared, and made his symbol a clenched fist under the slogan ``Never again.'' Although a relatively small number of Israelis supported Kahane in elections, in private conversations many would agree with his views. His message of Jewish force struck a sympathetic chord in the country founded largely in response to the Holocaust and surrounded by Arab enemies. Even a recent poll conducted among Soviet immigrants who just arrived in Israel showed that 9.8 percent of them were ready to vote for Kahane. Asked how he would expel Arabs from Israel, he replied: ``Picture Arabs putting on the radio one morning and hearing the new minister of defense is Meir Kahane. ... When they hear that, they'll pack themselves.'' The notion of becoming Israel's defense minister was pure fantasy. In three runs for election, he got into Israel's Parliament only once, by himself, and was finally barred from running in 1988 because of his blunt anti-Arab racism. Kahane founded the militant Jewish Defense League to protect elderly Jews against muggers, but it was later accused of planting bombs in a terrorist campaign against Arabs and Soviets. He was born Martin David Kahane on Aug. 1, 1932, the son of a rabbi in Brooklyn's Flatbush section, and took the Hebrew name Meir when he became a rabbi. He grew up during Judaism's most dreadful years. The full horrors of the Nazi Holocaust were becoming known, and a relative was shot to death by Arabs in Palestine. At 15, Kahane was arrested for throwing tomatoes at British Foreign Minister Ernest Bevin, a foe of Jewish statehood. It was the first of his many arrests in the United States and Israel. ``Kahane represented the undissipated anger at the Holocaust. There was no way that his anger and his fury could actually be expressed except through this way of seeing the Jews as either vulnerable or fighting,'' commented Zev Chafits, an American-born Israeli writer. In 1957, he won a law degree and an master's degree in international relations, and was ordained a rabbi. But he lost his first rabbinical post for enforcing Orthodox Jewish law too strictly on his Queens congregation. He became a sportswriter, went to Israel in 1962, and left defeated, mocked for his arrogance and his stuttering efforts to learn Hebrew. Journalist Robert I. Friedman, wrote in the biography ``The False Prophet'' that Kahane became an FBI informer, infiltrating radical groups such as the John Birch Society even as he cruised New York's East Side bars. Friedman says that in 1966 a fashion model named Estelle Donna Evans jumped from a bridge and died after Kahane, married with four children, broke off their affair. The New York Times did an expose on the sensational aspects of Kahane's career in 1971. At that time he was leading the Jewish Defense League, heading marches against black politicians and white liberals, whom he accused of pandering to blacks. Kahane soon widened his attacks to include the Soviet Union for its treatment of Jews. Right-wing Israeli politician Geula Cohen says she urged him to take up the cudgel against the Soviets, and Friedman says that Yitzhak Shamir, now Israel's prime minister, also encouraged Kahane's anti-Soviet radicalism. Kahane moved to Israel in 1971, to a circumspect welcome from the right wing. Mrs. Cohen says she told him ``that here we have the Israeli army, and we don't need you to deal with the Arabs.'' On the one hand, he was ``a foreign implantation, he didn't acclimatize, he didn't have roots in the political Zionist sense. He didn't fit in,'' Mrs. Cohen said. On the other hand, Kahane articulated the gut feelings many Israelis fear to say aloud: fear of the Arabs, a sense of isolation, a yearning for quick, clearcut solutions. Kahane's message - the one that got him elected in 1984 - seemed simple enough to some: ``I want to remove the Arabs - including Israeli Arabs - from the entire land of Israel.'' This meant expelling not only the 1.7 million Palestinians, but Israel's 800,000 Arab citizens. This, plus the Kach movement's thuggish tactics, proved too much even for the hard-liners. In 1988, Kahane's candidacy was disqualified under a specially enacted law against advocating racism. The rabbi took his anti-Arab campaign to the streets. An attack against Jews would bring out his followers, carrying Kahane on their shoulders and shouting ``Death to the Arabs!'' Thousands would join his hard-core supporters at Kach marches, either out of conviction or curiosity. During such a march - in July 1989, after a Palestinian killed 16 Jews by steering a bus off a highway - Kahane had his final run-in with Israel's establishment. For calling Arabs ``a cancer spreading in our midst,'' he was arrested and charged with sedition. At his death, the case still awaited a decision in the courts.

DOC.HEAD: Politics Alleged in Park Decision
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf with press office confirmation of signing after 2nd graf, Unsoeld, a; to update with bill signing SUBS 10th graf, If the
DOC.TEXT: The White House held up an announcement about a proposed historic site in Vancouver, Wash., to hurt the re-election chances of Democratic Rep. Jolene Unsoeld, her campaign charged Tuesday. Unsoeld, a freshman Democrat targeted for defeat by the Republicans, won passage of the measure before Congress adjourned late last month. The White House press office finally confirmed at 5 p.m. EST Tuesday that the president had signed the measure. Unsoeld's campaign was upset by the failure of the White House to announce whether President Bush had signed or vetoed legislation that would have authorized an 18-month study of a proposed historic reserve chronicling the birthplace of the Pacific Northwest. ``We suspected they would hold it to the last minute, but holding it past the deadline is a little ridiculous. This appears patently political,'' said Dan Evans, Unsoeld's chief of staff. ``The practical effect of their non-announcement is to deny Jolene an accomplishment story,'' Evans said. David Kalbaugh, assistant to the executive clerk in the White House Executive Clerk's Office, confirmed Tuesday that Bush's deadline for signing the bill expired at 12:01 a.m. ``Unfortunately due to the president's travel there has been no announcement,'' Kalbaugh said. ``When the president returns, there will be some sort of announcement from the White House press office.'' Bush returned to the White House Tuesday afternoon. Evans said the bill had been on the president's desk since Oct. 24. The bill will launch an 18-month study into the feasibility of creating a 300-acre Fort Vancouver National Historical Reserve on the banks of the Columbia River across from Portland, Ore. Vancouver and surrounding Clark County were viewed as a critical election battleground by both Unsoeld and Republican Bob Williams. The study calls for a five-member commission to report to Congress by 1992 with recommendations on establishing the reserve under management of the National Park Service. The Park Service already operates a wooden replica of Fort Vancouver, home to the original Hudson's Bay Company trading post, on the site. The study would determine whether to add the Vancouver Barracks, the newly restored officers row, the Columbia River waterfront and the Pearson Airpark, the oldest continually operating airport in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting to restore ELN designation in slug.
At the Polls: Americans Vote Once More, With Anger
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Behind the flags and bunting and mechanized curtains, in schools and churches and government buildings, Americans voted on Tuesday. Then, time and again, they declared disgust with the government they were electing. ``You have to kind of hold your nose and vote this time,'' said John Kirley, a semi-retired consultant voting in Dallas. His sentiments were widely shared by voters around the country. From outward appearances, the election was another page from a civics textbook. Voters streamed into a Mennonite church gymnasium in Fresno, Calif., a recreation center in Cape Canaveral, Fla., a housing project lobby in Minneapolis, a school cafeteria in New York City. They punched computer cards and pulled old-fashioned cranks. They participated in democracy. But beneath the surface ran a disturbing streak of cynicism - about the federal budget, about the U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf and, perhaps most sharply, about the dismal state of political campaigns. In northern Michigan's rural Benzie County, people filed into the Benzonia Township Hall to cast their ballots, exchange some small talk and sample Township Clerk Pat Mead's orange twists and sticky buns. Precinct worker Art Fleetwood kept up a running banter about Monday night's snow and this fall's bow hunting season for deer - anything but politics. But when talk did turn to politics, the people of Benzie County were as disgusted as voters anywhere. ``Kick them all out!'' one man said as he walked out the door. ``Start over!'' his wife chimed in. Family physician Bob Camp looked over the sample ballot posted on the wall. ``If there was a place on here for `No one,' I would have voted a straight ticket,'' he said. ``I am thoroughly disgusted. I am more than that. I am one step beyond disgusted.'' Six hundred miles away, in New York City, wind blew leaves into swirls outside the brick school building where 5-year-old Emma Rosenberg had just voted for the first time, with some help from her mother, Debbie. ``She voted for the environment,'' said Debbie Rosenberg, who had let Emma pull the lever for a vote on New York's Environmental Quality Bond Act. It was thrilling for a 5-year-old, but her mother's smile vanished when she was asked if she was satisfied with the slate of candidates on the ballot. ``No, who's satisfied?'' she said. ``Nobody's satisfied right now.'' A few minutes later, precinct worker Tousette G. Sefman stepped outside for a cigarette. As a black woman, she said, she felt especially obligated to exercise her right to vote. But she, too, was disgusted with her government. ``I think maybe a parliamentary system might be better,'' Ms. Sefman said. Turnout was heavy as usual at the Cape Canaveral Recreation Center, where nearly half the voters are retired. Many of the others are employed at the Kennedy Space Center or its offshoots in the aerospace industry. The common theme: Throw the bums out. ``There's nothing right today, from the banks to the S&Ls to the war to the budget,'' grumbled real estate agent John Jones, 54. ``I'm going to do what I can to change it.'' Jones said he voted against the incumbents. ``It's the first time in my life I ever felt so strongly about it,'' he said. In Braintree, Mass., Dr. Earl Hoerner voted against the entire Democratic state ticket, which was heavily laden with incumbents. ``Throw the guys out,'' he said as he left his polling booth. Further up the Atlantic coast at Cape Elizabeth, Maine, the mood of the voters was as foul as the weather. Rain fell in wind-driven sheets outside Cape Elizabeth High School where equipment operator Skip Ingalls voted. ``I watched the news last night and they described the NOTA - None of the Above,'' Ingalls said. ``That's how I feel like voting in several instances.'' These are the people who bothered to vote. For every one of them, there was at least one other qualified citizen who abandoned that right. And there were a few rays of sunshine - voters who still believed, or who were too young to be jaded. At Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., students trickled into a polling station set up in the lobby of a lab building. There were no signs of disillusionment among these voters, still fresh to the power they wield in a democracy. ``I haven't lost faith yet,'' said Les Bergsman, 21, in his third year as a voting adult. Campus billboards were pasted with fliers proclaiming, ``Don't Vote: Revolt!'' The fliers declared that ``voting is a form of social suicide'' and urged a sort of militant apathy to show contempt for a corrupt government. Bergsman wasn't buying it. Government has its problems, he said, but that is what voting is for. ``You do what you can to un-corrupt it,'' Bergsman said. ``By not voting you support a corrupt system. You leave it in the hands of those corrupt.'' ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This story was reported by Jeff Baenen in Minneapolis;
DOC.TEXT: Marcia Dunn in Cape Canaveral, Fla.; George Esper in Braintree, Mass; David Foster in Olympia, Wash.; William C. Hidlay in Cape Elizabeth, Maine; Mitchell Landsberg in New York; Scott McCartney in Dallas; Paul Nowell in Charlotte, N.C.; Paige St. John in Benzonia, Mich.; Lindsey Tanner in Chicago, and Noel K. Wilson in Fresno, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Target Key Republican Senators, Four GOP Governors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First returns in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Democrats bid Tuesday to fortify their majorities in Congress and challenged Republican control of four key governorships, highlights of a midterm election punctuated by the autumn stirrings of voter discontent. Voters were still in line at the polling places in many states as the first returns came in. They showed Republican Sen. Dan Coats leading in Indiana and Sen. Mitch McConnell ahead in Kentucky - a race where Democrats had harbored hopes of an upset. With 34 Senate races on the ballot, Democrats took aim at Republican incumbents Jesse Helms in North Carolina, Mark Hatfield in Oregon and Rudy Boschwitz in Minnesota in hopes of padding their current 55-45 majority. The House of Representatives was securely in Democratic control, as it has been since the Eisenhower era. All 435 seats were on the ballot, although most attention clustered around 29 races without an incumbent, 18 of them currently in Republican hands. Among 36 statehouse races, Republican governorships in California, Texas, Florida and Illinois were at risk, probably the biggest prizes of the year. The GOP hoped for victories that would protect their influence in drawing boundaries for House seats that will shift to the Sun Belt in 1992. Republicans vied to take over Democratic statehouses in Massachusetts and Ohio. Democratic Gov: pickup 5th graf a0562

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian President Appeals for Calm as Resignation Demands Mount
DOC.TEXT: President Zhelyu Zhelev appealed for calm Tuesday but students ignored his pleas to end a strike and workers threatened to cut off the gasoline supply if Bulgaria's government did not resign. Finance Minister Belcho Belchev meanwhile said economic woes could topple the government of former Communists, now members of the renamed Bulgarian Socialist Party. Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov has had his hands tied by Parliament, which refuses to back his economic reforms. Last week, he said he would resign if the 400-seat legislature did not approve his program. His Socialists hold 211 seats, and the main opposition group 144. The 10,000 workers at Bulgaria's main petrochemical plant threatened to strike Thursday if Lukanov does not quit, the state BTA news agency reported. The strike at Bourgas would halt the flow of already rationed gasoline and paralyze the country. Lukanov said after meeting plant management that the government would use ``all legal measures'' to ensure continued flow of fuel supplies, BTA said. In a statement carried by the news agency, the government said it would not yield to ultimatums but was open to dialogue. Belchev said price rises were imminent, but that meager supplies were unlikely to improve, BTA said. ``That will be the end of the government,'' it quoted him as saying. Zhelev, the former opposition leader, appealed to students who occupied Sofia University on Monday to end their sit-in strike, his spokesman, Valentin Stoyanov, said on state radio. The students refused. BTA said students also occupied the technical university in the pollution-plagued city of Ruse on the Romanian border and the medical academy in Sofia. It was not clear how many students were participating. They are demanding the Socialists accept blame for past Communist mistakes and responsibility for the current crisis. Stoyanov said the students' ``legitimate'' demands must be achieved ``with legitimate means.'' ``Such actions do not help the democratic process in Bulgaria, but destroy it because they create social tensions and unwarranted mistrust between the political forces,'' Stoyanov quoted Zhelev as saying. ``As the political forces are carrying out consultations on the formation of a new government, it is very important that the citizens maintain peace and calm in the country.'' The Socialists reiterated Tuesday they back a coalition government. But Vice Chairman Alexander Tomov said it must ``reflect the realities in Parliament.'' Lukanov heads an all-Socialist government because the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, refused to govern with the former Communists. On Monday, UDF's floor leader in Parliament, Stoyan Ganev, said his 17-party alliance wanted to form a UDF-dominated government with the opposition holding the prime minister's office and key ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Welfare Experiment Resumes After Suspension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5 pvs, `Learnfare, which...,' to ADD judge's name and that order applied only to Milwaukee County. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `The agreement...
DOC.TEXT: An experimental program that ties welfare benefits to teen-agers' school attendance has resumed after a judge lifted an order suspending it because poor attendance records caused unfair penalties. ``We think it will be a better program and we're upbeat,'' said David Blaska, a spokesman with the state Department of Health and Human Services, which oversees the Learnfare program. Blaska added that the state would pursue an expansion of the program to younger children. Learnfare, which docks the welfare benefits of families whose teen-agers skip school, was suspended in Milwaukee County during the summer. The court order suspending the program applied only to Milwaukee County, where the bulk of the program is carried out. U.S. District Judge Terence Evans last week lifted the suspension he had earlier imposed after state and Milwaukee school officials reached an agreement to ensure better attendance records would be kept. The agreement includes the assignment of 16 workers to verify attendance of truants before penalties are imposed. ``Milwaukee is where the action is, where so much is needed and the program is part of it,'' Blaska said. ``Getting the injunction lifted is a lift to our spirits.'' The program's supporters claim Learnfare discourages truancy and will help break the cycle of poverty. Critics say the experiment penalizes the poor. Among the safeguards state and school officials have added is a verification process that includes notices to all parents. Thy are told their children's attendance is being monitored and that truancy can result in cuts in Aid to Families with Dependent Children benefits. Families will also be contacted by case managers to make sure the student is actually enrolled and to set up interviews to explain the sanctions before any penalties are imposed. Other provisions include $750,000 in new state funds to create alternative education programs for Milwaukee school dropouts. ``I think it's a monumental step toward remedying the situation of inaccurate information,'' said Willie Little, director of community relations for Milwaukee Public Schools. More than 13,000 Milwaukee County teen-agers are subject to potential sanctions. Families of about 12 percent of the students had their payments docked in June, the month before the program was suspended. The program resumed immediately after the judge's ruling, but welfare benefits for violators won't be cut until February to allow time for the changes to be implemented, Blaska said. State officials said they would pursue an expansion that would allow them to apply the sanctions to welfare families with children between ages 6 and 12. The expansion would cost about $4 million a year and increase the number of students monitored statewide from 27,000 to 70,000, Blaska said. The earliest it could be instituted is late 1991, he said. The federal government has already granted the state permission to expand the program to elementary students and the Wisconsin Legislature is expected to consider it in January. ``We hope to catch truancy before it becomes a chronic problem,'' Blaska said. ``It's also easier to implement when the child is younger and more amenable.'' Under the proposed expansion, sanctions against families with children between ages 6 and 12 would be more lenient. The families of violators would not be penalized if they agreed instead to attend regular counseling with case managers. Milwaukee Public Schools officials say they are uneasy about the expansion and fear it may become an unnecessary administrative headache since elementary schools have a 95 percent attendance rate. ``We'd have to evaluate the current program before we decided if we support the expansion of Learnfare,'' he said. ``If it's going to get kids in school and keep them in school, then we would absolutely support it.''

DOC.HEAD: Council of Europe Admits Hungary
By MARY BETH SHERIDAN
DOC.TEXT: The Council of Europe on Tuesday admitted Hungary as its first member from the former Communist East bloc. The council, known for its human rights achievements, is the oldest post-World War II body promoting European cooperation. ``It is certainly a great day for me and for all Hungarians to be admitted into Europe and the Council of Europe,'' Foreign Minister Geza Jeszenszky of Hungary told a news conference in the 17th-century Barberini Palace in central Rome. He said membership in the Council of Europe ``is an additional protection for the newborn democracy in Hungary.'' Jeszenszky explained that if Hungary did not maintain high human rights and democratic standards, it would be forced to leave the 41-year-old Council. He spoke hours after he and Council Secretary-General Catherine Lalumiere signed documents admitting Hungary and committing it to the council's human rights treaty. ``When the time came, Hungary was bold enough to open a hole in the Iron Curtain,'' Ms. Lalumiere told council ministers gathered around the table in the gilt-edged room. ``The leaders and indeed the people have contributed so much to bringing the division of Europe to an end.'' The ministers then watched on TV as the red, white and green Hungarian flag was raised along the other 23 members' flags at the Council of Europe offices in Strasbourg, France. Czechoslovakia and Poland are expected to join the Council of Europe soon. Like Hungary, they made a dramatic, peaceful switch from Communist dictatorship to democracy. The Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Bulgaria have observer status and Romania and Albania may become observers soon. Tuesday's signing came at the start of a daylong meeting by Council of Europe foreign ministers. During the session, they invited the Soviet Union to sign the council's treaty on cultural exchanges. They also condemned Iraq's detention of hundreds of foreigners since its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. In a statement, the ministers ``agreed that unity of action would present the best chances for the unconditional release of all the hostages.'' The declaration was an implicit criticism of European politicians who have traveled to Baghdad to win freedom for their fellow citizens. The Council of Europe has produced 130 international treaties. It is best known for the European Human Rights Convention and European Court of Human Rights, whose rulings are binding on council members. Hungary applied for council membership a year ago, when reform Communists were still in power. A government dominated by the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum was formed last summer after the first free multiparty elections in four decades. The council is seeking to increase its influence in human rights issues and possibly develop a parliament bringing together the United States, Europe and the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Nighttime Curfew Ordered in Black Township
DOC.TEXT: The law and order minister imposed a nighttime curfew Tuesday in the black township of Bekkersdal, where violence sparked by students protesting school conditions has killed up to 25 people. The 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew confined thousands of blacks to their homes, and police were given wider powers to control disturbances. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok said the extra security measures were necessary following destruction of property and violence that began Thursday. He did not say how long the curfew would be in effect. One of those 25 people to have died in Bekkersdal, outside Johannesburg, occurred Monday when a man was shot by soldiers. Police said the troops opened fire when the man came at them with a knife. Most of the deaths are believed linked to a feud between student groups who disagree on whether to boycott year-end standardized school exams. Many black students demand boycotts of the tests to protest conditions in black schools. Police say the violence began when those students tried to prevent others from taking the tests. Schools have been empty this week, many workers have stayed home, businesses have been closed and some families have fled the area in search of safety. Police patrolled the township Tuesday following clashes the previous day that left seven people injured and houses in flames. Authorities said they confiscated two AK-47 assault rifles from the house of a man who belongs to the Pan Africanist Congress, a black opposition group. No new violence was reported Tuesday, and police did not have a breakdown for which days the deaths had occurred. The year-end school tests determine whether students advance to the next grade or gain admission to universities. Last year, 42 percent of black high school seniors nationwide passed the final exam, compared to a pass rate of more than 95 percent for white students. Many blacks blame the disparity on the white-led government, which spends about five times as much to educate a white pupil as a black pupil. More than 800 blacks have died since August in factional fighting in the black townships around Johannesburg. Most of the battles have been between supporters of the African National Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party, the two largest black opposition groups.

DOC.HEAD: 108 Hostages Promised Freedom; Baker Seeks Military Commitments
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further comment from Chinese foreign minister, ADD Kuwaiti allegation that Jordan shipping food to Iraq; EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2, TOK10
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Tuesday promised to free 108 hostages, none of them American, and insisted anew its foreign ``guests'' are well-treated. Secretary of State James A. Baker III pressed U.S. allies about their willingness to go to war. The Baghdad government was keeping an eye on Tuesday's midterm elections in the United States. It claimed any slippage in Republican support would reflect a lack of public support for President Bush's Persian Gulf policies. ``The American people will ... ask him why he is sending their sons to be killed in the Arab desert and he will reap the fruits of his mistake,'' said Iraqi Information Minister Latif Jassim. In the latest hostage releases, Iraq's official news agency said 77 Japanese nationals would be freed in response to an appeal from former Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. It also said 20 Italians, five Swedes, two Germans, two Portuguese and two Australians would be allowed to leave. It did not say when the captives would be freed, but some had already begun to assemble at a Baghdad hotel. They were among thousands of foreigners trapped when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Some had been held at strategic sites as ``human shields'' against attack. Iraq has since freed hundreds of captives, but Western governments have expressed growing fears that Iraq's Saddam Hussein is successfully using the hostages to divide the alliance facing him. Baker, meanwhile, was seeking to strengthen the anti-Iraq coalition. He is in the Mideast to assess support for stronger steps against Iraq, including a possible military strike. He met Tuesday in Cairo with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, but there was no immediate word on the outcome. Egypt has sent thousands of troops to join the multinational force assembled in the gulf. U.S. troops make up the bulk of the force, which numbers about 300,000. The Pentagon said Tuesday the U.S. troop deployment in the region had reached 230,000 and was still growing. In a sign of the escalating U.S. military commitment, the Marine Corps said it was calling up more than 600 reservists from eight states for combat roles. Up until now, the more than 34,000 reservists called to active duty have served in support roles. While in Egypt, Baker also met with China's foreign minister, Qian Qichen. China is a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, and its support would be needed for a U.N.-sanctioned military strike against Saddam. Qian did not explicitly approve sending troops into action - ``we'll still have to wait and see,'' he said. But U.S. officials said on condition of anonymity that his comments were an indication at the very least the Beijing government would not veto a U.N. resolution to authorize the use of force to liberate Kuwait. PLO chairman Yasser Arafat, who has tried to act as a mediator in the gulf crisis, said prospects for peace are improving as the world considers the consequences of an all-out conflict. ``War will be disastrous and catastrophic. This is the world's oil center. Just imagine what a disaster and a catastrophe it will be,'' Arafat told reporters in Baghdad. Saudi Arabia's foreign minister, however, reminded Iraq on Tuesday that the United Nations has not restricted the use of military force to liberate Kuwait. ``We would like a peaceful settlement, but that option is in the hands of the Iraqis,'' said the foreign minister, Prince Saud. Kuwait accused Jordan of breaking U.N. economic sanctions by trucking food across the border into Iraq. Mohammad Abu Al-Hassan, Kuwait's ambassador to the United Nations, said at a news conference in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, that Jordan it could face the same sanctions as Iraq if it failed to halt shipments of forbidden goods. At the United Nations, four non-aligned members of the Security Council drafted a plan calling for the simultaneous withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and foreign military forces from the region. The measure, sponsored by Colombia, Cuba, Malaysia and Yemen, was given little chance of passage. Iraq's freeing of its Japanese hostages comes as Japanese lawmakers are considering a plan to send troops to the gulf in non-combat roles. However, the measure has prompted strong protests in Japan and its prospects for approval look dim. Japan said it had not altered its gulf policy in order to win the hostages' freedom. Despite the European Community's disapproval of individual hostage-freeing missions, such trips are becoming increasingly common. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt met Tuesday in Baghdad with German hostages, and was to meet Saddam on Wednesday. Former Danish Prime Minister Anker Jorgensen arrived in Jordan and planned to travel on to Iraq when he obtained a visa, and former New Zealand Prime Minister David Lange was reported en route to the gulf. Last weekend, Belgium's foreign minister, Mark Eyskens, criticized ``Western pilgrims'' for courting Saddam in an effort to free their citizens. Iraq has been expressing fears that the United States will use the hostages as a reason for a military strike. On Tuesday, it offered its latest assurances that the ``guests,'' as it calls the captives, are being well treated. The official Iraqi News Agency quoted an unidentifed Trade Ministry spokesman as saying the detained foreigners held ``are receiving the same (supplies) as Iraqis.'' A day earlier, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher had said reports indicated many detainees were losing weight and eating poorly. Also, the Red Cross said Iraqi officials have agreed to allow Americans held at strategic sites to send messages home to their families.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with magnitude upgraded and tsunami ruled out. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Moderate to...'
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake struck west of the Aleutian Islands on Tuesday. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The quake, which hit at 11:14 a.m., measured 6.9 on the Richter scale, said Bob Hammond of the Alaska Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer. It was centered about 150 miles west of Attu Island, about 1,250 miles southwest of Anchorage. The earthquake was felt at Shemya Air Force Base, near Attu in the sparsely populated Aleutian chain, but was not large enough to generate a tidal wave, also called a tsunami, officials said. Moderate to strong earthquakes are commonplace throughout Alaska. The 1964 Good Friday earthquake, centered in Prince William Sound, measured 8.5 on the Richter scale. It generated large waves that devasted several coastal communities, and killed 114 people as far south as Oregon and Hawaii. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 6 on Richter scale can cause severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Governor of Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: The former governor of Rhodesia, Sir Humphrey Gibbs, who vigorously opposed the white minority government's declaration of independence, has died, his family said Tuesday. He was 87. Gibbs died Monday from influenza complications, family members said. Gibbs, born in London, settled in the former British colony as a farmer in 1928. Appointed governor by Queen Elizabeth II in 1959, he served for 10 years, the last four as a recluse in Government House after he tried unsuccessfully to fire the Cabinet of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith over the independence rebellion against the British Crown. Gibbs steadfastly supported Britain's contention that the 1965 declaration to entrench white rule was illegal. Smith retaliated by appointing his own representative to the Queen, ordered the media to stop referring to Gibbs as governor and cut off electricity, water and telephones to Government House. But Smith did not eject the defiant governor, evidently fearing retribution from Britain if the rebellion failed.
