The Cabinet, meanwhile, continued to pledge loyalty to the British monarch until 1969, when it decided to transform Rhodesia into a republic. Gibbs resigned his post, returned briefly to a hero's welcome in Britain and then retired to his 6,500-acre farm in Rhodesia where he lived alone. Smith's so-called officer administering the government, Clifford Dupont, moved into Government House but was never recognized by the British government or the Queen. Gibbs was a guest of honor when Robert Mugabe led Rhodesia to independence as Zimbabwe in 1980 after waging a seven-year guerrilla war. Funeral arrangements were incomplete and a list of survivors was not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Britain's Thatcher Moves Up Date for Party Leadership Vote
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Tuesday moved forward the annual vote for her Conservative Party's leadership, giving her foes only eight days to mount a challenge to displace her as prime minister. The sudden resignation Thursday of Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe underlined divisions within the governing party and prompted speculation that a challenger might try to oust Mrs. Thatcher in the annual party election. The leader of the Conservatives - the party with the majority in Parliament - automatically becomes prime minister. Under party rules the leadership election could have been held as late as Dec. 5 - four weeks after the opening of Parliament. But Mrs. Thatcher on Tuesday approved Nov. 8 as the date of the opening of nominations, Nov. 15 for the closing of nominations and Nov. 20 as the election day, sharply reducing the time for a challenge to be organized. Last year, a challenge by Sir Anthony Meyer, who was thought to have no real chance to win, was the first since Mrs. Thatcher became party leader in 1975. Meyer won 30 votes to Mrs. Thatcher's 314. Mrs. Thatcher must call the next general election by mid-1992. In Glasgow, Scotland, the Confederation of British Industry, the main employers' organization, warned earlier Tuesday that the embattled government risked losing power through divisions over Britain's role in Europe. ``This conference has a message to our friends in the government,'' director-general John Banham told the confederation's annual meeting. ``... Before it is too late, remember what every single person in this hall knows: a board that is divided is ripe for takeover.'' The Conservative Party is funded largely by big business, including members of the confederation. Her robust rejection, at an Oct. 26 European Community summit, of plans for political and economic union has split the Thatcher government, which was already in deep economic trouble. Opinion polls indicate the government is 12 to 21 points behind the opposition Labor Party, which is funded by labor unions and feared by big business. Banham, whose organization reported last month that British industry is now in recession, said failure to control inflation - now running at 10.9 percent -was the major disappointment of the 1980s. The confederation supports the British government idea of a European Community currency and the 12 currencies of member states circulating simultaneously. The idea has been rejected by the 11 other EC countries that agreed at the last summit to set up a single central bank by 1994 and possibly introduce one currency by 1997. ``We must be seen to be part of the new Europe,'' Banham said in his keynote address. ``Isolation uld be a catastrophe for British business.''

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Wins Re-Election Over Mitchell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in penultimate graf.
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Carroll Campbell on Tuesday defeated Democrat Theo Mitchell, who had sought to become South Carolina's first black governor. Another South Carolina Republican, U.S. Sen. Strom Thurmond, turned back token opposition from Democrat Robert Cunningham, an ex-CIA agent who apparently made no effort to campaign. Thurmond is the nation's oldest and longest-serving member of Congress. With 1 percent of precincts reporting, Campbell had 1,777 votes, or 67 percent, to 858 votes, or 33 percent, for Mitchell. With 1 percent of precincts reporting in the Senate race, Thurmond had 1,818 votes, or 66 percent, to 929 votes, or 34 percent, for Cunningham. South Carolina's U.S. House delegation, with four Democrats and two Republicans, all sought re-election. Four had opposition but none of the challengers could dent the power of incumbency. Mitchell's campaign got little support from the state's predominantly white Democratic leadership. Party officials complained Mitchell, a state senator from Greenville, knew little about running a statewide campaign. Mitchell lost a chance to debate Campbell when he lashed out at black supporters of the governor by calling them ``house niggers,'' ``Uncle Toms'' and ``black prostitutes.'' Campbell and some Democrats called on Mitchell to apologize. Mitchell refused, and Campbell declared he would not appear at the debate.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Gets a ``Low B'' in Outside Rating
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 11th graf: ``In addition,'' to CORRECT 81.61 to 80.61, conforming to 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: The Postal Service delivered about four-fifths of overnight mail on time in its first test by an outside consultant, a performance the postmaster general said Tuesday earns the agency a ``low B.'' Mail intended for overnight delivery arrived on time 80.61 percent of the time during a three-month test period that ended in mid-September, the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse reported. ``About as low a B as you can get, that's how I would characterize it,'' Postmaster General Anthony Frank said following the monthly meeting of the service's board of governors. While the national rating was just over 80 percent, performance varied widely from place to place with larger cities such as New York ``dragging down'' the average. Overnight delivery of mail destined for the Big Apple was on time just 46.94 percent of the time, the lowest share anywhere in the 50 states. Top rated for overnight mail was Kansas City, Mo., with 94.06 percent of overnight mail arriving on time. In addition to the performance figures, Frank said that the postal rate increase scheduled for next year, including a 30-cent stamp, is tentatively scheduled for Feb. 3. While the recent budget settlement signed by President Bush will cost the Postal Service $4.7 billion over five years, Frank said he hopes not to have to raise rates again until 1994 or 1995. Previously he had said he did not expect another rate hike until 1996, but the cost of the budget settlement will mean ``more, sooner'' as far as rates go, he said. Price Waterhouse conducted the delivery test by mailing 425,000 pieces of mail to 5,000 recipients in 286 ZIP codes across the country. The mail included letters, post cards and large flat envelopes, some with typed addresses and some hand written. In addition to the 80.61 percent performance for overnight mail, 74.38 percent of items intended for second day delivery arrived on time, and mail designated for three-day service was on time 81.11 percent of the time. Overnight, second and three-day service depend on distance the mail has to travel. A small share of mail took four, five or more days to arrive - an outcome that clearly annoyed the postmaster general. ``Maybe you can make a case for being a day late ... but you can't make one for being two, three or four days late,'' Frank said, promising an attack on that problem area. The postal service's Southern region was tops in overnight delivery at 84.02 percent on time, followed by the Eastern region at 83.83 percent. The West finished third at 81.39 percent followed by the Central region at 79.62 percent and the Northeast at 71.12 percent. Here is a rundown of the percentage of overnight mail delivered on time in major cities listed by the postal service: Albany, N.Y., 87.10; Albuquerque, N.M., 89.98; Alhambra, Calif., 80.67; Atlanta, 81.05; Austin, Texas, 88.27; Baltimore, 76.68; Birmingham, Ala., 89.51; Boston, 74.17; Brooklyn, N.Y.,71.91; Buffalo, N.Y., 86.58; Charleston, W. Va., 92.66; Charlotte, N.C., 86.34; Chicago, 72.96; Chicago North Suburban, 70.66; Chicago South Suburban, 50.79; Cincinnati, 86.09; Cleveland, 80.56; Columbia, S.C., 89.88; Columbus, Ohio, 93.26; Dallas, 84.93; Denver, 80.45; Des Moines, 92.44; Detroit, 78.66; Fort Worth, 91.30; Grand Rapids, Mich., 91.56; Greensboro, N.C., 93.03; Harrisburg, Pa., 83.69; Hartford, Conn., 72.58; Hicksville, N.Y., 66.96; Honolulu, 92.72; Houston, 75.61; Indianapolis, 89.12; Inglewood, Calif., 78.15; Jackson, Miss., 82.02; Jacksonville, Fla., 90.92; Kansas City, 94.06; Little Rock, Ark., 87.67; Long Beach, Calif., 74.98; Los Angeles, 70.29; Louisville, 93.40; Manchester, N.H., 86.47; Memphis, Tenn., 71.25; Miami, 80.41; Milwaukee, 77.33; Minneapolis, 87.39; Nashville, 91.18; New Brunswick, N.J., 85.10; New Orleans, 80.45; New York, 46.94; Newark, N.J., 76.75; Northern Virginia, 71.29; Oakland, Calif., 87.70; Oklahoma City, 86.42; Omaha, Neb., 92.64; Philadelphia, 76.74; Phoenix, 76.06; Pittsburgh, 90.06; Portland, Ore., 86.81; Providence, R.I., 87.91; Queens, N.Y., 66.07; Richmond, Va., 86.93; Royal Oak, Mich., 80.87; Sacramento, Calif., 83.38; St. Louis, 88.28; St. Paul, Minn., 90.42; Salt Lake City, 90.72; San Antonio, Texas, 86.62; San Diego, Calif., 80.47; San Francisco, 82.95; San Jose, Calif., 88.47; Santa Ana, Calif., 81.03; Seattle, 89.02; South New Jersey, 81.50; Southeastern Pennsylvania, 88.26; Southern Maryland, 83.35; Springfield, Mass., 81.33; Tampa, Fla., 86.71; Tucson, Ariz., 84.93; Tulsa, Okla., 84.54; Washington, 81.90; Westchester, N.Y., 77.59; Wichita, Kan., 84.84; Van Nuys, Calif., 74.50.

DOC.HEAD: Theologian Confesses to `Sin' of Apartheid Before Church Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A leading theologian from the Dutch Reformed Church confessed to the sin of apartheid Tuesday, an unusual public statement from a member of the church that long supported the racist policy. The statement, made at a conference of South African church leaders, was not an official church confession. But the theologian, Willie Jonker, said he felt he could speak for himself as well as the Dutch Reformed Church. Jonker went before conference delegates and said, ``I confess before you and before the Lord, not only my sin and guilt and my personal responsibility and structural wrongs that have been done to many of you ... but vicariously I dare also to do that in the name of the (Dutch Reformed Church) of which I am a member.'' The Dutch Reformed Church is the main church of the Afrikaners, the Dutch-descended whites who dominate the government. It has branches for whites, blacks and people of mixed race and has been isolated in South Africa for its support of segregation. The black and mixed-race branches oppose apartheid. The white branch has backed off its argument of past decades that the Bible supports apartheid, but it has not confessed to the sin of apartheid. It also has not moved to merge with the other church branches. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu accepted Jonker's confession. ``The confession is not cheaply made, and my response is not cheaply made,'' he told applauding delegates. Nearly 300 delegates from about 90 churches are attending the conference at Rustenburg, 62 miles northwest of Johannesburg. The meeting has brought together churches long divided by apartheid that now hope to reach agreement on the role of the church in a future South Africa. Two small churches that support apartheid, the Afrikaans Protestant Church and the Reformed Church, declined to attend.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Host Says Kahane Feared Jews, Not Arabs
With AM-Kahane Shot, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A day before his assassination, Rabbi Meir Kahane said he feared he would be killed by a Jew, not an Arab, a Miami radio host said Tuesday. Danny Tadmore had Kahane as a guest on his ``Voice of Israel'' program on radio station WVCG on Sunday. After an on-the-air interview, Tadmore said he asked Kahane if he wasn't afraid to walk around without bodyguards. ``He said, `I don't have a problem with the Arabs, I have a problem with the Jews,''' Tadmore said. ```And if somebody's ever going to kill me, it's going to be a Jew, not an Arab.''' ``Of course, he was wrong,'' Tadmore added. ``He was killed by an Arab.'' Kahane was shot to death in a New York hotel on Monday night. Police identified the assailant as El-Sayyid A. Nosair, 35, an Egyptian immigrant who took U.S. citizenship last year. Nosair, who was shot in the neck, was in critical condition Tuesday night. Tadmore said Kahane was fatalistic about the possibility of assassination. ``If you're a religious Jew, everything is preordained,'' Tadmore said. ``Let it come.'' Tadmore said he interviewed Kahane about conditions in Israel for an hour and 15 minutes, and afterward, Kahane hugged him ``and he didn't let go, as if he knew something was coming.''

DOC.HEAD: Justice Names Management Task Force
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department on Tuesday appointed a task force to improve management in the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The service was the subject of a highly critical department audit in March 1989 that described the agency as overwhelmed by sloppy accounting, poor management and the demands of recent legislation. The General Accounting Office, the investigating arm of Congress, also is looking into operations of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. A department announcement said Norman Carlson, who headed the department's Bureau of Prisons for 17 years, would head the new group. He will be joined by Tony Moscato, deputy assistant attorney general for administration; Don Wortman, director of federal programs for the National Academy of Public Administration and a former executive with the Social Security Administration and the Central Intelligence Agency, and others. ``With the passage of the landmark Immigration Act of 1990 it is important that INS be in a stronger position to fulfill its new mandate,'' Attorney General Dick thornburgh said in a statement. The congressional session just ended saw passage into law of a bill establishing major increases in immigration quotas.

DOC.HEAD: Peacetime Army Healthy Alternative to Civilian Life, Study Suggests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, ``Women in...'' to express relationship of death rates in percentages and UPDATE with detail on accidents. Figures `39 percent' and `139 percent' in 7th graf are cq. Pickup 8th graf pvs, `There are...'
DOC.TEXT: The peacetime Army is a healthy alternative to civilian life, say military researchers who found that soldiers in 1986 died at half the rate of their civilian counterparts. But one professor says choosing a year of peace for such a study may obscure the realities of serving a nation that goes to war about once a decade. Army researchers compared death rates among all 781,000 soldiers to civilian counterparts of the same age, race and sex in 1986. The study published in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association did not give actual death rates. However, the lead researcher said in a telephone interview that soldiers overall died at a rate of 109 per 100,000, while comparable civilians died at a rate of 215 per 100,000. The greatest disparity was for homicides, almost six times less common among soldiers than civilians, followed by smaller Army rates of deaths cause by disease and suicide, the researchers reported. The most striking difference was among black men, who died in homicides almost 12 times less often in the Army than in the population at large. The homicide rate among black soldiers was 9 per 100,000, compared with 100 per 100,000 for black civilians, said lead author Joseph M. Rothberg, a mathematician in military psychiatry at Walter Reed Army Institute of Research. Women in the Army, who comprised 10.2 percent of soldiers, died at 78 percent the rate of civilian women of the same age. Black women soldiers died at 39 percent the rate of comparable civilians. But white women soldiers died at 139 percent the rate of white women civilians of the same age. A large component of the elevated death rate among white Army women was due to their suffering more than 2{ times as many fatal accidents as civilian women the same age, but the researchers could not say why. ``There are a number of factors that determine the probability of death for any individual, and they're different for the Army than for civilian life,'' said Rothberg. Most important is the screening of Army volunteers, who must have high school degrees and are healthy enough to pass a physical exam, Rothberg said in a telephone interview Tuesday from Bethesda, Md. He also said the Army provides housing, food, meaningful work and ``lots of fresh air and exercise.'' It controls substance abuse and regulates firearms, he said. ``Everybody's told how to live their life and how to stay healthy. In civilian life, it's the individual's option,'' he said. Sam Sarkesian, a political science professor at Loyola University in Chicago, said he believed the study could give a skewed picture because it reflects peacetime mortality. Yet, he noted, ``we've been involved in a war virtually every 10 years since the end of World War II.'' Even in non-war years, members of the military die violently, such as in the 1983 Beirut bombing, when 237 Marines were killed; in the 1985 Gander, Newfoundland, airplane crash, when 248 died; and in the 1989 Panama invasion, when 23 lost their lives. ``From 1945 on, if you'd put all those together and compare it to the equivalent in civilian life, I think you'd get a totally different picture,'' Sarkesian said. But Charles Moskos, a sociology professor at Northwestern University in Evanston, said: ``Most of military life is peacetime. A peace year is more normal than a war year.'' Still, ``It's a sad commentary on America when military service is healthier for black youths than civilian life,'' said Moskos, head of an international group of 600 military social scientists.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell withstood a ripple of anti-incumbent sentiment and gained a second term Tuesday, defeating Democrat challenger Harvey Sloane, the former mayor of Louisville.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Voters Re-lect John Warner to U.S. Senate
DOC.TEXT: Republican U.S. Sen. John W. Warner won re-election to a third term Tuesday in a bid that was virtually unopposed. His only challenger was independent Nancy Spannaus, an associate of political extremist Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. With 6 percent of precincts reporting, Warner had 53,959 votes, or 80 percent, to 13,073 votes, or 20 percent, for Spannaus. LaRouche was on the ballot as well, running for Congress in the suburban 10th District. LaRouche, who is serving a 15-year prison sentence for fraud, was among three candidates trying to unseat Republican Rep. Frank Wolf.

DOC.HEAD: Mayoral Candidate Slain in Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: The mayor of an eastern town was shot to death at his re-election campaign headquarters, and the Interior Ministry blamed a domestic dispute. Police said Roberto Antonio Bonilla, 52, was killed by two assailants on Monday night in Jalapa, 63 miles east of Guatemala City. Jalapa is one of about 300 towns that will hold mayoral and city council elections on Sunday. Voters also will elect a president, vice president, 116 members of congress and 20 Central American Parliament deputies. A security guard shot one of Bonilla's killers to death, and officers were looking for the other one, police said in a telephone interview. There has been other election violence, but Interior Minister Gen. Carlos Morales Villatoro said there was no political motive behind Bonilla's killing. ``In accordance with investigations, it was determined that (Bonilla) was slain by a person who was to have married his daughter,'' Morales Villatoro said in a statement Tuesday night. ``Consequently, this crime was strictly due to family problems and there is nothing political in it.'' The statement did not give the killer's name. Bonilla is the second mayoral candidate killed since the campaign began. Also, two Central American Parliament candidates were attacked on Oct. 18, two other political party activists were slain earlier and one federal deputy was assassinated. Bonilla was elected in 1985 on the National Center Union ticket. This year he was running as the candidate of the center-left Christian Democrats and the Revolutionary Party. Twelve candidates are in the running for the presidency, including publisher Jorge Carpio Nicolle, who is favored in opinion polls. Carpio founded the National Center Union party seven years ago and lost a runoff against Christian Democrat President Vinicio Cerezo in 1985. Alfonso Cabrera Hidalgo, the Christian Democratic candidate, has been in a hospital in Houston for three days with pancreas trouble. A runoff is scheduled for Jan. 6 if none of the 12 candidates gets more than 50 percent of the vote. Former dictator Gen. Efrain Rios Montt ran unsuccessfuly for president on the Christian Democrat ticket in 1974, and was disqualified from candidacy this year because he took power through a 1982 military coup.

DOC.HEAD: Group Calls for Overthrowing Saudi Kings
DOC.TEXT: A previously unknown group on Wednesday called for the overthrow of Saudi Arabia's ruling family and the creation of a democratic system that would not need foreign forces to protect it. The group called the National Revolution and Struggle Front in the Arab Peninsula sent a four-page manifesto by fax outlining its demands to The Associated Press in Nicosia. The group gave little information about itself. It said only that it was based in the Arab peninsula. The line indicating where the fax originated was scratched out on every page. The statement's lack of specific detail and the wording of some of its demands indicated that it might be Iraqi propaganda. The group said the Al-Saud family, which has ruled Saudi Arabia since King Abdul Aziz ibn Saud unified the kingdom in 1932, should be replaced by a constitutional democracy and the country be renamed the Arab Peninsula. Citizens should be guaranteed the right to form trade unions and political organizations, and there should be free speech and a free press, the statement said. None of these is allowed in Saudi Arabia now. The statement demanded that foreign troops in Saudi Arabia be sent home and that the country pursue a policy of non-alignment. More than 250,000 troops, most of them American, have been sent to the country since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The group said it wanted to reinforce links with the Arab world and give greater support to the Palestinian cause. The wealth from the Saudi oil industry should be invested in national agricultural and industrial projects less connected to foreign powers, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Non-Aligned States Offer U.N. Persian Gulf `Peace Plan'
DOC.TEXT: Four non-aligned members of the Security Council drafted a plan Tuesday urging simultaneous withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait and of foreign military units from the region. The conciliatory proposal was given little chance of passage in the 15-member council but will prolong negotiations over an expected U.S.-backed measure to distribute Iraqi assets now frozen to victims of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The four sponsors - Colombia, Cuba, Malaysia and Yemen - met with General Assembly members in hopes of attracting dozens of endorsements that could be used to try to pressure reluctant Security Council members. The plan came as U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III visited the Middle East, seeking support for stronger U.N. action. Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen met Baker in Egypt Tuesday and signaled China's willingness to go along with a U.N. resolution to authorize the use of force to liberate Kuwait, U.S. officials said. China is one of the Security Council's five permanent members and can veto a council decision. The council has passed 10 anti-Iraq resolutions since Kuwait was invaded, including measures to establish a trade embargo and establish an air and sea blockade to enforce it. A multinational force of about 300,000 troops has been arrayed against Iraq following the invasion, including about 230,000 U.S. servicemen. Tuesday's proposal asks establishment of an all-Arab U.N. peacekeeping force to maintain order in Kuwait after ``the simultaneous withdrawal of all foreign armed forces from the region.'' It demands immediate Iraqi withdrawal from the emirate and says all previous U.N. sanctions on Baghdad would then be lifted. It says damage claims would then be heard before the World Court. The resolution urges ``prompt compliance with other outstanding Security Council resolutions, including those relating to the conflict in the Middle East, in particular, the Palestinian question.'' Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has tried to link the Kuwait issue with Israeli withdrawal from the Gaza Strip and West Bank, which Israel captured in the 1967 Middle East war. The United States and other Western nations say Iraq should pull out first, without conditions. Western diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they would press on with a harsher resolution against Iraq. One source expects a U.S. proposal ``within two or three days'' to attach frozen Iraqi assets. The Security Council also is expected to take up the issue of the Israeli-occupied territories and how to safeguard Palestinians there. The Palestine Liberation Organization is proposing that the Security Council send unarmed U.N. observers to the territories, but Israel has rejected the idea. The council was scheduled to meet Wednesday on the PLO proposal. New violence in the Gaza Strip has dramatized the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Lesotho Government Declares King Dethroned
DOC.TEXT: Lesotho's military ruler declared exiled King Moshoeshoe II officially dethroned Tuesday and stripped him of his title of head of state. Maj. Gen. Justin Lekhanya, head of the ruling military council, said he was retracting an Oct. 24 invitation for Moshoeshoe to return from exile in London. Moshoeshoe set unacceptable conditions for his return, including dissolution of the present government, Lekhanya told the National Constituent Assembly. ``The king has been a problem for Lesotho for the past 25 years, and the nation would be relieved at his dethronement,'' Lekhanya said. Moshoeshoe was forced into exile in March following disagreements with Lekhanya, who came to power in a 1986 coup that ousted Prime Minister Leabua Jonathan. Lekhanya's six-member military council gave the king some executive and legislative authority, but in February Lekhanya fired from the military council and government most supporters of the monarch. When Moshoeshoe refused to approve replacements, Lekhanya told the king to leave the country. When he issued the invitation for Moshoeshoe to return, Lekhanya said the two had held ``warm and constructive discussions'' in Britain and settled their differences. Sources close to the government said the king had agreed to accept a role as constitutional monarch with no executive power. In Tuesday's announcement, Lekhanya said that when the king imposed conditions for his return, the military council decided to strip him of all powers. Lekhanya did not say when a replacement would be named, but it was expected to be Moshoeshoe's eldest son, Prince Mohato. He is in Lesotho. Lesotho, a small landlocked country surrounded by South Africa, gained independence from Britain in 1966. Lekhanya has promised a new constitution and a return to civilian rule by 1992.

DOC.HEAD: McConnell Turns Back Sloane For Senate, Proves Wrong Anti-Incumbent Theory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting to fix category code
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Mitch McConnell on Tuesday turned back Democrat Harvey Sloane, who had hoped a ripple of anti-incumbent sentiment would grow into a wave and wash his opponent out of office after a single term. With 81 percent of precincts reporting, McConnell had 383,710 votes, or 53 percent, to 345,710, or 47 percent, for Sloane. Heading into the election, Sloane didn't appear to have benefitted much from voter anger against Congress, and McConnell was favored to win a second term. In polls conducted by The (Louisville) Courier-Journal, McConnell's support eroded from 53 percent to 44 percent between September and late October. But Sloane's support stayed relatively constant at 33 percent in September and 34 percent in October, and undecided voters grew from 14 percent to 22 percent. Sloane, a non-practicing physician and former Louisville mayor, had a relatively meager campaign bank of about $2 million to finance commercial attacks on McConnell and so began using increasingly harsh language in his appearances. At times, Sloane called McConnell a liar, sham and hypocrite. McConnell responded with an advertising blitz paid for with more than $5 million in campaign funds that depicted Sloane as a free-spending liberal who couldn't manage government when he was a mayor and county executive. All four Democrats in Kentucky's congressional delegation had opponents. Only one of the three Republican congressmen had opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Man Taking Driving Test Crashes Through DMV Office, Six Minor Injuries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with driver's name, accident details; CORRECTS his age to 72, sted 70. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A man taking a driving test crashed into a Department of Motor Vehicles office Tuesday. Dozens of people scattered for safety as the car plowed 30 feet inside. Six minor injuries were reported, and damage to the office was extensive, authorities said. John A. Anderson, 72, was behind the whevrolet El Camino and preparing to take a road test when the pickup suddenly lurched forward and crashed into the building, saiel of a 1980 Ched California State Police Capt. Howard Hughie. ``He told us the accelerator stuck, causing him to lose control and smash through the wall and into the building,'' Hughie said. Two people were treated at the scene for minor injuries and four were examined at a hospital. The driver wasn't injured in the morning crash that caused an estimated $40,000 damage to the office in suburban Canoga Park. The office was to remain closed several days for repairs.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Boycott Schools, Turn Out at Polls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: JoAn Moye and Tee S. Greer are cq.
DOC.TEXT: Dade County blacks, including students, teachers and bus drivers, boycotted schools Tuesday as a protest against what community leaders call a series of racist affronts. Boycott leaders encouraged participants to use their time to vote, and turnout at the polls soared in black neighborhoods. Many predominantly black schools in the nation's fourth-largest district had only 20 or 30 percent attendance. And 72 percent of the school bus drivers stayed home, creating long delays for students who did not boycott, district spokeswoman JoAn Moye said. Even teachers who did not honor the boycott wore black ribbons showing support for the action. ``I think it's having a tremendous effect,'' said the Rev. Victor Curry, whose church held a teach-in for boycotting students and teachers. ``All across the county, we are hearing that teachers are not reporting to school, as well as bus drivers and students.'' James Fleming, associate superintendent of schools, confirmed that large numbers of black students and teachers joined the boycott. Blacks account for 33 percent of Dade's students, and district absenteeism on Tuesday was 30 percent. He said 2,500 teachers also honored the boycott, along with the district's bus drivers, most of whom are black. ``It totally crippled the transportation system,'' Fleming said. ``But we can understand and empathize with the frustration people must feel and their need to express that.'' About 1,000 protesters carrying signs reading ``Stop Racism Now'' and ``Keep the Pressure On'' showed up for a noon rally in front of school district headquarters. Dade County elections officials reported that, based on initial voting patterns Tuesday morning, projected black turnout was 80 to 90 percent, in contrast to the countywide figure of 67 percent. The black turnout raised Dade's total projected turnout from a 59 percent initial estimate to almost 64 percent, said David Leahy, elections supervisor. The boycott was touched off by last month's appointment of Octavio Visiedo, a Cuban-American, as schools superintendent. Black leaders had supported Tee S. Greer, a black administrator who had previously acted as interim superintendent. They complained that Greer not only had more experience but, unlike Visiedo, has a doctorate. ``This is an issue of racism and the time has come to face it,'' said the Rev. Richard Dunn, a boycott organizer. School board members would speak only in general terms about their reason for choosing Visiedo, who has overseen a massive building program for the district. ``He does address the needs of the whole community,'' school board member and Visiedo-backer Betsy Kaplan said. The school district did not condemn the boycott, saying only that the staff was working to take care of the students who attended classes. ``We're going to cope with it,'' Ms. Moye said. Dunn said Visiedo's appointment was only the latest in a series of incidents, including the snub of South African anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela by the county's Cuban-American mayors in June, and violent police repression of a black demonstration outside a store after a fight between a Haitian customer and the shop's Cuban owner. Tuesday's school boycott received wide support from parents and students. ``I don't like what they did, so I decided not to come to school,'' said Joseph Small, a student at Edison High. ``I told my father, and he approved it.''

DOC.HEAD: Truck Broadsides Car, Killing Five Passengers
DOC.TEXT: A car apparently ran a stop sign and was broadsided by a tractor-trailer truck Tuesday, killing five members of a family, authorities said. A Morrisville woman, her daughter-in-law and three of the younger woman's four children were killed, the Polk County Coroner's office said. The younger woman's husband and their 4-year-old son were injured. Polk County Coroner Sidney Pitts identified the dead as driver Alline Schnick, 65; passenger Sharon Schnick, 45, and the children, Katrina Schnick, 19 months; Jennifer Schnick, 5; and Kimberly Ducker, 9. Gary Schnick, 42, was in critical condition and his son, Joshua, was in serious condition at a hospital Tuesday. The truck driver and his passenger were not injured in the 7:30 a.m. accident at Missouri highways 13 and 215, about 15 miles north of Springfield, a highway patrol spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: Austria Scraps Two Provisions of State Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The government on Tuesday declared obsolete two provisions of the 1955 state treaty that gave Austria its postwar independence following 10 years of occupation by the four World War II Allies. The move could signal a revision of Austria's neutral status, which is hindering Austrian attempts to become a full member of the European Community. The provisions ban the purchase of missiles, German-made armaments and German civilian planes and restrict the restitution to German citizens of property held by Nazi Germany in Austria. The state treaty was signed on May 15, 1955 after arduous negotiations with Moscow. It provided for withdrawal of Soviet and all Allied troops. Five months later, as part of a tacit agreement with the Kremlin, Austria enacted a law guaranteeing this nation's permanent neutrality. Neutral status has come increasingly into question with the unification of neighboring Germany and the collapse of Communist rule in Eastern Europe. Leaders of the major parties say Austria will cling to its neutrality. But several foreign officials and legal experts argue this would preclude Austria's attempt to join the 12-nation EC. Austria apparently did not seek prior formal approval to cancel the two provisions from the states which signed the 1955 treaty - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. Chancellor Franz Vranitzky said there had been contacts on the issue with the four nations and those governments will be officially informed of the move. The Soviet government said in a memorandum that ``being mindful of the changed situation in Europe'' and contacts with the other allies and Austria, it did not object to the decision, the Soviet news agency Tass reported. When U.S. Ambassador Roy Huffington took up his duties here at the end of September, he said Washington would approve changes in the state treaty following prior consultations with Austria.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Rules Lawyer Must Relinquish Ruby's Gun
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer was removed Tuesday as executor of Jack Ruby's estate, whose major asset is the .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver the Dallas nightclub owner used to kill presidential assassin Lee Harvey Oswald. A six-person jury ruled that Ruby's former attorney, Jules Mayer, grossly mismanaged the estate after Ruby died in 1967. Mayer still practices law at age 82. Dallas County Probate Judge Robert E. Price must now decide how to distribute Ruby's assets. State law mandates that if he upholds the jury's decision, he must appoint a new executor. No hearing date was set. Ruby's brother, Earl, filed the lawsuit, asking to be named executor of the estate. Ruby's heirs and Mayer have wrangled over the estate for 23 years. The gun Ruby used to kill Oswald in the Dallas County Jail two days after President Kennedy's assassination on Nov. 22, 1963, is stowed in a bank safe deposit box. Mayer has said it could bring $125,000 on the collectors' market. Ruby bought the gun for $62.50 in a Dallas gun shop. Mayer wanted proceeds from the gun's sale to pay off Ruby's debts. He said they include the $65,000 it has cost him to handle the estate, including the expense of fighting Earl Ruby's lawsuits. Earl Ruby, of Boca Raton, Fla., who is also acting on behalf of his sister and a nephew, charges that Mayer is trying to profit from the estate. He wants the estate liquidated to pay off his brother's debts and ``wipe the slate clean.'' Ruby was convicted of murder in 1964 and sentenced to die in the electric chair. A Texas appeals court overturned the conviction in 1966, citing reasons that included failure to move the trial from Dallas. Ruby died at age 55 before a new trial could be held.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Favored to Dominate Races
DOC.TEXT: Republican Rep. Bob Smith jumped easily Tuesday into the U.S. Senate seat being abandoned by the downwardly mobile Gordon Humphrey, who left Congress to run for the state Legislature. Smith's Democratic opponent, John Durkin, had based his campaign on charges that Smith was beholden to special interest groups that poured more than $500,000 into his campaign. With 8 percent of precincts reporting, Smith had 17,582 votes, or 65 percent, to Durkin's 9,327 votes, or 35 percent. Republican Gov. Judd Gregg returned to the Statehouse for a second two-year term, fending off Democrat Joe Grandmaison's charges he was incompetent to lead the state out of its economic doldrums. With 8 percent of precincts reporting, Gregg had 16,691 votes or 62 percent, to 10,418, or 38 percent, for Grandmaison. In the bitter Senate contest, Durkin, a U.S. senator from 1975-1980, used tart one-liners to jab Smith, calling him ``Bumbling Bob'' and the ``bag man'' for PACs. Durkin used the term ``Japs'' to accuse a Japanese-made automobile trade PAC of trying to buy Smith the seat with a $350,000 media campaign. He later apologized for the slur, and Smith wrote the PAC and asked it to stop the ads.

DOC.HEAD: Governor McWherter, Senator Gore Bury Weak Opposition in Tennessee
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Ned McWherter and U.S. Sen. Albert Gore buried weak Republican opposition Tuesday in their bids for second terms. Incumbent congressmen also had little competition, including U.S. Rep. Harold Ford, who is under indictment on charges he sold political influence to two crooked bankers. McWherter beat Republican Dwight Henry, a freshman state legislator. Gore, who was a 1988 presidential hopeful, downed Republican William Hawkins, a freelance writer who conducted almost no campaigning. With 29 percent of precincts reporting, McWherter had 134,226 votes, or 63 percent, to 80,225 votes, or 37 percent, for Henry. Also with 29 percent of precincts reporting, Gore had 148,936 votes, or 70 percent, to Hawkins' 62,849 votes, or 30 percent. Republican leaders concentrated their efforts on trying to pick up seats in the Tennessee Legislature, where they are in a minority in both houses.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Paul Simon captured a second term Tuesday, fending off a challenge by Republican Rep. Lynn Martin, whose anti-tax message and late call for limiting the terms of Washington lawmakers failed to dent the popularity of the liberal incumbent.

DOC.HEAD: Schaefer Favored In Race Against Husband-Wife Team
DOC.TEXT: Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer held on to his job Tuesday in his battle with William and Lois Shepard, the Republican husband-and-wife team who ran for governor and lieutenant governor. With 23 percent of precincts reporting, Scheafer had 105,919 votes, or 60 percent, to 69,545 votes, or 40 percent, for Shepard. Schaefer's early strong standing had slipped as Shepard hammered away at the governor as a big spender who had turned a $400 million surplus into a current deficit estimated at up to $300 million. The challenger angered many Republican leaders when he picked his wife as his ticket-mate. He slowly regained much of the party support, but his campaign was crippled by lack of money. Schaefer raised more than $2.3 million and Shepard just over $100,000. All eight incumbent members of Congress - six Democrats and two Republicans - sought re-election. Only Democrat Roy Dyson, locked in a tight battle with Wayne Gilchrest, faced a serious challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Senator Defeats Democratic Challenger
DOC.TEXT: Democratic challenger Joan Finney led Gov. Mike Hayden, who had been only slightly favored to win re-election Tuesday and become the first two-term Republican governor in Kansas in 28 years. Finney, the state treasurer, was bidding to become Kansas' first woman governor. With 8 percent of precincts reporting, Finney had 34,296 votes, or 56 percent, to 26,646 votes, or 44 percent, for Hayden. Hayden and Mrs. Finney had been deadlocked in polls through the final month of the campaign. The incumbent finally edged marginally ahead at the end. U.S. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, daughter of the late Gov. Alf Landon, defeated her Democratic challenger, Dick Williams of Wichita, who teaches English as a second language to college students. With 3 percent of precincts reporting, Kassebaum had 16,197 votes, or 72 percent, to 6,298 votes, or 28 percent, for Williams. Four incumbent U.S. House members also were strong favorites to win re-election, while the 5th District of southeast Kansas was electing a replacement for retiring Republican Rep. Bob Whittaker. Republican Dick Nichols, a banker, was slightly favored over former Democratic state Rep. George Wingert. A Nichols' victory would maintain the 3-2 Republican advantage in the state's U.S. House delegation. Voters also were expected to reject a proposed state constitutional amendment that would restore full control of public education to the Legislature, rather than keeping it vested in independent boards. Hayden, 46, battled a perception that he is mean-spirited, unable to build legislative support for his programs and responsible for large property tax increases. Mrs. Finney, 65, became the first woman nominee of a major party when she defeated former Gov. John Carlin by 1 percentage point in the August Democratic primary.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Lawton Chiles, who said he was ``burned out'' two years ago when he retired from the Senate, scored a stunning comeback Tuesday, ousting Republican Gov. Bob Martinez after a single term.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Mourn Extremist Rabbi at Funeral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to move up background on alleged killer, including comments by former neighbors. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `Thousands of ...' DELETES grafs 20-23, `The suspect ...' to remove extraneous material. Picks up 24th graf, `The postal ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY38, NY33
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of mourners, some vengeful, some crying ``Never again!'', thronged a Brooklyn synagogue Tuesday to bid farewell to the assassinated Meir Kahane and to pledge to carry on the radical rabbi's anti-Arab war. His alleged killer, a Moslem who immigrated from Egypt in 1981 and took U.S. citizenship last year, lay in critical condition in a Manhattan hospital. Police said he had no links with terrorist groups. ``There will be revenge. We believe in revenge,'' said Sol Margolis, president of Kach International, the U.S. arm of Kahane's extremist party, which advocates the ouster of Arabs from Israeli-held territory. Kahane was gunned down Monday night while addressing a Zionist group at a Manhattan hotel. Police said Kahane was taking questions from the crowd when the gunman stopped 4 feet from him and fired a .357-caliber weapon. The Israeli government appealed forpeace as police and army reinforcements spread out in Israel and the occupied territories to head off revenge attacks. The deaths two Arabs on Tuesday were linked to Kahane's slaying. The fear of retribution in New York prompted stepped-up security at the U.N. missions for Israel, Saudi Arabia and Egypt, El Al Israel Airlines offices and several Jewish newspapers, said Police Commissioner Lee Brown. The alleged gunman, a $30,000-a-year city maintenance man, was shot in the neck by a U.S. Postal police officer who spotted him fleeing the hotel. The suspect, identified by city officials as El-Sayyid A. Nosair, 35, of Cliffside Park, N.J., was in critical condition, hospital officials said. He was charged with murder, attempted murder, assault, criminal possession of a weapon and of a defaced weapon, and unlawful imprisonment, police said. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said he believed the gunman acted alone. Nosair had no previous criminal record and no links to any terrorist organizations, Borrelli said. Nosair's wife, Caren, and three children were staying with relatives in Brooklyn. Mrs. Nosair provided no clues about her husband's motives, Borrelli said. Police searched Nosair's apartment. Until four months ago, the family lived in Jersey City, where Nosair's former neighbors described him as a quiet, intellectual man with no involvement in political organizations in the city's 400-strong Moslem community. ``They were just a basic family,'' said Laura-Jean Banks, 36. ``I couldn't believe it was him because he was so quiet.'' Nosair was carrying three New Jersey driver's licenses with different addresses when he was arrested, said Jersey City police Deputy Chief John McAuley. Thousands of people jammed a synagogue in Brooklyn and spilled onto a four-lane highway for the funeral of the 58-year-old Kahane. His body was to be flown to Israel for burial Wednesday. ``It is possible for the heart to well up and cry for the horrible loss our nation has suffered,'' Rabbi Moshe Tendler of Yeshiva University said as thousands cheered outside Young Israel of Ocean Parkway Synagogue. Rabbi Herbert Bomzer, a longtime friend and leader of the synagogue where the service was held, said Kahane was always welcome there. Many synagogues barred Kahane because he sanctioned violence. ``Rabbi Meir Kahane was a friend, a leader, a fighter, a writer, a thinker. He was a spokesman for the defense of Jews all around the world,'' Bomzer said. The militant Jewish Defense League, founded by Kahane in 1968, has been linked by the FBI to various acts of violence, including a 1972 firebombing that killed one person and injured 13 others. The loudest applause came when Bomzer proclaimed that Kahane ``was a strident voice calling `Never Again,''' the slogan used by Kahane in reference to the Holocaust. ``Tell all Arabs don't sleep so quiet tonight,'' Margolis said. ``We are Jews, we are religious Jews and we don't buy that crap of turning the other cheek. There will be hell to pay for this affront.'' Asked if he was threatening Arabs, Margolis said: ``I use simple English and I won't elaborate beyond this.'' Police had no official crowd estimate. The synagogue holds about 1,000 people. Thousands more clamored to get near the building and loudspeakers were set up so those outside could hear the service. Occasional fights were broken up by an estimated 200 police officers who were there to control the crowd. Moderate voices called for calm. ``This is not the time to be speaking of revenge; it is the time to be speaking of peace and reconciliation,'' said Rabbi Marc D. Angel, president of the Rabbinical Council of America. ``The guilty person should be tried and punished under our laws,'' said Rabbi Irwin Groner, president of the Rabbinical Asembly. ``But we urge that no further violence be perpetrated. This will only lead to more violence and bloodshed.'' The New York-born Kahane, who moved to Israel in 1971 and served four years in Israel's parliament until his extremist party was banned, was struck by a single bullet in the neck and died an hour later at Bellevue Hospital. The postal officer and a bystander at the hotel also were wounded. They were in stable condition, Bellevue Hospital spokeswoman Brenda Rivera said. In an interview with a Miami radio station Sunday, Kahane said he feared he would be killed by a Jew, not an Arab, said radio host Danny Tadmore. ``He said, `I don't have a problem with the Arabs, I have a problem with the Jews,''' Tadmore said Tuesday. ```And if somebody's ever going to kill me, it's going to be a Jew, not an Arab.''' Department of General Services spokesman John Beckman said Nosair has been a city employee since 1988. Israel Army radio reported that Nosair once lived in the occupied territories. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher called the killing ``a despicable and cowardly act.'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar also decried Kahane's killing and violence in the occupied territories. ``He deplores these and all acts of violence,'' said a spokeswoman, Nadia Younes. State Assemblyman Dov Hikind, who represents the rabbi's old Brooklyn neighborhood, said Kahane didn't want police protection. ``He said that when his turn would come, when God called him, no one could prevent it,'' said Hikind.

DOC.HEAD: Levin Goes Back to Senate, Blanchard in Re-Election Battle
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard struggled in a surprisingly tough race Tuesday against Republican John Engler, who went after the Democratic incumbent hitting hard on cutting property taxes. U.S. Sen. Carl Levin outdid his GOP foe and kept his seat. With 4 percent of precincts reporting, Blanchard had 52,060 votes, or 51 percent, to 50,401 votes, or 49 percent, for Engler. In the Senate race, U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette tried to play up his longstanding opposition to taxes - he's never voted for a tax increase during six years in Congress. But he made little headway against the popular Levin. With 4 percent of precincts reporting, Levin had 84,732 votes, or 58 percent, to 61,393 votes, or 42 percent, for Schuette. A Detroit News poll published Sunday showed Blanchard, the two-term governor, with a 14-point lead, 54 percent to 40 percent, but Engler predicted an upset, saying his promise to cut property taxes by 20 percent had caught on with voters. In the final days of the race, Engler handed out 5,000 nickels as he campaigned. ``That's how much Jim Blanchard wants to cut your property taxes each week. I think it's an insult,'' Engler said. In the U.S. House races, 10 Democrats and 5 Republicans bid for re-election. Another two Congressional seats were open races.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Couple $7.5 Million from Toyota
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 4Runner is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A jury ordered Toyota Motor Corp. to pay a couple $7.5 million in damages after the seat belt in their 4Runner vehicle failed during a crash and the husband was severely injured. Company officials were shocked by the size of the award and plan to appeal, said Toyota spokeswoman Mindy Geller. Since the Feb. 9, 1988, accident, Cliff Sadlier has had to rely primarily on a wheelchair to get around, but he can walk short distances with crutches and braces. Sadlier, of suburban Bloomfield Hills, said the vehicle's selt belt failed when he was driving alone and crashed into a tree. When the belt failed, his head went through the windshield and his body hit the dashboard. He and his wife, Joanne, sued the company, saying the belt lacked a device to take up slack in the belt. Toyota's lawyers said the belt met federal specifications. ``We felt the seat belt was defective by design,'' said Robert Gura, foreman of the U.S. District jury that granted the award Monday. ``It doesn't provide the protection the federal law says it should.'' Gura also is a supervisor at Chrysler Corp.'s stamping plant in Warren, Mich.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: George Voinovich, the popular former mayor of Cleveland, swept to victory in the governor's race Tuesday over Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., regaining control of the office for the Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. Roy Dyson was ousted from office Tuesday, losing to Wayne Gilchrest, a Republican schoolteacher who blasted the incumbent for his ties to defense contractors and his status as a conscientious objector during the Vietnam war.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat in Tight Race With Republican Senate Challenger
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley, an immensely popular Democrat who often is mentioned as a presidential contender, was in a dead heat Tuesday with his Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman. With 52 percent of precincts reporting, Bradley had 506,494 votes, or 50 percent, to 505,904 votes, or 50 percent, for Mrs. Whitman. Republicans did their best to tar Bradley and his fellow Democrats with the brush of Gov. Jim Florio's unpopular tax hikes. Florio wasn't on the ballot. A Star Ledger-Eagleton poll released last week showed Bradley leading Mrs. Whitman by a 36-point margin. Mrs. Whitman is a former president of the state Board of Public Utilities and a member of a prominent New Jersey Republican family. The Florio tax package has provided most of the fodder for GOP campaigning throughout the state. But with President Bush embracing a variety of higher taxes on the federal level in late October, the tax issue became a more ambiguous issue for both parties. There are two open congressional seats among the state's total of 14, but neither contested race was expected to alter the political balance of the delegation. There are seven Democratic congressmen and six GOP representatives in New Jersey, with one seat - the one abandoned by Florio - vacant.

DOC.HEAD: Voinovich Wins Governor's Office
DOC.TEXT: George Voinovich, the popular former mayor of Cleveland, swept to victory in the governor's race Tuesday, ending eight years of Democratic control. Voinovich, a Republican, beat Democrat Anthony J. Celebrezze Jr., the state's attorney general. Polls throughout the campaign showed Voinovich with big leads, although the margin narrowed toward the end of the campaign. With 28 percent of precincts reporting, Voinovich had 519,393 votes, or 55 percent, to 431,625 votes, or 45 percent, for Celebrezze. The incumbent, Democrat Richard Celeste, will leave office in January after serving two consecutive terms, the most allowed by law. He has been governor since 1983. Republican Jim Rhodes was governor before that. Ohio will have at least three new members of Congress because of the departures of Democratic Rep. Thomas Luken and Republican Reps. Michael DeWine and Donald Lukens. Luken is retiring, DeWine ran for lieutenant governor, and Lukens was defeated in the May primary after being convicted of having sex with a teen-age girl. Ohio's delegation is now divided 11 Democrats to 10 Republicans. All but one seat were contested. The closest race was between Republican J. Kenneth Blackwell and Democrat Charles Luken, mayor of Cincinnati and Luken's son. The GOP considered Blackwell's candidacy important because of the possibility of a black Republican being elected to Congress. Voters also were deciding whether to change the state constitution to permit casino gambling. At issue was whether residents of Lorain should be permitted to decide in a later election whether to allow construction of a casino in their city.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete, battered by the state's economic problems, lost his office Tuesday to millionaire Democrat Bruce G. Sundlun, who had run against the incumbent twice before without success.

DOC.HEAD: Democrat Cuomo Wins Third Term
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo breezed to a third term over splintered Republican opposition Tuesday, maintaining his standing as a leader of the Democratic Party and potential presidential candidate for 1992. While Cuomo has consistently maintained that he ``has no plans to run for president and no plans to make plans,'' Democratic leaders said a re-election victory would increase interest in him. ``He'll be under more pressure than he's ever been under before,'' Robert Strauss, a former Democratic national chairman, predicted last week. Cuomo's opposition included millionaire economist Pierre Rinfret, the Republican challenger who was an unknown in New York politics six months ago, and Conservative Party nominee Herbert London. With 19 percent of precincts reporting, Cuomo had 389,863 votes, or 49 percent, to 193,809 votes, or 24 percent, for Rinfret, and 181,166 votes, or 23 percent, for London. In the final two months of the campaign, the outspoken, underfunded Rinfret spent almost as much time bashing prominent Republicans as he did attacking Democrat Cuomo. Rinfret's paltry campaign war chest reflected GOP displeasure. With Rinfret's campaign in shambles, Republicans scrambled to produce enough loyal voters to keep London from finishing second. By finishing third, the GOP could lose its second-row ballot spot in New York elections for at least the next four years. Also threatened by a possible low Republican turnout was GOP control of the state Senate. A Marist College Institute for Public Opinion poll released last week had Cuomo the choice of 61 percent of those surveyed with Rinfret and London tied for second place at 11 percent each. Of New York's 34 congressional members, 21 Democrats and 13 Republicans, five ran unopposed and the others were favored to win re-election. On Staten Island, voters decided whether to start a process that could lead to secession for the smallest of New York City's five boroughs. Meanwhile, Cuomo asked voters statewide to approve a $2 billion environmental bond act that would provide $800 million to buy land and $625 million for garbage problems.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Voters Have Little Faith in Congress, Nation's Future
DOC.TEXT: Voters were a gloomy bunch with little faith in Congress or the nation's future, according to an Election Day telephone poll. Nearly three-quarters of those questioned Tuesday in the ABC News Voter Poll said the economic outlook was getting worse and the nation was on the wrong track. An overwhelming majority of those with dim views were Democrats. The poll respondents rated the deficit and the Persian Gulf standoff the nation's most important problems. Their top few ``very important voting issues'' included the federal budget, Iraq, taxes and the national economy. The poll suggested that recent Republican waffling over taxes and the federal budget has reinforced the perception that the GOP is the party of the rich. Two-thirds of those questioned said the Democratic Party was ``best for the poor'' while 79 percent - including 37 percent of the Republicans - said the Republicans were ``best for the rich.'' Looked at by income groups, 66 percent of voters making less than $15,000 a year said they voted for Democrats. The Democrats also were favored by those making up to $49,000. Among those making more than that, the vote was about evenly split between the two parties. The voters in the survey also were evenly split on which party they said could be ``trusted on future problems.'' But there was broad bipartisan support for President Bush's policies in Iraq - 69 percent total, including 45 percent of the Democrats. About the same percentages said they would support U.S. force if it is needed in the gulf. Bush's approval rating may be lower than it once was, but the ABC poll suggests people are more than three times as fed up with Congress. A full 57 percent of those questioned said they approved of Bush's performance - but only 18 percent said they approved of the way Congress was doing its job. In addition, 77 percent said Congress needs ``fresh ideas'' rather than experience. Despite their negative view of Congress, however, 62 percent said they approved of their own House member's performance. And when push came to shove, more than half - 55 percent - said they voted to retain their current congressman or woman. In a very early peek at the 1992 presidential race, Bush came out substantially ahead of an array of Democrats who conceivably might run. But doubts about Vice President Dan Quayle persisted, with only 44 percent of those questioned saying he was qualified to be president. The ABC poll was based on interviews with 661 people who had already voted or who indicated in replies to several screening questions that they were going to vote. The poll-takers warned that telephone polling sometimes overstates turnout since some people do not make it to the voting booth. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney Grills Woman Who Recalled Watching Dad Kill Best Friend
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer on Tuesday attacked the credibility of a woman who claims she suddenly remembered watching her father molest and kill her best friend 20 years ago. During a second day of cross-examination, defense attorney Douglas Horngrad pointed out variations in Eileen Franklin-Lipsker's story since she first claimed the resurfacing of a repressed memory last year. Horngrad demanded to know why she changed her story after telling relatives the memory surfaced while she was under hypnosis. Ms. Franklin-Lipsker has acknowledged telling family members months later that she lied about the hypnosis to make her story more believable. Horngrad suggested Ms. Franklin-Lipsker changed her story because she learned hypnotically-induced memory would not stand up in court. ``By that time, you knew that hypnotically-induced testimony was inadmissible in California?'' Horngrad asked. ``No, I don't think so,'' Ms. Franklin-Lipsker said. George Franklin Sr., 51, was charged with killing 8-year-old Susan Nason after his daughter told police she had suddenly remembered the Sept. 22, 1969, attack. He pleaded innocent to the charges. Ms. Franklin-Lipsker, now 29, claims her father threatened to kill her if she told anyone about the crime. She testified the memory flooded back last year as she looked at her own young daughter, and details of the crime emerged in subsequent months. Nason's body was discovered in a ravine three months after she was reported missing. A blood-stained rock was discovered nearby. On Tuesday, Horngrad also questioned Ms. Franklin-Lipsker about when and how the memory resurfaced. Ms. Franklin-Lipsker testified she first recalled the murder in January 1989 and told a therapist about it five months later, saying the memory had ``recently'' resurfaced. Horngrad asked her why it took her so long to discuss the memory with a professional. ``Is five months recent?'' he asked. ``I would say that if I had a 5-month-old memory of a 20-year-old murder, that's very recent,'' she replied. On Monday, Ms. Franklin-Lipsker recounted details of the slaying and recalled that when she was 11, her father pinned her down on a table as his best friend raped her. Like the alleged murder, Franklin-Lipsker testified, the memory of the rape remained repressed until recently.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell won a sixth term Tuesday, turning back a surprisingly weak challenge from liberal Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Strikes Down Reform Plan for Injured Workers
DOC.TEXT: A reform plan that cut workers' compensation benefits by 30 percent was struck down Tuesday by a judge who said it was cluttered with unrelated, unconstitutional provisions. The state will appeal the Circuit Court ruling and the law, enacted earlier this year, will remain in effect until the outcome of the appeal. The law was challenged by the Florida AFL-CIO and other unions. They argued that 150 provisions of the law violated the Florida Constitution, mainly denying an injured worker's right to appeal lost benefits in court. Judge Lewis Hall did not declare that provision unconstitutional, but said the law improperly dealt with workers' compensation issues in violation of the constitution's requirement that parts of a law be relevant to a single subject. ``How many subjects can you put under that broad an umbrella?'' Hall asked in his ruling. Hall said sections of the law setting up foreign trade offices had little to do with workers' compensation and could have given lawmakers a way to justify their votes on the bill, which was supported by business but opposed by workers' groups. Other provisions violated separation of powers requirements by giving the governor judicial authority through his appointments to a commission set up to decide workers' appeals, he said. ``In essence, there's so much in there that it reduces the accountability of the legislator because he can always say he voted for the good part and not necessarily for the bad part,'' Hall said. Deputy Attorney General Mitch Franks said he disagreed with Hall's reasoning on the single subject and separation of powers issues. State AFL-CIO President Dan Miller was elated with the ruling, even though the state said it will bypass other courts and ask the Florida Supreme Court to hear the appeal. ``I think it's a great victory for injured workers in this case,'' Miller said. ``If the Supreme Court upholds this decision, we'll revert back to the law that was in effect in 1989. It's not perfect, but it's fairer than what the Legislature passed.'' The Legislature enacted the comprehensive reform to reduce skyrocketing workers' compensation insurance rates paid by businesses by up to 25 percent. The reduction was achieved by slashing workers' benefits by about one-third. Under the 1989 law, for example, the fringe benefits of an injured worker were included in the amount used to figure his workers' compensation. Such fringe benefits were removed from the formula under the new law.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democrat James P. Moran, mayor of Alexandria, turned Rep. Stanford E. Parris out of his House seat after six terms from the 8th District. Moran had accused Parris of being more interested in the governorship than in serving his constituents.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Mike Hayden, blamed for large property tax increases, was turned out of office Tuesday after a single term, losing to Democratic State Treasurer Joan Finney, who becomes the state's first woman governor.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Renewing Control of Senate
URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout. Democrats regain control of Senate. Exon, Pell, Kerry, Simpson winners. Helms leading.
DOC.TEXT: Democrats on Tuesday won two more years in control of the Senate as incumbents showed their strength. In the most closely watched contest, conservative Sen. Jesse Helms was leading in his battle against Democrat Harvey Gantt in North Carolina. Democrats seemed assured of at least 51 seats, another Senate majority, after results showed 12 of their incumbents had won and several others were leading, including several who had been targeted by the GOP. Republican incumbents showed similar strength, however, and it appeared the GOP would hold on to all three seats where their senators were retiring. Democrats had hoped to improve on their 55-45 majority anywhere they could, but especially in North Carolina. Early returns and exit polls, however, suggested Helms would survive. The race between Helms and Gantt captured national attention not only because it was close, but because the candidates represent such extremes. Helms is a national symbol of right-wing politics and the Senate's most diehard opponent to civil rights legislation. Helms ran campaign ads accusing Gantt, who is black, of favoring racial quotas and taking advantage of minority-preference rules for personal gain. Gantt is an unapologetic liberal and racial trailblazer, the first black admitted to Clemson University. During the campaign, he blamed Helms for the poor state of North Carolina education and the state's environmental problems. Polls were kept open late in heavily black Durham County after voting machines there broke down. Another Democratic challenge fell short in Kentucky, where first-time Sen. Mitch McConnell beat off former county commissioner Harvey Sloane. But in New Jersey, GOP challenger Christine Todd Whitman, a virtual unknown in her first statewide bid, put a scare into Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley. She was close behind him in the polls. And in one of the open Senate seats, Rep. Robert Smith defeated former Sen. John Durkin in New Hampshire, keeping that seat in the GOP column. Democratic incumbents Claiborne Pell in Rhode Island, Carl Levin in Michigan and Paul Simon in Illinois won surprisingly easy victories over well-financed Republican House members. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., beat former Republican Rep. Hal Daub. Other incumbents of both parties won with ease. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, won unopposed. Thad Cochran, R-Miss., and David Pryor, D-Ark., also won without opponents. Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo., the Senate's deputy minority leader, won easily. Other senior incumbents returned to office were Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., at 87 the Senate's oldest member, Howell Heflin, D-Ala., John Warner, R-Va., David Boren, D-Okla., Pete Domenici, R-N.M., William Cohen, R-Maine, and Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va. Nunn was one of several possible future presidential candidates seeking re-election to the Senate Tuesday. Others who won re-election were Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Phil Gramm, R-Texas. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., handily won a third term and Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., who ran for the Democratic presidential nomination in 1988, also won. Indiana Republican incumbent Dan Coats, who was appointed to the Senate seat vacated by Vice President Dan Quayle, won his bid for election on his own over Democrat Baron Hill. Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., whose second term appeared threatened at one point because of voter discontent, crushed developer Jim Rappaport. In Hawaii, incumbent Daniel Akaka was trying to hold for the Democrats a seat his party has controlled since statehood. But Republican Rep. Pat Saiki was running even in pre-election surveys to Akaka, who was appointed to the Senate last spring following the death of Sen. Spark Matsunaga. Another threatened Senate institution was Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., who has served four terms. Hatfield appeared a shoo-in until businessman and scientist Harry Lonsdale, running as a Democrat, tapped into voter discontent with politicians. Democrats also used the anti-Washington theme in Kentucky, South Dakota and Minnesota as they went after GOP incumbents. Republicans used the same tactic in Massachusetts. In Iowa, incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin was leading in his bid to become the first Democrat in that state ever re-elected to the Senate. Chances that Tuesday's 34 Senate elections would produce a major shift in the chamber's current 55-45 partisan split appeared slim. There was virtually no chance the Republicans would take over, or that the Democrats would gain enough seats to assure an override of every veto issued by Bush. But even a change of one seat could weaken or strengthen President Bush's position. For example, the Senate recently failed to override his veto of the 1990 Civil Rights bill by a single vote. The North Carolina race was easily the most costly Senate contest in the nation. At last report, two weeks before Election Day, Helms had spent $10.8 million and Gantt $4.6 million. Both candidates were getting most of their money from out of state. If the Democrats succeeded in adding seats, they would get their biggest margin since the 59-41 majority they held from 1979 until 1981, the last two years of the Carter administration. California could get a new senator as a result of Tuesday's election, but the seat would not change parties. If Republican Sen. Pete Wilson were to beat Democrat Dianne Feinstein, he'd resign from the Senate and appoint his successor. In the District of Columbia, Jesse Jackson won election as a non-voting ``shadow senator'' to lobby Congress for statehood.
DOC.HEAD: Pickup dash matter, a0575.
BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. Doug Walgren lost his bid for an eighth term in the U.S. House on Tuesday to Republican attorney Rick Santorum, who portrayed the incumbent as a tax-and-spend liberal.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bill Bradley, a Democrat often mentioned as a presidential contender, scratched out a narrow win Tuesday against his relatively unknown Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman.

DOC.HEAD: Incumbent Farrelly Wins Gubernatorial Race in U.S. Virgin Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Farrelly win, vote totals. CORRECTS challenger's name in lead, edits to conform. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Incumbent Gov. Alexander Farrelly easily defeated challenger Juan Luis in gubernatorial elections Tuesday in the U.S. Virgin Islands. With 100 percent of the vote tabulated in the three Caribbean islands, a U.S. territory, Farrelly topped former governor Luis by 13,331 votes to 9,078. The race had been expected to be close between the 66-year-old Farrelly, a Democrat, and Luis, who was running as an independent. Virgin Islands non-voting delegate to the U.S. Congress, Ron de Lugo, a Democrat, ran unopposed for a ninth two-year term, garnering 16,675 votes. Farrelly is a Yale-educated corporate lawyer vying for his second four-year term. He is believed to have lost support for his handling of the aftermath of Hurricane Hugo, which hit the Caribbean in September 1989. The hurricane struck all three islands, including St. Thomas and St. John, but St. Croix was affected the most. Residents there accused the governor of being slow to react to the crisis because he took several days to inspect the damage. Puerto Rican-born Luis, 50, had support among the islands' Hispanic community, who are about 25 percent of the islands' 100,000 residents. He was governor from 1977 until 1986 but his administration came under scrutiny following a controversy over a multimillion-dollar public works contract. Widespread looting broke out in St. Croix after Hugo struck, flattening one-third of the homes with its 200 mph winds. President Bush sent in 1,100 military police to restore order and they stayed for two months.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Douglas ``Pete'' Peterson upset U.S. Rep. James W. ``Bill'' Grant, a recent convert to the GOP who was targeted by the national Democratic Party for defeat in north Florida's 2nd District.

DOC.HEAD: Police Flatten Indian Roadblock, Arrest More Than Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with police flattening roadblock, arresting more than 60 protesters. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police used a bulldozer Tuesday to flatten a blockade of trees, furniture and other debris an Indian group erected across a roadway used by loggers and arrested more than 60 protesters. No violence or injuries were reported as Royal Canadian Mounted Police removed the 4-month-old blockade, though some protesters were led away shouting and kicking. ``They're putting up some resistance,'' police Sgt. Peter Montague said. ``We were expecting that.'' While Indians chanted and beat drums, the officers escorted at least 63 protesters to a nearby checkpoint and handcuffed them with plastic restraints before being put aboard chartered buses. Montague said those arrested would have to sign notices promising to appear in court before they would be released. The Mount Currie Indians band set up the 3-foot-tall barricade on an unpaved road about 85 miles north of Vancouver on July 12 to show support for Mohawk Indians in their standoff with police at Oka, Quebec. After the Oka standoff was resolved, the group decided to maintain its blockade to draw attention to its land claims. The British Columbia Supreme Court on Monday gave police power to make arrests if necessary to remove the blockade. Indian Affairs Minister Tom Siddon said he would meet with Chief Fraser Andrew of the Mount Currie Indian band on Wednesday to try to persuade the Indians ``to honor and abide by the decision of the courts.'' Siddon said he would urge the group to settle its land claim through the normal negotiation process. Loggers who often use Duffey Lake Road have been hurt by the blockade. Logging contractors and their crews have had just a few days of work since the blockade went up, said contractor Peter Staehli. Trucks began rumbling down the roadway again after the blockade was dismantled Tuesday. Terri John, a spokeswoman for the Lil'wat People's Movement, vowed Monday that the group would not recognize the order and would peacefully resist police orders to move. The Indians would ``continue to resist ... the B.C. Supreme Court injunction because they have no jurisdiction over the Indian nation,'' she said. The blockade was a series of mounds of earth, some teepees and old couches, stretching 330 feet across a dirt road nestled in a large meadow beneath thew snowcapped Coast Mountains. Many protesters had lived in tents at the site since the blockade began.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: HARTFORD, Conn. (AP) Conservative Republican Gary A. Franks became the first black elected to the U.S. House from Connecticut since before the Civil War, as former U.S. Rep. Toby Moffett fell to a carpetbagger label for moving into the 5th District earlier this year.

DOC.HEAD: BULLETIN
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin bucked a spirited challenge from Republican Rep. Tom Tauke to win a second term Tuesday, after a 2-year, $11 million campaign that was the most expensive political race in Iowa history.

A gunman believed to be of Arab descent assassinated Rabbi Meir Kahane after a speech at a hotel by the Brooklyn-born extremist who demanded the ouster of all Arabs from Israel, authorities said today. Kahane, 58, was shot to death Monday night after addressing a Zionist group. The gunman, El Sayyid A. Nosair, 35, was shot and wounded in the chin by a postal police officer as he tried to flee, police said. Israel Army radio reported early today that Nosair once lived in the occupied territories. Police said only that the gunman was believed to be of Middle Eastern origin and that his nationality was not known. He was believed to live in New Jersey, police said. Nosair was reported in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital, where Kahane was pronounced dead. Kahane, as founder of the Jewish Defense League, had urged Jews in the United States to arm themselves against anti-Semitism.
