Later, as a member of the Israeli Parliament, he was one of Israel's fiercest anti-Arab politicians. ---=

The environment, taxes and whether politicians should be turned out of office before they get too comfortable in the job confronted voters today as they tackled 236 ballot questions in 43 states and the District of Columbia. Alaskans could make the private use of marijuana a crime, Arizona voters could declare Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday a state holiday, and Oregon residents could give parents a $2,500 tax credit for sending a child to the public, parochial or private school of their choice. In California, Washington and Missouri, environmentalists looked to the voters to adopt measures protecting forests, coasts and other sensitive lands. The tax revolt faced an important Election Day as well. Citizen initiatives that would cut or limit taxes or hold down government spending were on the ballot in Massachusetts, Nebraska, Oregon and other states. ---= TORONTO (AP) - The French-speaking province of Quebec, determined to take charge of its political destiny, has begun a serious self-examination to decide what its future relationship with the rest of Canada will be. The failure of the Meech Lake accord four months ago, which would have recognized Quebec as a ``distinct society'' within the Canadian federation, was seen by many in the province as a rejection by English Canada. Beginning today, a newly formed Commission on the Political and Constitutional Future of Quebec takes up the question of the province's fate. The creation of the 35-member commission is seen by many Quebecois as a watershed in the province's history. Relations with English Canada will never be the same. ``If the status quo were acceptable, there would be no commission - that's the starting point,'' said Michel Belanger, one of its chairmen. ---= RENO, Nev. (AP) - When it comes to selling a brothel, the Internal Revenue Service has a few hang-ups. Condoms and paintings of bare-breasted women are OK at next week's tax sale of the Mustang Ranch. Dirty movies are out. Among the gaudier items to be sold when the auction of the 100-room bordello and its contents begins Nov. 13 are teddy bears, pajamas, sequined and feathered gowns and pocket-sized ceramic liquor bottles decorated with naked women. What's not for sale at America's best known legal brothel is a small collection of porno flicks that were found in the purple, mirror-walled Orgy Room when the IRS seized the property Sept. 21 for $13 million in back taxes owed by Joe and Sally Conforte. The IRS hopes to earn at least $1.8 million when the property falls under the auctioneer's gavel. ``We highly encourage the neighborhood yard sale enthusiast to come out and make a bid on anything they may want,'' Ms. Pagni said. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Pianist Leon Fleisher's tragedy was losing his right hand to a crippling muscle disorder. His triumph was showing the world that it hardly mattered. After building a new life for himself in the past quarter-century as a conductor and teacher, Fleisher, 62, returned to the concert stage last weekend for a bravura piano recital featuring solo works for the left hand only. His homecoming performance in the Kennedy Center's crowded Terrace Theater was praised by music critics with the same enthusiasm that greeted his Carnegie Hall debut with the New York Philharmonic in 1944, when he was a gangly 16-year-old from San Francisco. Several works on Saturday night's program were written for other great pianists who, like Fleisher, were unable to use their right hands. It was Fleisher's first solo recital in a major concert hall since he was stricken more than 25 years ago.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv07
For release Wed PMs, Nov. 7, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: TV and Tobacco: Smoking and the Message of the Medium
DOC.TEXT: Not a Marlboro Man has galloped through the intellectual wasteland since television banned cigarette commercials in 1971, but California public health researchers say there's still too much smoking on TV. Commercials are banned, but people still smoke: The grizzled old cop fires up a grizzled old stogey; the troubled teen lights a filter tip; the sneering gangster takes a puff on a coffin nail. Television, with its power to inform and entertain, also has aterrible power to persuade, cajole and educate. What does it say about smoking? Glad you asked. ``We wanted to assess the prevalence of smoking on television and we wanted to look at who it is that is smoking, and the message that is being given,'' said Patricia Madden, co-author of the study of smoking on prime-time television. She and Georgette L. Overby are researchers at the Prevention Research Bureau in Berkeley, Calif., one of a dozen state- and federally funded centers for social and biomedical reasearch on alcohol and other abused substances. The foundation of their experiment is the ``cognitive social learning theory'' developed by the sociologist Albert Bandura and others. It is, in essence, the Kid with a Stone theory of social behavior. If the Kid sees somebody toss a stone through a window, the Kid is likelier to do the same thing if the behavior is rewarded, and somewhat less likely to do it if nothing happens. If the tosser is a ``high-status'' role model, someone who is powerful, attractive, competent - a hero, for example - the Kid is more likely to imitate the throwing than if the tosser is an unattractive ``low-status'' model. Got it? Funny, it all seemed so clear when ``Andy of Mayberry'' was on. Ms. Madden said the researchers collected 139{ hours of ``routine, fiction network prime-time programming'' in the fall of 1989, and ended with a sample of 70 prime time shows, hours and half-hours, comedies and dramas. University of California-Berkeley students then scanned the programs, using a kitchen timer and the VCR's pause button to check for smoking at minute-by-minute intervals. Once a ``smoking act'' was seen, the viewers noted the context of the smoking - the status of the characters involved in the smoking and how they reacted to it. The observers also checked for embedded anti-smoking messages. The results were more surprising than you might expect. ``The scales are still tipped toward the pro-smoking message,'' Ms. Madden said. The study found an average 2{ minutes of smoking per hour, with anti-smoking messages in little more than three-quarters of a minute per hour. ``You'd have to watch two hours to see an anti-smoking message,'' Ms. Madden said. Smoking occurred in 53 percent of all programs and 41 percent of all episodes in the sample, while anti-smoking messages occurred in 39 percent of all programs and 20 percent of all episodes. Crime shows had more smoking on them, and the smokers tended more often to be bad guys. ``We were encouraged by the fact that smoking does not tend to be glamorized any more on television,'' Ms. Madden said, ``and we would like to see scriptwriters weave more anti-smoking messages into their plots.'' Where anti-smoking messages were involved, the majority of smokers and the people who reacted negatively to smoking were adult, white male, plot-related characters, the study found. ``Overall, we had 129 smokers in our sample and 35 characters who reacted negatively to smoking,'' Ms. Madden said. ``This could be anything from waving away the smoke to actually saying something to the character about their smoking.'' In addition: -The negative ``reactors'' were more affluent than smokers, likelier to be ``good guys'' and positive role models. -Smokers usually were guest characters and bad guys with ``low role model potential.'' -Fully 15 percent of smokers were under age 18. ``As a public health professional, I would not advocate the total elimination of smoking on television,'' Ms. Madden said. ``I would like to see more of the consequences shown, consequences ranging from someone asking a character to put out a cigarette, to medical shows with episodes on cancer and emphysema.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... YAAAAAAAAAY!!! ABSOLUTELY THE LAST CBS PREMIERE: ``Broken Badges,'' an action-drama about a special police crimefighting unit ``composed of cops temporarily on psychiatric leave from the force'' makes a Nov. 24 debut. This long-awaited series, prized chiefly for its appalling lack of irony, is sure to be a hit with the Rubber Gun Squad. Think about it: Armed emotionally disturbed people in the streets! Welcome to New York City! The show stars Miguel Ferrer, Eileen Davidson, Jay Johnson and Ernie Hudson. It is the last premiere of CBS' new shows for the fall season.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, Nov. 7
$adv07
For Release PMs Wednesday, Nov. 7
DOC.HEAD: Great Market for Homebuyers
DOC.TEXT: The time has come for some very patient families who saved their money, bided their time and never lost faith that someday they might be able to afford a house. Through most of a decade their vision could be only perceived dimly. Prices soared and interest rates stayed high, and the market was full of eager buyers to whom price seemed no object. It was a seller's market. Those were tough times for people with limited incomes, and that included millions of families. In many months, popular indexes of affordability showed the typical family couldn't even qualify for the typical single-family house. How things have changed. Home prices are dropping in many areas. In some neighborhoods, the ``for sale'' sign on the front lawn has become almost as common as the mail box on a post. Interest rates seem to be on a steady course lower. A survey of 125 primary mortgage-market lenders showed rates on a 30-year fixed rate mortgage have dropped steadily to 10.17 percent and on a one-year adjustable rate to 8.17 percent. Moreover, while some banks might be cutting back on lending to businesses, many banks are aggressively seeking borrowers who offer homes as collateral. At the same time, affordability has soared. The median home price measured by the National Association of Realtors was down to $94,300 in September from $97,100 in August, while the national median income rose. Those changes put the association's affordability index at 110.9 in September, one of the highest in recent years. In the mid-1980s it had fallen well below 100, meaning the typical family couldn't afford the typical house. Translated, the September index meant a family earning the national median income of $35,239 in that month had 110.9 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a median-priced home. It has been six to eight years in many sections of the country since such favorable buying conditions existed, a long time in terms of the economic cycle, and one that probably led some would-be buyers to give up the search. Many buyers did remain patient, however, recognizing that the most certain thing you can say about the economy is that it is cyclical, rising and falling and rising again - and that the real estate cycle is even more pronounced. The coalescing of favorable factors, however, does not make a perfect market for buyers. In the nature of things, a shrinking economy means less job security and more uncertainty, and the latter is unusually high today. Prudent shoppers take that into consideration, of course, but they realize also that no investment is without risk. Included in their assessment of risk will be the cost of renting vs. buying and relative tax benefits. In a market of sluggish sales, these tax benefits are one of the more convincing sales inducements being used by real estate agents. Deductibility of interest on mortgages, you might say, is the common person's only ``loophole.'' Prudence also dictates that buyers have a reserve of funds for emergencies, of course, but also to pay for the various items that may accompany the purchase of a home: furniture, drapes, lawn mower, washing machine and more. Perhaps it isn't a perfect market for buyers; it never is. And it is even conceivable that better buys might lie ahead. But those who for years have postponed buying a house can at least begin looking and planning now.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Wed, Nov. 7
$Adv09
For Release Friday AMs, Nov. 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Japan To Enthrone First `Symbolic' Emperor
DOC.TEXT: Emperor Akihito formally assumes the world's oldest hereditary throne Monday in lavish ceremonies that also may be an important rite of passage for postwar Japan. No other monarch has ascended the Chrysanthemum Throne under the constitution enacted in 1945. For the first time, a Japanese emperor is to be enthroned as merely a national symbol, as stipulated by the constitution imposed by the U.S. occupation after Japan's surrender in World War II. Most Japanese appear comfortable with the largely ceremonial role of their new emperor, a remarkable break with the past. The late Emperor Hirohito, Akihito's father, was enthroned as a living god and was the object of fanatical devotion. Even the official name the government has given Akihito's reign - Achieving Peace - reflects a desire to move away from the turbulent times of Hirohito, who died of cancer early last year. The monarchy dates to the 6th or 7th century, but the Japanese public associates it most closely with Hirohito's 60-year reign. In that period, Japan waged expansionist wars in the name of the emperor, suffered a crushing defeat and foreign occupation, then rose to become an economic superpower. Akihito, 56, became emperor immediately after his father's death, but his formal enthronement awaited a year of mourning and the growing of ``sacred'' rice for a coronation rite. During the interval, Akihito has tried to create a softer, more open image for the often aloof royal family, insisting on fewer uniformed police along his procession routes and addressing people with the title ``san,'' a term of respect similar to Mr. or Mrs. in English. Reflecting the different times in which they were raised, Akihito is believed to be more democratic in thinking than his father, and has pledged to ``protect the constitution along with the people.'' Empress Michiko, the first commoner to marry a future Japanese monarch, is crafting her own quiet revolution inside the royal household, in large part by providing Akihito with a family life similar to that of ``common'' Japanese. She broke tradition, for example, by making clear that her children would not be taken away and raised by strangers. Although the palace remains distant to most Japanese, opinion polls indicate it has wide public support. Few, however, still see their monarch as a god. Government officials say they have taken pains to adapt the enthronement ceremonies to a more democratic age. They also have hewn closely to prewar precedent for the nearly month-long rites, however, creating widespread concern that the ``new era'' might actually represent a step backward in time. Royalty, heads of state and other dignitaries from more than 150 nations will be in Tokyo when Akihito announces his accession on Monday. The main coronation ceremony will be at the imperial palace, an oasis of greenery in central Tokyo built in the late 19th century on the site of a former samurai castle. Akihito will ascend a 20-foot-tall throne on a three-layered dais of black lacquer, beneath an octagonal roof adorned with golden mirrors and phoenixes. Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu will stand before the throne as Akihito, in a reddish-brown kimono with a design of paulownia trees, bamboo and mythical animals, reads an address announcing his accession. Kaifu will lead the Japanese among the 2,500 guests in three rounds of ``Banzai!'' - a traditional cheer for long life - to conclude the 30-minute ceremony. Officials say Akihito will read his announcement in colloquial Japanese, unlike Hirohito's use of stilted classical language most Japanese cannot understand. To reflect the postwar constitution's emphasis on popular sovereignty, Kaifu will lead the banzai cheers from a point level with the throne instead of descending several steps, as his predecessors did. An official in the prime minister's office told reporters a military salute coinciding with the enthronement would be reduced from 100 to 21 cannon shots because ``that's the way foreign dignitaries are received.'' Aside from such cosmetic adjustments, Akihito's coronation is expected to be much like those held since his great-grandfather assumed the throne in the middle of the last century. In what many critics of the government see as a snub to the constitution, about 2.5 billion yen ($17 million) in public money will be spent on a rite steeped in Shinto, Japan's state religion until 1945. In that rite, to begin 10 days after the main coronation ceremony, Akihito will step back into the world of myth for a ``communion'' of fresh rice with the sun goddess, from whom the imperial line is said to have descended, and all the gods of heaven and earth. Opponents say public funding violates the constitutional separation of church and state. The Kaifu administration argues that the money is not being used to promote religion, but to preserve an important cultural tradition. Critics emphasize that the rite has undergone major changes during its 1,200 years of existence. It was ignored for more than 200 years, beginning in the late 15th century. In response to questions about whether holding the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual, is intended to restore living-god status to Akihito and future emperors, Nobuo Ishihara, the deputy cabinet secretary, replied: ``I am aware that there were some scholars in the prewar period who claimed that, through performance of the Daijosai, the emperor assumed a divine nature. However, the government is not in a position to make any comment as to whether the emperor does or does not.'' Police have begun Japan's largest security operation, mainly because ultra-leftist radical groups have said they will disrupt the ceremonies. A bomb believed planted by radicals exploded last week at a Tokyo police dormitory, killing one officer and wounding six other people. Late last month, 26,000 Tokyo police officers were mobilized for security in the capital, and at least 6,000 more will be brought in before the main ceremony. Nearly 45 percent of the total coronation budget of 12.3 billion yen ($94.6 million) is being spent on security. A high-ranking National Police Agency official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the extraordinary security was justified because leftist radicals ``are planning to attack the palace with explosive rockets.'' He said police believe one group has devised mortar-like weapons with a range of nearly four miles. Along with protecting the many visiting dignitaries, including Prince Charles of Britain and Vice President Dan Quayle, the police are concerned about security for a parade after the coronation. Akihito and Empress Michiko are to ride in a convertible in the 30-minute procession from the imperial palace to the royal residence at Akasaka Palace. Oficials say about 7,000 officers will line the three-mile route.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Nov. 9
$Adv09
For Release Friday AMs, Nov. 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Emperor To Commune With Gods in Mystical Shinto Rite
With Japan-Enthronement
DOC.TEXT: Clad in white robes reserved for the holiest ceremonies, Emperor Akihito will complete his accession to the throne by communing with the Shinto gods in a room bathed in flickering torchlight. Palace officials say the communion, part of an enthronement ritual more than 1,200 years old, has become an integral part of imperial succession and is an important aspect of Japanese culture. It also has given rise to heated constitutional debate and allegations that the government seeks to revive the ``living god'' status of former monarchs. Members of the leading opposition party, the Socialists, plan to boycott the rite. The head of the Japan Federation of Bar Associations has questioned its constitutionality and the National Christian Council of Japan has collected nearly 80,000 signatures on a petition against it. The ceremony, to begin just after dark Nov. 22 and end before dawn, is known as the Daijosai, or Great Food Offering Ritual. About 900 Japanese dignitaries will gather for the ceremony at a special complex of buildings recently completed on the grounds of the imperial palace in central Tokyo. No foreigners are invited. Among the guests will be Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, speakers of both houses of Parliament, the chief justice of the Supreme Court and the cream of Japanese society. Ancient court music will be played as the guests are seated in two large tents. A procession of chamberlains and palace officials, clad in traditional kimonos, will escort the emperor to one of two ceremonial halls. In a lantern-lit inner chamber, well away from the sight of the guests, Akihito will be assisted by two female attendants as he begins the rite. Sitting on a bamboo floor covered with rush matting, he will pray and offer newly harvested and polished rice to the sun goddess, from whom the imperial line is said to have descended. He then will join all the gods of heaven and earth in a communion of rice, rice wine and produce from all over Japan, including squid, abalone and chestnuts. Just after midnight, the ceremony will be repeated in the other hall. Relatively few details of the mystical ceremony were known to the public until earlier this century. Because each of the inner chambers contains a stylized bed, scholars have argued that, at one time, the rite may have involved the emperor symbolically having intercourse with the sun goddess, thus becoming one with the divie. Palace officials say the bed represents the place where the gods rest until summoned for the communion. Iwao Miyao, deputy head of the Imperial Household Agency, which supervises palace affairs, told reporters recently that prayers offered by previous emperors indicate the rite is not intended to bestow divine status on the monarch. Miyao quoted a prayer by Emperor Gotsuchimikado in 1466 that was an appeal to the sun goddess for peace, abundant crops and blessings on ``all the people, both high and low.'' He said that prayer and two others had, ``for some reason or other,'' become known outside the palace. Miyao refused to divulge what Akihito will say because ``such matters are intended exclusively for the deities.'' Akihito is to be the first monarch enthroned under Japan's postwar constitution, written while Japan was administered by Allied occupation forces after World War II. Although the charter redefined the role of the emperor from that of ``sacred'' sovereign to a largely symbolic one, Akihito's Daijosai will be essentially the same as those of his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Critics consider this important, since the content of those rites was strongly influenced by those who wanted to restore imperial rule and build a national cult of emperor worship. The cult was used later to rally the nation to war. Opponents also point out that the late Hirohito, the new emperor's father, renounced his divinity in 1946. They claim Akihito's Daijosai amounts to a retraction of that historic decision.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Nov. 9
$Adv09
For Release Friday AMs, Nov. 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Bulgaria More Democratic, but Divided and Poor
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria is more democratic a year after a Politburo coup ousted Stalinist leader Todor Zhivkov, but it also is a divided nation heading for economic disaster. Many Bulgarians were taken by surprise when Zhivkov fell Nov. 10, 1989, after 35 years in power. Dissidents and ordinary people celebrated, but there has been little cause for rejoicing since. Exhorting Bulgarians into the streets of Sofia, the fledgling opposition forced talks in January with the governing Communists, who hurriedly began implementing reforms after Zhivkov was thrown out. In June, as a result of the negotiations, Bulgaria held its first free elections in 58 years. Instead of solving the nation's problems, however, the elections seemed to create more. The Communist Party, now called the Socialists, became unique among former masters in the Soviet bloc by winning at the polls. The stunned opposition Union of Democratic Forces accepted the result, but has seemed unable to live with it. Little has been accomplished in the 400-seat Parliament, where theformer Communists have 211 members and the opposition alliance 144. It required six weeks for the assembly to chose a president, former UDF leader Zhelyu Zhelev, and longer to approve an all-Socialist government. Endless argument by deputies of the opposition alliance, and divisions among the former Communists, have made it impossible to pass legislation on foreign investment, selling state companies and other economic and political reforms. UDF members refuse to support Premier Andrei Lukanov or join a Socialist-led coalition. Although polls indicate the UDF would win if elections were held now, many Bulgarians are critical of the opposition's conduct in Parliament. Frustration, fear and tension have increased in the streets. A mob burned the governing party's headquarters in September after smashing windows and demanding the Communist red star be removed from the roof. The charred walls and the empty mausoleum next door that once housed the embalmed body of Communist founder Georgi Dmitrov - removed and reburied in July - symbolize the collapse of Stalinism. Bulgaria's economy seems about to collapse with the old regime, and Sofia is preparing for a bleak winter. Harvests were ruined by the driest summer in 32 years. Meat, cheese, milk and even bread are rationed, and prices of available goods rise steadily. Power cuts to factories and homes are routine. Industrial production is down 30 percent from last year. Life is hardest for pensioners and the poor. ``These food lines, these prices; this is death for older people,'' said Maria Ivanova, 64, waiting in a chill rain for a store to open. ``We are eight people at home,'' said Stefka Savova, 61, who had waited three hours to find only milk and rationed bread available. ``We have a 2-month-old baby there and they give us just five cartons of milk. I don't have sausages, meat or cheese.'' Mrs. Savova, a retired nurse with a monthly pension equivalent to $14, said she had thought Zhivkov's fall was the beginning of a brighter future. ``We expected things to get better, and they have gotten worse,'' she said. ``I can do nothing ... only walk through the streets and cry.'' Legislators share the sense of helplessness. Parliament is ``incompetent and rather weak,'' said Dragomir Draganov, a reform-minded deputy for the newly named Socialists. Instead of either uniting to govern or splitting into into orthodox and reformist parties, he said, the Socialists have become a deadlocked hybrid of Stalinists and Social Democrats. On the other side, the the 17-party Union of Democratic Forces is united only in wanting the former Communists out of power. Political polarization and the coming winter ``create perfect conditions for every populist,'' Draganov said, and a succesful one ``could liquidate even the small gains we have made on our way to democracy.'' Petyo Bluskov, editor of a new business-oriented weekly, 168 Hours, expressed the public impatience: ``What kind of moral respect can (deputies) win if they argue for a week over what their salaries should be?'' he said. Opposition refusal to support the government's much-needed economic reform program, or accept anything less than the leadership of a coalition government, threatens to dash hopes of economic recovery. Until the stalemate is resolved, foreigners have little reason to invest in Bulgaria, a nation of 9 million with an obsolete industrial plant that relied on now vanishing supplies from old East European trading bloc. ``You know why you can't find beer in Bulgaria now?'' film director Angel Wagenstein asked. ``Not because there is no beer. Not because there are no btttles. We lack the tiny piece of plastic inside the metal caps, which came from some other part of Eastern Europe.'' The Persian Gulf crisis has been a serious blow. Iraq used to pay installments of its $1.3 billion debt to Bulgaria in oil. That has ceased and Soviet supplies, which must be paid for with hard currency starting next year, are getting scarce. Bulgaria cannot afford to pay the higher prices on the world oil market, and stopped payments on its $11 billion foreign debt in May. In September, international creditors agreed informally that debt payment resume only late next year.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, Nov. 9
$Adv13
For Release Tuesday AMs, Nov. 13, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Greek Minority, Religion, Democratic Demands Change Albania
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Eight years ago, a folk music group from neighboring Greece came to this ethnic Greek village in southern Albania. The audience waited hours in burning heat, but neither smiled nor applauded. A witness said the people turned out to demonstrate ethnic identity, but dared not show emotion in the Albania of Stalinist dictator Enver Hoxha. Hoxha died in 1985 and, by Oct. 26, 1990, things had changed. Foreign Minister Antonis Samaris of Greece was welcomed like a 20th century messiah when he visited Gorandsi and nearby Derviciani, another ethnic Greek settlement. Thousands of people surged past uniformed and secret police simply to touch or smile at him. Albania's Communist rulers have given hints of reform and are gradually losing control of the 3.2 million citizens they repressed for half a century. Startling evidence of the change came in July, when thousands of Albanians sought refuge at foreign embassies in Tirana, the capital, and were allowed to emigrate. Outside pressure has grown for improvements in human rights, particularly from the 2 million ethnic Albanians in neighboring Yugoslavia. If it wants to rejoin Europe, as it says, Albania must lift the ban on religion imposed in 1967, allow free speech and honor its promise, made before the mass emigration, of passports for all wishing to travel abroad. An illustration of the Communist leadership's dilemma was the Samaras visit to a minority Albania says numbers 80,000 and Greece, by including all the Greek Orthodox faithful, puts at more than 400,000. Trucks blocked the road to Gorandsi. Samaras stopped his motorcade and insisted on his scheduled visit to 1,000 people who awaited him in the dusk. Men from the Sigurimi, the Albanian secret police, were sprinkled liberally through the crowds in both villages. In Derviciani, a senior Albanian official threatened to expel a Greek journalist who was handing out Greek-language books to children. A woman identified by Greeks as Veronika Kallas, emboldened by the rare presence of foreigners, defied secret police to slip a visa request to a Greek journalist. She said her husband was in jail for trying to flee Albania. ``It shows you have not forgotten us,'' an excited teen-ager said as the crowd showed Samaras the former Greek Orthodox church of Gorandsi, now a dilapidated storehouse with a faded cross etched in the stone portal. Donkeys grazed in the yard. A woman gestured her eagerness to pray. Jars with burned-out wax on window sills of the warehouse attested to continued reverence for the church. Officials contend religion always was alien to Albanians, that the Moslem, Roman Catholic and Greek Orthodox faiths were imposed by occupying outsiders over the centuries. Recently, however, the authorities removed religion from a list of anti-state propaganda. After religion was outlawed, many churches and mosques became storehouses or ruins. Only a few are preserved as historical monuments. Albania was the only European nation not to sign the 1975 Helsinki agreements on European security and cooperation, which include comprehensive human rights provisions. It now wants to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, which resulted from the Helsinki accords. Albania may have little idea of what such membership entails. It has isolated itself from the West for two generations, broke with Moscow in 1968 and with China in 1976. ``I tell government officials that joining Helsinki means non-government organizations have the right to come here and ask `Why is this church or mosque closed?' and to get an answer,'' said a foreign official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``They simply don't understand what that means.'' Samaras' criticism of the host country's human rights record, delivered at a conference of Balkan foreign ministers in Tirana, was omitted from Albanian media reports. Officials were clearly unnerved by having to deal with the 105 foreign journalists allowed in for the conference, and gently urged the last eight to leave to do so before their visas expired. Government secrecy makes it virtually impossible to verify numerous rumors of human rights violations. Reports of border shootings or torture often arise in Greece or Yugoslavia. Both have an interest in painting Albania darkly, the Greeks because of their minority in the country and the Yugoslavs because of the restive ethnic Albanian majority in Serbia's Kosovo province. Kosovo's Albanians are far freer than citizens of Albania, despite being stripped of provincial autonomy by Serbia. Hunger for cross-border contacts is increasing, and hundreds of people a day apply for visas at the Yugoslav consulate in Tirana. In May, acknowledging international pressure for the first time, the Albanian leadership published figures indicating only 35 political prisoners were held. Aleks Lasuari, a Tirana University legal expert, told reporters the death sentence is reserved only for severe crimes, and that only three or four people are executed each year. How Deputy Foreign Minister Sokrat Plaka handled the Samaras trip is an example of the government's quandary. First, he insisted to a reporter that those in the enthusiastic crowd around the visitor were complaining that Greece was not issuing enough visas. Minutes later, he pointed at the smiling faces and said: ``You see, people are happy here in Albania.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Nov. 13
$Adv13
For release Tuesday AMs, Nov. 13, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Mr. Mom Fighting for Entry Into Mother's Group
DOC.TEXT: Joel Chaiken changes diapers, cleans house and is the chief caretaker of his toddler son. He does everything the other mothers in his Bronx neighborhood do. His problem is he's not a mother. That's why he was banned from a local mothers-infant group, which deemed his male persona, non grata. Chaiken, 32, tried to join the Riverdale Neighborhood House support group last October when his son, Benjamin, was 7 months old. ``I thought basically it was a place to go during the day and meet new people; a place to find out about baby care - to find out real information, the kind your pediatrician can't give you - a place for Benjamin to socialize and a place for support, to a certain extent.'' Instead, he found a closed door. Chaiken is trying to pry it open by filing what is believed to be a precedent-setting discrimination suit. The state Division on Human Rights recently decided Chaiken's case has merit and has ordered a public hearing. ``We found enough reason to believe he was treated differently because he was a man,'' said Felicia Clavell of the state agency. Some in Riverdale's upper-middle class neighborhood some 11 miles north of midtown Manhattan say that's the way it should be. ``There are mothers and there are dads and he's not a mother,'' said Caryl Malka, 33, boiling the argument down to basics. ``I would feel very uncomfortable talking about personal things in front of him,'' the two-time mother and former group member said. ``It's not a play group, it's not just about the semantics of scheduling or diapering ... It's women getting together and talking about very intimate things and a man joining the group would really change that.'' Chaiken agrees, but he doesn't think that's negative. ``I think it would change for the better. Once they learn a real man could be understanding and compassionate, their own relationships might change.'' ``Women don't have a monopoly on emotional support and compassion toward others,'' said Chaiken's wife, Sue Ellen Dodell, who encouraged her husband to file the complaint. Gender equality is important to the couple. That's evident in the surname they chose for their child. It isn't one name or the other, or a hyphenated version but an equal combination of the two: Chaidell. It's also evident in the Chaiken-Dodell-Chaidell family's toy-strewn living room, littered with everything from a diapered baby doll to pickup trucks. Chaiken said they decided ``at conception'' that he would give up his $37,000-a-year engineering job to care for their child. Dodell, 35, is a lawyer for the city. His wife suggested he join the group after seeing an advertisement in a local paper inviting ``mothers with babies up to 1 year old'' to come and ``relax with a cup of coffee and enjoy each other's company while they care for their babies.'' The ad said topics included ``easing the transition into parenthood, new routines, infants' sleeping and eating habits, talking to your pediatrician and choosing child care.'' Chaiken attended an open house and told social worker Etty Bar-Shai, who runs the group, that he was interested in joining. ``She said it was full and that I should check again in January,'' Chaiken said. The center limits the group to 10 members; there were four in the group the semester Chaiken applied. He said he continued asking questions about the group but ``I got the feeling she was uncomfortable.'' The next day, Chaiken's wife called to ask about joining and was told, ``Sure there's spots open, why don't you come in for an interview.'' When he confronted Ms. Bar-Shai, she told him the group was only for mothers. As a woman, Dodell said, ``I understand some may feel uncomfortable at first but I think they should just give him a chance and see. I really think they could benefit from his perspective.'' But that, she said, is the emotional side of the issue. Legally, she believes, the center is plain wrong. ``It's a place of public accommodation and Joel should be permitted in the group, period.'' Riverdale Neighborhood House is a nonprofit center that receives city and state funding for a variety of educational and support programs. The state Human Rights agency agrees and will argue Chaiken's viewpoint at an as yet unscheduled hearing, Clavell said. ``They placed an ad and said, `Come one, come all, join us.' But when Mr. Chaiken took them up on the offer, they said, `Oh no, you have to be a woman.' When you invite the public that includes men,'' Clavell said. Donald Cohn, a vice president at the center and an attorney at the high-powered, Park Avenue law firm of Webster & Sheffield, insists there was no discrimination. ``He took advantage of other programs at Riverdale House and he was invited to participate in other programs,'' Cohn said. ``This one was just not appropriate for him.'' After the hearing, an administrative law judge will make a recommendation and State Commissioner of Human Rights Douglas White will issue a final order. The case may take longer than a year to resolve. Chaiken realizes the decision will come too late to benefit Benjamin, who at 19 months old is already happily ensconced in a toddlers group, albeit not at Neighborhood House. Chaiken said he was allowed to join the toddler group at the center but was already committed to a different program. ``So why are we fighting on? We're fighting on because this issue really has to be resolved,'' said Chaiken. ``It's really to help future fathers who stay at home so they won't have to go through this battle,'' Dodell added. Besides, they said, the decision may come in time for child No. 2.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Nov. 13

DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, Nov 10-11

DOC.TEXT: The Big Three automakers' sales of North American-made cars and light trucks rose 5.3 percent in late October and were up 2.7 percent for the first month of the 1991 model year, confounding pessimistic economic news. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said Monday their car and light truck sales rose 5.3 percent to an average daily rate of 34,009 in the Oct. 21-31 period, from a daily sales rate of 32,302 in the same period last year. Car sales rose 8.4 percent while sales of light trucks edged up 0.5 percent. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Sales of existing homes from July through September slipped 2.5 percent from their level a year earlier and will remain slow in the first half of 1991 because of the weakening economy, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Monday that sales of previously owned homes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.66 million units in the three-month period. Sales declined in the year's two previous quarters as well. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - United Press International said it will be forced into liquidation in less than two weeks unless union employees of the news service accept a 90-day pay cut of 35 percent. A spokesman for the Wire Service Guild, which represents the employees, said Monday that the union is recommending rejection of the proposal. UPI last week said it was cutting management salaries 35 percent for 90 days and would seek similar concessions from employees represented by the guild to try to improve the company's financial condition as it seeks a buyer. --- DETROIT (AP) - The United Auto Workers won a 35-hour workweek at a St. Louis minivan plant in a new national contract, a provision the union may seek nationwide, union President Owen Bieber said. The provision, which still must be voted on by members of a local at the St. Louis plant, is included in a special section of the tentative national labor contract between the union and the nation's No. 3 automaker. --- BOSTON (AP) - General Cinema Corp., which has a majority share in Neiman Marcus Group, called off a deal to buy remaining stock in the specialty retailer less than a week after the offer was announced. General Cinema said Monday it took the action because a special committee of the Neiman Marcus board of directors had decided to withdraw its recommendation supporting the $14.40 a share tender offer. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Time Magazine announced a 6.5 percent rate boost for a full-page, four-color advertisement in 1991 national editions. The weekly magazine, one of the nation's largest, on Monday attributed the hike to rising costs, including an expected postal rate increase. The magazine said its last rate increase was four years ago. The rate increase, effective in January will boost the price for a four-color national ad to $128,000 a page, up from $120,310. That type of ad accounts for about 55 percent of the magazine's ad revenue. --- NEW YORK (AP) - A former stockbroker settled charges that he illegally traded on information in advance copies of Business Week magazine. John L. Petit, an ex-broker with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in Newport Beach, Calif., was the 11th person charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with illicit trading involving the weekly business magazine. Petit, who now lives in Boca Raton, Fla., agreed Monday to pay $195,528 in illegal profits, fines and interest to settle the charges. --- GENEVA (AP) - The leading airline industry group recommended up to an 8 percent increase in passenger fares and 7 percent rise in cargo prices to help airlines offset high fuel costs caused by the Persian Gulf crisis. The International Air Transport Association's recommendations, issued Monday during its conference in Geneva, marked the second time since the crisis began three months ago that the industry has moved to raise prices because of fuel inflation. Any increase is subject to approval by affected countries. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Field Publications has settled charges it mailed books to its subscribers that they had not asked for or agreed to receive, and then billed them for payment, the Federal Trade Commission said. Field, the publisher of Weekly Reader Books and other book plans, said Monday it has acted to correct the shortcomings. ---

The stock market Monday extended a rally on the strength of continuing hopes for lower interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.39 to 2,502.23 on top of last week's 54.70-point gain. The dollar fell sharply, reaching a new post-war low against the German mark and new lows against the Swiss and French francs. Gold prices rose. Bond prices rose. Soybean futures prices sagged to new three-month lows; grain futures finished mixed; oil futures fell sharply; precious metals rose; coffee was down; livestock futures were mixed; and pork bellies soared.

DOC.HEAD: City on Financial Brink Improvises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX4 of Nov. 5
DOC.TEXT: Outside contractors are demanding payment up front and city employees are being urged to write on both sides of their memos to save paper as Philadelphia totters on the brink of insolvency. And if the city doesn't pay certain bills that are due, it's out of toilet paper. Strangely, there is no panic among city workers. They say they have felt all along a bailout will come from somewhere before the paychecks stop and they must decide whether to work on faith alone as Mayor W. Wilson Goode said he expects them to. Employees said in interviews they and their colleagues feel that after Tuesday's elections for governor and state lawmakers, Wednesday will be city-saving day. ``Until the election is over the Democrats and Republicans are looking at that'' rather than the crisis, said John J. Shaw, head of the police union. ``After the election they will look for solutions and try to float the city again.'' Officials expect the cash to run out sometime next month. Besides the immediate cash flow problem, officials also project a $207 million deficit at the end of the year and an even bigger one the next year. Department heads are busy turning on immediate cost-cutting moves such as turning off office machines that use up paper, supplies and electricity while crafting contingency plans for the day the checks bounce. Contractors and suppliers are demanding payment for new work up front and businesses like toilet paper suppliers won't deliver until back balances are paid. Just Monday, Episcopal Community Service said it was cutting off services to new AIDS patients because the city has paid nothing on a $300,000 June contract. ``It's a terrible choice to make,'' said the Rev. Gilbert Avery, who is in charge of the service, which provides home meals and transportation to and from doctors offices for up to 100 people. The 25,000 city workers have organized no outside job pools, resume services or other emergency plans for themselves. Many say they have considered the situation but see no reason to get too excited. ``I've done most of my Christmas shopping, under the circumstances,'' said Deputy Sheriff Donald Sicura. The police, the street cleaners, even the auditors who add the numbers in City Hall cling to the belief that Philadelphia's fiscal crisis will be resolved before December. Their faith is undeterred by Goode's repeated denial that no secret rescue plan is in place and he has repeated his feeling that city workers should come to work even after the cash runs out. In September, city employees began finding letters in their pay envelopes that said the city would be unable to meet its payroll starting sometime in December. The Philadelphia Inquirer reported last week that a secret plan already had been worked out and would be unveiled after Tuesday's election. Goode again flatly denied any such plan. And he reiterated his claim that no full-scale state bailout is necessary. ``Whatever pain we're feeling now, every other city will go through the same pain,'' Goode said in a recent interview. ``And we're going to recover faster and first and be stronger, longer, in my view.'' ``Philadelphia does not have a problem that is beyond the means of its politicians to solve,'' he maintained. Not many believe the mayor's denial, saying it's all just politics. In the meantime, in addition to cost-saving measures and delayed payments to outside suppliers and contractors, overtime has been cut off in most departments. Seasonal workers at Fairmount Park were laid off a month early. The workers normally stay on until winter to help with trash removal and help plant the city's yearly allotment of 60,000 to 70,000 bulbs. In the courts, 17 new judicial clerks missed a payday in September after the city finance director ruled they arrived after the city's hiring freeze Sept. 21. The clerks, hired at salaries between $22,000 and $25,000, were kept on only after negotiations between city officials and court administrators. Leon Walker, 55, a court officer for 13 years, is one of the few city workers who would say he has made plans to deal with a pay stoppage. ``Well, the thing is I done paid my rent a month in advance,'' he said last week as he ate his lunch on a bench outside City Hall.

DOC.HEAD: Philly Mayor: City Will Move From Chaos
LaserPhoto PX4 of Nov. 5
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With PM-Philly Finances, Bjt. Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A city that today is mired in debt, litter and social ills will become the envy of other major cities in the years ahead, Mayor W. Wilson Goode says. Goode looked at Philadelphia's financial crisis with optimism during a rare one-on-one interview recently and maintained Philadelphia is even now moving into position as a role model. ``Whatever pain we're feeling now, every other city will go through the same pain,'' Goode said. ``And we're going to recover faster and first and be stronger, longer, in my view.'' However, Goode said long-term solutions are still to be worked out and, until they are, the city will continue to try to borrow enough to avoid going broke. State involvement so far has been little more than a shadowy presence, partially because of Tuesday's elections for governor and the Legislature. Despite Republican campaign statements to the contrary, Philadelphia does not seek or expect a state bailout, the mayor contends. He also said he knows of no plan by Gov. Robert P. Casey to provide one. Instead, Goode is looking for a little help from the state, like changes in tax laws, rather than a wholesale takeover. ``Philadelphia does not have a problem that is beyond the means of its politicians to solve,'' he maintained. He was also optimistic about loan opportunities. Investors shunned the city's attempt to borrow $375 million in September and Goode would not say by what means the city would try to borrow in coming days. ``To say that might mean that the people who are working with us might very well decid not to do it at this point,'' he said. The borrowing would be the first of a three-part solution, Goode said. The other parts are to erase this year's deficit and create a sound budget for the next fiscal year. The process could be influenced by Democrat Casey's re-election bid against Republican Auditor General Barbara Hafer and contests for half the seats in the state Senate and the entire state House. The Senate in Harrisburg has 27 Republicans and 23 Democrats. The House has 103 Democrats, 99 Republicans and an empty seat. ``If the Democrats keep control over the state House and can gain control over the state Senate, and if Bob Casey is re-elected by a mandate margin, then I think that Philadelphia stands, in my opinion, to gain a great deal from those elections,'' Goode said. If Casey wins and the power structure is unchanged in the House and Senate, ``I think it will be more difficult to get a consensus as to how best to deal with our problem,'' he said. If Hafer wins, the Democratic mayor said he expects a stalemate. One twist to the city's woes is that Goode, prevented by the city charter from seeking a third term next year, is drawing some of his most visible support since the 1985 armed standoff with the MOVE cult and the police bombing of their headquarters that killed 11 people, including five children. Several businesses and non-profit institutions have prepaid taxes and about 400 people attended a rally on his behalf at a church. ``I think there are a lot of people out there who feel I've become a victim of uncontrollable circumstances, and therefore want to help me morally, financially and governmentally to solve the problems,'' Goode said.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Say Late-October Car, Light Truck Sales Rise
DOC.TEXT: Late-October sales of North American-made cars and light trucks managed an 8.5 percent increase from a year ago, but some car dealers say many shoppers are just looking. For the full month, the first of the 1991 model year, car and light truck sales were 5.7 percent higher than last October, the 10 major domestic makers said Monday. Foreign companies' U.S.-made car sales were up 33.8 percent in the Oct. 21-31 period, while General Motors, Ford and Chrysler accounted for a 5.3 percent increase. Some car dealers were dissappointed that the new 1991 models didn't lure more people to their showrooms in October. ``They're just not in a buying mood,'' said George Turner, sales manager at Bill MacDonald Ford in St. Clair, Mich. The news auto sale news came out days after the federal government reported a decline in the Leading Economic Indicators and a decline in employment. Sales of North American-made cars rose 12.1 percent in the Oct. 21-31 period while light truck sales rose just 2.4 percent, the companies said. Auto analyst Mary Ann Sudol of Fitch Investors Service said the lackluster performance of trucks could be a result of consumer concerns about gas mileage. Overall sales topped last October's figures, which were down sharply from a strong September when sales promotions to clear out 1989 model inventories bolstered sales. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. said their car and light truck sales rose 5.3 percent to an average daily rate of 34,009 in the Oct. 21-31 period from a daily sales rate of 32,302 in the same period last year. Car sales rose 8.4 percent while sales of light trucks edged up 0.5 percent. For the first month of the model year, the Big Three reported sales up 2.7 percent, with their car sales up 6.1 percent while truck sales lagged 2.7 percent. For the first 10 months of the calendar year, sales of North American-made cars and light trucks remained 3.8 percent behind last year's, with car sales down 4 percent and trucks trailing by 3.4 percent. GM said its car and truck sales for late October were up 3.6 percent, with a 5 percent increase in car sales, and truck sales up 1 percent. GM said its vehicle sales were still down 4.3 percent for the first 10 months of the year. Ford said its late-October vehicle sales were 10.5 percent ahead of last year, with cars up 13.3 percent and trucks up 6.5 percent. Ford said car and light truck sales still trailed 8 percent for the year so far, however. Chrysler said late-October vehicle sales edged up 0.9 percent, with a 10.1 percent rise in car sales overcoming an 8.2 percent drop in sales of light trucks. Chrysler said its combined car and light truck sales were down 13.8 percent for the year through Oct. 31.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Auto Sales, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are sales results for the 10 major U.S. automakers for third period of October 1990. Percentage changes in sales are based on average daily sales during each period rather than comparisons of straight totals. There were nine selling days in the period this year and nine selling days last year. For the month, there were 27 selling days this year and 26 selling days last year, and for the year so far, 257 selling days this year and 256 selling days last year. Cars and trucks made in the United States by Honda, Nissan, Toyota, Mazda, Subaru, Isuzu and Mitsubishi are counted as domestic and appear in this table separately and combined as transplant cars. Mazda has begun selling sport-utility vehicles made in a Ford plant in Kentucky. Cars and trucks imported for sale under the GM, Ford and Chrysler names are counted as foreign.

DOC.HEAD: Trash Hauler Reaches $19.5 Million Settlement in Price-Fixing Suit
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest trash hauler, seeking to avoid costly court battles, has agreed to pay several customers $19.5 million to settle civil claims of price fixing. Waste Management Inc. denied wrongdoing in reaching the settlement. Subsidiaries from California to New York had been targeted in federal antitrust investigations, and in several markets where criminal charges were not brought the parent company faced civil action, said spokesman William J. Plunkett. ``Our decision was made to avoid certain protracted and costly litigation,'' Plunkett said on Monday. ``The plaintiffs were never able to develop any information even suggesting antitrust conduct beyond the local markets to which our settlement monies will be distributed,'' Plunkett said. ``We refused as a matter of principle to consider any payments to a nationwide class, because we vigorously denied that there was any impropriety of that scale.'' The suit was brought by a group of customers led by Cumberland Farms Inc., a Canton, Mass., convenience store operator. Waste Management, based in Oak Brook, said the settlement received preliminary approval Monday in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania. The lawsuit contended that subsidiaries of Waste Management and Browning-Ferris Industries, the second-largest trash hauler in the country, conspired to fix prices for containerized waste disposal. Waste Management's settlement money will be distributed in 13 markets where antitrust investigations had been conducted. The plaintiffs agreed to abandon all other claims against Waste Management. Officials at Cumberland Farms could not be reached for comment. Antitrust investigations resulted in criminal charges in seven markets against Waste Management subsidiaries. In December 1989, two subsidiaries of Waste Management pleaded guilty to federal price-fixing charges in California and paid fines totalling $1.5 million. In October 1987, subsidiaries of Waste Management pleaded guilty to similar charges in Toledo, Ohio, and the company paid $1 million in fines. Units of Waste Management also were convicted in 1984 in federal district court in Atlanta of price fixing there. The settlements applied to cases in Toledo; Memphis, Tenn.; Jacksonville, Orlando, and Dade and Broward counties, Fla.; Phoenix; Atlanta; Rochester, N.Y.; three counties in southern California; and a market encompassing several counties in northern New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Pitney Bowes Announces Layoffs of 100 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Pitney Bowes Inc. says 100 workers at its distribution center will lose their jobs by early December as part of a decision to stop refurbishing used copier equipment. The $2.9 billion office products company employs 350 workers at its Newtown site. The remaining 250 workers will continue with the company's istribution division, spokesman Terrence Marable said Monday. Pitney Bowes, based in Stamford, said in September it would no longer remake used copier equipment, deciding instead to concentrate on new, higher-margin copiers for large corporations. The Newtown plant was the only site where the company refurbished used copier equipment for resale, Marable said. Pitney Bowes, struggling under declining revenues, adopted a three-year reorganization plan last December. The company said then it would cut 1,500 jobs from its payrolls over the next three years. Some employees were offered a severance package consisting of two weeks pay for each year of service or 75 percent of their annual salary, whichever was greater. In May, George B. Harvey, chairman and chief executive officer, said 1,040 workers chose to take a severance package and leave the company this year. Another 500 jobs were targeted for elimination through attrition and other initiatives, a spokesman said. For the nine months ended in September, Pitney Bowes earned $131.9 million on sales of $2.33 billion, down from earnings of $243.3 million on sales of $2.06 billion for the same period in 1989. Net income last year was boosted by an accounting change, and the 1990 figures included a one-time third quarter restructuring charge of $86 million. In addition to copiers, Pitney Bowes makes mailing, shipping, dictating and facsimile systems, as well as mailroom and related management services. It employs about 30,000 workers worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Prudential-Bache Securities Lays Off Two-Thirds of Investment Bankers
DOC.TEXT: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. is laying off at least two-thirds of its investment bankers and the head of its investment banking division has resigned from that post, a published report said today. The Wall Street Journal reported that in laying off about 120 of its 180 investment bankers, the brokerage firm is effectively ending its four-year effort to become a major investment bank. Separately, reports in the Journal and The New York Times today said Prudential-Bache was expected to settle several pending disciplinary cases with the New York Stock Exchange. A spokeswoman for the firm, Eleanor Mascheroni, said she wasn't able to comment on the report of personnel moves, and said it was premature to comment on the disciplinary cases. In its story on the planned layoffs, the Journal said James F. Crowley has resigned as head of investment banking at the firm but will continue as a senior officer. Prudential-Bache spent heavily four years ago to shore up its investment banking business and become one of the nation's biggest investment banking firms by 1989. The brokerage had been geared toward small investors. But the Journal said Prudential-Bache chairman George Ball said in an internal memorandum on Oct. 22 that the firm needs to cut 1991 costs by $100 million and singled out the investment banking department. ``First, the Investment Bank is hurting on the bottom line and we intend to scale it to a size where it'll be profitable in 1991,'' Ball wrote. Pudential-Bache lost $51 million overall last year. In the first nine months of the year, Prudential-Bache ranked 42nd on Wall Street in total value of completed deals such as mergers, spinoffs and stock repurchases and was in the top 20 in the number of completed deals, according to Securities Data Co. The Journal and the Times each reported that one of the cases the firm is expected to settle with thew NYSE is related to a Securities and Exchange Commission action the firm settled last year in which it was censured for incorrectly monitoring about $200 million in customers' securities. Prudential-Bache has said that customers weren't harmed by the monitoring problems.

DOC.HEAD: Editors:
DOC.TEXT: The four commodity exchanges in New York City have decided to remain in the lower Manhattan financial district, passing up offers to move to New Jersey. A story slugged PM-Commodity Exchanges-Site will move within 20 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Last of Big Three Contracts Set for Ratification
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers' Chrysler bargaining council has approved a new contract with the automaker that includes a 35-hour workweek for workers at a minivan plant. The new union contract includes a provision that will allow the 35-hour workweek for 3,500 workers at Chrysler's St. Louis minivan plant. ``That is a plum we were very happy to pluck off the tree,'' UAW President Owen Bieber said Monday. ``Certainly it is something we would look at with great delight in the future.'' The union's Chrysler bargaining council voted overwhelmingly Monday to submit the tentative contract reached last Tuesday for rank-and-file ratification among about 63,000 hourly and salaried Chrysler workers. That process is expected to be completed within two weeks. Last May, at the UAW's bargaining convention, Bieber and other union officials said they planned to negotiate nearly identical terms for each of the Big Three contracts. The contract is similar to UAW agreements signed last month with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. In all, more than 450,000 active workers are covered by UAW agreements with the Big Three. Chrysler has been looking for ways to boost production at its St. Louis II and Windsor, Ontario, minivan plants for more than a year. The minivan is Chrysler's hottest-selling vehicle - more than 300,000 have already been sold this year. A year ago, the company and the UAW leadership tried to get members of Local 110 to accept a scheduling scheme that would have included three crews working two shifts, boosting production by about 20 percent. The workers overwhelmingly rejected that idea, saying it ate into their overtime. That concern could be wiped out by the 35-hour week for 40 hours of pay. The tentative agreement will let the 3,500 workers at the St. Louis II plant vote to change their scheduling plan within 120 days of contract ratification. Otherwise, in July 1991, the factory will change to a three-shift operation Monday through Friday with two nine-hour production shifts on Saturdays if the company chooses. The Saturday shifts will be paid at the full overtime rate. Elsewhere, the Chrysler contract contains many of the same provisions as the GM and Ford agreements, including a commitment to guarantee full pay for employees laid off for more than 36 weeks at factories closed because of slumping sales. GM committed about $4.1 billion and Ford said it would pay up to $1.6 billion for the same program. Chrysler's commitment is about $659 million.

The stock market fell slightly this morning, amid concerns of possible war in the Persian Gulf and modestly rising oil prices. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.66 to 2,492.57 in the first half hour of trading. Volume on the Big Board came to 18.95 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 376 up, 583 down and 492 unchanged. Analysts said the market was watching the behavior of interest rates in the credit markets. The possibility of war in the Middle East, combined with higher oil prices, can put upward pressure on interest rates and reduce demand for stocks. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks climbed .74 to 170.75. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .06 at 291.52. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.39 to 2,502.23, on top of last week's 54.70-point gain. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 9 to 5 on the NYSE, with 1,027 up, 543 down and 424 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 147.51 million shares, against 168.70 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Manufacturer Agrees to Buy Cookson Graphics for $215 Million
DOC.TEXT: International Paper Co. said Tuesday it has agreed to buy the graphics business of Cookson Group PLC of the United Kingdom for about $215 million. International Paper, based in suburban Purchase, N.Y., said it was buying Cookson Graphics, a global supplier of lithographic printing plates, press-room chemicals and plate processing equipment to the commercial printing industry. Cookson Graphics employs about 1,600 people and has manufacturing facilities in the United Kingdomn, Germany and the United States. Its sales are expected to amount to about $300 million this year. International Paper, a leading producer of paper and forest products, said Cookson Graphics' product lines will complement the photosensitive papers and films made and sold by its Anitec division and boost the company's sales in imaging products to more than $900 million a year. International Paper earned $864 million, or $7.72 per share, on sales of $11.4 billion in 1989. Cookson Group, based in Leeds, England, is an industrial materials company.

DOC.HEAD: Suits Accusing Airlines of Price Fixing Consolidated in Atlanta
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge in Atlanta has been chosen to hear a consolidated lawsuit alleging collusion and price-fixing among several of the nation's air carriers and their computerized fare network. The suit, formed when 31 claims filed across the country were consolidated Friday in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia, alleges that the airlines signal fare changes to each other, agree on price increases and threaten fare cuts via computer. Defendants in the case are USAir, Northwest, Delta, Continental, United, TWA and American airlines and the Washington-based computer clearinghouse that links them, Airline Tariff Publishing Co. They deny wrongdoing. The suit charges that, as a result of the alleged collusion, passengers are forced to pay artificially high ticket prices. Anyone who purchased a plane ticket since 1987 could potentially be a party in the suit. The case was assigned to U.S. District Judge Marvin H. Shoob when a panel of federal judges from around the nation decided Friday that Atlanta was easily accessible to all parties in the suit. If Shoob certifies the lawsuit as a class action, a decision expected early next year, the plaintiffs could number in the millions. It could be the largest civil litigation ever ``in the history of Atlanta, if not the largest in the United States,'' said W. Pitts Carr, the Atlanta attorney who filed the first suit here last July. ``In 1988, 150 million tickets were sold, so that would give you a rough idea of the possible magnitude of this case,'' he said. ``There are literally tens of millions of people or companies who are potential class members.'' The defendants deny any collusion. ``Delta denies totally the allegations ... concerning our participation in any conspiracy to fix prices,'' said Edward B. Krugman, one of the airline's attorneys. The suit asks for undetermined damages that could be tripled under federal antitrust laws. It also asks that the airlines be restrained from further violation of antitrust laws and that the computer network be ``restructured so as to discourage future collusion among airlines.''

The stock market was off slightly this morning, amid uncertainty over what the United States will do in the Persian Gulf once today's elections are out of the way. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 1.49 at 2,500.74 as of 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Volume on the Big Board came to 43.81 million shares. Gainers barely outnumbered losers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 637 up, 604 down and 475 unchanged. Analysts saw no real pattern in today's trading. ``It's uncertainty more than anything else,'' said Sara Cerato, a vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``I'm hearing more rumors about war breaking out after the election.'' Some investment strategists are even starting to pick days that they believe will be the beginning of the war, she said. Analysts said the market was watching the behavior of interest rates in the credit markets. The possibility of war in the Middle East, combined with higher oil prices, can put upward pressure on interest rates and reduce demand for stocks. In early trading on the NYSE, Browning Ferris was down 5\ at 25, Unisys was off [ at 2} and Waste Management was down 1[ at 33~. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks fell .32 to 171.17. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .39 at 291.19.

DOC.HEAD: EC Commission Frees Imports Of U.S. Solvent
DOC.TEXT: The European Community Commission said Tuesday it was satisfied that imports of an organic solvent from the United States would not threaten the trade bloc's chemical industry. In a statement, the Commission said that U.S. manufacturers of the solvent called propan-1-ol would no longer have to set a minimum price on their product in the 12-nation trade bloc. Propan-1-ol is used as a solvent in the printing and pharmaceutical industries, and as an intermediary agent in the manufacture of pesticides. Following a complaint from the Council of the European Federation of Chemical Industries, the Commission began an inquiry into whether foreign manufacturers were dumping propan-1-ol on the European market at unjustifiably low prices in 1983. U.S. producers, including Eastman Kodak Co. and Union Carbide Corp., subsequently agreed to set a minimum price on the chemical for five years, ending in 1989. At the end of 1988, the council asked the commission, on behalf of EC's sole propan-1-ol maker, BASF AG of Germany, to investigate again the impact of the imports on free trade. The Commission concluded that imports of U.S-made propan-1-ol had been cut by nearly half over the five-year period, to 4,428 metric tons in 1989 from 8,738 tons in 1983, and no longer constituted a threat to EC manufacturers. ``The profits made by the plaintiff industry have risen to a level where they must be considered satisfactory,'' the Commission said.

DOC.HEAD: After Threatening to Leave, Exchanges Say They'll Remain In New York
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-9 pvs, `Under the... to CORRECT that $225 million is cost of trading floor sted entire project; PICKS UP 10th graf, `The heads...
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street's leading commodity markets gave economically battered New York a welcome respite today, promising to stay in the financial center after threatening to leave for a cheaper bigger home in New Jersey. The decision by the four exchanges, which trade items ranging from crude oil to cocoa to gold, was announced after an all-night bargaining session with New York city and state officials who gave the exchanges a generous package of tax breaks, land and other incentives to build a new home here. ``It is clear this is a long-term investment in the economic future of our city that we believe is worth making,'' Mayor David Dinkins told a news conference. ``This vote in the confidence of the future of our city is so very important.'' The announcement is a relief for the city, which is confronting an overall economic decline incited by a devastating recession on Wall Street that has persisted since the stock market crash three years ago. Thousands of people have been laid off in the financial district, which also is home to the New York and American stock exchanges. Moreover, the city is once again facing a looming financial crisis of its own reminiscent of the dark days when it verged on going broke in the 1970s. The four commodity exchanges, on the other hand, have been straining to expand in order to compete with rival exchanges in Chicago and elsewhere. The New York commodity exchanges employ about 12,000 people, a figure that is expected to rise sharply in coming years in the battle for domination of that business. They had threatened to leave the city unless they could work out an attractive deal to move into bigger quarters. Dinkins said exchanges generated more than $1.3 billion in economic activity annually and produce $165 million a year in city and state taxes, even with all the abatements. He said the overall package will not significantly affect the city's own budget crisis. Under the deal, New York state and city will provide a total of $145 million in incentives for the four exchanges to relocate from their cramped quarters at the World Trade Center to a new building to be constructed on an empty plot nearby, to be completed in four years. The total cost of the project was not determined, officials said, but the new trading floor alone is expected to cost of $225 million. The new site will triple the size of the exchanges' total floor space to 1.2 million square feet. The heads of the exchanges told the news conference they'll recommend to the membership that they move to the new site. The exchanges had considered moving to the Harborside Financial Center in Jersey City, N.J. Their decision to remain in New York was unanimous. ``Although we seriously considered a move to ... Jersey City, we believe that the long-term needs of the exchanges wil be best served by staying in New York City,'' the exchange leaders said. ``At our new home in the heart of New York's financial district, the exchanges will have the space, the flexibility and the state-of-the-art technology we sorely need ...'' Jersey City Mayor Gerald McCann was not immediately available for comment. The city's offices were closed for election day, and the mayor did not return a message left on his home telephone answering machine. Members of the exchanges will be asked to ratify the decision in December. If they fail to do so, the exchanges will remain at the World Trade Center. The exchanges involved are the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange Inc., established in 1882 and the world's leading market in those commodities; the Commodity Exchange Inc., established in 1933 and the world's most active metals market; the New York Cotton Exchange, established in 1870 and the world's only raw cotton and citrus market; and the New York Mercantile Exchange, established in 1872 and the world's dominant energy market.

DOC.HEAD: CBS, NBC Election Coverage Without Sponsors
DOC.TEXT: Tonight's prime-time election specials on the CBS and NBC television networks won't be sponsored, although ABC's coverage will have commercials. The one-hour NBC special and CBS' two hours of election night coverage in prime time will be carried as ``sustaining,'' or unsponsored, representatives of both networks said. This means the CBS and NBC broadcasts won't be counted in the current November ratings ``sweeps,'' one of four key ratings periods each year that help network affilliates set their local advertising rates. Both NBC and CBS will use the time, however, to promote shows they're broadcasting as the sweeps period continues this month. NBC acted after CBS decided against seeking sponsorship for its election night program, said an NBC executive who asked not to be identified. It took that step because of the tight prime-time ratings race of all three networks this season, the executive said. If NBC's coverage was sponsored and included in Nielsen ratings, low viewing levels the networks expect on election night might pull down NBC's overall ratings average for this week. NBC again is first in prime-time ratings this season, but its margin over second-place CBS is small. According to ratings averages for the season through last Sunday, NBC has a 13.3 ratings average, CBS a 13.0 and ABC a 12.5. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes.

The stock market was slightly lower at midday, amid uncertainties over what the United States will do in the Persian Gulf after today's elections. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 1.49 at 2,500.74 as of noon on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 745 up, 554 down and 513 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 68.40 million shares at noon, down from 72.46 a day earlier. Analysts saw no real pattern in today's trading. ``It's uncertainty more than anything else,'' said Sara Cerato, a vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``I'm hearing more rumors about war breaking out after the election.'' Some investment strategists are even starting to pick days that they believe will be the beginning of the war, she said. In early trading on the NYSE, Browning Ferris was down 5] to 24~ on a disappointing earnings report that came as a surprise to many analysts. Waste Management was off 1[ at 33~ after announcing it will pay a court settlement of $19.5 million to avoid fighting civil price-fixing claims.
