Circuit City dropped 2] to 11~ following the release of sales reports that were not as strong as analysts were hoping. Unisys fell [ to 2} amid concern that it may have to sell assets at distressed prices. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks was down .04 at 171.45. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .43 at 292.01.

DOC.NOTE: For release Sunday, Nov. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Accountants, Wary Of Lawsuits, Turning Clients Away
With Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Several months ago Bob Israeloff sat down with the president of a Long Island high-tech manufacturer who was looking for a new auditor. The account would have generated $75,000 a year in fees for Israeloff, Trattner & Co., a mid-sized accounting firm. But after carefully reviewing the company's financial statements, he turned the executive down. It wasn't the first time a potential client sent up red flags in Israeloff's mind. Like a growing number of accountants, he was worried that doing business with the company might result in malpractice charges. Lawsuits targeting accountants - filed by businesses challenging audits or shareholders claiming to have received faulty financial information - are on the rise, and the threat of litigation is having a chilling effect on the profession. According to a recent survey by the New York insurance broker Johnson & Higgins, four out of five certified public accountants have cut back on the services they provide. The poll of 500 accountants nationwide also showed that 56 percent have ceased doing business with clients considered at ``high risk'' for initiating lawsuits, and 98 percent ask clients to sign protective contracts before work begins. Allen Berger, a partner in Chicago-based Blackman Kallick Bartelstein, said his firm declined an invitation to bid on auditing a savings and loan. ``The thought of having your name in the newspapers just wasn't worth the return,'' he said. While S&Ls top the list of businesses being shunned, the survey showed many accountants are steering clear of start-ups and companies considering initial public offerings as well. Fear of litigation comes at a time when accounting firms are squeezed for cash. Laventhol & Horwath, the nation's seventh largest accounting firm, recently said it was under so much financial pressure that it was cutting the pay of its nearly 3,500 employees by 10 percent for three months. Philadelphia-based Laventhol blamed the cuts on a deteriorating economy. But the firm also has been hurt by unfavorable settlements and judgments - only some of which were covered by insurance - stemming from lawsuits challenging the quality of its audits. Laventhol went to trial last month in North Carolina over the auditing of Jim Bakker's PTL ministry. The suit, which also named Deloitte & Touche, charged the firms oversaw a secret bank account that was used to pay Bakker and others millions in bonuses. The trial is still under way. Deloitte has had its own problems. This summer the firm agreed to pay Inter-Regional Financial Group, an audit client, $19.75 million to end a 1986 lawsuit challenging its audits. Experts say some private settlements have reached the $100-million mark, and more may be on the horizon. Federal regulators have brought nearly $1 billion in suits against major firms that audited failed thrifts. Time was when ``accountants pretty much accepted whoever walked in the door and didn't think much about liability problems,'' said Israeloff, executive partner of the Long Island firm that bears his name. ``But today, because of the economy, the S&L fiasco, the depressed real estate market, plaintiffs are striking out against accountants all over the place,'' he said. Israeloff turned down the Long Island high-tech maker after discovering the company had had two auditors in the past three years; long-term relationships with accountants are the norm. In addition, ``it was a public company, which increases the odds of outside parties suing you'' because financial statements are more widely circulated, Israeloff said. Many suits are brought by third parties who relied on accountants' work when making investment decisions. Finally, the company was not particularly healthy. ``If a company is not doing well, unfortunately people are going to blame the auditors even though we have nothing to do with'' how the company is run, he said. Indeed, Jim Williams, who is representing Deloitte in the PTL trial, has said his client ``was not in the crystal ball business, nor should it have been.'' Shareholder attorneys have little empathy. Arthur Abbey, a New York lawyer who specializes in suing accounting firms, told the New York Times earlier this year that in these very rough times, ``accountants are very often the ones who know - or should know - what's going on.'' Abbey did not return calls to The Associated Press. The key to avoiding lawsuits is screening clients carefully, said Philip Zimmerman of the New York firm Paneth Haber & Zimmerman. Without revealing how many times his firm has been sued since it was formed 25 years ago, Zimmerman said he has settled only five cases and has won ``many more,'' none of which had gone to trial. Scott Rhine, of the Boca Raton, Fla.-based firm Rhine, Johnson & Co., said his firm has been able to ``lessen our risk by becoming niche-oriented.'' The firm evolved away from auditing to specializing in tax services. Accountants blame the plethora of lawsuits on a perception that they have deep pockets. The corollary - though undocumented - is that not having insurance may be the best protection against litigation. ``They don't want your house, they want money,'' one accountant said of those who sue professionals. Suits targeting accountants are expected to increase as the recession deepens. Malpractice insurance provides CPAs with an essential comfort level, but it comes at a high price. In the mid-1980s, Israeloff was paying about $30,000 a year for $7 million in coverage. Today he's shelling out $200,000 for $5 million in coverage, and his deductible has risen considerably. Liability insurance usually is a firm's No. 3 cost, behind compensation and rent. Annual premiums can consume up to 5 percent of a firm's total fees and perhaps as much as 25 percent of partners' pre-tax profits. Most accountants say they will need increased insurance protection in the coming years, and clients ultimately will pay for it. Accountants may be growing more wary of their clients, but no one suggests that the day will come when a company will find itself unable to secure an auditor. There is always someone willing to take on the job. But accountants do agree that the best firms probably won't take on the riskiest work.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 11
For release Sunday, Nov. 11, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Accountants See A Long Road To Limited Liability
With BC-Accounting Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The thought of being held liable for the deeds of others is enough to make anybody nervous. When it comes to tempermentally conservative accountants, they're shivering in their boots. Because most state laws require accountants and their firms to operate as private partnerships, they are deprived of the limited liability enjoyed by corporations. That puts a partner's personal net worth on the line every time a lawsuit is filed. It would not be unheard of, under current law, for a certified public accountant in Texas to be held accountable for an audit conducted by a partner in his firm's Boston office - a partner the Texas CPA may not have known. ``Most practicing accountants would consider the risk of legal liability one of the largest concerns facing the profession and themselves individually,'' said Bob Mednick, a partner in Arthur Andersen & Co.'s Chicago headquarters and chairman of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants' legal liability committee. Under general partnership laws, ``if the assets of the partnership are not sufficient to satisfy a judgment, then the plaintiff can go after the personal assets of individual partners, including those who don't even know the plaintiff is a client,'' Mednick said. The issue is becoming more critical as lawsuits against accountants mount. Arthur Bowman, who publishes an Atlanta-based industry newsletter, estimated that partner income fell $25,000 from an average $135,000 at Laventhol & Horwath because of rising litigation and settlements. Members of the AICPA will soon be asked to vote on amending the group's code of professional conduct to allow accounting firms to function as limited liability corporations. Ballots are to be mailed out early next year to the group's 300,000-plus membership. Although about 50 percent work for corporations, the government or in academia and therefore are unaffected by the liability issue, it is widely anticipated the vote will pass. But a favorable vote will only serve as ammunition to be hurled at lawmakers, who will have to amend their own state statutes to permit the change, Mednick said. ``Hopefully this vote will act as a catalyst to achieve change at the state legislative level,'' he said. Even after laws are changed, it would be up to individual accountants and firms to comply. No matter how unfavorable state laws appear, they only mirror accountants' own creed. Decades ago, long before litigation became an issue, accountants instituted a professional code that held them personally liable for their work. Accountants vouch for the accuracy of financial statements used by the public, ``and the thought was that we want to tell the public we stand by our work all the way down to our personal assets,'' Mednick said. In these litigious times, that desire has come back to haunt them. Like banks that have had to establish reserves to cover bad Third World loans, some accounting firms are setting aside funds to pay for the uninsured portions of any judgments against them.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Sunday, Nov. 11

DOC.HEAD: Unions Pledge $2 Million to Striking Newspaper Unions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to CORRECT that newspaper has 10 unions, sted nine, UPDATES with minority recruiting, picks up 7th graf `Circulation figures... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Striking workers of the Daily News got a boost from local and national labor leaders who pledged $2 million to help the paper's unions. Management, meanwhile,worked to continue to publish the tabloid as more newsroom workers wavered over whether to break with the nine unions which have been on strike for nearly two weeks. A 10th union, of typographers, has stayed on the job. And the News asked minority journalists' organizations for help in recruiting permanent replacements for strikers. Nine unions representing groups from Teamsters to teachers agreed Monday to assist the strikers at the nation's third-largest daily with a $2 million loan. ``We need it to go out on radio and TV and fight the enemy,'' said George McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, a coalition of unions at the News. The strike began Oct. 25. About 2,000 people are on strike, although some have returned in various departments staffed by members of the Newspaper Guild, which represents reporters, photographers and other workers. At least two editorial workers left the paper Monday for the second time, but seven other workers of the 350-member editorial department crossed picket lines. News officials said about 150 members of the Guild have returned. Daily News Editor James P. Willse wrote letters to the National Association of Black Journalists and similar Hispanic and Asian-American groups, saying 50 permanent workers are needed for the newsroom, The New York Times reported today. Thomas Morgan, a Times reporter who heads the black group, said his organization had agreed to give the News its mailing list but would not ``take a position on who is the guilty party in this strike.'' Circulation figures provided by the News have been widely disputed as editors have worked to get the paper out with new hires, returning workers and reporters and editors from other papers owned by the News' parent, the Tribune Co. News management sources speaking on condition of anonymity said the paper printed 600,000 copies Sunday, down from its normal Sunday run of 1.4 million. A source at a rival newspaper, also speaking anonymously, said its circulation people estimated the News distributed only 257,000 copies. ``They were really hard to find on Sunday,'' the source said, adding that newsstand availability had been holding up until midweek. ``I think it all fell apart.'' Newsstands and delivery trucks have been vandalized during the strike, and the News said newsstand operators have been threatened not to carry the paper.

DOC.HEAD: UPS Orders 25 Boeing Jets
DOC.TEXT: United Parcel Service Inc. has ordered 25 Boeing 757 jet freighters, Boeing Commercial Airplane Group said Tuesday. The total value of the order, including spare parts, is about $1.7 billion. Fifteen of the orders were converted from options UPS previously held for the twin-engine, mid-sized jets. UPS now has 55 757PFs in its fleet or on order, and holds options for an additional 41. The planes ordered Tuesday are to be delivered through 1997. The 757PF is a windowless version of the 757 jetliner, set up for package freight. The plane has a large cargo door on its forward left side and its main deck is designed to accommodate 15 cargo containers or pallets. In the past year, UPS has purchased 23 other jet aircraft from various sources, and by the end of the year will have 121 jets in its fleet. ``Our commitment to fleet expansion during the past 12 months has been greater than in any year since UPS began its air service,'' said Dick Oehme, president of the UPS airline. Greenwich, Conn.-based UPS is the largest package-delivery company in the world, serving all 50 states and more than 180 countries and territories.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Show First Drop in Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline pump prices fell slightly over the past week, by 0.3 cent to $1.377 for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded, according to a national American Automobile Association survey on Tuesday. AAA said the lower national average price marked retail gasoline's first decline since the week of Sept. 18, when the pump price dipped 0.2 cent a gallon. Despite this week's decline, the average price is still 30.2 cents higher than Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and sent oil prices spiraling upward, according to the AAA survey. Prices were slightly higher in New England and the Great Lakes region, but they were down in all other regions.

DOC.HEAD: Emerson Posts Higher Profits for Fourth Quarter, Year
DOC.TEXT: Emerson Electric Co. on Tuesday reported a 3.3 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits and record profits for its 33rd consecutive year. For the quarter ended Sept. 30, the company had net earnings of $154.6 million, or 69 cents a share, up from $149.6 million, or 67 cents a share, in last year's final quarter. Sales were $2.03 billion, up 15.7 percent from $1.76 billion for the 1989 fourth quarter. For the year, Emerson had net earnings of $613.2 million, or $2.75 a share, up 4.3 percent from the $588 million, or $2.63 a share, in fiscal 1989. Sales for fiscal 1990 increased 7.1 percent, to $7.57 billion from $7.07 billion. ``These results were achieved in a domestic economic environment that became increasingly difficult as the year progressed,'' said Charles Knight, chairman and chief executive officer. ``We view the economic outlook for fiscal 1991 with a great deal of caution.'' Knight said the deteriorating economy has hurt the sale of Emerson's consumer products, such as tools and ceiling fans, along with the demand for appliance components and computer equipment. ``The weakening domestic economy highlighted the international strength of the company as international sales grew by more than 30 percent,'' Knight said. However, Knight cautioned that higher oil prices may make further growth in foreign sales more difficult. Emerson, headquartered in St. Louis, makes electric motors and uninterrupted power supplies and compressors for refrigerators. It also owns companies that make tools for Sears Roebuck Co., Skil power tools, ceiling fans, ladders and other consumer products. In September, the company completed a plan to spin off five defense-related subsidiaries into a separate company in order to exit the defense business. Defense products had comprised about 10 percent of Emerson's annual sales.

DOC.HEAD: Exchange Investigates Use of Malicious Rumors to Manipulate Stocks
DOC.TEXT: London's Stock Exchange confirmed Tuesday it was investigating more than a dozen suspected ``bear raids'' in which stock manipulators illegally profit by spreading malicious rumors about companies. ``It is certainly true that there have been a growing number of complaints,'' said a stock exchange spokeswoman who was not identified, in accordance with exchange practice. ``What we have to do is investigate to see if there is a foundation in those allegations,'' she said. Polly Peck PLC and Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Co. are among the companies whose share trading is being investigated by the exchange, company and exchange sources said anonymously. Polly Peck's administrators declined to comment, although chairman Asil Nadir has blamed his company's recent spectacular collapse on false rumors. Polly Peck, which owns the Del Monte fresh fruit and Sansui hi-fi businesses, is now in the hands of court-appointed administrators after its share price plummeted 55 percent in one day. Peninsular & Oriental said it had no comment other than that recent rumors about the shipping and property company have been false. The company's shares fell sharply two weeks in October on rumors that the company was selling new stock to sha with the rumor that the chairman has been assassinated or has died, it certainly has an impact on the company's shares,'' Nadir said. While such rumors existed, the market also was disturbed by the news that Nadir was interviewed by the Serious Fraud Office the same day and that the fraud office had raided a Nadir-linked company the previous day. Nadir, who has denied any wrongdoing, said it was common knowledge that illegal bear raids go on ``constantly'' and that it was ``more than a suspicion.''

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday, although investors were largely withdrawn from what could be a difficult week in the market. Players have been driven to the sidelines by a number of factors, traders said, including the increasing threat of war in the Middle East and nervousness on Wall Street. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 19.7 points, or 1 percent, at 2,069.8. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 17.8 points at 1,598.9, while the broader Financial Times 500-share index rose 7.22 points to close at 1,101.65. Volume came to 386.3 million shares, compared with 306.3 million shares Monday.

The stock market was lower this afternoon, as traders pondered the uncertainties raised by the elections, Persian Gulf crisis and an enormous sale of new U.S. Treasury debt. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 9.90 at 2,492.3 as of 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Decliners barely outnumbered gainers in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 708 up, 714 down and 488 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 100.68 million shares with two hours to go. Analysts saw no real pattern in today's trading. ``It's uncertainty more than anything else,'' said Sara Cerato, a vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``I'm hearing more rumors about war breaking out after the election.'' Some investment strategists are even starting to pick days that they believe will be the beginning of the war, she said. Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said traders were also nervously watching oil prices and waiting for the results of the quarterly government bond auction, which began today and will be completed Thursday. The Treasury is selling a record $34.25 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year debt securities. In midafternoon trading on the NYSE, Browning Ferris was down 5~ to 24] on a disappointing earnings report that came as a surprise to many analysts. Waste Management was off 1] at 33| after announcing it will pay a court settlement of $19.5 million to avoid fighting civil price-fixing claims. Analysts were not sure whether the settlement was moving the stock. Circuit City dropped 2{ to 11} following the release of sales reports that were not as strong as analysts were hoping. Unisys fell \ to 2| amid concern that it may have to sell assets at distressed prices. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks was down .68 at 170.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .26 at 291.84.

DOC.HEAD: Zenith Gets $1 Million State Grant For HDTV Work
DOC.TEXT: Zenith Electronics Corp. said Tuesday it received a $1 million grant from the state of Illinois to develop new manufacturing processes for high-definition television monitors. The grant from the Illinois Technology Challenge Grant Program will augment Zenith's $50 million commitment to HDTV, the emerging television technology on which the last U.S. consumer television maker is betting its future. High-definition television, featuring picture clarity like 35mm photographs and sound like that of compact disks, is perceived as the future of the television industry. Zenith is competing with larger and better-financed foreign manufacturers to develop an HDTV system that it hopes will be chosen as the U.S. standard. Zenith, based in this Chicago suburb, said in a statement that the grant will support its development of manufacturing technology for the company's patented ``flat tension mask'' picture tubes for computer monitors and eventually for HDTV sets. Zenith said foreign companies are building or recently completed six large-screen color picture tube plants in the United States. The company said it plans to ``leapfrog over the foreign competition with new production processes.'' In August, the Defense Department said it would give Zenith more than $1 million in research funds for flat tension mask technology with military applications. Zenith's bid to succeed through HDTV is regarded by many analysts as a long shot. The company lost money four of the last five years and rolled up a net loss of $26.8 million from continuing operations through the first nine month of 1990. Zenith also faces a possible takeover bid by New Jersey manufacturer Nycor Inc. Nycor recently disclosed it owns 8.2 percent of Zenith's common stock and said it is considering acquiring the company.

DOC.HEAD: BellSouth To Cut Up To 3,000 Jobs Through Early Retirement
DOC.TEXT: BellSouth Corp. said Tuesday it will eliminate up to 3,000 management jobs through a special retirement option for certain employees. The plan, effective Dec. 1, is being offered to management employees who are eligible for retirement, the company said. It includes a special one-time payment to those who agree to leave within a designated time period. ``To respond to the increasingly competitive telecommunications marketplace, we must continually introduce structural and operating efficiencies,'' said Roy Howard, senior vice president of corporate human resources. ``Toward that end, our regulated and unregulated companies will be cutting their management ranks by up to 3,000 persons though implementation of this ... plan.'' Atlanta-based BellSouth is a regional telephone holding company that serves nine Southeastern states through its Southern Bell and South Central Bell subsidiaries.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with ministers reaching agreement
DOC.TEXT: The European Community late today approved a plan for modest cuts in government farm payments, breaking a nearly monthlong deadlock that had threatened the collapse of world trade talks. Agriculture and trade ministers of the 12-nation trading bloc endorsed a carefully worded proposal that sought to ease fears of many governments that their farmers would be severely hurt by the reductions. ``What we have offered is a very considerable (proposal),'' said British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer after two days of bargaining. The proposal will now be presented to negotiators in the Uruguay Round talks, an ambitious four-year effort to overhaul the world trading system. The agreement came after a second day of bargaining among the ministers, agonizing over a way to remove one of the most emotional obstacles to easing world trade tensions, the generous subsidies paid to European farmers. Six previous attempts to find a solution ended in failure. At issue was a proposal to pare subsidies on farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years, starting in 1986. Some reductions have already been made. The trading bloc was under international pressure to resolve the dispute, which has threatened the outcome of the Uruguay Round of negotiations, an ambitious four-year effort to overhaul the world trade system. Agriculture is one of 15 areas under discussion in the trade negotiations, which began in 1986 in the Uruguayan resort of Punta del Este. But the United States, Australia, Argentina and others insist it holds the key to liberalizing trade in other areas, including textiles, manufactured goods and services, such as telecommunications and banking. Argentina has even threatened to walk out of the round if deep cuts are not made in farm subsidies. On Monday, the 14 nations of the Cairns group, led by Australia, said if no real progress were made in the agriculture talks by mid-November, they would have to ``reassess'' their position on the final round of bargaining, set to get under way in early December in Brussels. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said she hoped the European Community ``will heed the Cairns group's call to negotiate fundamental agricultural reform.'' ``The success of the Uruguay Round now hangs in the balance,'' she said Monday in Geneva. The new EC proposal will be be submitted to the trade talks as the community's opening position in the final round of bargaining. The community is the only participant that has not yet put its offer on the table. The deadline was Oct. 15. The Bush administration wants its trading partners to slash farm income supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent over a 10-year period, starting in 1991. The Uruguay Round is held under the auspices of the 100-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and an accord for freer world trade.

DOC.HEAD: Wal-Mart to Acquire The Wholesale Club Stores
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS total value of deal in lede, new graf after 4th pvs, Wal-Mart operates. Picks up 5th graf pvs, The Wholesale.
DOC.TEXT: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has entered into a merger agreement to acquire The Wholesale Club Inc. for about $170 million, the companies announced Tuesday. Wal-Mart President David Glass said the Wholesale Club's outlets and operations would complement Wal-Mart's Sam's Wholesale Club Division and give the discount chain a significant presence in new markets. The Wholesale Club operates 27 membership clubs in six states. Sales for the six-month period ended Aug. 4 totaled $333 million. Wal-Mart operates 141 Sam's Wholesale outlets and 1,503 Wal-Mart discount stores in 34 states. A statement by the companies said Wal-Mart would acquire The Wholesale Club for the equivalent of $21 a share. With about 8 million shares outstanding, the deal is worth $170 million, said a spokesman for The Wholesale Club. The Wholesale Club shareholders will have the option of receiving either Wal-Mart common stock or cash for their common stock, subject to the limitation that not more than 20 percent of the aggregate may be paid in cash. The deal is subject to approval by The Wholesale Club's shareholders and other conditions.

The stock market fell today, as traders pondered the uncertainties raised by the elections, the Persian Gulf crisis and an enormous sale of new U.S. Treasury debt. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 13.86 at 2,488.37 as of 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Decliners outnumbered gainers about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 678 up, 749 down and 511 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 117.13 million shares with one hour left to trade. Analysts saw no real pattern in today's trading. ``It's uncertainty more than anything else,'' said Sara Cerato, a vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``I'm hearing more rumors about war breaking out after the election.'' Some investment strategists are even starting to pick days that they believe will be the beginning of the war, she said. Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said traders were also nervously watching oil prices and waiting for the results of the quarterly government bond auction, which began today and will be completed Thursday. The Treasury is selling a record $34.25 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year debt securities. In midafternoon trading on the NYSE, Browning Ferris was down 6[ to 24[ on a disappointing earnings report that came as a surprise to many analysts. Waste Management was off 1} at 33\ after announcing it will pay a court settlement of $19.5 million to avoid fighting civil price-fixing claims. Analysts were not sure whether the settlement was moving the stock. Circuit City dropped 2| to 11| following the release of sales reports that were not as strong as analysts were hoping. Unisys fell \ to 2| amid concern that it may have to sell assets at distressed prices. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks was down 1.05 at 170.44. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up .71 at 292.29.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Close at 8-Month Low Amid Slack Demand, Bigger Crop Signals
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell to their lowest levels in eight months Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as signs of slack demand and large yields prompted selling and profit-taking. Wheat futures ended slightly higher. Corn was slightly lower. A survey of grain analysts revealed that most experts expect the Agriculture Department to raise its 1990 U.S. soybean crop estimate Thursday from last month's projection of 1.82 billion bushels. The private estimates averaged 1.84 billion bushels but at least one respected firm, Memphis-based Sparks Commodities Inc., expects a harvest of 1.9 billion bushels. Don Roose, an analyst with U.S. Commodities Inc. in Des Moines, Iowa, said further selling was prompted by sluggish export sales of U.S. soybeans and by technical, chart-based factors. ``I do think the overall psychology in the market is bearish,'' Roose said. ``We've got an overabundant amount of bearishness coming at us right now.'' At the close, soybean futures were 7 cents lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in November at $5.76 a bushel, the lowest close for a near-month contract since March 14; wheat was 1{ cents to 1} cents higher with December at $2.65} a bushel; corn was } cent to 2 cents lower with December at $2.30 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.20 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Ford's Credit Company Acquires Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Credit Co. will acquire a subsidiary of Marine Midland Banks Inc. to develop non-Ford business, the companies announced Tuesday. The new business will continue to operate for now as Marine Midland Automotive Financial Corp. Later, its name will be changed and headquarters will be established in Nashville, Tenn. Its president will be George E. Watts Jr., head of Ford Motor Credit's Canadian operations since March 1988. The price of the acquisition was not released. Ford Motor Credit provides financing help for dealers selling cars, trucks and tractors made by Ford Motor Co. and its subsidiaries and customers of those dealers. The new company will begin by providing financial services for dealers handling products made by Mazda Motor Corp. and Jaguar PLC. Ford Motor Co., the parent company of Ford Motor Credit, owns 25 percent of Mazda and all of Jaguar. Ford Motor Credit will acquire the stock, most of the organization and some assets of Marine Midland Automotive. Marine Midland Banks, with headquarters in Buffalo, N.Y., will continue handling Marine Midland Automotive's current consumer loans.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Decides Against Selling Honolulu-Tokyo Leg of Route
DOC.TEXT: Financially-ailing Continental Airlines yanked the Honolulu-Tokyo leg of its Houston-Tokyo route from a list of assets it may sell, saying Tuesday that the hard-won route is too important to put on the block. The decision came just days after Continental President Hollis Harris told local business leaders the airline may have to sell some international routes and possibly implement layoffs to cope with skyrocketing fuel prices. Harris said then that one plan under consideration was selling Continental's Air Micronesia, the carrier's Pacific service operation. Air Micronesia holds the authority to fly from Honolulu to Tokyo. But Continental said Monday it had decided not to slll that leg, which began service four months ago. ``We decided against it because it is of great importance here in our hometown,'' Continental spokesman Art Kent said Tuesday. Kent noted that local business and civic leaders worked with airline officials for 24 years to ``get direct air service between Houston and Tokyo. There are a large number of businesses here, and the potential for industrial growth is very important.'' The route also ferries Japanese vacationers to one of Hawaii's prime holiday spots. ``(Harris) said last week that the Honolulu-Tokyo (route) might have to be included (in asset sales), but after further consideration, we decided that this direct service is just too important to our community and to Continental, so we decided to take it off the block,'' Kent said. Jim Kollaer, president of the Greater Houston Partnership, noted that the route helps foster business with Japan. About 125 Japanese companies do business in the city. Although Continental can fly under its own authority from Houston to Honolulu, Air Micronesia holds the governmental authority to fly from Honolulu to Tokyo, the most lucrative leg of the trip. Continental officials have negotiated with Air Micronesia and received approval to separate the Honolulu-Tokyo route from any future sale of the partnership. The carrier also said it has been reviewing several options for dealing with monthly fuel bills, which have risen substantially since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Continental said its October bill was $70 million more than it paid in July. Last month, Continental's board of directors considered filing for bankruptcy protection because of the rising fuel bills - the result of the continuing Persian Gulf crisis. But it opted to sell off assets and undertake other measures to remain afloat.

DOC.HEAD: Kellogg Holds Prices on Best Sellers
DOC.TEXT: Kellogg Co., which has seen private-label brands take a bite out of sales of its most popular cereals, is making its latest price increase a bit easier for consumers to swallow. The world's largest cereal maker said Tuesday it has raised prices on most of its products an average of 3.7 percent, but is exempting Corn Flakes - for the second straight year - and Frosted Flakes, two of its biggest sellers. Because those cereals and some smaller brands were omitted from the increase, the net price increase is about 2.8 percent, Kellogg spokesman Richard Lovell said Tuesday. The increase took effect Saturday. William E. LaMothe, Kellogg's chairman and chief executive officer, told industry analysts last week that since 1987, private-label versions had increased their market share to 6.2 percent from 3.6 percent, largely at the expense of Corn Flakes, Frosted Flakes, Rice Krispies, Raisin Bran and Froot Loops. LaMothe told the analysts that ``in response to very competitive conditions, including competition from unbranded products, we'd be very conservative in our increases,'' Lovell said. Over the last couple of years, Kellogg has seen its market share dip from about 41 percent to 38 percent of the approximately $7 billion ready-to-eat domestic cereal industry. The industry has been relatively flat this year after a few years of hefty sales growth, analysts said. Kellogg's increase is well below the average 5.9 percent increase rival General Mills Inc. announced Oct. 19. However, analysts noted, Kellogg raised its prices an average of 2.2 percent last spring, while General Mills' last increase was in November 1989. Ralston-Purina Co., which makes about half of all cereal sold to private companies for sale under their own labels, also is gaining ground with such novelty children's products as Teen-age Mutant Ninja Turtles and Batman cereals, said John C. Maxwell Jr., cereal analyst for Wheat First Securities of Richmond, Va. But, Maxwell said, Minneapolis-based General Mills is in the best position for the 1990s with the popularity of oat-based cereals such as Cheerios still on the rise. ``If it doesn't say bran or oats on the label, people aren't buying,'' Maxwell said. ``Unless Kellogg develops new products to offset the decline (in older brands), they're going to be in trouble.'' However, LaMothe told analysts last week that new products, because of their increased cost and riskiness, probably would not be a key to regaining market share. Analyst Edward Eyring of Argus Research Corp. in New York said his company recently has taken a more bullish view of Kellogg and thinks the relatively conservative price increase is a ``step in the right direction.'' ``We think Kellogg has untapped potential,'' he said. ``We have confidence that the company will be able to successfully tap the international market for cereals as it intends to do and weather the competitive pressures that private brands are putting on it.''

DOC.HEAD: European Ministers Finally Endorse Crop Subsidy Plan
DOC.TEXT: The European Community late Tuesday approved modest cuts in government farm payments, breaking a nearly month-long deadlock that had threatened to end world trade talks. The agreement was reached on the community's seventh attempt to endorse the proposal. The plan would pare subsidies on major farm crops by 30 percent over 10 years, starting in 1986. Some reductions have already been made. It's unlikely, though, that the offer will be received warmly by the United States and other nations. The Bush administration wants its trading partners to slash farm income supports by 75 percent and export subsidies by 90 percent over 10 years, starting in 1991. But Italian Trade Minister Renato Ruggiero cautioned, ``It would be a grave error on the part of our trading partners to judge that this position is not (one) of great openness and ambition.'' The plan will now be presented to negotiators in the Uruguay Round talks, an ambitious four-year effort by 100 nations to overhaul the world trading system. The community is the last major player to put its offer on the bargaining table. It missed an Oct. 15 deadline for submitting positions for the final round of negotiations, which begin next month. The proposal endorsed Tuesday by ministers from the 12-nation trading bloc seeks to ease fears that the nations' farmers would be hurt severely by the subsidy cuts. The plan includes assurances to not only compensate farmers for income losses, but also to assure that cheaper, imported goods will not push home-grown products off the market. It also pledges to limit the impact on poor regions in the European Community and to soften proposed cuts in supports for olive oil and other products grown in Mediterranean countries. ``After long negotiations, we got very good improvements,'' said German Agriculture Minister Ignaz Kiechle, whose country along with France had been balking at bigger cuts. ``We can say to our farmers that they will have compensation for the 30 percent reductions.'' French Agriculture Minister Louis Mermaz described the outcome as ``excellent.'' ``We have to look the Americans straight in the face. We are not going to buy from them what we make ourselves,'' he added. British Agriculture Secretary John Gummer, whose government had been opposing French and German efforts to weaken the plan, said there was little change in the original proposal. But he said the community's drawn-out discussions indicated that further cuts would be very hard to negotiate. ``It is clear from the negotiations that the European Community ... (does) find reductions in support extremely difficult,'' he told reporters. The trading bloc was under international pressure to resolve the dispute. Agriculture is one of 15 areas under discussion in the trade negotiations, and the United States, Australia and Argentina insist it holds the key to liberalizing trade in other areas, from textiles and services to telecommunications and banking. Argentina has even threatened to walk out of the round if deep cuts are not made in farm subsidies. On Monday, the 14 nations of the Cairns group, led by Australia, said if no real progress were made in the agriculture talks by mid-November, they would have to ``re-assess'' their position on the final bargaining round. In delaying the agreement, the French and German governments voiced different concerns. Germany, whose government is worried about the farming coalition in Dec. 2 elections, insisted on compensatory measures to make up for any income losses to farmers. France, the EC's chief farm exporter, argued the plan could lower trade barriers so much that cheaper, imported goods could flood the trading bloc. The Uruguay Round is held under the auspices of the 100-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a forum and an accord for freer world trade.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Increase Not Necessarily Good News
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS 3rd graf to CLARIFY improvement in quarterly productivity. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: American workers' productivity climbed at the fastest pace in two years during the July-September quarter but hours worked fell, the government said Tuesday in a sign that the economic slowdown is forcing businesses to make do with fewer employees. ``The good news is that productivity is up; the bad news is we're in a recession,'' said economist Michael K. Evans, a Washington-based consultant. In the third quarter, non-farm productivity - output per hour of work - advanced at a 1.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate compared with the previous three-month period. It was the third straight quarter in which productivity improved from the previous three-month period, and the best pace since the July-September quarter of 1988. Productivity rose 0.3 percent in the second quarter, fell 1.3 percent in the first quarter and dropped 2.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year. However, the number of hours worked edged down 0.1 percent in the third quarter, the first decline in more than four years. Economists say this shows that employers are coping with economic sluggishness with layoffs, hiring freezes and limits on overtime. ``What's happened here is that in 1989 the economy was very weak, but business optimism was still strong and businesses didn't lay off people,'' Evans said. ``Productivity has picked up because they are laying off people who should have been laid off last year.'' Despite the improvement, productivity is still well below the level needed to significantly boost Americans' living standard, according to most economists. ``It's better, but subpar,'' said economist Allen Sinai of the Boston Co. Increased productivity, or getting each worker to produce more during each hour of work, is vital to increasing the nation's standard of living without inflation. Non-farm productivity is increasing at an average annual pace of 0.2 percent so far this year, compared with a 0.7 percent decline for all of last year. Since 1982, productivity growth has averaged 1.6 percent a year - better than the 1.2 percent average in the 1970s but far worse than the 2.5 percent annual gain posted from 1947 to 1967. Sinai said manufacturing, where productivity leapt at a 5.6 percent annual rate in the third quarter compared with 2.6 percent for all of last year, is making impressive gains. However, productivity growth in the service sector, which accounts for a much larger share of the economy, remains dismal, he said. A fundamental improvement in education, increased investment in new technology and better roads and other public infrastructure are needed in the long term to improve services productivity, Sinai said. ``In the meantime, the squeeze of a recession will force services to do more with less. ... But that's a ... painful way to get productivity growth up,'' he said. Meanwhile, hourly labor costs, a major indication of inflation for businesses, shot up 4.5 percent in the third quarter. That was an improvement over the 5 percent rate in the second quarter but still worse than the 3.2 percent increase for all of 1989. Unit labor costs, a key gauge of future price inflation, rose 2.8 percent in the third quarter compared with 4.7 percent in the second quarter. Unit labor costs averaged 3.9 percent in the 1989. Total business productivity, including farming, rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Ratings Agency Lowers Rating on $1.7 Billion in Harcourt Debt
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. lowered its ratings Tuesday on about $1.7 billion in debt issued by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publishing and insurance giant. The ratings agency said business setbacks last year in the company's flagship elementary reading program ``hobbles growth for the firm,'' and a heavy debt service commitment due in 1993 increases chances that the company will have to undergo a debt restructuring or sell assets before then. The agency said it was lowering its ratings on $200 million in senior unsecured notes to CCC from B-minus and on $1.5 billion in subordinated debt to CCC-minus from CCC-plus. Under the agency's ratings system, debt with a CCC rating is seen as predominantly speculative with respect to its ability to pay interest and repay principal according to the terms. A debt rating is one of the features that determines the price of a bond in the marketplace. Harcourt, based on Orlando, Fla., took on a heavy debt load in May 1987 when it underwent a restructuring and paid a special dividend that effectively warded off a hostile takeover bid from British media baron Robert Maxwell. Harcourt said in a statement it was disappointed by the agency's ratings action, but pointed out that the agency noted that Harcourt's operating profit had resumed growth. Harcourt said it was ``making adequate capital investments to produce a competitive elementary reading program in 1992'' and noted that it recently hired the investment firm Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. to explore alternatives for dealing with Harcourt's heavy debt. For the first six months of the fiscal year through June 30, Harcourt lost $94.9 million, or $1.47 a share, on revenue of $625.4 million. It lost $158.7 million, or $2.77 a share, on revenue of $570 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Precious Metals Surge on Renewed War Fears
DOC.TEXT: Heightened fears of war in the Middle East spurred a rally in the precious metal markets Tuesday. On other commodity markets, oil futures rose; pork futures soared, helping to lift the cattle markets; soybeans hit an eight-month low; and grain futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $7 to $7.40 higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in December at $388.10 a troy ounce; silver was 3 cents to 3.2 cents higher with December at $4.257 a troy ounce. Platinum futures finished $6.10 to $10.20 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange with November at $426.80 a troy ounce. Analysts said speculation is mounting that the U.S.-led multinational military force in Saudi Arabia will soon attack Iraqi troops in occupied Kuwait. Randolph Donney, chief commodities analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J., said some observers expect an offensive to be launched as soon as this weekend. He said the rally was fueled by signs the Soviet Union may be willing to send troops to the region to bolster the U.N. force and by perceptions that Secretary of State James A. Baker III was ``laying down the ground rules'' for an attack during his visit to U.S. allies in the Middle East. Other analysts cited the views of some military strategists that a military strike would best be launched in November, before the desert winter sets in. ``There are lot of things coming into play and I think you're getting a little bit of a war scare there,'' Donney said. Gold is often viewed as a safe investment haven in times of international crisis. Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc., linked further buying to signs of firming demand for gold at the recent low prices and to position-evening ahead of Friday's expiration of December gold options on the Commodity Exchange. Oil futures ended mostly higher on the New York Merc, where war-related buying interest was tempered by ideas that oil supplies might not tighten as much as previously thought in the event of Middle East war. After the close, the American Petroleum Institute reported that U.S. supplies of crude oil rose by 5 million barrels last week, surprising market analysts who had expected a decline of up to 2 million barrels. Light sweet crude oil settled 43 cents lower to 67 cents higher with December at $32.63 a barrel; heating oil was .35 cent to 1.92 cents higher with December at 86.38 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent to .99 cent higher with December at 87.75 cents a gallon. Pork futures rallied strongly on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, helping to lift the cattle markets. Near-term hog futures rose the permitted daily limit of 1.5 cents a pound and all pork belly contracts soared the 2 cents-a-pound limit on signs of slow slaughter rates and ideas the markets have reached a seasonal bottom. Reports of wintry weather in the Midwest also fueled buying of pork contracts. Snow and cold could further slow the movement of hogs to market. Live hog futures settled .25 cent to 1.5 cents higher with December at 53.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 2 cents higher across the board with February at 68.25 cents a pound; live cattle were .18 cent to .37 cent higher with December at 77.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent to .83 cent higher with November at 87.90 cents a pund. Soybean futures prices fell to their lowest levels in eight months on the Chicago Board of Trade as signs of slack demand and large yields prompted selling and profit-taking. Wheat futures ended slightly higher. Corn was slightly lower. A survey of grain analysts revealed that most experts expect the Agriculture Department to raise its 1990 U.S. soybean crop estimate Thursday from last month's projection of 1.82 billion bushels. The private estimates averaged 1.84 billion bushels but at least one respected firm, Memphis-based Sparks Commodities Inc., expects a harvest of 1.9 billion bushels. Soybeans settled 6} cents lower to } cent higher with November at $5.75} a bushel, the lowest close for a near-month contract since March 14; wheat was 1\ cents to 2 cents higher with December at $2.65{ a bushel; corn was { cent to 1{ cents lower with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.20 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up on Middle East Concerns, Technical Buying; Gold Rises Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose Tuesday on concerns about the Middle East crisis and on technical buying by traders adjusting their positions in advance of the results of the day's elections. Gold prices moved sharply higher largely on technical factors. Currency traders bought dollars aggressively on news that the U.S. might send more troops to the Middle East and on speculation about unrest in the Soviet Union. The Marine Corps said it was calling up more than 600 reservists from eight states for combat roles in the Persian Gulf. Meanwhile, clashes continued among several ethnic groups in the Soviet Union. The dollar tends to rise in times of political uncertainty overseas, because it is generally seen as a relatively safe investment. Furthermore, crude oil is bought and sold in dollars, so if an outbreak of war in the Middle East sends oil prices skyrocketing, there will be more demand for the U.S. currency. In addition, analysts said traders were buying dollars to hedge their positions pending the outcome of Tuesday's election, with its potential to redistribute political power by carving up key election districts. ``Just that uncertainty makes people cover up their short positions,'' said Karen Gibbs, a currency analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. In earlier overseas trading, the dollar was little changed because of market fears of a U.S. recession and anticipation of subsequent cuts in U.S. interest rates. A reduction in interest rates dampens demand for U.S. investments, and therefore sends the dollar downward. The dollar rose against the Japanese yen in New York, closing at 128.15 yen, up from late Monday's 126.55. In overnight trading in Tokyo, the dollar fell to 127.20 yen from 127.35 yen Monday, and in London, it was quoted at 127.25 yen. The British pound fell to $1.9657 in New York from $1.9740 Monday, and in earlier London trading, sterling fell to $1.9635 from late Monday's $1.9675. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's late rates, included: 1.4927 German marks, up from 1.4850; 1.2545 Swiss francs, up from 1.2505; 5.0055 French francs, up from 4.9810; 1,121.00 Italian lire, up from 1,116.00; and 1.16295 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15875. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4875 German marks, down from 1.4880; 1.2505 Swiss francs, unchanged; 4.9885 French francs, down from 4.9875; 1.6768 Dutch guilders, up from 1.6765; 1,116.75 Italian lire, up from 1,116.25; and 1.1609 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1586. Gold rose sharply in domestic trading, climbing $7.10 a troy ounce to $386.60 on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $385.60, up $6.95. Analysts said gold rose on unconfirmed rumors of a large Middle Eastern buy order. In earlier trading in London, gold rose to a late bid price of $380.25 a troy ounce, up from $377.25 late Monday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $379.50, up from $376.30 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $4.20 to close at a bid $381.13. Silver rose on the Commodity Exchange, closing at $4.234 a troy ounce, up 3.1 cents. In London, silver was unchanged at a late bid price of $4.18.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices meandered in slow trading Tuesday and finished mixed, depressed on the one hand by evidence of ample supply and declining demand, boosted on the other hand by speculation about Persian Gulf war. ``The market is divided equally between fundamentals and Middle East concern,'' said Bob Baker, a trading strategist at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the key market for petroleum futures contracts, the December delivery price of benchmark light sweet crude rose 67 cents a barrel to $32.63. But the price for oil to be delivered through later winter months closed lower. Among refined products traded on the exchange, wholesale home heating oil for December delivery rose 1.92 cents a gallon to 86.38 cents. Later-delivery month contracts also rose. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for December delivery rose .21 cent a gallon to 87.75 cents, while later-delivery months were .99 cent higher to .50 cent lower. Natural gas for December delivery fell .02 cent per 1,000 cubic feet to $2.383, while later-delivery months all rose slightly. The oil market has been transfixed on developments in the Persian Gulf since Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein's forces seized Kuwait three months ago, inciting world condemnation, a trade embargo and a U.S.-led military expedition into neighboring Saudi Arabia. Crude prices went from about $20 a barrel to more than $40 but have since retreated into the $30 range, largely because no shots have been fired and other oil producers have filled the vacuum caused by the absence of Kuwaiti and Iraqi crude. Moreover, demand for petroleum has fallen since the crisis began, putting further pressure on prices to fall. Many oil-trading strategists agree that the only thing propping prices at current levels is what they call a war premium. ``In the past, there was fear that if we did drift into war, prices would take off,'' said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J. ``At this stage, people are saying on one hand, we have plenty of oil, but on another hand we're going to have to deal with Saddam Hussein sooner or later.'' Some traders said business was slow Tuesday because of the impending release of weekly figures of U.S. energy supplies and production from the American Petroleum Institute, a Washington trade group. The statistics, released after trading finished for the day, showed stocks of crude oil and gasoline rose in the week ended Nov. 2 vs. a week earlier, while the supply of home heating oil remained steady. The figures also showed crude imports increased to 5.9 million barrels a day from 5.1 million barrels a day the previous week. The figures substantiated the view that the nation's energy supplies remain plentiful and that foreign exporters have alleviated any shortfall caused by the gulf standoff. In another sign of easing pressure on prices, the American Automobile Association reported Tuesday that the average price of self-serve regular unleaded gasoline fell .3 cent per gallon last week to $1.377. It was the first weekly drop since a .2 cent decline Sept. 18. AAA's survey, based on a nationwide spot check of stations, still shows the average price of gasoline has increased 30.2 cents since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Price-Fixing Suit Against Airlines Consolidated in Atlanta ^Eds: ADDS reax from airlines after 9th graf pvs, `Delta denies. Picks up 10th graf pvs, The suit.
DOC.TEXT: An Atlanta federal judge will hear a consolidated lawsuit alleging collusion and price-fixing by some of the nation's major airlines and their computerized fare network. The suit was formed when 31 claims filed nationwide were consolidated Friday in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Georgia. It alleges the airlines use computers to signal fare changes to each other, agree on price increases and threaten fare cuts. As a result of the alleged collusion, the suit charges that passengers are forced to pay artificially high ticket prices. The defendants are USAir, Northwest, Delta, Continental, United, TWA and American airlines and the Washington-based computer clearinghouse, Airline Tariff Publishing Co. The case was assigned to U.S. District Judge Marvin H. Shoob after a panel of federal judges decided Atlanta was most accessible to all parties in the suit. If Shoob certifies the suit as a class action, a decision that's expected early next year, the plaintiffs could number in the millions. Customers who purchased a plane ticket since 1987 could potentially be a party to the suit. ``In 1988, 150 million tickets were sold, so that would give you a rough idea of the possible magnitude of this case,'' said W. Pitts Carr, the Atlanta attorney who filed the first suit here last July. ``There are literally tens of millions of people or companies who are potential class members.'' The defendants deny the charges. ``Delta denies totally the allegations ... concerning our participation in any conspiracy to fix prices,'' said Edward B. Krugman, one of the airline's attorneys. Spokespeople for United, USAir and Northwest declined comment. Continental also declined comment, but spokesman Art Kent added, ``We have gone on record before as saying there is no price collusion and we set our prices according to the market.'' The suit seeks undetermined damages that could be tripled under federal antitrust laws. It also asks that the airlines be restrained from further violation of antitrust laws and that the computer network be ``restructured so as to discourage future collusion among airlines.''

DOC.HEAD: Union Carbide to Build Ethylene Glycol Plant in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Union Carbide Chemicals and Plastics Company Inc. has formed an international consortium to build a new ethylene glycol plant in Canada, the company said Tuesday. The company will be built in Prentiss, Alberta, and be called Alberta & Orient Glycol Co. Ltd. Union Carbide will own 50 percent, while the remaining 50 percent will be shared equally by the other three participants, Far Eastern Textile Ltd., Taiwan; Mitsui & Co. Ltd., Japan; and Oriental Union Chemical Corp., Taiwan. The plant, to be built on the same site as Union Carbide's existing ethylene glycol plant, is scheduled for startup during the second half of 1994. The company said the new plant will boost total ethylene glycol capacity at the site to 600,000 tons annualy. Ethylene for the plant will be supplied by Dow Chemical Canada Inc. from a new unit to be located at Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta. A.W. Lutz, president of Union Carbide's Industrial Chemicals Division, said output from the new facility will go primarily to Far Eastern polyester markets. Union Carbide is a world leader in production of ethylene oxide and ethylene glycol, which is used in antifreeze, polyester fibers, film and bottle resins and other products.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS third graf to CORRECT gainers and losers; SUBS 16th graf to CORRECT S&P 500 index
DOC.TEXT: The stock market fell Tuesday, as traders pondered the uncertainties raised by the elections, the Persian Gulf crisis and an enormous sale of new U.S. Treasury debt. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 17.08 to 2,485.15. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 10 to 9 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 709 up, 760 down and 510 unchanged. Analysts detected no real pattern in Tuesday's trading. ``It's uncertainty more than anything else,'' said Sara Cerato, a vice president at Nomura Securities International Inc. ``I'm hearing more rumors about war breaking out after the election.'' Some investment strategists are even starting to pick days that they believe will be the beginning of the war, she said. Jack Solomon at Bear Stearns & Co. said traders were also nervously watching oil prices and waiting for the results of the quarterly government bond auction, which began Tuesday and was to be completed Thursday. The Treasury is selling a record $34.25 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year debt securities. Crude oil futures, which often move in the opposite direction from stocks, went up 67 cents to $32.63 per barrel Tuesday for December delivery contracts on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The most active stock in Tuesday's session, Browning Ferris, was down 6 to 24\ on a disappointing earnings report that came as a surprise to many analysts. Waste Management was off 2 at 33 after announcing it would pay a court settlement of $19.5 million to avoid fighting civil price-fixing claims. Analysts were not sure whether news of the settlement had helped move the stock. Circuit City dropped 2~ to 11] following the release of sales reports that were not as strong as analysts were hoping. Unisys fell [ to 2} amid concern that it may have to sell assets at distressed prices. Big Board volume totaled 141.13 million shares, down from 147.51 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 175.63 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $18.86 billion, or 0.64 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all listed common stocks fell 1.28 to 170.21. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 3.47 to 364.97, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 2.97 at 311.62. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell .23 to 340.53. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 292.15, up .57.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Parent Loses $88.3 Million in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines Holdings Inc. lost $88.3 million in the third quarter as higher fuel prices increased costs, the company said Tuesday. The loss amounted to $2.31 a share. In the same period last year, Continental lost $158 million, or $4.09 a share. The company had revenues of $1.5 billion in the quarter, compared to $1.7 billion in the same quarter last year. ``Our results mirror the industry-wide problems posed by unrestrained increases in the price of fuel,'' Continental chairman Hollis Harris said in a news release. Fuel costs, the company's largest expense, are $70 million higher per month now than before the Middle East crisis, Harris said. ``Considering fuel problems, we're in the pack,'' spokesman Art Kent said. The company's losses ``puts us pretty much in line with what everyone else is suffering with,'' he said. For the first nine months of 1990, the company lost $97 million, or $2.83 a share, on revenue of $4.9 billion. That compares to a loss of $522.8 million, or $13.51 a share, on revenue of $5 billion in the first nine months of 1989. Continental released the earnings statement after the markets closed. The company's stock closed up 12{ cents at $2.75 a share on the American Stock Exchange Tuesday. The airline holding company, which was known as Texas Air Corp. until this summer, is the parent of Continental Airlines. Texas Air was the parent of Continental and Eastern Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection in 1989 and has been run by a government-appointed trustee since April 10. Included in the holding company's nine months 1990 results is Eastern's $149.1 million loss on revenues of $673.1 million before April 10. The company's nine months results last year included Eastern's loss of $569.7 million on revenues of $1 billion. Continental Airlines lost $55.1 million on revenues of $1.4 billion during the third quarter this year. In last year's third quarter, the airline earned $43.5 million on revenues of $1.3 billion. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Continental earned $62.9 million on revenues of $4 billion. That compares to net income of $59.1 million on revenues of $3.9 billion for the same nine months in 1989. Continental has said it took the Honolulu-Tokyo leg of its Houston-Tokyo route from a list of assets for sale, saying the hard-won route was too important to the city. Last week, Harris told local business leaders the airline may have to sell some international routes and possibly furlough employees to cope with higher fuel costs.

DOC.HEAD: Additional NLRB Charges to be Filed
DOC.TEXT: The staff of the National Labor Relations Board is bringing additional charges of unfair labor practice against Greyhound Lines, the board announced Tuesday. The charges result from complaints by the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, whose 6,000 drivers went on strike in March over wages and job security issues. The company contends they no longer have jobs because the bus line has hired replacements. Jerry M. Hunter, general counsel of the board, said he has authorized the NLRB's Milwaukee office to file additional charges in 16 cases around the country. The new charges will allege that Greyhound unlawfully fired strikers because of union activities, coerced employees through the throwing of rocks at strikers by company guards, threatened strikers and refused to provide the union with information, he said. The new charges will be consolidated with the original complaint filed by the Milwaukee office at Hunter's recommendation. That complaint, filed in May, accused Greyhound of putting its final bargaining proposal into effect before a breakdown in talks, and said the strike was the result of an unfair labor practice. If the general counsel prevails before the five-member board, the original complaint could result in an order to reinstate the strikers with back pay. Still other accusations against the company by the union remain to be investigated, and will require postponing a hearing before an administrative law judge on the original complaint from Nov. 29 to Jan. 15. In Dallas, LIz Dunn, a spokeswoman for the company, said Greyhound had not seen the original complaint, but, ``Greyhound fully expects to prevail when we have an opportunity to present the case.'' She said the new charges would not affect the filing of a reorganization plan with a bankruptcy court later this month. The company has been operating under court protection from creditors.
